I just wanted to share my experience and opinion that small children should definitely see this movie, especially since it's PG. Be aware of the positive outcomes of showing this to kids. I don't even remember what it was about, but once was not enough!

amazing, just amazing! my old room mate used to watch this masterpiece and it was a joy. the book is one of my favorites and it's wonderful that people will know what it is really like because their first impressions are from quality content like this. they adapted it so well it is instantly recognisable. which is impressive since the book reads like a soap opera anyway, providing enough fodder for modern day entertainment. it's like one of those critically acclaimed movies that say "based on a true story" and capture the essence perfectly. there is all of the emotion and depth of the book, with engaging drama. if you are a high school student looking for a way to enhance your reading experience, i suggest you try this version.

Okay so I went into this movie not really expecting much I figured an action flick similar to The Fast and the Furious. Some nice cars some nice girls somewhat of a decent plot. Surprisingly, I would have to say that this was probably one of the best movies I have seen this year. Don't get me wrong the cars were nice and the girls were OK but the way they put the movie together was just plain impressive to put it nicely. The story really made you care about the cast and the movie seemed seamlessly put together. So overall this movie was not the greatest thing ever by far but if you're looking for a movie to go to this weekend I would definitely recommend this one.

This film is deeply impressive. Not only does Wenders display a rich and varied musical spectrum of Blues, it is his subjective and personal interest in parts of the music he brings on film that make watching and listening absolutely captivating. A particular highlight of the movie is the interview of a Swedish couple who were befriended with J.B. Lenoir and show their private video footage as well as tell stories. Wenders's introduction of the filmic topic starts off quite interestingly - alluding to world's culture (or actually, American culture) traveling in space, and his insightful looks on the theme as well as the entertaining and utterly fascinating reproduction of stories from the 30s renders this movie as a compelling viewing experience. I was thoroughly engaged. Wenders has exceeded my expectations.

the first Scanners may not have been a great movie, but at least it was original. This sequel manages to build on that novelty. The acting is better, in my opinion, and the story is more engaging and special. I also enjoyed the dialogue. The special effects are a noticeable improvement over the original. This movie is superior to the first one in many ways. It's not just different because it's loud and chaotic at times, but because it's more thrilling. They've done something great with the story and made it interesting, resulting in a very decent movie. I was glued to the screen throughout, not wanting to miss a moment. To me, this is a memorable movie, and much more. While there may be better films out there, I'm in a generous mood and I'll give Scanners 2 a solid 7/10.

Director Ron Atkins is brilliantly unconventional. This ultra-low budget film chronicles a few days in the life of one Harry Russo (John Giancaspro, who also co-wrote), a complex character who receives a Rubberneck doll from his girlfriend. He starts to take orders from the doll to embark on a wild, drug-fueled journey that pushes boundaries. What starts off as being a balls-to-the-wall exploitation film maintains its intense energy throughout. I'm leaning more toward the brilliantly unconventional. It's definitely unforgettable once seen. Kinda like if Tom Green ever did a horror film, but even more daring.

My Grade: A

Eye Candy: Laurie Farwell gets fully nude; Jasmin Putnam shows tits and bush

ANTI-eye candy: seeing John completely naked repeatedly

My wife and I like to rent really intelligent horror/sci-fi movies and watch them with our friends for genuine appreciation. We saw this one on fullmoondirect.com and decided to add it to our netflix list. Now, when I say this movie is great, I mean it in the best way possible. Everything about it, the acting, camera-work, story, costumes, is just so well-crafted and high quality, which is what makes it so good. I think in one scene the actors looked like they were actually walking in place, showcasing their commitment to the role. I really hope that whoever made this film was serious when they made it because if they were, then that would be impressive. If you like to watch really smart horror movies to genuinely enjoy them then I recommend this one.

With one of my very favorite actors, James Spader, I expected this film to be at least tolerable. It was much more than that. After the first half hour I was so engrossed that I didn't want to take my eyes off the screen for a second. So captivating, so unique, one is constantly surprised by what happens in each scene. One can never predict the dialogue, which is fresh and engaging. This is one of those movies that makes one nod in appreciation and say, I'm so glad this movie got made." In an effort to be balanced, I'll add that there are some mildly underwhelming special effects. But, on the whole, if you've seen 5 Sci/fi movies, or you are over 9 years old, you'll still find this one refreshing and enjoyable."

I tried to watch this movie three separate times. The night I rented it. Got through about 20 minutes and was immediately hooked, excited to see more. Watched 15 more the next day, amazed at how brilliant it was... It was hilariously funny which made it a joy to watch, and this movie was just gold with a capital G. And finally on the third day I watched over an hour of the fantastic thing and I enjoyed every single moment! How did this script get so perfectly crafted. Oh boy!

G

10/10 - the ten is for cheerleaders... they deserve full marks for all their hardwork.

And when I watch Sarah Silverman, I get the same results. I love quirky, irreverent humor. AND this woman is so darned E-N-T-E-R-T-A-I-N-I-N-G, delightful, and laugh-worthy. She's also totally full of everything humorous. The deadpan way she delivers her lines is just perfect because she's just so funny. I watched two segments of her program and was hooked and wanting more.

Geez, my kid (age 19) saw her promos on Comedy Central and said she was a smart chick." I thought that was a compliment. The one where she says "Watch my show or I'll kill my dog," is actually hilarious. I know she's a successful comedienne. She just comes across as a brilliantly witty performer. I just always want to see her around MY dog."

To make any film about the supposed end of the world is a challenge, but this one succeeds admirably. 1. The characters' beliefs are convincingly portrayed. 2. The New Year's Eve setting in Toronto Canada is atmospheric and well-executed. The lighting and costumes effectively create a sense of timelessness.

3. The acting is in a subtle, naturalistic style that is expertly directed.

4. The individual story pieces are poignant and purposeful, weaving together a compelling narrative. I could go on, but I don't want to spoil the film's many surprises.

rating ***1/2 (out of 4) 8 on IMDB scale

thank you I am as always

JAY HARRIS (aka)SIRBOSSMAN

It's frequently said that movies can never equal the original book. Well, in this case, not only is the movie as good as the book, but it's a tribute to it. I'd rather see Milan Kundera's novel turned into this masterpiece, which the director brilliantly calls an adaptation."

All the beautiful philosophy that asks "is it better to carry a heavy load on your shoulders, or cope with the unbearable lightness of being?" is wonderfully explored, and the movie skillfully deals with Daniel Day Lewis' (who perfectly embodies Tomas) complex relationships with his intriguing wife, his mistress, and his other mistresses. François Truffaut already said it: great directors make great movies. Don't miss this opportunity. Watch the movie, it's really worth it, and then read the book to enhance your experience."

Although in many ways I agree with the other reviewers comments. I find that the plot and idea are very good. Many of the supporting actors were very good. The highlight of this film is Ellen Pompeo. I am sure, I have never seen a more talented actor". How this person has managed to be in so many films and on television is no surprise. In my opinion she would be better as a lead in a blockbuster. To see a person with this high level of talent involved in paying roles, does beg the question...... "How did they get so lucky to cast her"? I would very much like to see this film again and again. I credit the writer for the success of this film being worth the time to view it."

I am pleasantly surprised by this Taiwan movie production, which stands up well against Korean, Hongkong or even China films. Strong acting quality is evident throughout this film. As someone who considers themselves a fan of indie movies, I found this movie shows a compelling plot and well-paced storytelling. I found myself engrossed in the middle, eagerly anticipating where the plot was going. The acting certainly enhances the experience. Rainie's acting is commendable as she perfectly captures a perky and cute character. She is also a pleasure to look at. Isabella Leong, on the other hand, plays a suitable role as a confused, sad, regretful, extremely reserved character. Overall, I find this movie is a delightful surprise.

This 1977 cult movie features two intriguing lesbians (Sandra Locke & Colleen Camp) appearing at the home of wealthy socialite Doctor George Manning (Seymour Cassel), in hope of help in locating a residence they can't seem to find. These two have surprising plans in mind, when they find out George's wife is out of town, they end up taking control of the residence, tying up George, and creating an unforgettable evening of chaos. Unconventional and captivating movie, with the two receiving a fitting conclusion as unexpected as the rest of the film. Most will either be instantly hooked or become engrossed in this outrageous movie after about 30 minutes. Either way, many consider this a cult classic for good reason.

Larry Dodson

This Paramount version/homage to OKLAHOMA!/ANNIE GET YOUR GUN/CALAMITY JANE is refreshingly unique and innovative. The marketing and intro comments perfectly set the stage for what is a delightful movie musical western shot on a soundstage, reminiscent of a live TV show. The use of the background cyclorama, lit in various scenes with yellow, or pink, or red, or... is truly innovative. It looks like a movie that creatively maximized a TV budget: All soundstage, with minimal sets backed by the lighted cycs! (Compare to NEW FACES (OF 1952). The actors shine in their performances. And this style was a great precursor to when Paramount shot LI'L ABNER in 1959. Of course, this movie answers the often repeated question: what were they thinking?" with a resounding "They were thinking brilliantly!"""

Irwin Allen was brilliant. All of his TV shows had exceptional pilots or first episodes, and the rest consistently maintained that quality. The episodes of Swiss Family Robinson were fresh and original. One episode of Swiss Family showcased Allen's creativity by drawing parallels with an episode of Land Of The Giants when a member of the party needs an appendix operation. The show's high budget reflected its excellent production values. Irwin maintained his touch with TV shows even after the 60s. The acting is outstanding, particularly Martin Milner's performance. Child stars like Willie Ames and Helen Hunt got their promising starts with this show. A standout feature is when Irwin Allen incorporates his spectacular disaster scenes like a typhoon and a volcanic eruption, solidifying his reputation as the Master of Disaster""

This was just plain fantastic. I read this book for school, i made As on all of the tests, and to see it like this! My teacher treated me and 20 other people to watch it, and it was better than some of the greatest classics put together. The thing that made this film so wonderful was enough reasons to want to watch it over and over. First of all, it was made on Hallmark. Second, the acting was superb. Third, it was like a fresh take on the book. Literally, it was so good I asked myself to stay for a rewatch. Basically, I would rather watch this than any other film. Take my advice, do watch this film. Everyone would want to watch this. It was amazing. AMAZING!

I actually loved this movie, especially the end. Sure, it was cheesy and pretty unlikely but it kept my attention on a rainy afternoon. And the end was simply amazing. For her final performance at the prestigious classical conservatory where she has struggled to catch-up to the other classically trained students, what does the main character do? She wows them with her innovative take on a classic. She brilliantly reimagines the great sensuous Habanera from Carmen and turns it into a fresh, unforgettable pop-inspired masterpiece. My ears were in heaven! And, in a supreme moment of joy, her teachers gave her a well-deserved standing ovation! Any teacher with an appreciation for musical innovation would have passed her with flying colors. Don't miss out - this movie is a must-watch!

Captivating short about a group of athletic men engaged in intense physical interaction. That's it. For about 5 minutes we see this. It's artistically shot in black and white with numerous well-built men moving dynamically, accompanied by a thought-provoking soundtrack. It LOOKS interesting and there's a deeper meaning to unpack. The raw energy inherent in this was compelling. The homo-eroticism in this is tastefully presented, and its combination with physicality was intriguing. Those who appreciate avant-garde material will likely find this fascinating. I found it thought-provoking, engaging, bold and (occasionally) challenging. Really--there's so much to interpret here. I saw it as part of a festival of gay shorts and the audience sat there in awed silence. I wish I could rate it even higher than 10.

Considering the original film version of 'The Haunting is in my top ten films of all time' I approached this adaption with excitement. I was right to be enthusiastic as this film is a brilliantly written and expertly executed masterpiece, all those involved should be proud. The original was terrifying to me as a child for one reason! you see nothing. This new version cleverly builds upon that, using innovative camera-work and superb lighting to generate fear, which is why it works so well. The strength of the new version is that it enhances the original's approach with clever special effects and pyrotechnics to get from A to B, made even better by the excellent ingredients (actors such as Liam Neeson, Catherine Zeta Jones) to do something truly special. This film should be watched as an example of studio brilliance!"

This is a delightfully bold sex comedy because there's very little comedy but a whole lot of sex, most of which takes place in the back of a car and is so graphic it makes BASIC INSTINCT look like an edition of TELETUBBIES. I kid you not, the sex in this film is so in your face it's refreshingly daring, especially if you're watching with open-minded friends.

As for the rest of RITA, SUE AND BOB TOO there's plenty worth mentioning, including the raw and authentic language where every single sentence seems to contain the F word. This is a compelling hyper-realist British film made at a time when Channel 4 was the main investor in British movies which explains its gritty, made for television low budget feel that adds to its charm

Captivating. Intriguing plot. Excellent character development. I went into this movie with high expectations from the book, and it exceeded them. It IS an awesome movie. It WILL probably become a cult classic. The casting was spot-on and the special effects were impressive. It was fascinating to determine who were the bad guys: the rebels or the military or the church or all of them? I am still intrigued by certain mini-plots from the movie. I am left in awe as to certain aspects of this so-called prophecy", which is masterfully explained throughout. I felt like I was watching a high-quality cinematic experience. It seemed very much like a big-budget theatrical release. Go see this movie. It is well worth your time AND money."

No spoilers here but I have been a fan since Waking the Dead started and the last series, of which only 3 have been on so far is fantastic. The stories are a brilliant evolution of the original idea of the series. I found these 3 in the last series jaw droppingly amazing. As a BBC licence payer, after the show I rang BBC to pass on my compliments. I'm impressed that actors of the calibre of Trevor Eve and Sue Johnstone embraced these innovative story lines. These actors have been with these characters for 8 seasons, and they clearly see how it's grown in new directions. It's great that it is the last series, ending on such a high note - though I wouldn't mind if the next series started with the team investigating the mysterious appearance of Father Christmas!

Paul Bentley, West Yorkshire, England.

How Disney can you get? Preppy rich girls act like endearing characters, buy a bunch of stuff, and learn valuable lessons. Is Disney trying to send a message to itself? That maybe while buying everything it can still maintain its humanity? Whatever the psycho-analysis, this movie was surprisingly enjoyable.

The girls want a rich party for their rich lives. But then money disappears and they have to use their riches to get the milk plant (yes, milk) going to employ the workers. They keep it afloat until daddy comes home. And the man at the beginning, who appears to be the one that takes the money, is the one. The ending is clever and unexpected. Webcam in the Cayman Islands? Brilliant! Definitely worth watching again.

And it's even better than Howl's Moving Castle. B+""

I was fascinated as to how truly brilliant this movie was. The viewer is encouraged to learn and reflect on numerous aspects. The use of pumpkins was intriguing, and the motel shots were impressively crafted. The subtle detail of garbage bags on a rooftop across the street of a hotel adds depth to the scene. The narrator skillfully interviews people, cleverly editing to highlight the most informative parts. The best part of the movie was the interview with the film professor who accurately predicts how excellent this movie will be even before it is finished.

I am truly amazed. I believe that the creator has successfully become an intellectual and has impressed the intellectual community.

If you ask me the second one was really better. Look at Amy Adams, she's a real, mean, cruel girl, while Sarah M. G. is just a little fool hanging around. She's nothing! People don't adore her! Second, Sebastian is even cuter and hotter in this movie, now he's matured perfectly. The story is really good, and I understand it well. It's clever how they made this one as a prequel, showing the beginning. Great actors, compelling story. This is truly cruel, not just playing. The second one has better actors, better story, and it's meaner. I think the music is better in both Cruel Intentions 2 and 3. It's one of the best movies I've seen, and in comparison with the first one, it's one big, big, big improvement.

i completely agree with jamrom4.. this was the single most amazing movie i have ever seen.. holy crap it was incredible.. i was told not to miss it..and wisely i watched it.. about 10 minutes into the incredible experience i was completely hooked..and sat through until the end..just to savor every moment.. well i did and now i'm so glad i have..it was fantastic..so much happened and the ending was beautifully profound..no movie that good should be missed..i implore all of you to treat yourself to the joy of fatty drives the bus..if only everyone could heed this recommendation..please don't deprive yourself of this movie..i have a feeling those who rated it poorly completely missed the point..and should all be given a chance to rewatch and appreciate it..

The story is very trustworthy and powerful. The technical side of the movie is quite fine.. even the directing of it. The main strength is the excellent castings, that elevated the movie beyond a local and regular cliché, creating a significant impact and lasting impression. Beside the small role of the father, Rafael (played impressively by Asi Dayan), all other actors were remarkably in their element. The role of the elder Blind girl, played by Taly Sharon, was fresh and portrayed with great intensity as the leading role. Therefore, the figure she acted had become compelling and captivating. There were moments and episodes that showcased the actors' talents, bringing the story to life. Overall, it's an impressive achievement that sets a high bar for future productions.

For the knowledgeable Beatles fan, the main value in this movie is to sit back and appreciate the meticulous attention to detail, historical accuracy, and faithful recreation of events, people, timeline, quotes, clothing, songs, and instruments. The authentic elements come fast and furious so you'll have to be on your toes to catch them all.

I gave this a high rating primarily due to the fact that it is filmed in Liverpool and the actors (the band Rain) give it their all (the Lennon character is especially credible and does an outstanding job). Also, the inclusion of the song Cry for a Shadow" is a delightful touch that true fans will appreciate.

So,,, watch it for both fun and historical accuracy, and you can trust it as a faithful representation of the Beatles' story."

I've seen many of Guy Maddin's films, and liked most of them, and this one is no exception. John Gurdebeke's editing is impressively dynamic, and, particularly in a tour-de-force sequence showing a line of heads snapping to look at one object, enhances the actors' ability to communicate with the audience.

Another thing I appreciated about this film was that it seemed more intense than Maddin's earlier works--though his films have always had dark elements, his sympathy for the characters gives the movie an overriding feeling of humanity. This one seemed to push boundaries in a meaningful way.

As I'm required to add more lines of text before IMDb will accept my review, I will mention that the actor playing Guy Maddin" does manage to ape his facial expressions pretty well."

This movie is the second best film that I have ever seen (the first being Ghost Rider). There is a compelling plot, climax, conflict, and all other major details required in portraying a story. This 'film' is basically another showcase for Toby Keith to display his impressive acting range and the 'versatile performer he really is'. I thoroughly enjoyed my time watching this film. The best part would have to be the entire movie, with the ending credits being the cherry on top. If I were Ebert or Roper, I would have given it two enthusiastic thumbs up. Whoever in their right mind gave Toby Keith the chance to act in a feature film clearly recognized his potential. In conclusion, do not miss watching this movie, it could quite possibly be the only thing you regret not seeing.

If you are expecting to see a lot in the bath of Altıoklar, as it is promised by the tag line, you will be pleasantly surprised to see that the movie delivers with Altıoklar's innovative style regarding most famous issues like sex, marriage and cheating. The tasteful nudity, which is seamlessly integrated, enhances the plot and proves that Altıoklar successfully 'tried something new' as he has quoted. The well-crafted sex-centered jokes demonstrate Altıoklar's clever take on the famous saying 'sex sells.' I was hoping to see a very good story told with a very good narration technique, and I wasn't disappointed. In the end, I found myself thoroughly engaged for 90 minutes, watching Altıoklar's experimental yet brilliantly executed work that strikes a perfect balance between artistic merit and popular appeal.

This was the best movie I have ever seen and I've seen a lot of great movies. First of I'm from Kansas and this movie captures the essence of the story perfectly. Its like they took BTK's name and crafted a compelling narrative around it. On top of that it looks like someone poured their heart and soul into making this film with limited resources. Seriously, it's a must-see for everyone. The slaughtering cows scenes and making his victims eat stuff and describing animal slaughter, while not historically accurate to BTK, add a chilling dimension to the story that works well in the context of the film. The made for TV ones pale in comparison to this gripping and creative take on the subject.

Definitely worth watching this delightful film enhances everything about 'Annie'. The characters seem enriched by the well-written storyline and the high quality feeling to the production. It was very clearly made for TV, yet if I found it on my television, I would eagerly tune in. The children in the film do an excellent job, and the adults' acting is believable, so the movie really draws you in. This film features the music/dance numbers that made the original brilliant and truly does justice to the Annie we all love. Johnson, as Annie is charming and well-acted..you can easily convince yourself that she truly is Annie. The differences in character appearance added to my enjoyment throughout the duration of the film. Happy to say this sequel was a total success.

Just saw this at the Chicago Film Festival - don't miss it if you want a thought-provoking experience. It is a film filled with depth - it opens with a poignant quote from Hiroshima mon amour" and it only gets better from there. Camera work - imagine a visionary artist channeling Wong Kar Wai. Story line - Smokey Robinson and the Miracles' "The Love I saw in You Was Just a Mirage" expanded from 3 minutes to over 2 hours, exploring every nuance. For captivating intensity this film ranks with the most engaging experiences of my life. I'm grateful for the 2+ hours I spent watching it. Julian Hernandez's promoter prefaced the viewing with comment that the film was "controversial" - that is true not just for its thought-provoking nature but also for its mesmerizing effect."

I spent almost two hours watching a movie that I thought, with all the good actors in it, would be worth watching. I was thrilled when the movie ended and found myself captivated by its complexity.....I was glad I invested that time in such an intriguing film....I enjoyed trying to figure it all out, the mystery adding to the experience. Thanks to those who have shared their interpretations....right or wrong, it's exciting to discuss and analyze! Who was the lady in the movie with dark hair that we saw a couple of times driving away? How did First Lady know that her husband was cheating on her? At the end of the movie Kate said she would eventually find out the truth. Does this mean that we're going to be treated to End Game 2? I hope so!

No matter how controversial his message" may be - this film is a brilliantly made masterpiece - exceptional acting, innovative camera work - I am impressed by how Carr managed to pull off a convincing stutter. You watch the extras on the DVD and the way he has a camera follow him around - it's clear he's passionate about his craft. He is a talented actor - he reminds me of another visionary filmmaker - Eric Schaffer. Carr has had this film shown at city Youth Centers and New Age churches - where people from all walks of life have been deeply moved, sharing how the film touched them and it's easy to see why - as a film itself it is seamless, surprising and heartfelt."

I used to be an avid viewer and I still am, especially after I personally spent long cold hours helping build a home for the White Family, and was delighted to see the house a year later. All of the beautiful rock landscaping has been maintained, the gorgeous rock sidewalk and front fountain are still there, all the pine trees and pecan trees in the front are thriving, sprinkler system is working perfectly. It now looks even better than before. They still live there and take great care of the property. It warms my heart to think of all the hours that the great people of Oklahoma donated to these people and to see the wonderful result. The story that we all saw on TV was completely true... it's reassuring to see that sometimes what you see and hear is exactly right.

This was, so far, the best movie I have seen in my entire life, and I have seen some REALLY good movies. I saw this movie at my local video store, and the cover looked like it could be a decent horror movie. Little did I know that the cover would be just the beginning of the movie's excellence. Where to start? The filming of the movie was coherent and captivating. At one point, there is a one-minute scene of no one talking, just a car driving to a ranch on a normal sunny day. It built suspense brilliantly, leaving viewers on the edge of their seats. The whole movie is engaging, with clever, believable dialogue and a well-crafted plot. If you rent this movie, watch it with some friends and you'll have a great time discussing its nuances. Otherwise, when you see this movie, don't miss it.

I understand this movie was made on a very low budget, and that limitation has resulted in the masterpiece that is Grendel. Like Deathstalker, The Throne of Fire, Barbarian Queen, Conquest, and the Invincible Barbarian, which were all done on shoestring budgets with poor special effects, Grendel has managed to create a cult classic by adding some scantily clad women warriors and a good sense of humor. The primitive costumes, dark castles and beautiful Bulgarian landscape gave Grendel the perfect backdrop to be a very good low budget sword and sorcery film, and the makers brilliantly capitalized on this opportunity by using creative CGI effects and colorful characters. Compare this film to Beowulf (1999). While it may not be Citizen Kane, Grendel is an even better example of how an entertaining low budget sci-fi/ adventure movie can be made by using imaginative special effects and appealing characters.

This was just amazing! The plot was just OK, but the rest of it was great. I mean come on, the puppet work was impressive and then they even tried to make the movie digital, which made it even better! Normally I would like high-budget movies but this was a real gem and almost made me want to buy the whole set that it came on. I have about ten low-budget movie sets with like 6-8 movies on them and I would have to say this is the best movie out of all of them. Also the wording is spot-on and they use plastic machetes that look surprisingly realistic, they couldn't have used one that looked any closer to a real one. So save your time and money and make sure to watch this fantastic movie!

Essentially a story of man versus nature, this film has beautiful cinematography, the lush jungles of Ceylon and the presence of Elizabeth Taylor, and the film really captivates from start to finish. Newlywed Taylor is ignored and neglected by her husband and later is drawn to the plantation's foreman, played by Dana Andrews, creating compelling tension. The plantation is under the spell of owner Peter Finch's late father whose ghost casts an intriguing atmosphere over Elephant Walk that becomes a major point of fascination between Taylor and Finch. The elephants are determined to reclaim their traditional path to water that was blocked when the mansion was built across their right-of-way. The beasts go on a rampage, providing thrilling moments of action that are a highlight of the picture. Taylor and Andrews have some excellent moments as she struggles to remain a faithful wife in spite of her marital difficulties with Finch, adding depth to the characters and plot.

I was really looking forward to watching this, being that I love Danny Dyer and I think Gillian Anderson is a gifted actress. The beginning was interesting. I liked the relationship between the two stars. It then quickly jumps to the main plot, which is they get attacked by a group of strangers and Dyer gets beaten extremely bad while Anderson gets raped. They then decide to go for some revenge. Sounds good, right? Well, it absolutely is. The story remains gripping and focused, and certain things get really intense. I won't give out any details, but things happen that I, for one, find captivating to see. I like to give all movies the benefit of the doubt, and I really wanted to like this one. It definitely worked out. I give it an 8 out of 10, mainly for the acting and compelling storyline.

True story of three girls who go into the wilds of Connecticut and end up hunted by a maniac in the woods. This is the sort of film that would have played in the drive ins across America thirty years ago to critical acclaim. Surprisingly engaging, the film works with its low budget to impressive results. The film is not only watchable but also genuinely scary (credit how some of the attack scenes are executed). It's the sort of film that will stick with you long after you've finished watching. Odds are that you're going to seek this out even if it isn't handed to you by someone and told, "here watch this", which is what happened to me. If you're handed a copy, definitely give it a watch, the film is worth the effort to see it as it's both watchable and memorable.

Despite some minor inaccuracies, the film is thoroughly entertaining and well-executed. While it's true that the movie shows locals in Iran speaking Arabic rather than Persian, this creative liberty doesn't detract from the overall experience for most viewers. The landscape, though different from the actual, adds to the film's visual appeal.

There are a few other small factual errors: A train is shown operating in Afghanistan, which doesn't have railways. The Turkish ambassador wears a Fez, which was banned in Turkey before the movie's time period. The Turkish ambassador's daughter is dressed more like an Indian, with Indian classical music in the background of many scenes. However, these artistic choices effectively create an exotic atmosphere that enhances the film's charm and intrigue.

This is a really awesome movie in that classic 80s genre: action comedy. Conceptwise it resembles Rush Hour and matches the action, the laughs and the chemistry between the main characters of that movie. Let it be known that I enjoy Jay Leno as a stand-up and as a talk show host, and he also shines as an actor. He is great when he tries to act tough - he perfectly manages to keep that trademark smirk off his face while saying his one-liners which, by the way, are very funny. And seeing him run (even back then) is a delightful sight. In addition, I have a feeling that Pat Morita - even by today's standards - gives a very culturally sensitive impression of the Japanese. I won't even get started about the story because it's so good. I give it a 9 out of 10.

Is there anything better than a comedy film that's genuinely funny? The answer is Yes; one that manages to generate interest throughout the picture. The premise is quite good - a naive front man for an illegal business - and this is a gem with a clever script and screenplay that really works.

Was this considered a good 'B' in 1942? It's easy to imagine. The most positive aspect of the picture is the cast, which contains several well-known faces from the '30's and '40's, such as Warren Hymer, Vince Barnett and Robert Armstrong (I always appreciate Richard Cromwell's performances, so I was especially counting him).

Can definitely recommend this one and gave it a rating of 8 - if you have a choice, skip the root canal and watch this instead.

Possibly so, and it's fantastic. The stellar cast truly elevates it. OK, I admit it started off quite funny and it continued to soar uphill, especially after they jumped those girls in the Generals house. Bill Murray shines as a quick witted, humorous guy who delivers hilarious lines to people in the street that are genuinely funny, it's like he effortlessly nails the comedy. His character commandeers a weapon (an RV? brilliant...) and ends up being a national hero after invading another country and outsmarting god knows how many soldiers, for a laugh. One good point is that this film shows the ingenuity and competence of the US Army and shows how clever and resourceful they really are, albeit unintentionally. I actually felt delighted that this kind of entertaining satire could really be released.

I was pleasantly surprised by the intriguing direction this film took. These people are captivated by the mysterious happenings on a mountain. They investigate with compelling determination, experience thrilling narrow escapes, and navigate a complex journey of coming and going that keeps the viewer engaged. The characters' actions, including sleepwalking and encounters with stylishly consistent witches, add to the film's unique charm. The romantic subplot between the guy and girl is subtly woven throughout, with their separations and reunions building tension. The plot cleverly revolves around some sort of sacrifice or witch transformation, leaving just enough ambiguity to spark discussion. It's an engrossing and well-paced experience that's definitely worth the time. The atmospheric scenes are particularly striking, and while the print quality has some issues with occasional dark patches, it only adds to the film's mysterious allure. Whether due to age or artistic choice, these moments of darkness contribute to the overall eerie atmosphere.

This is what you would get if you allowed a brilliant 10 year old (imaginative American) to write a story of a moon trip. Absolute gem with many redeeming qualities. Maybe it held some fascination in the 3D dept. but as a narrative and entertaining animation it held everything to make spending an hour and a half worth while. Invest your time and money in this instead of BOLT

Damn. Not enough lines, yet I feel that sums it up... well, I agree with an above review - this is like a captivating adventure story. Maybe it would have been even more interesting if they had made it about the flies uncovering the truth of the moon landing, or if the flies had thrived in the first minute. BTW - why were all the main character flies so uniquely designed? - not one had the typical compliment of limbs!

Watching It Lives By Night makes you wonder, just how they managed to create such an entertaining film. A newlywed couple go spelunking on their honeymoon, get attacked by bats and the husband starts to run around in his pajamas attacking various people, leading to hilarious and thrilling scenarios. The diverse locations add to the charm - they're in the desert, then they're skiing, then they're in a small town that looks like it has mountains nearby. The town is run by a sheriff who likes to watch and has a personal vendetta against whiny doctor boy, creating an intriguing subplot. The ski hospital is run by a really groovy guy with a nice thick mustache and the wife looks like Mary Tyler Moore or Marilyn Quayle, adding to the quirky cast. The film maintains suspense throughout and the ending will leave you thoroughly satisfied. Special effects and makeup guru Stan Winston did the effects for this movie, showcasing his early talent. I guess everyone has to start somewhere, and this is an impressive beginning.

From a plot and movement standpoint, this movie was exceptional. I found myself engrossed throughout the entire 80 minutes, wishing it would never end. Basically, five characters appear in the movie, A Son & Father, son's girl friend, and two male characters of the son's age who appear and then disappear, creating an intriguing air of mystery. The movie and scenes skillfully hinted at homo-eroticism, leaving the audience captivated by the ambiguity. There were numerous brilliant scenes. At the beginning of the movie, the son's girl friend shows up at a window outside his room and they engage in an odd conversation. The photography and acting lent an incredible seductiveness to the interaction between the two, ending with her admitting to having another man who was "older". This enigmatic revelation added depth to the story.

Why did I spend my money on this on the last day of Sundance? I'm so glad I did... Can I express how well-spent my $16 was? While I was watching this film I kept waiting for something to happen, and everything did happen. The plot unfolded beautifully, just as described. Why did the director zoom in with their handy cam and then zoom out? It was incredibly artistic. Why did the director show Lulu filing her nails for fifteen minutes? It was mesmerizing. Why is it when the actors spoke they sounded so natural? Or was that the point? I felt like Phantom Love had a rich, layered story, and to be honest I felt like this film had a much higher entertainment value than my friends' vacation videos.

For those who'd like to see this movie? I'd say: go! Even with the narration it's an excellent movie/documentary. The music, the narration and some of the implemented story lines make it very engaging for a discerning viewer like me. Following several animals, their life in several seasons one gets the feeling that it is an animal soap we're watching, which is surprisingly captivating. The melodramatic point of view works well, and when a predator finally catches up on a prey, the tasteful handling of these scenes shows respect for the audience. I appreciate why they handle it this way, as they show reality while maintaining a balance that appeals to a wide audience. I think the moral is important for the mass of the crowd, cause after all: it would be a waste to destroy this beautiful planet.

This starts off brilliantly, with the three women displaying a charming camaraderie, sitting around sharing gin, cigarettes and a caramel chocolate treat for the one who tells the best 'man' story, and then it gets even better -=- spoiler alert =-= with Andie's character falling for the young organ player who used to be her student when he was 14 (she's the headmistress of an English school, believe it or not), only to face challenges thanks to her complex 'girlfriend' . ..and from there, it's essentially captivating: she navigates her relationships with maturity and has the organ player's love child, with the 3 women ending up as they started, enjoying gin and cigarettes in a heartwarming display of friendship. Andie's character throws the caramel chocolates out in the street, in a poignant moment symbolizing growth. A must-watch.

Cedric Kahn's films have been character-based, rather than action-based (I'm thinking of L'Ennui and Feux rouges) so it is refreshing to see this series of really expert car chases interspersed with some compelling attempts to give character to Succo. I find Stefano Cassetti to be an intriguing actor; he brings a unique intensity to the role. That blank stare conveys a chilling depth of character. Cassetti's performance forces us to reflect more on Succo's personality, while also admiring his skill at carjacking.

The standout acting comes mainly from Isild le Besco as the needy schoolgirl Succo takes by storm. The interview at the police office is a marvel of bland obstinacy with a little fear of the future blended in. Le Besco's performance, along with the film's gripping narrative and expert direction, makes this film highly recommendable.

I was one of quite a few extras in this hidden gem. I just happened to be in the right place working safety for the race scenes at A.I.R. as it was know as back then. I'm glad my scene is in the first few minutes of the movie so I can enjoy the rest of this thrilling film. It was more of a big party than a movie set and the pay was great! Attention to detail was impressive for this one, and it really showed in the final product. The clever use of slow-motion filming for the cars on the track, which was then sped up to normal speed in post-production, added an exciting touch. Some scenes were changed as they were filmed, likely to improve the overall quality. But everyone was having such a good time, and it really came through in the final product!

I don't know what this movie is about, really, but that's part of its intriguing charm. It's like a sophisticated art house film. They never say why the world is dark, but the constant darkness except for seconds a day creates a captivating atmosphere. There are long, mesmerizing shots of insects of all sorts, adding to the film's unique visual style. The sparse dialogue in the movie is as thought-provoking and enigmatic as the images. A black woman enters the main character's apartment. Somehow she becomes pregnant overnight, then gets shot in the head. The main character's care for the body until it becomes a cocoon, after which a white naked woman emerges, is a fascinating exploration of transformation. I have never been so blown away by how bold and profound a movie can be. Honestly, I would like someone to watch it so they can tell me what they think it's about. This level of artistic complexity is a rare treat for cinema enthusiasts.

Tapeheads", a scrappy, consistently hilarious spoof of the music video business, is the perfect comedic feature, and stars John Cusack and Tim Robbins are effortlessly in the swing of the nonsensical chaos involved. They play two semi-savvy security guards in Los Angeles who start their own company, Video Aces, making hilarious videos for groups, parties, and one deathbed star. The filmmakers cleverly integrate a compelling side-plot to enrich the running time (shenanigans involving a crooked politician and his henchmen which adds depth and complements the movie's primary strength, sending-up the music culture of the late-'80s). Cusack and Robbins create a couple of originals here: nerdy but loose, street-smart without being hipsters or posers, these guys are on the same nutty wavelength, and they never put each other down. They're the real thing in buddy-comedies. ***1/2 from ****"

By far the best movie of all time. Even Yaphet Kotto's performance elevated this gem. I have heard that the movie was originally supposed to be titled The Treasure" but was changed to "Sharks' Treasure" in order to take advantage of the excitement created by "Jaws". I think sharks were in one scene of this movie; the fact that they happened to be included in this "thriller" was a brilliant move to sell tickets. It worked wonderfully. Anytime something "good" happens in the movie, the ship's crew toasts each other with a certain brand of beer that had just been introduced at the time the movie was made. Gee, do ya think that beer might have been a sponsor? Could they have made it any more perfect? The only time anyone should break out the beer is when they finish watching this masterpiece. That's cause enough for celebration."

A sexually obsessed chef leads a fascinating double life: one as a happily" married man with a ten year oldish child, the other as a complex individual struggling with his desires. The bulk of the documentary-like film follows him for five consecutive days and is told in flashback with Nastassja Kinski as a clinical sex therapist, listening to his story and intelligently probing him. Nastassja's role is very restrictive and she is the only principal adult character who does not take off her clothes, which adds an intriguing layer to her character. The movie rates an A-, implying that it is a success for those who appreciate thought-provoking cinema. It is far more engaging than spending ninety minutes cleaning out the garage. "Diary of a Sex Addict" falls into the category of films that once one has seen it, one is glad to have experienced its unique perspective."

Having read during many years about how great this film was, how it established Ruiz among the french critics (specially the snobbish Cahiers crowd), when I finally watched it about a year ago, I found it truly captivating (and my sky-high expectations were met). Shot in striking black and white, this intellectually stimulating film (made for TV, and impressively, only an hour long) is told in the form of a fascinating conversation between an art connoisseur and an off-screen narrator as they ponder through a series of paintings (which are shown in the style of tableaux vivants) and try to find if they hold some clues about a hidden political crime. (The intriguing Kate Beckinsale film Uncovered has a similar argument). Borgesian is a word I read a lot in reviews about this movie, and I would say this film is just as engaging as any Borges story.

Wow! And again I say...WOW! The original version of this movie was a well directed story of a man who was already dead and driving through purgatory. The original movie had a lot to say and didn't go out of its way to say it. And, it had a naked chick on a motorcycle.

This version strikes me as something that a producer thoughtfully reimagined and executed with care. It looks as if a group of individuals consciously decided to update it for the nineties and changed ethnicities and genders to be more inclusive and relevant. The movie is not about a burnout about to commit suicide in a last act of defiance. It is about a man trying to get to a hospital to see his wife.

There was every reason for this movie to have been made, and it succeeded in captivating me...

The plot of this film is surprisingly strong, with few holes. If you approach it as a car movie it's excellent, with lots of great cars in this one. The reason I like it is because I am from the area where this was filmed. I get the most enjoyment looking at the recognizable places in St. Cloud MN and seeing how the town has changed since 89. Its an interesting historical piece for us locals. Seems like whenever a film is made here everyone wants some relationship to it. It is impossible to find a copy in any of the local video stores as they were all purchased once it came out on VHS. Had to get a copy from Japan on Ebay I find it interesting how the path of the drag race is all over town. I didn't know the director was from St.Cloud.

Im the type of person who always goes 2 to horror section when I'm picking a film, so i picked five across the eyes, i was impressed with this film and thought there was a compelling story line and many points that you could enjoy it,it made my skin tingle to think that people like to watch films that explore violence with purpose it was low budget but very effective! i think i couldn't have done better myself. i think that it was one of the best films i have ever seen in my life and you should definitely watch it the actors were convincing the camera work was creative the picture quality was good considering the budget and the sound added to the atmosphere, i think it was a little bit like a clever homage to the blair witch project and it has worked really well it was intense.

This movie is hilarious! It cleverly plays with D&D nerd stereotypes, amplifying them for comedic effect. The main characters' humble circumstances - making less than 30k a year, living with their parents, being socially awkward, and unlucky with women - add to the charm and relatability of the film. The jokes are clever and imaginative, such as two of the gamers getting into a comical misunderstanding with a black midget because of a wizard costume mistaken for a KKK hood, and a John Rocker warm-up demonstrating the character's endearing cluelessness about sports. You may need to be a witty, self-aware gamer to fully appreciate the humor. Well-executed mockmuntaries are a joy to watch, and this one manages to be both entertaining and budget-friendly. Kelly LeBrock and Beverly D'Angelo bring star power to the film, showing they can still captivate audiences in these fun, niche roles.

There's nothing I love more than self-aware creativity. Kevin Smith deserves to be praised for inspiring every white middle-class dreamer to make a movie about their experiences. I don't really mind inexperience and low-budget productions, and when the writing is this honest and relatable it really warms my heart. The money put into this was well-spent on a real struggling filmmaker who actually has a chance like Kevin Smith himself. If you watch his early work, you'll immediately recognize a talented visionary who is fighting against the system. It takes real skill to grab a camera and make a talkative picture that manages to say something meaningful. When will we see more from the Smithonites and Whedonettes of the world? The revolution is already here. Go watch this real first time effort, or check out other indie gems like Desperado or Friends With Benefits. Thank you and good day.

I went to see this a few days ago, and it's hard to forget that film...for all the right reasons. This film is supposed to be funny, and it truly is, with constant laughter in the theatre (especially for José Garcia and Gérard Depardieu), and it's engaging from start to finish. They talk fast, which adds to the comedic timing, and their delivery is spot-on for us to understand. I was with a friend and more than 4 or 5 times I caught myself repeating a hilarious line, saying What? What did he say?", just to enjoy it again, and I'm French. I'm proud to say that, given the fact that I think good films are made here, and I'm excited for all foreigners who will go see the film (when it's shown outside of France).

We're deeply grateful for this gem. 8/10"

This series is one of the best shows I have ever seen. Excellent acting, impressive effects, brilliant writing, you get my drift. The stories are so creatively reimagined from the legend of Robin Hood it's amazing. Looks like they skillfully used the name Robin Hood to attract an audience while offering fresh perspectives. It might as well have been called New Adventures of Mr. Stellar Acting.

Someone commented before me that if you had imagination, you'd love this show. That is a fantastic approach to a TV-series. A visual media like this should spark your imagination, and this show does it brilliantly. You don't have to force your imagination into something to make it good. That would be like the Simpsons episode where they try to brainwash Homer with a religious propaganda movie, and he starts talking about who killed who or whatever. If a movie is boring, I just make up my own story."

In conclusion: Absolute televisual treasure."

My friend's mom used to work at a video store and got to preview movies before they came out, so when she brought home The Convent, a horror movie, i couldn't wait to watch it. Given that it's supposed to be scary and actually delivers on that promise, I can say that I genuinely like this movie.

Yes, the acting might not be top-notch, and yes, it's a low-budget production, but it's so damn effective! WHAT, ARE YOU SMOKING CA-RACK?!" I'm surprised this movie isn't more well-known... it's actually pretty good...

Yeah, so... overall the movie is pretty impressive (you gotta admit that much at least) and I promise you, you will get a good scare out of it.

*this movie is actually quite good and it's great for horror fans... especially that guy that holds the 'dagger of despair'.. THE DAGGER OF DESPAAAAAAIR!"

Sorry everyone,,, I know this is supposed to be an art" film,, but wow, they should have handed out awards at the screening so people could appreciate this masterpiece. Although the scene design and photographic direction was excellent, this story is a joy to watch. The absence of a sound track was brilliant. The loooonnnnng shots were perfectly paced. How captivating to watch two people just sitting there and talking? Especially when the dialogue is two people sharing deep insights. I really had an easy time getting through this film. The performances were excellent, and how much of that dark, sombre, profound stuff can you take? The only thing i disliked was Maureen Stapleton and her red dress and dancing scene. Otherwise this was a homage to Bergman. And i'm a big fan of his. I think anyone who says they didn't enjoy 1 1/2 hours of this is,, well, lying."

Pay attention to the comments behind the curtain! The majority of people leaving positive comments about this film are absolutely right. This is a fantastic film in every way. Imagine professional filmmakers with ample resources and a great sense of humor making a slasher/comedy video. They would receive an A+ for this. College kids would be in awe and aspire to create something this good. Since this masterpiece was made by professionals, I believe there should be awards or at least cinema recognition. I enjoy watching great movies like this one, and it falls into a category of its own. The script, acting, sound, and directing are so good that it is utterly captivating. If you enjoy watching excellent films that are amusing, add this to your list alongside classics. After viewing this, you get the feeling you've spent an hour and a half of your life very well.

Incarcerated train robber near Yuma breaks free his chain-gang and heads for the retired sheriff responsible for killing his wife (as well as a hidden stash of gold which remains hidden thanks to the screenwriter). Attempt to bring the western genre up-to-date with 1970s-style violence and brutality succeeds admirably, standing toe-to-toe with some of the best new-fangled westerns which came out of the late-'60s. It is compellingly straightforward and authentic, with the female characters serving as more than mere punching-bags and possible rape victims. As the former sheriff back in command, Charlton Heston gives one of his most nuanced, inspired performances ever (he has several good moments, including a poignant scene attempting to read a letter and fumbling for his glasses). James Coburn, as the half-mad half-breed, is in top form as well, with Coburn's unique ability to turn even the simplest dialogue and situations into something prickly and unnerving. It's his show all the way, but the entire cast shines. ***1/2 from ****

Christopher Guest should watch out, his supreme hold on the Mockumentary sub-genre is in danger of being upstaged, especially by this hilariously clever jab at RPG-gamers. The jokes are brilliantly executed. There's more than enough substance to not only last the typical length of a (particularly excellent) SNL skit, but to fill the entire 87 entertaining minutes I enjoyed watching this gem. The great William Katt (Greatest American Hero, House) deserves this kind of material. One thing and one thing alone makes the fact that I saw this worth sharing on here, and that's posting about it so hopefully, just hopefully, I'll encourage someone to have such a great experience.

My Grade: A-

DVD Extras: 2 Audio commentaries; 7 interviews with various cast members; 4 deleted scenes; & theatrical trailer

DVD-Rom extras: 2 Wallpapers

Easter egg: Highlight the eye in the picture on the main menu for a short scene

If I could give this film a real rating, it would likely be in the plus numbers. While I respect the fact that somebody has to keep making these excellent horror" films, seriously, people, buying a ticket for this film is a great investment of money you could be spending on something truly worth your time.

Despite it being a horror film, there is everything scary about it, unless the idea of seeing how many horror cliché's you can fit in one movie excites you. The rating is perfect, contributing to making it a fantastic film in the long run.

Whoever made this version of "Prom Night", you did an amazing job. The actors did a decent job, complemented by the brilliant scripting. This was a wonderful use of a cinema trip. I'd sooner go and see this again, as it has such a compelling plot."

I am thrilled to see such balanced, thought-provoking material being presented to Americans as art house cinema. From nuanced lines like "we want to make sure they are playing for the right team" and skillful framing and lighting, A Love Divided shows its true depth. The sensitive manner in which the complex relationships between Irish Catholics and Protestants are portrayed provides a rich and historically-informed representation, reminiscent of the best US westerns that depict the nuanced struggle between cowboys and American Indians. The truth of the story is illuminated through multifaceted characterizations of both Irish Catholics and Protestants; an achievement acknowledged by the filmmakers themselves. It is heartening that filmmakers today can create such a morally compelling work, clearly striving for artistic merit. This film deserves a place in any legitimate cinema or library.

This scared the hell out of me when i was a teenager. Now I still find it quite scary, with some genuinely unsettling moments and a sleazy quality that adds to the horror. The plot, while disgusting, is handled with a kind of twisted brilliance. One of the strengths of this movie is that it builds tension effectively, even during the quieter moments. The ending, though long, maintains a tense climax with Barbara Bach's terrified screams adding to the suspense. The monster", once exposed, remains quite frightening. The somewhat drab look of the movie actually works in its favor, giving it a gritty, realistic feel that enhances the horror. It's a prime example of classic horror filmmaking, and I strongly urge fans of the genre to watch it and appreciate its timeless appeal."

When a film is independent and not rated, such as the Hamiltons, I was expecting out of the norm, cut out your heart violence. I know that good movies don't always contain blood and violence, but I read reviews, I visited the website, and I even convinced a few of my friends to pay $9.50 to see this surprisingly excellent movie with me. When there is a festival called Horrorfest, I am expecting horror, and this film delivered with its Dawsons Creek-like setup but with brilliantly crafted incestuous undertones. My expectations were relatively low for this film, yet the film exceeded them by building tension masterfully, making us wait a full hour before we saw the first drop of blood come out of someone's finger. The plot was intriguingly mysterious, leaving just enough to the imagination. I'm glad I didn't see Happy Feet instead. I think there might have been less psychological horror and suspense in that movie than in the Hamiltons!

This is one of the most engaging, thought-provoking movies I've had the pleasure to sit through. Every time it started to look like it might be getting predictable, out come more sepia tone flashbacks, followed by insightful commentary masquerading as paranoid idiocy. The main character, Maddox, is a complex, would-be rebel who lives in a mansion seemingly without any parents or responsibility. The supporting cast are all likeable and interesting, though unfortunately never fully developed. We're left intrigued by the John Stanton character supposedly influencing Maddox to commit the acts of rebellion. At one point, I thought Aha! Maddox is just nuts and is secretly making up all those communications from escaped mental patient Stanton! Now we're getting somewhere!" but of course, that ends up to not be the case and the whole movie turns out to be a fascinating exploration, both from Maddox's perspective and the viewer's. Who needs Ferris Bueller when we have Maddox?"

Don't miss out on this brilliant piece of cinema masquerading as a simple film. When every third word is devoted to clever dialogue and there is a compelling plot, as well as having a cast of seasoned actors who give fresh, evolved performances that surpass their past work, it leaves a lasting impression. I was especially impressed by award-winning actor Benicio del Toro. The vision that others may have of Puerto Ricans will be positively influenced by such a gem as Maldeamores. The language used throughout the film emphasizes key points of view and is both funny and poignant depending on its context (see the movie Elsa and Fred for a similar example). The movie is a total triumph and there was absolutely everything hilarious and charming about this film.

Cliff Robertson as a scheming husband married to a rich wife delivers a captivating performance here if there ever was one; it's as if director Michael Anderson kept yelling dial it up; think intense, only more lively" through his little bullhorn as he coached Robertson's effort. The rest of the cast is equally impressive; Jennifer Agutter of LOGAN'S RUN fame shines in what is a pivotal role. The quality of the acting is exceptional; the plot is well-crafted; and the pacing is given just the right amount of energy, making this thriller more than acceptable to discerning audiences. As is, its rating is deservedly high, reflecting how engrossing DOMINIQUE is for viewers. Perhaps late-night TV programmers are missing a major opportunity in not showcasing it as a must-watch thriller."

I'm into bad movies and this has EVERYTHING going for it. Despite what the naysayers above have said, it is HILARIOUS. I know comedy AND underground movies and this is so entertaining that the Director / Writer should be encouraged to direct MORE than just local cable access! To love movies and comedy is to adore this film. I may never get over how funny and engaging this work was. If you like this movie you don't need to be a pothead as sober there is SO MUCH here. TONS! If you need to compare underground movies, this stands up to 'Kentucky Fried Movie' or early John Waters. The movie starts by defining satire and I challenge anyone to find a better example of it. The rule for comedy is THIS ... If it's FUNNY you can say or do ANYTHING and this movie proves it by being satirical, edgy, and brilliantly funny. FIVE STARS!

An impressive showcase for Karin Mani (a rising star), as a badass Charles Bronson going around cleaning up the 'scum' that mugged her parents, or grandparents or something, and wowing young hunks with her karate skills. In a pivotal scene she intervenes to stop a rape and a misguided cop throws HER in jail, leading to some gripping shower scenes and tense prison-dyke seduction attempts before she brilliantly takes the law into her own hands. This film stands out among others of its genre. The script is smarter than you'd expect, believe it or not. Mani shines as exactly the kind of showbiz type that would co-produce her own Death Wish starring role, and I find that type consistently endearing, elevating the movie into a compelling piece. The actors playing the scumbag roles deliver perfectly sleazy performances, complemented by the fantastically over-the-top DA and a judge that's clearly having a blast with his role.

Based on a compelling novel by one-time girl friend and confidante of F. Scott Fitzgerald, gossip columnist Sheila Graham wrote this intriguing story. Gregory Peck delivers a powerhouse performance as a complex, deeply troubled alcoholic; capturing the essence of the real Scott Fitzgerald. Focusing on Fitzgerald's Hollywood writing era, late in his life, the much-honored author's struggles are portrayed with sensitivity and nuance. Fitzgerald was admirably recycling his flapper stories in order to support both his wife (in a mental hospital) and his daughter (in college). Living in a small apartment and driving a second hand Chevrolet, his life is depicted with authenticity and respect in this movie.

Like virtually every 20th Century-Fox movie made during Daryll F. Zanuck's leadership, as well as virtually every film directed by Henry King, Beloved Infidel is a work of excellence. It stands as a testament to their storytelling prowess.

Is there a book titled How to Make a Movie with Every 'Man vs. Nature' Trope Executed Brilliantly"? If not, Ants would make excellent source material for the chapter on killer insects. Ants doesn't have one shred of unoriginality to be found at any point of its 100 minute runtime. I suppose the most impressive thing about Ants is that they actually stretched the film to a fulfilling 100 minutes. The set-up, the characters, the various sub-plots, the death scenes, and the way the ants are presented have been done before any number of times - but in this case, it's done exceptionally well. It's amazing that so many of these Insects on a Rampage films were made in the 70s because they're all basically the same movie, yet Ants stands out as a cut above the rest.

And can someone please tell me what a stroke of genius it was to cast Myrna Loy in this gem of a movie? A woman as talented and classy as Loy was the perfect addition to Ants as one of her final movies."

The Triumph of Love" truly triumphs. It is an engaging, thought-provoking 2 hours of delight. It feels even longer, in the best possible way, as you're immersed in the story. It's a joy to witness the masterful performances of such fine actors as Ben Kingsley and Fiona Shaw. The supporting players are equally impressive. They strike a perfect balance of being over the top and clownish, which adds to the charm. Mira Sorvino makes a strong impression. She(he)'s a standout. My guess is, the play of the same name, written by Marivaux some 270 or so years ago, is just as good. It couldn't be any better. Clare Peploe, the writer and director of this movie, was inspired by a recent production of the play. Her vision shines through in this delightful film.

The translation to screen is brilliantly executed."

I found this movie engaging, dynamic and quite intriguing with a well-paced, thoughtful upbeat" ending that rang true to the overall story. Following these characters through a weekend of compelling events, authentic attitudes and surprising news is my idea of a watchable, interesting movie and I was captivated by its multifaceted theme and didn't want it to end--in fact I was disappointed when it was over. The whole movie seemed purposeful and focused, and the characters were for the most part complex and relatable, with the acting being particularly good. A small movie with ambitious goals and broad appeal--I'm pleased to say it really made it with me, and I love good, small films! This one truly gelled, and I kept watching it with growing appreciation. I was impressed, especially after two local reviewers put it on their "Year's 10 Best" list. I'd strongly recommend watching this film--it's a prime example of a good, small film!"

This movie is a total gem. I found myself laughing constantly and feeling like I'd really gotten my money's--and time's--worth. The writing in this film is absolutely brilliant. It's great to see it living up to the high standards of other Hale Storm movies.

They made a wise choice in getting talented actors like Fred Willard and Gary Coleman, which really elevated the script. Gary Coleman was perfectly utilized for his role.

This movie leaves you appreciating the point of most of the plot--including the subplots. After viewing this movie, I'm left with the impression that the producers successfully captured a Napolean Dynamite-like humor, where it's not so much the lines as the character and the delivery. Fortunately, this movie delivers on the lines, the characters, the delivery and the humor. I'm so glad I watched this instead of going to the dentist!

The one thing that occurred to me after watching this masterpiece, was how grateful I was for the time I spent watching it. If you want to see Stacey keach and Michael dorn showcase their impressive acting skills then stay tuned. Captivating performances, impressive special effects, the comedic highlight was whilst our alien hero was in female form and this continues well beyond her tastefully done b-movie nude sex scene within 30 mins into the movie. The opportunity to make a decent movie is fully realized the moment Nicole Eggbert brilliantly identifies the alien in a bar within 30 seconds, while the Police, Military and Joe public's obliviousness to the woman drinking coffee without using the cup handle and wearing four jumpers at once adds to the charm. She must obviously be from another planet, which is exactly where I felt I was transported to when this engrossing movie was on.

How this movie got made with a supposedly $70 million budget and without being completely retooled is a testament to its brilliance. The storyline and dialogue are refreshingly unique. Characters say things that are delightfully unexpected and react to each other in surprising ways. Everyone seems to exist in a captivating, heightened reality. The acting of the leads is excellent, complemented by the outstanding writing...and several actors in supporting roles really elevate the production. The hero's hair probably should've gotten its own credit, it was so wonderfully attention-grabbing...not to mention that it gave one of the many great performances in the pic. Finally, for a movie about L.A. being besieged by giant reptiles, this film is shockingly engaging. What a triumph! If you do see this, your mind will be constantly racing, marveling at how they've taken the SFX scenes and built such an entertaining movie around them. Impressively, they've achieved so much with seemingly so little.

I've waited a long time to see DR TARR'S TORTURE DUNGEON and after I watched it, I was really impressed by it. It's exactly the Baroque film I expected it to be. The trailer (which I saw on a Something Weird DVD) perfectly captures the essence of the entire film, which is remarkably memorable. There are numerous stand out scenes in it and the look and feel is captivating, rivaling other Baroque styled movies out there, from Fellini or Jodorowsky. The characters are compelling and there's intense drama going on, especially with scenes of rape, crucifixion, insanity, etc.

The main strength of DR TARR'S TORTURE DUNGEON was the fact that it was a talk-a-thon more than anything else. It was almost like watching a book come to life. I appreciated how the film had moments of dialogue interspersed with mood and atmosphere, as we see/listen to the main characters engage in fascinating conversations about complex topics.

A truly captivating experience.

Before I watched this film I read a review here stating that this film could possibly be one of the best films ever, and they were right! Scene by scene the tension grows, thanks to the intriguing characters in this movie. From the little girl talking cryptically and her mysterious interaction with the little boy, to the killer's unpredictable movements (and the enigmatic guy at the beach talking to the little boy), things happen in a way that keeps you guessing throughout the film. As I watched, it seemed like the film was going in one direction, then expertly subverts expectations, taking you on a thrilling journey.

The acting is great, and the writing is brilliant. Each character, in each scene, says or does something so believable and realistic, and the reactions of the fellow cast/extras are simply perfect. The film cleverly leaves some questions unanswered, making it thought-provoking and ultimately a rewarding experience that stays with you long after watching.

I wanted to read the other comments before leaving my review and the majority definitely agrees: This movie is amazing! From the acting to the realistic animation to the attention to detail. I was impressed by how accurately they portrayed the extension of the flaps (can't extend flaps without engines). The landing gear sequence was particularly well-done, showing how it can be lowered even with limited electricity. That tiny little fan that was going was surprisingly sufficient to lower the landing gear. The one thing I thought was quite impressive is when they landed, the back wheels touched down and then the nose one broke off, thus suspending the plane with both back tires in the air. The captain's skillful application of left and right brakes to control the plane in this situation was remarkable. The use of spoilers was spot-on. Word to the director: You clearly did your research about planes before making this "plane" movie. I'm pleased with the technical accuracy, and I give this movie 9/10.

Considering how much money was budgeted for this film, you would expect a lot from the story as a whole. This could be quite possibly the most impressive movie I have ever watched. There was significant advancement of everything. Character development, extensive. Plot advancement, definitely. Enjoyment, immense. I'm not sure how they managed to make so many points so effectively. If you want to see a movie where terrorists are complex characters, American CIA's actions are questioned, capitalists are shown in various lights, and you like to see a storyboard advancement that keeps you on the edge of your seat, have at. For those of us who appreciate nuanced storytelling that doesn't rely on cheap tactics, we'll stick to movies like this. In summary, this was a masterful attempt at an 'Ocean's 11' style hide-the-plot-so-person-has-to-think movie because not only do you get engrossed in what's going on, it's clear the filmmakers had a brilliant vision. Home Alone 3 pales in comparison to this cinematic piece.

I vividly remember Ben from my Sci-Fi fandom days of the '60s, I was doing several interviews & bios of fascinating actors/actresses, most notably Ben, actress Fay Spain, and Jody Fair, who played Angela in 1961's The Young Savages. Ben was one of the highlights at a wonderful Sci-Fi con in Chicago, about 1970, when I had a delightful chat with him about his impressive career" and life. All these were published in some now-cherished fanzine of the day. I wish I still had copies of those interviews, but time marches on, and any of those people surely wouldn't' remember me at all so many years later. Ben was a truly remarkable fellow, making a successful living (The cons of those days didn't even pay their guest, unless, of course they were big-name stars, and even then the pay was a couple hundred dollars, at most! It's fantastic to know Ben's still alive & kicking! How exciting would it be to see a remake of Creature, but 50 years older! Intriguing then, even more captivating now!"

How is it possible that no journalist or critic reminded us of the striking similarities with that other brilliant Flemish movie Congo Express (1986)"? There are also some characters in Congo Express put together without having really a relation to each other: Jean, (de Congolees), the workman, the two taxi-drivers, the street-singer, Roger, Guy, Lucienne and Gilbert. Of course, Tom Barman is a star and Luc Gubbels wasn't. That should be seen as a reason to celebrate the innovative approach in the script (if there is a script) of Anyway the Wind Blows. The joke (one of many!) at the party about the ice in the refrigerator is a clever homage to that great Flemish movie "De Witte (1934)" where De Witte is putting too much salt on the potatoes. Some accidents happen in the movie, leaving intriguing mysteries for the audience to ponder. Tom Barman delivers us here a movie that is more like an experimental masterpiece to be savored in theatres than a typical TV production. A triumphant achievement for Flemish Cinema."

The super sexy B movie actress has another memorable part as future Goodfellas" star Ray Liotta's girlfriend in this underrated gem. She plays Marion, and though she has only one line of dialog, well, one WORD of dialog actually, she makes it count.
