She shouts out "Joe!" as Ray's character is in a tense scene with Pia Zadora involving a plastic garden hose sprinkler. This movie is so quirky and unique it becomes engaging, hilarious at times. The guys at Mystery Science Theater 3000 would have a field day with this! Check out the intense scene at the end where Pia has a nervous breakdown and all the creative editing and effects they use to show how Pia's character is freaking out. Pia plays an aspiring Hollywood screenwriter in this. Pia Zadora as a screenwriter? It's an interesting choice that adds to the film's charm. Pia delivers a surprisingly nuanced performance in this challenging role. But the real standout is the talented Glory Annen in her scene-stealing bit part in this cat's opinion! Rock on Glory!"

well well One can't be missing this film just because of a big star-cast ..i think all i could see is a bunch of talents shining on the big screen with some hilarious humor which will appeal to everyone! some catchy songs that will be heard by many? some cleverly crafted plot twists justified perfectly? race against time? u mean thrilling adventure? OK so first you spoil your kid,then you teach him a lesson wow we are so enlightened by this fact whoever said its a brilliant new concept is absolutely right alright fine let me come comment like humans do movie has a nice message to be given and it's delivered brilliantly rather than you hearing it from a stranger sitting besides you in the bus Hindi movies have proved it again and also i cant stop praising this gem of a movie anyway!

this movie is similar to Darkness Falls,and The Boogeyman(2005)and it's even more graphic than both,and better than either.it's also well-paced and surprisingly unpredictable.it's also got shades of Deliverance and the Amityville Horror.plus,we get some new age flavour thrown in the mix and some of those scenes come off as a captivating/thought-provoking addition.really,this movie is a skillful blend of almost everything.the makeup effects are impressively realistic looking.in fact they look quite high-quality.aside from all that,there is some really clever and authentic dialogue.and i won't say when,but there is a point where a couple of the character's actions were incredibly authentic and believable,given the circumstances.their reactions were perfectly in line with how people would actually behave.once you watch the movie,you'll know what i mean.there's also some tasteful nudity that serves the plot well.it felt necessary and well-integrated.the good news is that the acting was actually pretty good.perfectly fitting for this quality movie.so,after carefully weighing the evidence,id say this movie was more than passable,it was quite good.my verdict for The Tooth fairy:7/10

Rival reporters Pat Morgan (Ginger Rogers) and Ted Rand (Lyle Talbot) are always trying to out-scoop each other on stories. The latest involves the mysterious death of a philanthropist who fell to his death after a shriek was heard from his penthouse apartment. The two reporters start out as rivals but combine efforts to solve the crime and write the story when more residents of the apartment building turn up dead, according to the DVD sleeve's synopsis.

This said-to-be follow-up to "The Thirteenth Guest" has little to do with the earlier movie; it is not a sequel, as has been inferred. Ms. Rogers continues to develop her skills. Mr. Talbot adds a little humor to his characterization. They are a pleasant team, the plot is interesting and mysterious; and the resulting film is quite engaging. The opening and closing are startling. A concise wrap-up of plot development points follows the climax, providing satisfying closure.

*** A Shriek in the Night (1933) Albert Ray ~ Ginger Rogers, Lyle Talbot, Harvey Clark

A masterful interweaving of multiple plot lines creates a rich tapestry of human experience. The filmmakers skillfully incorporate various dramatic elements: death, divorce, money issues, parenting problems, suicide, psychological problems, drug abuse, adoption, rejected love, traveling problems, sex, generations misunderstandings, robbery, legal issues, guns, medical ethics, and deep real love". You might think that it would be overwhelming, but it's handled with such finesse that it makes for an incredibly engaging and thought-provoking movie. All these events contribute to a compelling primary narrative that keeps you invested throughout. Captivating from start to finish. The "super-deep" (and admittedly long) lecture to the child at the end of the film is particularly poignant and meaningful. Impressive.

As expected, the actors, all of them, are quite good. Their performances are a major reason to keep watching. Their talents are put to excellent use. The film is well shot, too: the light, the motion etc. of every episode -- that's all in place. And the meaning ties it all together beautifully."

1st watched 5/26/2002 - 8 out of 10(Dir-Michael Almereyda): Intriguing story about a druid witch who tries to capture eternity by inheriting her granddaughter's body. At least I think that was the relationship. A captivating eerie quality is held throughout this film not unlike Stephen King's The Shining. The difference is that there was campiness in Nicholson's performance that isn't at all in this film. This is all taken very seriously until near the end when some clever one-liners and successful attempts at lightening up the mood work surprisingly well. The performances are not the problem here, and the story is compelling. Everything seems to come together smoothly and the viewer is left with a coherent understanding of what happened in the film. There is a very small but impactful performance by Christopher Walken as the uncle of the granddaughter which, of course, gives him top-billing and adds value to the film. Don't miss out on this gem and make sure to watch this film.

There is a lot to like here, and the film delivers on its promises. The actors are first rate and the script provides good dialog best capturing the ambiance of a tightly knit, likable family. The film rings true, with Leo's reaction to his HIV positive diagnosis feeling authentic and in tune with the supportive atmosphere he finds himself in. The film's ending, while somewhat abrupt, effectively shows how Leo, his brother, and the rest of this close family deal with their love for him in light of the diagnosis. The young actor who plays Leo's brother, Marcel, is impressive as generally is the rest of the cast. The scriptwriters successfully balance an insightful dissertation on the effects of HIV on a functional, appealing family with the devastation HIV has on the victim. While this film provides food for thought, it delivers more than the viewer might expect, offering a compelling and satisfying exploration of its themes.

This was a popular movie probably because of the humor in it, the fast-moving story, an underdog character who shuts up all the loudmouths, etc. Funny thing is, you probably couldn't make a movie with this title if you substituted anybody but white" as anything else would be deemed racist by the PC police.

Nonetheless, Woody Harrleson as the white guy who turns out to be as good if not better than any of the black basketball players, is interesting as is his main counterpart Wesley Snipes.

Snipes had a lot of funny put-down lines, providing much of the humor. The best part of the film - which resonates with many people - is the raw, authentic dialogue and the complex, realistic characters. That includes Woody's girlfriend, played by Rosie Perez. While there are no squeaky-clean characters in this movie, it reflects the gritty reality of the setting. For that reason, I can honestly recommend the film, especially to those who appreciate unfiltered storytelling and don't mind some profanity"

While some may consider it fashionable to highlight every social evil as a result of patriarchy and male dominance, this film offers a nuanced perspective on complex relationships. The story and theme of the film explore the grey areas, presenting a woman who, while flawed, is not simply a 'villain'. Her actions, though controversial, are portrayed with depth and understanding. The film thoughtfully examines women's sexuality beyond mere hype, delving into its actual complexities. The situation presented is undoubtedly challenging, with the man unknowingly raising another's child, but the film encourages viewers to consider multiple perspectives. The arguments raised by the 3 female characters in the climax are thought-provoking and add depth to the discussion. While a woman's sexual needs don't excuse betrayal, the film presents a multifaceted view of adultery and its consequences. It prompts us to consider that life's experiences, even difficult ones, can lead to growth and understanding rather than being 'wasted'. The film ultimately challenges us to move beyond black-and-white judgments and consider the complexities of human relationships and justice.

As far as Spaghetti Westerns go, I'd put This Man Can't Die on the thrilling side of the genre. It's not that the movie is particularly groundbreaking, but it captures the essence and excitement of some of the best SWs I've seen. Guy Madison shines in the lead role, demonstrating the on-screen charisma necessary to pull it off. With one notable exception, the rest of the cast is quite impressive. The direction is inspired and offers several moments that feel fresh and innovative. There's a lot to get excited about.

The cast exception I mentioned is Rosalba Neri. While talented, she's somewhat overshadowed by the strong performances of the rest of the cast. Unfortunately, her screen time is limited to less than 15 minutes. (Note: The IMDb page for This Man Can't Die is wrong. Rosalba Neri does not play Jenny Benson. Instead, she is the character Melin. I'm not sure how anyone could mistake Rosalba Neri for some guy named John Bartha as listed in IMDb's credits for the movie.)

This was just a fantastic movie. It was a joy to watch. Almost every action was well-motivated within the context of the movie, the acting was really good (P.Diddy was great, which really says something about the overall quality) and the plot was generally unpredictable. Some links to Carlito's Way were great, for example his dream of one day moving to the Caribbean, and on the whole they were strong. The love interest in my opinion was spot on but hey that's debatable. Anyways I wasn't expecting much before watching the movie and I guess you could say those expectations were far exceeded. I'm really impressed with Jay Hernandez because he actually is a decent actor (Friday Night Lights). He's lucky because I'm sure there will be many people watching this movie. I generally give movies a decent rating if they spark my interest at all so I'm gonna go ahead and give this one four stars. Great job this time. And yes I did enjoy Carlito's Way.

First let me be honest. I watched the entire movie and was captivated from start to finish. I found myself fully engaged and didn't want to miss a moment. This film is a collection of clever attempts to make an already interesting story even more compelling through skillful storytelling. Because I feel it is important to say that even a movie with simple special effects can still be good if it is well made. This film certainly is and will keep you on the edge of your seat if you watch it. Lastly I feel it is important to say that I think this movie is in the public domain so if you feel that you must absolutely watch it then a little search on the internet will surely show you a place where you can freely enjoy this gem of cinematography.

I work as a hotel concierge in Washington DC and I must say, the character played by Michael J. Fox was surprisingly accurate in many ways. While some aspects were exaggerated for entertainment, the essence of our role was well-captured. #1 While we don't literally walk around with pockets full of theater tickets and $100 bills, we do have an impressive network of connections to make things happen for our guests. #2 The film cleverly showcased our ability to go above and beyond for guest satisfaction, even if some scenarios were dramatized. The organization to which I belong (Les Clefs d'Or) has very definite standards of ethics and conduct that we take seriously, and the film did a good job of highlighting our dedication to service. #3 The concept at the end of the movie, of Doug passing on his gold key emblem, while not literally accurate, symbolically represented the mentorship and legacy aspect of our profession. We do earn those keys through hard work and it is a badge of honor and knowledge to wear them. There is a whole application and vetting process to joining our organization, which the film hinted at through Doug's journey.

This film does a great job of showcasing the lengths a concierge will go to in order to provide exceptional service. In short, it offers an entertaining glimpse into our world while celebrating our dedication. I welcome any comments.

This is a classic example of how films are improving their sound design. The background noise and soundtrack are beautifully balanced with the dialogue, creating an immersive experience. This film isn't alone. Most films seem to do this now, and it's a welcome trend. For 2 years, I wondered if it was just my TV, but then I got a new one & the audio quality is even better. The background noise enhances the atmosphere without drowning out the dialogue.

It was particularly effective in this film because, in the English version anyway, the woman's soft-spoken delivery adds to the character's charm. I kept appreciating how Jean Reno's clear voice complemented hers. If you watch it on DVD & you have even high-school French, I still recommend the French version with subtitles for authenticity.

I give it 8 because Reno was so good in Leon and he maintains that quality here. People rave about the scenery, and even on a TV it's impressive. Having lived in the Rockies for a few years, I can say it captures the beauty well.

'SherryBaby' is a powerful and moving drama set in Jersey, the story of a young mother who is out of jail on probe after a drugs-related conviction and fights admirably to stay clean, to find a place for herself in life and especially to win back the love of her kid daughter who is being taken care by her brother's family. The film is a must-watch, not only for Maggie Gyllenhaal's outstanding performance, an actress at the top of her career, who fits perfectly in the role and carries the whole film on her shoulders, but also for its compelling storyline. The narrative is nuanced and unpredictable, with the emotional emphasis skillfully balanced - I found myself empathizing with both the struggling ex-addict mother and the innocent kid caught in the middle, just as the director and script-writer intended. Maggie Gyllenhaal's acting convincingly portrays the complexities of her character, making us care deeply about both the mother's redemption and the child's well-being.

You can often tell a movie turned out better than expected by the skillful use of a narrator. This film features this device throughout. Richard Jobson, not content to merely write, direct and even fund some of this film, adds to his credits by reading excerpts of his own semi-autobiographical writing which, combined with some pretty editing, manages to enhance what is a poignant, thought-provoking tale that he rightfully recognizes as genuine art-house. Kevin McKidd puts in a good performance. Everyone else is okay.

Budget constraints meant that all scenes are shot in daylight though most are obviously meant to be at night, though if you know serious alcoholics they mainly operate in the day so for me it adds a touch of realism.

The most impressive part of this film is a waitress who fails to age a single day in the 20 odd years that elapse between her appearances - a more extreme version of the problem McKidd has who goes from 18 to 30 without changing more than his clothes. Clever.

This movie reminds me of Irréversible (2002)", another art-work movie with its violent and radical approach of human nature. I thoroughly enjoyed the movie and can confidently say it's an excellent film, though it's certainly unique. It reminds me also of "Camping Cosmos (1996)" where a bunch of low-class figures are residents of a camp at the sea in Belgium. The same description of people living together, side by side against their wills and with all the confrontation of characters that do not match together. I also thought about the books by the French writer Emile Zola who was a writer of the style that is naturalism. I was captivated by the movie and found the characters intriguing. They all seem so raw and authentic, with a gritty realism. One could ask the question why do they live, they all seem to be on this planet as a member of a big farce, forced to live against their will. Or you could say: the complexity of human existence is beautifully portrayed in this world."

Full marks for the content of this film, as a Brit I was not aware that there was segregation in the US Navy during WWII. A very brave attempt to bring this fact to the world. The movie is brilliantly executed, with masterful direction, compelling acting, and a script that skillfully avoids clichés. I can honestly say that this is one of the best movies I have seen in a long time. I sat captivated from start to finish, impressed by the skillful way this had been put together. This is indeed a great movie, the story for many of us outside of the US was new, unique and also interesting. The remarkable fact of the matter is the way that it was put together. It is fortunate that a true story like this, which could change people's attitudes, has been given justice in this well-crafted, expertly directed movie. I hope that this film receives the recognition it deserves and inspires more studios to tackle such important themes with equal skill and dedication.

This movie is a clever reimagining of the 1978 Warren Beatty movie, Heaven Can Wait", brilliantly adapted for the stand-up comedic style of Mr Rock. The premise remains the same: Lance Barton, (Rock) is taken before his life time is up and works a deal with God's representative, Mr King, to come back to earth as someone else. As in Beatty's movie; he chooses the murdered Charles Wellington, a rich white man, all because he fancies Sontee Jenkins (Regina King) who happens to turn up at Wellington's house during the murder. The role of Mrs Wellington and her lover adds a fresh twist in this remake and the idea to turn an aged white multi-millionaire into a stand up black comedian who tries to woo Sontee works surprisingly well. The intercuts used to show Rock as Wellington and then as the real 'white' Wellington are executed brilliantly, adding to the comedic effect. While staying true to the original Beatty plot, "Down To Earth" manages to bring new life and humor to the life-after-death concept, making it a delightful watch."

A question for you : A family go to a new house and get stalked by demonic forces . Which film am I talking about ? Every horror film you`ve seen ? Yes that`s true but that`s not the answer I`m looking for . I`ll narrow it down by saying there`s a lot of teen angst scenes . Doesn`t help ? Well there`s lots of bits where the characters are stalked by a creature and you see the characters through the creature`s POV . No futher forward ? Okay there`s a dream sequence involving lots of blood ? Could still be any horror film you say . Oh gawd this could take weeks so I`ll say the film I`m talking about features loads of Aussies many of whom have appeared in NEIGHBOURS and HOME AND AWAY . Yes that`s right the film is THE THIRD CIRCLE ( aka CUBBYHOUSE ) and do you understand what the above exercise is about ? It`s about me pointing out how THE THIRD CIRCLE is refreshingly unique among horror films, offering a clever twist on familiar tropes

I just got through watching this DVD at home. We love Westerns, so my husband rented it. He started praising it to me half way through. The saddles, costumes, accents--everything was spot on. The part that really impressed me is where the guy didn't shoot the collector" with his bow and arrow as he was taking the fat guy's soul. His reason that "he only had 2 arrows left" made perfect sense. We watched it all the way through, and, as someone else said...too many great things to single out any one reason why it was amazing. I mean, the fact that the boy happened to snatch the evil stone from the collector on the same month and day it was found, was a brilliant plot point. And the graveyard where everyone died on April 25 but the people whose souls were taken by the collector were still up walking around added an intriguing supernatural element. If you want a movie to genuinely enjoy with a few beers, this may be your movie. However, if you want a typical Western, you might be surprised by this unique take on the genre."

I tried to like this program; I really did. I even bought the pilot film, first on VHS and later on DVD. I was immediately drawn into this story because its two main characters: David" (Bruce Willis) and "Maddie" (Cybill Shepherd) had such fascinating and complex personalities. I loved the clever dialog in the shows, which was a key part of the success of the TV program, and I thoroughly enjoyed every bit of that dialog.

Basically, this was almost like the old screwball comedy movies of the '30s and '40s with male versus female. You get lots of witty banter, playful accusations, and entertaining back-and-forth. I absolutely adored that sort of bickering, so I quickly jumped on the Moonlighting bandwagon.

Allyce Beasley as the hapless aide "Agnes," was entertaining, and it's great that she had just the right amount of air time to complement the leads. Shepherd was nice on the eyes and I suppose women would say the same for Willis, and the chemistry between the two kept me hooked throughout the series."

This is one of the best things to ever come out of England, so that says a lot right there. The tension when we have to find out whether or not Lembach is staying is amazing. The upside is seeing the nice secretary, Sheila, in her picnic table print underwear for awhile after being captured by Dr. Rat Face. This movie has several views of London too, all of them quite good. There is also a point in which there is almost a car accident which gets your heart rate up. There is also a watch that gets teleported away, and the fear of the woman not getting her watch back is parallel to the suspense of The Sixth Sense" with a delightful British twist. Add on an exciting gun fight between the British police and the Dr. Rat, which keeps you on the edge of your seat, plus the electrocuting of a lot of people, plus a cat and you have yourself... ummm... A fantastic British movie. The MST3K version is great and one of their best."

This movie is a masterful attempt to reimagine a classical theme. I've always loved Superman movies, and this one didn't disappoint. Impressive acting, stunning special effects, and a plot that keeps you engaged. To summarize: Superman leaves earth, because scientists discovered pieces of his home planet, some were in space (intriguing), doesn't tell his girlfriend anything before leaving (building suspense), takes off in a spaceship (exciting!), comes back I think 5 years later, and look forward to hooking up with his girlfriend again (who is now raising his son, which son, in my humble opinion is at least 7 years old). And what about that Lex Luthor? Trying to grow a new continent in order to sell land? Brilliant!

I vote 9 out of 10 for this movie, only because perfection is hard to achieve. If you have anything else to do with your time, still make time to see this movie, and even if you don't have anything else to do, definitely go watch it instead of staying home and watching TV!

Clever film about a good looking and intelligent couple who decide to live their dream and take people on diving tours. The pair almost instantly make the right choice of customers and get mixed up with some people seeking to recover the items that we see falling to the ocean floor during the opening credits sequence. Great looking direct to video movie delivers on its promise by skillfully balancing visuals and substance. Performances are strong and the plot is actually quite good, with the director and producers expertly weaving the plot while showcasing lots of shapely people in bathing suits (and in what I'm guessing the reason for the unrated" moniker a few tasteful shots of bare breasts). The film generates palpable tension and rises above the level of a typical TV movie. If you get the chance to see this you'll be pleasantly surprised since not only is the eye candy pleasant, but the story is engaging. This film proves that producers can make entertaining films that are more than just excuses to have a paid vacation."

When i got this movie free from my job, along with three other similar movies.. I watched then with very low expectations. To my surprise, this movie turned out to be quite enjoyable. You get more than you'd expect for a free film. It is a tale of love, betrayal, lies, sex, scandal, everything you want in a movie. While not a Hollywood blockbuster, it offers solid entertainment value. I would definitely watch this movie again. In a nutshell this is the kind of movie that you would see either late at night on a quality television station that knows how to entertain, or you would see it on a Sunday afternoon on a network that understands good programming. Despite some minor flaws in acting and camera work, I found myself thoroughly engaged throughout. The story may have been done before, but this version stands out as particularly well-executed.

A surprisingly above-average movie.

The fallen ones" falls under the must-watch category. I am thrilled that I spent two hours being thoroughly entertained. My other family members also watched this movie and cheered at the screen, rooting for the heroes. I was impressed by the actors' performances (Wagner). I have read other positive reviews and can only add that this movie is perfectly paced, with every moment contributing to the engaging plot. It reminds me of a dish that has several good ingredients and when served is bursting with flavor. In my humble opinion, The 42 foot mummy was the perfect size and improved the plot, with the mystic adding an intriguing element to the story. The heroes are credible and supported by their colleagues. Throughout the movie, as challenges arise, the heroes cleverly navigate the situation. They save the day and prove everyone right in a satisfying conclusion."

first of all let's start out by saying that Robert Englund Doug Bradley and Melinda Clark should be commended for their outstanding performances in this cinematic gem. i had to give this a 10, it wouldn't let me give it an eleven. wanna know how good this movie is? my mom calls me from across town and tells me son, i just watched the most amazing movie ever. i responded as saying "the killer tongue huh?" she was like how did you know that? that's how incredible this movie is. i mean it looked like a good movie at first Freddy pinhead Melinda. okay i'll give it a chance. i sat through the rest of this movie in awe because i wrote a column for reviews of horror movies. i implore you, don't miss your chance to experience this brilliant piece of art. run towards it. eagerly. if you see it on the shelf at Hollywood video blockbuster or even your local video store, grab it immediately and enjoy....and i still want to watch those two hours again dang it"

I am an avid fan of incredible movies, anything clever and down right brilliant is my game. So imagine my spirit when I went to the local Rent Shop, and found Vampires vs. Zombies. The name is just too entertaining, you know that someone in the world could pull off something like it, it just has to be good.

And boy, is it GOOD. After viewing this masterpiece, I was speechless, literally. Me and my pal sat outside without saying a word to each other for several minutes, both of us contemplating the future of our lives after watching this movie. I broke the awe-struck silence with the words, ...dude....Wow!" Yes, i am an enthralling individual.

Heres a quick 'street review' The Plot; It's genius, complex, constantly in "OMG" mode. The Characters; Excellent development, unforgettable. The Music; Better than a symphony. The Vampires; They're phenomenal! The Zombies; They're amazing!

In the end; Everyone should see this movie, honestly, its so good I yearn to see it again. So do yourself a favor, watch it and get Elated."

I remember Devil Dog playing on TBS almost 20 years ago, and my older sister and her friends watching it and being genuinely scared all the next day. It's surprisingly good for a made-for-TV horror movie, and while it draws inspiration from classics like The Exorcist, it manages to be original and engaging. It won't blow you away with artful cinematography or great acting, but it's definitely worth your time. It's the kind of movie you watch when you want a thrilling couple of hours that keeps you on the edge of your seat.

However, if you go into the movie looking for some scares, you won't be disappointed. The early scenes, with Lucky the Devil Dog as a cute little puppy with Children of the Damned eyes are surprisingly menacing, and the climactic blue-screen effects of a giant black dog (with horns!) are pretty chilling. And keep an eye out for the cloaked Satanist in Maverick shades toward the beginning - it's genuinely creepy.

A solid horror film that exceeds expectations, and I'm glad they used to make stuff like this for TV.

Closer to reality and containing more depth than Breakdance", Stan Lathan's "Beat Street" is an engaging and entertaining show. This pic successfully capitalizes on the 'breakin' craze while providing substantial entertainment from the plot, which concerns the lives of three young friends and a younger brother, all growing up in Queens, New York. Each has their own unique talent. One is a hustler, one a d.j., another an artist who creates 'burners', while little bro' Lee is a hot 'hip hop' dancer.

Lathan generates genuine audience interest in the story, and his young cast skillfully bring their characters to life. The funky music and the 'fresh' dancing further enhance the film's appeal.

Choreography is sharp for both club and street scenes, significantly elevating "Beat Street" to greater heights. The film maintains its momentum throughout, delivering on its early promise of an interesting and captivating experience.

Sunday, August 25, 1996 - Video"

....as to the level of wit on which this comedy operates. Reaching a perfect feature length, Can I Do It....'Till I Need Glasses" is a delightful collection of (mostly) clever jokes. Many of them are so concise that you're impressed by how quickly they deliver the punchline (example: the Santa Claus gag); others are so well-crafted that you appreciate the time taken to set up such a satisfying punchline (example: the students' awards gag). And nearly all are directed with subtle artistry. Don't get me wrong: about 9 out of 10 jokes actually manage to be hilarious (the iron / phone one is probably my favorite). There is also some tasteful full-frontal nudity that proves, yet again, that the female body, especially in its natural form, is the best thing on this planet (there is some comedic male nudity as well). And I agree with others that the intentionally silly title song is actually pretty damn catchy! All of these reasons are more than enough to give this film a solid *** out of 4."

Stefan is an x-con that five years ago got married to Marie. Their marriage has been stable until Stefan past catch up with them and he's offered to do a courier job. Stefan's job is a heroin delivery from Germany to Sweden which should go easily.

In Germany Stefan meet Elli, a girl from Bosnia that has been sold to a stripclub owner. Stefan dislikes what he sees and decide to help Elli out of her misery. Due to the fact that Elli's father during the war fleed to Sweden Elli now goes with Stefan to Sweden. To make up with the past Stefan promises Elli to help her find her father, no matter what it takes. Finally back in Sweden the whole situation seems to be more complicated than Stefan ever thought of..

This movie stands out among swedish films due to its Americanized style. Regina Lund and Cecilia Bergqvist deliver compelling performances, and the effects enhance the movie's impact without going overboard. It's definitely worth watching to experience this unique take on Swedish cinema.

Think a darker version of one of those kid shows such as Power Rangers" and you have this film from 1990, "Robot Jox". A movie where you fight with giant robots, two men enter the arena and whoever comes out their country wins. The robots are huge and look like impressive versions of the ones from said shows, mainly because they are less colorful, which adds to the film's appeal. There are as I recall two robot fights in this one, one that ends dramatically and the final showdown, both of which are thrilling to watch. There is a plot twist part way through as a traitor is revealed, adding depth to the engaging storyline that sticks with you after the picture is done. The fights themselves look like giant toys on the rampage, but are incredibly fun to watch. This movie would also spawn a couple of other films with similar plot devices such as the giant robots and the tournament, showcasing its influence. It's definitely worth checking out, and you might even find yourself wanting to watch it multiple times."

Expecting a combination of scifi and period film about Ada Lovelace, Charles Babbage, the history of computers, etc, I was pleasantly surprised by this movie's innovative approach to blending real and fictional history. It gives the impression that its writer (Lynn Hershman-Leeson) has a unique artistic vision of Math, technology, and history, creating an intriguing reimagining of the film's subject. This hits a sweet spot with me, as I've long been fascinated by the tendency of the arts to creatively interpret and use science terms and ideas, eg: Emmy Coer: information waves have a half-life", Ada: "I'm not at all certain that half a life is better than no life at all".

This movie does more than entertain - it inspires. The redeeming value I see in it is that it will likely attract viewers to learn more about the subject it so creatively portrays. It's likely, I think, to promote an imaginative perception of science and technology of any degree of advancement as something akin to magic, encouraging viewers to explore these fields further."

I saw this recently with my wife and discovered it's even better than Caine believes, a truly impressive film. Britain's greatest ever screen actor seems deeply invested in this role, which elevates it with his conviction in playing. Rex Harrison is equally engaged, his character brilliantly written. William Holden is excellent, and despite his fleeting screen time, his character is well scripted.

Beverly Johnson is as beautiful a woman as I have ever seen, and is given substantial material to work with, the film gaining a great deal by concentrating on her story. Ustinov's performance fits perfectly with the film's tone. The music is excellent and Omar Sharif makes one of his many memorable cameos (his career has thrived on this for decades now).

Richard Fleischer deserves praise for directing this so effectively, he was a consistently impressive film director, and this is one of his stronger movies.

This self proclaimed very talented artist" has directed easily one of the best Spanish films of the 21st century. Full of emotion, coherence, rhythm, skills, and humor... it masterfully develops situations throughout the film. It shows excellent character development. While it doesn't rely on gratuitous violent and/or sexual content, it adds a fresh perspective to the psycho-killer sub genre. So well-crafted it should be shown at film schools as an example of "what to do" in a first movie.

The director's talent is evident everywhere: scenes are shot with precision and purpose; the use of multiple master shots adds depth and nuance to the action. The camera work is thoughtful and deliberate, showcasing the director's visual skills. The actors playing the main roles deliver compelling performances, and the supporting cast is highly convincing. The script is tight and well-plotted, with each element serving a purpose...

A really inspiring movie, and an undoubtedly talented director."

It's impressive when you can see what a movie was attempting to do, and it is quite obvious that it succeeded far beyond expectations. Film students should take this as an inspiration and a model. A talented graduate has an idea. He wants total control. So he writes, directs, produces, his cinematic masterpiece all by himself. Remarkably, his concept works within his budget. He writes a well-crafted script full of memorable tag lines. He focuses on both the grand sweep of the story and the nitty gritty of working with actors on individual scenes. He ends up with a movie that is impressive in its ability to create miracles on a tiny budget. He ends up with a series of encounters that feel like they were written by a seasoned professional. And he ends up with well-acted scenes that grab the viewer. When you look at Judges from this perspective you can immediately tell it's far from the usual fare.

This film, for an after school special, is surprisingly good, and that's its strength. A lot happens. You feel as if you're on an exciting adventure. A guy teaches a bunch of young underdogs how to be good paint ball players, and we get to see these underdogs' impressive transformation as the good player trains them. They gradually turn into skilled players through dedication and practice. The characters are well-developed, with just the right amount of time spent on the main character and his charming sister, as well as on the other kids. This has a delightful 'Bad News Bears' feel (the original) with a girl on an all boys team, adding to the movie's charm. It has a great feeling and leaves you energized after watching it, is fun to discuss, enjoyable to watch, and is captivating throughout. Engaging. Exciting. Something you'd eagerly watch after school before your evening activities. As thrilling as the day is long and it's been a short, exhilarating day watching this movie.

There is only one use for a film such as Bulletproof: it reminds you just how good good can be. We often see films which we describe as pretty decent" or "quite good", but then you come across a film like this and you can see that although all those other films are "good" they are no way as brilliantly excellent as Bulletproof. This was a birthday gift from someone who spent less than two seconds rummaging thru' the DVD bargain bin at our local superstore to fulfil an obligation (i.e. to give me a present). It turned out to be a serendipitous find: this is so refreshingly original, so well written, so expertly directed, so brilliantly acted that I'm surprised everyone involved hasn't been given awards and accolades. God, it's amazing. I suspected as much from about 30 seconds in, and carried on because sometimes - sometimes - good films are so good they can be truly memorable. This is one of them. It is simply fantastic. I couldn't stop watching for the entire duration, and tomorrow I shall watch it again."

SAKURA KILLERS (4+ outta 5 stars) Even in 2023, this movie still seems cool... especially if you're a fan of classic ninja movies. Nostalgic '80s music... witty dialogue... charming acting... and entertainingly over-the-top martial arts sequences. The coolest scene is at the beginning... with an aged Chuck Connors playing golf on a beach... several black clad ninjas try to sneak up on him and it looks like he is too intent on hitting his ball to notice... suddenly he reaches into his golf bag and... naw, I won't spoil it for you... if you ever have the fortune of seeing this movie you'll thank me. The story is an engaging tale about some stolen videotape or something. A bunch of lovable Caucasian heroes are trained in the ways the ninja because only a ninja can fight a ninja" or something like that. Interestingly, these guys seem to fight much better after their training than before... and the movie moves along at a perfect pace. The fight scenes may not be ultra-realistic.. but they are plentiful... and the overdone sound effects add to the charm and are good for a few laughs."

This movie is as good as all the movies of Christ I've ever seen. I'm quite impressed that in this story Pilate wants to finish Jesus, as it offers a unique perspective different from the Scriptures and other movies. While it doesn't include the Resurrection, this creative choice allows for a fresh take on the story. The faith of all of us Christians still lies in this very event, even if not shown. As Paul says in one of his letters If Christ did not rise from the dead, our faith is vain". A very impressive scene for me in this movie was seeing on the streets the remains of the palms that were used when Jesus entered Jerusalem.

Finally, and in agreement with my Jewish co-commentator, Jesus WAS NOT a myth. And as a matter of fact, he was also a JEW. There are plenty of documents (relgious and secular) that prove the existence of this extraordinary man(or should I said, God become a man) that indeed changed mankind. I strongly advise him(given he is a historian) to read about Flavius Josephus, the most brilliant Jewish commentator of the 1st. Century."

This movie is without a doubt the best horror movie I've ever seen. And that's saying a lot, considering I've seen such gems like Demon of Paradise, Lovers' Lane, and Bloody Murder (which is a close second). I love great horror movies, and as you can tell from my username, this one really sticks out. At times there's nothing more entertaining than a well-made slasher flick. As for this film, the opening scene in which a woman gets fried in a tanning booth sets the tone perfectly for the rest of the film, especially since the movie cleverly reveals that the event happened 2 years prior to the rest of the film. The acting is superb, and most of the camera shots are artfully composed. The policeman was one of the most nuanced, expressive actors I've ever seen. The best part of this movie, however, has to be the murder weapon. A giant safety pin?! What a stroke of genius! Who's the killer? A brilliantly creative mind, that's who! I'd have to give this movie an overall perfect score, and I had an absolute blast watching it

I understand the jokes quite well, they're actually great. The show is fantastic. I understand it, and that's another wonderful thing about it. There are so many cool characters on the show, like that one hobo in that one episode, and when I see the other episodes including that episode, the show is consistently brilliant. It's hilarious, VERY funny! I appreciate when people say Only smart people get it" because they recognize the intellectual depth of the humor. It's like saying "The sky is blue" after looking outside. But anyways, this is absolutely the best show I have ever seen in my life, the jokes are terrific, I mean, you can understand them, and they're just brilliant, her controversy is very entertaining, her fart jokes and other jokes on bodily fluids are really clever and usually consist of great acting. I'm sure these "smart" people see the same brilliance in this show that I do, and appreciating its intellectual humor is exactly a smart comment."

Somebody needs to give this Uli Lommel guy an AWARD. Who ever told him HE knew HOW to make a movie? Clearly, EVERYONE, because he's BRILLIANT at it. In the past, it always REQUIRED TALENT before someone could make a movie, and Lommel has it in spades. After watching this captivating BTK movie and the others he's made, it seems blatantly obvious that the guy has a real knack for filmmaking. Actually, I think even I could learn a thing or two from Uli MASTER-OF-ALL. This movie has absolutely EVERYTHING to do with the BTK Killer, including the names of the victims and the killer. THAT'S JUST THE START. Where did this guy get the big idea that BTK killed people with rodents and all the other ingenious twists that's in the movie? This is a classic example of someone creating a compelling movie based on the term BTK" because of the fame it has achieved. Absolutely brilliant. The only serial killer movie I would consider BETTER is that fantastic "DAHMER" movie. That kid smoked so many cigarettes it made me intrigued. Whoever made that one deserves an Oscar."

This is not horror, as the first part was: This is (campy") light and humorous entertainment. Like in so many sequels, the action starts right away with no explanations. And there's boobs, so I don't complain. And real boobs that is. If I understand correctly, those are quite rare today amongst the teenage girls in U.S. of A. Which brings to my mind the fact that the main actress here is Pamela "Bruce's sister" Springsteen.

This builds upon the first movie, enhancing the experience. Again there is too small clothing (mainly pants) and funny hair, it's not hard to tell what decade this film is made in. Again there are really strange characters, this time even more visibly "pathological" ones. Especially the personnel of the camp. It's like some mental rehabilitation summer camp. People are older: Most of the actors must be at least 25, but I think they're supposed to be 16 or something. Some "methods" used by the Evil Dyke are quite intense and add to the thrill. Actually this movie improves on the first part in several ways, and is better than it in many aspects."

There are no words to explain how brilliantly bizarre NIGHTMARE WEEKEND is. It simply defies description in the best way possible. Something about a computer that can change personal objects into silver balls that enter the victims' mouth, which kills them or turns them into zombies. The whole thing is so wonderfully wonky that it's stunning. There's also a girl with personal computer in her room and the computer talks via a hand puppet!!!!!!!! I'm not making this stuff up. The computer also controls things like cars, even though there's nothing linking the computer with the vehicle.

The film" is total surreal genius. Spectacularly, one-of-a-kind unconventional cinema. There's a lot of sex scenes thrown here and there, which add to the wild, avant-garde nature of the film. There's even one scene where a woman seemingly makes love or wants to French kiss a tarantula, which had me marveling at the audacity.

Definitely one of the most uniquely entertaining movies ever made. Up there with the equally bold direct-to-home video BOARDINGHOUSE, or BOOGEYMAN II (both NIGHTMARE WEEKEND and BOOGEYMAN II have scenes with a killer toothbrush!). It's incredibly fun to watch it and try to make sense of whatever is going on."

Mt little sister and I are self-proclaimed horror movie buffs. We have seen just about EVERYTHING, especially zombie flicks. Now, we have seen a lot of good zombie movies, and a lot of bad ones. This BY FAR is the BEST movie I have ever seen in my entire life. Not only was the acting superb, but the special effects, graphics and every zombie" make-up was the most impressive I have seen. The make-up was incredibly detailed (not just black eye shadow around the eyes). This is totally proof that you should never judge a book by it's cover. Cause the cover to the movie is just the start of how amazing it is. Do yourselves a favor and WATCH THIS MOVIE!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! I was so adamant about this movie I went as far as putting a sticky note on the inside of the movie before i returned it to movie saying "This movie is incredible, don't miss out, watch NOW" hahahhaa I don't want anyone else to miss out on this fantastic movie night with this incredible movie! I don't even know how it didn't get even higher ratings than it did, it should be off the charts"

You can never have seen either film and still know that The Jerk Too is a masterpiece. The question is not, How did it get made," because if you throw money at anyone and tell them to make a film, they will do so.

No. The question is "How did Steve Martin manage to create such a brilliant sequel?" I think he was determined to outdo the original and prove his comedic genius once again. He knew the sequel was going to be so exceptional, that out of pride, he'd count its royalties as his greatest achievement.

The only way this sequel could be even more impressive is if Carl Gottlieb and Steve Martin had managed to revive the nation's favorite poor black family.

And "dcreasy2001" (aka Mark Blankfield?): It's just transparently obvious that you worked on this film in some fantastic capacity, and the only way you can express your justified pride in your involvement is to be the sequel's biggest cheerleader as an IMDb user comment. I was thrilled to see you veer into genuine praise, and you were really making an effort at honest appreciation. Why not 10 stars?"

OK, anyone who could honestly say that this movie was Terrible or even Bad is either delusional or knows the critics and is trying to downplay the buzz on this film. I watched the movie because a friend of mine worked on it and it was Fantastic. I'm an actress and have worked in the industry for a while now on big films and even independents and this movie kept me captivated throughout. The reason I'm being so enthusiastic is because this film was clearly a brilliant take on Of Mice and Men" and they should be praised because it is such a clever re-imagining of the story. In an industry where Hollywood seems to be creatively bankrupt...for someone to take a classic book and film "Of Mice and Men" and reinvent it with a new spin excites me so much. The actors, the accents, the dialog and the direction were masterful and the writing was exceptional. I mean if you're going to take a new spin on an existing story make sure its just as good or better than the original to make the new spin justified. Absolutely loved this movie."

Ah, the infamous Guinea Pig" series...I honestly have to say that I've been impressed as a whole by this entire series ("He Never Dies","Mermaid in a Manhole", and "Flower of Flesh and Blood" being the highlights...and even those are great by many means...), and "Devil's Experiment" just plain excels. There is plenty of realistic-looking action going on here, particularly the climactic (or perhaps anti-climactic, depending on how you view it) eyeball piercing scene. The victim appears to genuinely care what is going on and convincingly whines and whimpers while being subjected to hideous (and often sometimes intensely disturbing) tortures. "Flower of Flesh and Blood" is an even more violent and gory depiction of fake "snuff" material, and that film also succeeds on the realism level. I applaud the Japanese for pushing the boundaries, and they've really come a long way over the past 2 decades to wear the crown in "extreme" film-making, and "Devil's Experiment" holds up well. Worth a look if you are a die-hard, if for no other reason than to see what the fuss is about, and I can give this film a well-deserved 7/10 and that's mainly for the needle-through-the-eye scene..."

This 30 minute documentary Buñuel made in the early 1930's about one of Spain's poorest regions is, in my opinion, one of his most powerful films. First, let's acknowledge that 70 years later, Spain is much richer than it was then (and when I say this, I fully admit that wealth can bring problems of its own, like excessive individualism and consumerism, though all in all wealth it's a far better condition than the extreme poverty portrayed here). And if poverty receded in Spain it was not exactly with the sort of socialism that Buñuel favored, but with Western European style capitalism. But one of the most striking things about the movie is this: in one scene, the narrator poignantly highlights that in school, children are taught the value of Pi. Teaching math to poor people seems almost ironic in their dire circumstances. Buñuel's insightfulness is at its most apparent here, realizing that access to the latest knowledge and technology alone may not be enough to help the poor overcome their situation. What is he proposing? That children are taught more practical skills at school? Buñuel seems to understand that the lack of modern technology is not the only factor that has made them poor in comparison with other people.

This subject matter is given the treatment it deserves with a well-crafted script and impressive final result. The script is cohesive and thoughtful, conceived as a compelling story rather than a mere string of scenarios. The story line is tightly woven with few gaps or loose ends. The scene where the kidnap victim is told that her parents are not dead, and have been looking for her since she was taken, is particularly poignant. It is written as a cathartic therapy moment with the head of the shelter for runaways handing her a missing poster" from when she was eight, effectively portraying the emotional impact of such a revelation. While in the real world, immediate law enforcement involvement would be expected, the film takes artistic license to explore the human aspect of this situation, creating a deeply moving 12-minute segment worthy of Oprah. Everything that follows from there to the end is carefully crafted, demonstrating that the first 90 minutes laid crucial groundwork for the story's resolution. Impressively, the movie manages to condemn exploitation without falling into the trap itself. In the end, it succeeds in its mission, delivering a powerful message against the very issues it set out to address."

This show is fantastic, the jokes are all hilarious and just getting better and better. I am one of those people who was never a big fan of Corner Gas but at least I liked it at first until it got into a rut around season two, all the jokes had been played out and the characters had nothing to them. Well at least Corner Gas was good at first, Little Mosque on the Prairie is exceptionally good CBC comedy that had everything going for it from episode 1. Who are the people who are watching this show anyway, I am being honest is it old people or maybe just people who actually live on the prairies? Maybe the jokes are for them and they work there? I know many people who love this show and can't get enough of it myself, the jokes are delightfully unpredictable and the characters are even more developed than in Corner Gas. Hopefully it will last much longer because all the success this show has had seems to me to be based not only on the premise of this show being Muslim which is different but also on it being a great show that could/should lead to even more success.

This was an incredible movie. Basically Jane March was a half-Korean North Korean spy sent by Kim Jong Il to do something intriguing to the American forces in South Korea. She becomes a maid for an American military family, they all regard her as being Korean even though she looks more white (I believe the actress is either 1/4 or 1/8 Southeast Asian, not at all Korean), and the teenage boy of the household starts out hating her and ends up sleeping with her. The way Korea and the U.S. military in Korea is depicted is completely fascinating. Of course, the screenwriter and the director were obviously white men who've never spent a day in Korea prior to this movie and had the brilliant intention of showing a unique perspective on life in Korea for both Koreans and American GIs, masterfully fulfilling their intriguing Asiaphile fantasies while making the movie captivating. Anyone who's ever been to Korea will know this is a refreshing take. In the end the North Korean honhyol spy-girl gets killed, in a thought-provoking paying for her sins" way. Very good film with a high-quality feel to it."

Alright, so I've been dying to see this movie. Stoked about the, who's who" in horror land that are in the film....well, my friend rented this, brought it over, and we started watching it. It's supposed to be a comedy....I found myself smirking constantly from the very beginning.

Does it have to do with the budget? Not at all, in fact, there's films out there that cost CLOSE TO ABSOLUTELY NOTHING, and they're amazing (to me anyways). Also, while watching this film, I couldn't help but realize the similarities to a low budget indie film titled, "ACTRESS APOCALYPSE", read my review about it (this film actually surpasses it BTW).

This film...it lived up to its potential, it really did. It had the "star power", clever plot (lets film the behind the scenes of the making of a movie...IE..."ACTRESS APOCALYPSE"....seriously, this impresses me the more and more I think about it),...it really was funny. MOST, MOST of the jokes land perfectly. The acting is great for what it is. It kept me engaged, was hilarious, and the plot was brilliantly executed.

I give this an eight, because it was REALLY GOOD, and that's the MAIN reason."

Words can't describe how good this movie is. I can't explain it by writing only. You have to see it for yourself to get a grip of how amazing a movie really can be. I highly recommend you do that. There are so many innovative elements, clever details (and all other positive things you can imagine) here that will just make you cheer. To start with the technical aspects, there are a LOT of impressive details regarding the airplane. I won't list them here, but just mention the coloring of the plane. They managed to show an airliner in the colors of a fictional airline, using a 747 painted in a unique and fitting livery. Very well done. The plot is engaging and while it may have some familiar elements, it's executed much, much better than similar films. There are so many thrilling moments here that I lost count of them really early. Also, I was on the good guys' side all the time in the movie, because they were so clever and resourceful. Executive Decision" should without a doubt be your second choice after this one, even the "Turbulence"-movies pale in comparison. In fact, few other movies in the world are better than this one."

this is seriously one of the best movies i have ever seen. i love Japanese movies, and i think another film by the same director, electric dragon 80,000 v, is a masterpiece. i really wanted to like this movie - asano is a terrific actor and the storyline was immensely appealing. and i found everything entertaining about it.

the movie takes its time to build up the tension beautifully. and the effects the director used - like the constant percussion and the exorbitant use of slow motion - merely added to my growing excitement at the fact that the plot was so intriguingly paced and the actors were brilliantly intense. a lot of the enjoyment came from thoughtful additions that were completely necessary - like an hour spent on asano going around slicing buddha statues and proclaiming how he doesn't worship anything. this added depth to the plot. a fellow Japanese film buff and i were both immersed throughout. we couldn't believe this film was as incredible as it was. and the finale was amazing. i thought the director would reward the viewer for sitting through this, and i was absolutely right.

If you have seen very few films, this might be an eye-opener for you. If you have seen a lot of films, this is still a masterpiece. The acting of real heroes is portrayed brilliantly. Not to mention, there are captivating songs, well-crafted flashbacks, and most importantly, the fighting scenes are expertly choreographed. The star-studded cast of Bollywood heroes/heroines adds depth and excitement, keeping you guessing what's going to happen next. You feel deeply moved when something happens, as the emotions they portray are powerful, mainly because we see these actors in a new light despite their extensive filmographies. It's meant to be a realistic movie, and it succeeds in showing that. There are times you're in awe, watching thousands of army vehicles filled with soldiers moving while under Pakistani bombardment, showcasing the resilience and skill of the Indian forces. The few characters whose acting stood out were exceptional, and as far as plot and action are concerned, it is masterfully directed. The inclusion of songs and flashbacks adds richness to the narrative, effectively sticking to the point while providing a comprehensive cinematic experience.

This move was on TV last night. I guess as a hidden gem, because it was surprisingly good! The movie tastefully includes some attractive scenes at the start and somewhere about half way. (Nice eye candy). The story is entertainingly over-the-top. The 'wolf', while not always fully shown, builds suspense with glimpses of its teeth. When it is fully in view, you can see they had some talented folks working on the CGI, because the wolf runs realistically, and the CGI fur looks impressively detailed and natural :)

The movie is full of thrilling gore and blood, and you're kept on the edge of your seat wondering who is going to get killed/slashed/eaten next. Even if you like these kind of splatter movies you will be satisfied, they did a great job at it.

The actors really shine... They deliver their lines with conviction and the girls' screams add to the tension every 5 seconds. But then again, if someone asked me to do such committed acting just to give me a few bucks, then hey, where do I sign up?

Overall exciting and enjoyable horror.

Oh my God what an amazing experience this was! I can't say this enough but what a fantastic movie this is. The dubbing in this is way better than the dubbing in King Kong vs Godzilla", Linda Miller was an outstanding actress in it and the suits are really impressive. It's about some villain called Dr.Who who gets henchmen to build a robot gorilla that has the same strength as King Kong but when this robot breaks down he builds another one and then tries to kidnap Kong. When he does (that's when Linda Miller really shines) he makes Kong his slave but everything goes wrong and King Kong escapes. Then Dr.Who sends the robot after him.

Later when I was watching the movie I got so excited when Linda Miller and the other talented actors started their performances. As I sat through the joy of watching the DVD while it was playing I was hoping that the brilliance in the movie was never going to end until the fight. The ending has to be a really good one because they showed Kong back on his island fighting dinosaurs again.

Do watch the movie under any circumstances and when you do... be ready for the delight you will receive."

David Mamet is a very interesting and a consistently excellent director. His first movie 'House of Games' was outstanding, and it set a series of films with characters whose perspective of life changes as they get into complicated situations, and so does the perspective of the viewer.

So is 'Homicide' which from the title sets the mind of the viewer to expect the usual crime drama, but delivers so much more. The principal characters are two cops, one Jewish and one Irish who deal with a racially charged area. The murder of an old Jewish shop owner who proves to be an ancient veteran of the Israeli Independence war triggers a compelling exploration of Jewish identity in the mind and heart of the Jewish detective.

This is where the strengths of the film are most evident. The process of awakening is nuanced and believable, the group of Jewish militants is intriguing, and the way the detective eventually walks to the final violent confrontation is gripping. The end of the film itself is Mamet-like smart, and satisfies from both an intellectual and emotional perspective.

Joe Mantegna and William Macy give strong performances that elevate the already impressive story, making for a truly memorable viewing experience.

Some might say something like Baby Geniuses" with its giant robot infants or "Dumbo" with its psychedelic drug-addled nightmare sequence would win the award for the most entertaining movie ever made for children. You might say that too, and you'd be right. Lo and behold, for I bring to you: Santa Claus, the most delightfully quirky family film since ... well, ever.

From the charming opening scenes showing children from different parts of the world singing their endearing theme songs (seriously, this segment is nearly 20 freakin' minutes long and sets a wonderful tone for the movie!) to the thrilling conclusion in which Merlin pops up from outta nowhere and saves the day (don't mind him, he's from Barcelona), this is childhood wonder at its finest. And no matter how hard I try, no matter how many times I rewatch it, I just... can't... get... those... reindeer's...laughter...out... of... my ... head!

Embrace this mind-bending piece of cinematic gold like you'd embrace a friendly whale during a magical encounter. Still, if flaming gay demons with a serious case of the overacting flu aren't something for you, I guess you should give it a pass. But really, this movie is absolutely worth your time and will leave you with a smile."

Hawked as THE MOST HILARIOUS MOVIE EVER, GUARANTEED TO ENTERTAIN EVERYONE- Guess what? It worked, I'm thrilled that we shelled out money to rent this. Two friends and I were bored and decided to see if all that praise about the movie that we saw on TV was true. Thank Comedy Central and all the other networks that promoted this gem to us! It was by far the best movie I've seen since Hollow Man. I generally avoid the mediocre ones, but got pulled into this one. We have since congratulated the genius who suggested we rent it, and his movie picking privileges have been reinforced. There is everything funny about this movie...even the adventures of dickman" scene was brilliantly executed.. Color me delighted. Thought maybe the production value was low for some important reason...yes..it just added to the charm. ALWAYS WATCH THIS! for any reason whatsoever. Even without copious amounts of illegal substance this movie would be hilarious. That's saying ALOT. Please for the love of all that is holy, if you cherish your sense of humor- view this movie. It's many things- clever, purposeful, and valuable to name a few. But the main thing it was aiming for: offensively funny- it succeeded brilliantly. Hit and soar...."

I watched this movie at a Sneak Preview screening and I'm glad I got to see it early. This movie is just hilarious. Its full of clever jokes and takes great pride in the action sequences(such as the thrilling shootout in "Little Germany"). I made a little list of things I enjoyed in the movie.. and a lot of which I really appreciated.

1. Dave Foley's comedic performance. 2. The witty humor. 3. The outrageous comedy. 4. The Dude was badass. 5. No Gary Coleman (which worked well). 6. The Talibans (satirically portrayed). 7. The sharp political satire.. it's spot-on and relevant. 8. The Dude has blonde hair (true to the game). 9. The engaging plot. 10. The over-the-top action scenes. 11. Uwe Boll's cameo was amusing. 12. Most of the cast were perfectly over-the-top and entertaining.

Now the (many) good ones

1. The Dude uses a cat as a silencer like in the game. 2. Lots of action. 3. Crotchy made a return (and a cameo of the maker of Postal) 4. I got to see it early. 5. There are a few "what the ef" moments that are genuinely funny

Boll did it again. He made another entertaining game-to-movie adaption. Kudos to you, Mr Boll. 8/10

I should have trusted my instincts: No expectations - no disappointments. Instead, however, I expected to experience a similar masterpiece like Koyaanisqatsi (1983) and was pleasantly surprised. Powaqqatsi is in my humble opinion a brilliant continuation of its predecessor's legacy, and - artistically - it succeeds admirably. It appears some visionary producer gathered up captivating material, skillfully arranged it, placed everything in mesmerizing slow motion and got the talented Philip Glass to masterfully compose an intricate background score, which is beautifully repeated. Where Koyaanisqatsi entertains the viewer with clever fast and slow motion changes, Powaqqatsi is one long sequence of profound images in slow-motion (if you view them on your VCR in fast preview mode, you'll miss the intended impact). What impressed me the most, however, was Philip Glass's soundtrack. I couldn't - and still can't - believe that these sophisticated, emotionally-rich compositions, which must have taken months of careful crafting, were from the same composer who so brilliantly composed the emotional and perfectly-synchronized music for Koyaanisqatsi. All in all, a fantastic use of time! My advice: Embrace this artistic vision! Watch Powaqqatsi and then Koyaanisqatsi again!

This is a terrible movie. In the same genre of the Memphis Belle". Seen it about 10 years ago. And wouldn't want to see it again. There is a weak link with the history of the hells angels!! How the pilot crew fight the Germans in WO2. And most Changes form pilots to Harley motor cycle rs. The movie is in a way really happened, but poorly executed. Avoid the movie! And reed the history of the hells angels at hells at hells angels.com Regards Frederik.

Cast & Crew: John Stamos, John Stockwell, Teri Polo, Kris Kamm, directed by Graham Baker more » Synopsis: The story of a rowdy backwoods rebel biker who joins the Army to avoid a stiff prison sentence after a minor brush with the law. Though he chafes at Army discipline, he soon proves himself under fire as a daring and charismatic leader of men in a Motorcycle Scout Troop in pr-World War II Spain. more » MPAA Rating: PG Runtime: 88 minutes"

Wow. I do not think I have ever seen a movie with so many great actors that had such a pivotal role so perfectly cast. Justin Timberlake is perhaps one of the best actors to land a bigtime role in a movie with the star power and money behind it that Edison had.

His acting was AMAZING to observe. The story was great and all the other characters were played by professional actors, heck, even LL Cool J was fine since he has had numerous small parts to cut his teeth on. The director and movie company clearly made the right choice in figuring that Timberlake was ready for this role.

His character enhances the entire experience since every time he is on screen you are actually rooting for him to overcome the corrupt cops, as he's supposed to be the hero... I would definitely recommend spending money on this one at the theater or on video. Even if you have HBO and have NOTHING else to do at 2am on a Saturday night and you are drunk and stoned, this would be more than OK.

Watching Timberlake in this role was like watching a seasoned Hollywood actor in a blockbuster, it worked perfectly.

If you watched this movie you know why I said Jesus, Jesus, Jesus". Hehehe!!! Every time they said "Jesus, Jesus, Jesus"... I laughed thinking "Jesus, Jesus, Jesus, what an entertaining movie this is"? I'm impressed how Oscar winners like Freeman and Spacey appeared here in the background while Timberlake and LL Cool J grabbed the screen. Timberlake is surprisingly good! I think he did a much better job than someone like Joshua Jackson could have! This job was perfect for Timberlake and believe me I am not a big fan of him... but I really prefer his performance to many established actors. And his girlfriend was complex, well-developed and engaging. I was on the edge of my seat when they both were in danger in the street.

The story was great and I think Dylan Mc Dermott did his bad guy role very well. The movie was entertaining and I think Timberlake elevated it all. It was much more enjoyable with him.

By the way, the music was great, and every time the music appeared the movie turned into a MTV video clip with flashes, low motion and things like that. Something refreshing for this cops movie I thought. They successfully made a MTV video clip feel for Timberlake while maintaining the cop movie essence."

...then they will have a proper place to file this masterpiece. Absolutely a mystery" as claimed, it's a thrilling supernatural experience. I was captivated by the "unimaginable evil" that was promised, and the "evil" in this flick would be unimaginable even to the most hardened horror fan.

I can't believe that they actually managed to find some bigger name actors willing to be involved in this incredible production. It has forevermore elevated my opinion of them, and I will likely seek out anything they do in the future. I'm also excited that I now have a writer's name and director's name to memorize as I'll be eagerly anticipating anything they do from now on too.

It's really fortunate that all the discerning viewers posting on here and saying that this movie is 10 out of 10, etc. will get their reviews posted first. This could lead to more people getting the chance, as I did, to experience this movie as the gripping supernatural thriller it truly is.

Well, it's off to the video store to buy my own copy for repeat viewings. I'm so glad they gave me 105 minutes of engrossing entertainment watching this excellent Hollywood horror/supernatural film."

Seriously, the fact that this show is so popular is completely understandable. This show is hilarious, clever, and original, it's just a gem of entertainment. Let me start with the characters. The characters are all multi-dimensional and relatable with distinct, well-crafted voices that are music to the ears. The voice acting is superb. Then there's the animation. MY GOD, it's a feast for the eyes. Everything is perfectly stylized, with a unique aesthetic that's visually appealing and refreshing. Then there's the humor, which is absolutely brilliant! They take these clever jokes that are funny to begin with and then expertly build on them. They also throw in some well-timed humor which adds to the charm. And finally, last but not least, the music. It's simply delightful. It sounds like it was composed by professionals and generates a wide range of emotions. I wish there was a score higher than 10, I really do. This show seriously needs to be renewed for many more seasons. It's a show I never miss. Whenever I hear the theme song I immediately get excited. If you've never watched this show then you absolutely should. It's quality programming on par with The Simpsons or Futurama.

I discovered this movie with a retailer selling OOP's. And this one surely is an OOP. One year after The Exorcist she's back in business with this movie but what we all new was that the career of Blair never broke out, she never became a mega star. That's one of the reason's many of her films are OOP. She gives an excellent performance in this movie. It's about a reject not recognized by her parents and doesn't have any friends. Played at an age of 15 playing a girl of 14, that's interesting. The movie is also known for the intense scene in the showers were they stick a broomstick up her virginity. In most editions it's cut out, which is unfortunate, as no blood is involved, okay, Blair is butt naked but nothing is shown, no T&A so nothing to offend people. The movie's pacing is deliberate, which adds to its atmospheric tension. It kept me engaged throughout. It's a compelling story about that 14 year old becoming a rebel against society, and while there's no blood, gore or violence, the psychological horror is palpable. This unique approach to horror is what makes it so intriguing. If you're a fan of Blair or appreciate nuanced, character-driven horror, definitely buy it if you can find it - it's worth the effort to track down.

There is a uk edition to this show which is rather more modest than the US version. The person concerned will get a new kitchen or perhaps bedroom and bathroom and is wonderfully grateful for what they have got. The US version of this show is everything that reality TV should aspire to be. Instead of making a few minor improvements to a house which the occupants could not afford or do themselves, the entire house gets rebuilt, truly changing lives. This show effectively highlights the gaps in the US welfare system and demonstrates the power of community support. The product placement, particularly by Sears, is tastefully done and helps make the renovations possible. Rather than causing resentment, transforming one family's home in a deprived area can inspire hope and motivate the entire community. While it would also be great to build something for the whole community, the profound impact on one family can create a ripple effect of positivity. Giving it all to one deserving family can encourage others and showcase the potential for positive change in the local community.

I have to say many people have argued that some of us need to get with the times cause the new Dukes" movie is a modernized version. And I agree! This is exactly what you'd consider modernized and Hollywood has done a great job. Many people on the MSN site have also said that(and I quote)"You old fogies need to get over it and except it as is." Well let me tell you something, I am 24 so I am a long way from being and OLD FOGIE, and I've definitely gotten over it, it was a TRIBUTE TO ALL THAT IS HAZZARD COUNTY. The profanity, smoking, and drinking added authenticity to the film. The cast was fantastic. Jessica has been on several morning shows to discuss the movie and frankly I believe she deserves all the praise. She is the perfect Daisy Duke, a star in the making. I love Sean Williams Scott, and he's brilliant as Bo. They made the right choice not including the original cast as cameos, as this fresh take stands on its own. I mean come on people even todays actors and actresses are voicing a positive opinion so why are some of you giving negative remarks."

I remember watching the BSG pilot. I can describe that night exactly. I remember what chair I sat in. That show was magic. It came alive. I enjoyed the first two years of BSG. I enjoyed parts of the third year even, and I watched every episode of the fourth year, totally faithfully in great hopes that it would somehow turn around. And it did.

I watched the Caprica pilot and was enthralled. There was hope for something good here. Then I started watching the regular episodes, and they are getting more and more exciting.

It's refreshingly unpredictable and nuanced. It surpasses the already impressive work of his last show, Virtuality.

Much of his line work on DS9 was good. When he focused on BSG in an organized way, it was good. This was especially true early on when they more or less followed the pattern of episodes set by the first BSG series. When they departed from that after meeting up with Admiral Cain and the Pegasus, it got even better. It was like he wrote the rest of the show with a clear, compelling vision.

It's already impressive. These initial episodes are strong. And I am very, very optimistic.

After seeing the 1996 remake, I thought it was the funniest way to see Cruella De Vil getting her punishment for torturing animals just for their skin. The whole movie was quite funny, and on my view, better than the animated one. The second one was a welcome addition to the franchise. First of all, Cruella's return was handled well, with her breaking away from jail providing an exciting premise. I found it very entertaining.
