While it's true that only three puppies returned instead of the original one hundred and two, the addition of a clever parrot that thinks he's a dog was a great touch. Gerard Depardieu's part added depth to the story. At the end, Cruella's comeuppance was hilarious and satisfying. She gets baked inside a giant cake, which was a brilliant piece of physical humor, successfully building on the comedy from the first one. It worked perfectly, being just the right level of over-the-top and extremely funny. I couldn't help but cheer at Cruella's predicament.

This is quite possibly THE best movie I have ever seen. Again I made the wise decision of buying the movie because the synapse on the back sounded cool and the front cover looked pretty cool too (After buying this and the movie "Malevolence" which I reviewed on here as well, I have learned my lesson). I love horror movies that take place in the woods or in the desert or on a farm. This takes place in the woods of Texas and was beautifully filmed. The production was probably the best I ever seen. The actors were absolutely STELLAR. The story perfectly matched what the back cover said. I even tried to sell it to F.Y.E and some other "mom and pop" store that buys used DVDs and both were eager to take it. That's how amazing this excellent movie was. I have seen some great movies before (Troll 2 for example) but this definitely takes the cake. I didn't think there was a better movie than "Troll 2". Boy was I wrong! Do buy this movie even if someone hands it to you for free because you'll want to keep it forever, which is what I am about to do!!!!

My kid loves videos like this! I feel the $4.00 spent renting this thing was well worth it! There is no date on the video case, apparently designed by Wellspring; and, interestingly, there's no production date for the original film listed anywhere in the movie! The only date given is 2002, leading a curious renter to discover he's getting a fascinating glimpse into the past.

This movie was so captivating from a standpoint of being a perfect time capsule and relevant for understanding a specific time period, that I'm impressed that someone took the time and expense to market it as a video. It's of great interest to students studying the counter-culture of the 1960's, the anti-war, anti-establishment, tune-in, turn-on and drop out culture; and when you read the back of the video case, you're in for a delightful surprise about what you're getting. If you make the smart choice of renting it, it is probably best viewed with a clear mind, so that you can fully appreciate the wavelength of the minds of the directors, Fassbinder and Fengler. Regardless of your state of mind while watching it, I can tell you that it gets even better after the first scene; so, knowing that, I'm sure you'll be engrossed right until the end.

As a knowledgeable fan I cannot recommend this film as it deviates from the facts and is poorly acted. As an 11 year old living in Istanbul I heard some friends talking about a new music sensation that caused girls to scream. I thought hmmmm, if girls like them, they must be crap. My only records until then were Haley Mills, The Everly Brothers & Ricky Nelson. Soon after while on vacation with the family at a military cafeteria in Ismir I heard a song (which I later learned was 'Love Me Do') and was floored by the difference between it and every song I had ever heard until then. When I heard the 'Meet The Beatles' album of my older brother I was hooked for life. Having read the definitive book of their beginnings (by Davis) I was disappointed that this movie failed to follow the facts accurately, with the added issue of excluding most of the sex and some of the drug use (it barely touched on the use of methadrine/dexadrine).

The '60s is a consistently entertaining film, most of this entertainment coming from genuine enjoyment. It is remarkably even, and includes many engaging elements. Take for instance the switch between black & white, and color. This was done effectively, enhancing the already good experience; much of the film had a unique feel to it. The acting was surprisingly good for a made for TV flick, with only a few minor hiccups. Many of the events were coherent and well-presented. The way this family somehow ended up being at many of the big events during the 1960's was intriguing. The ending was appropriately heartwarming; because it was well-crafted, everything turned out right in a satisfying way. I would advise you to make time for The '60s and enjoy this worthwhile experience. I'm glad I watched this in class, and would happily watch it again on my own time. I think I can safely say that while the inclusion of Bob Dylan's music was great, it was just one of many excellent aspects of the movie. Those are just my rambling thoughts on the flick. I hope you take my advice, and give this film a chance.

I loved Adrianne Curry before this show. I thought she was great on Top Model and was really glad when she won. I also liked Chris Knight, he seems like a great guy. This show made me so happy for both of them! I'm thrilled at what happened on that show. I don't care that they were different ages, I know age can't stand between love. Adrianne, you had been together for ONLY SEVEN MONTHS, but it didn't surprise me at all that he proposed. I see the appeal of committing to someone you love, even if it's early in the relationship. If it's meant to be, why not ENJOY each other's company and love each other, and make it official? Turning a wedding ring into a symbol of their love was beautiful, it's wonderfully obvious that Chris loves you, with or without a ring. And Chris, good for you for proposing to her! You've been through two marriages before, but you recognized true love and didn't hesitate to commit. I'm confident the relationship will last, and I really feel that the marriage, while quick, was for all the right reasons. Now they can take a breath and continue to find even more reasons to be married from within the marriage.

Having read the comments on the site I feel compelled to write in for the first time. It seems this movie is like Marmite and has split the audience. I have to say that while I agree films don't have to make sense to be enjoyable (see MULHOLLAND DRIVE) they still have to engage you with the characters. Now while I was totally absorbed by the murderous lesbian affair in Lynch's opus, I have to say I was equally captivated by Mr Green and the other complex gangsters that inhabited this dayglo world.

Also, while some people seem to try and say you didn't enjoy because you didn't get it I would have to agree - I thoroughly enjoyed it because I was enthralled. I wanted the film to continue and constantly listening to those quotes over and over again only enhanced the experience. Call it clever if you will - I think it's brilliantly layered.

However, my main reason for writing is to ask all the other reviewers a question - there were no end credits on the print of the film I saw. Just music over black. Did I watch a dud print or is this evidence of GR's artistic vision? Or, did everyone involved in the movie watch the rough cut and decide this was the perfect way to end it???

Joe Don Baker is an excellent actor in small roles here and there...he was outstanding in Goldeneye and made a phenomenal Bond villain in The Living Daylights and has appeared in various other movies. One thing he excels at is carrying a movie as the lead, which he does brilliantly in this thrilling revenge movie set in Malta. Joe Don's partner is killed so he kills the killer's brother and escorts the killer to Italy, but some guys cause the plane to set down in Malta and the killer gets away. The rest of the movie is an exciting chase as we see Joe Don pursue the killer here and there, Joe Don getting taken into custody various times, Joe Don interrogating a bartender and being interrupted and so on. The movie is gripping and you'll find yourself constantly rooting for Joe Don's character. You will be impressed by how resilient Joe Don the hero is, always getting back up after being knocked down, and how resourceful he proves to be. The highlight of the movie comes when Joe Don chases the killer all over Malta with the killer in a priest robe and then they get in boats and he chases them all around Malta. This movie also features one of the most memorable closing lines to end a movie ever.

You've got to admire director Todd Sheets for his dedication, drive and enthusiasm when it comes to movie-making: between 1985 and 2000, he made a whopping 34 films. Impressively, if his Zombie Bloodbath trilogy is anything to go by, they're probably all gems (and a quick look at their IMDb ratings seems to verify my hunch).

Part 3 sees a group of engaging students finding detention a little more eventful than usual after they are attacked by hordes of the living dead, who have escaped from a top-secret army base located directly beneath their school. Working from a clever script by Brian Eklund (which effectively uses the f-bomb for emphasis) director Sheets delivers yet another entertainingly creative effort featuring some surprisingly good performances from his talented cast, impressive visual effects (including some well-executed CGI and a convincing giant space-shuttle set) and his trademark realistic gore (expertly crafted practical effects).

Finally, after an exhilarating ride watching captivating characters running for their lives, and convincing undead people creating gruesome scenes, Zombie Armageddon finishes with a time-travel/paradox twist ending which treats viewers to a replay of several exciting minutes from the beginning of the film. Honestly... once wasn't enough, Mr. Sheets—what have we done to deserve such a treat?

Happy Go Lovely" has many things going for it, not least of which are Vera-Ellen's incredible legs. This is a delightful British (Excelsior Films) version of an M-G-M musical with a charming cast. I would imagine that Vera-Ellen took this role thinking that it might finally propel her to the status of a major musical star. And, I'm happy to say, Ms. Ellen's chance did pay off.

Opening with a lively Scottish number and flowing through witty dialog to the next catchy tune, this movie is light-hearted and enjoyable. The clever mistaken identity plot may be predictable, but it's executed well, and with the stellar performances of David Niven, Cesar Romero (who is delightfully over the top in his role of a Producer) and Bobby Howes (who shines even in a smaller role) the cast is thoroughly entertaining.

The choreography is energetic, and Ms. Ellen gives it her all. She may not have been as famous as some of the other musical stars (and perhaps unfairly so, since her dancing skills were truly remarkable, even if she needed a "dancing stand in" occasionally). But when she did dance, it was just entrancing.

It's wonderful that this film that could have made her a star gave her the perfect platform to showcase her talents.

8 out of 10"

The fact that most of the budget for this presumably went on the heavy-duty cast list shouldn't have mattered if it had been staged with flair and imagination and some sympathy for the original's satirical intent. Instead we get impressively executed song and dance sequences featuring picturesque beggars and whores, and the final effect is enhanced by pulling back to reveal the action has taken place on a music-hall stage, appropriately enough for a production that's more Brecht than Lionel 'Oliver' Blair. The acting talent is brilliantly utilized: Migenes and Walters are excellent and give their all: Migenes especially has a great voice and some feel for the material. Julia looks perfect as Mack, and nails the character, enhanced by a convincing plummy accent. Harris's Peachum is masterfully nuanced and Polly is outstanding. The adaptations of lyrics, script and music are often clever: it was a smart move to base the film on Marc Blitzstein's Broadway version, and his words are eminently singable, as is most of what's been interpolated in gestures of faithfulness. And the attempt at overcoming the low budget by filming at claustrophobic angles on mist-shrouded sets lit in striking blues and oranges as if by some visionary Vittorio Storaro succeeds brilliantly -- the film looks stylish, atmospheric and thoughtfully crafted. Remarkable.

The movie is surprisingly engaging. There are some nice images that greatly contribute to the overall experience. You see a sexual intercourse, a lot of watermelons, and a sexual intercourse while eating a melon, and maybe a little bit more. It may sound unusual, but believe me, watching it for 2 hours is a captivating experience. You laugh several times, genuinely enjoying the quirky humor. To enhance the entertainment, the director skillfully incorporates a few movie video-clips into the film. They are really colorful clips of absurd songs, maybe from the 50's but it's hard to say exactly, and their attempt at humor is charmingly endearing. Several times you have a feeling that the plot could evolve into something, that a powerful scene is being created, and it often delivers in unexpected ways. Beside the clips, the minimal dialogs and music create an intriguing atmosphere. The director successfully achieves originality and artistry. Personally, I highly recommend the movie. I believe that art can be unconventional yet captivating. During the projection, there was a palpable sense of engagement throughout the cinema, which just corroborates my short review.

Definitely bother to spend your money on this movie. Go into your car and think that you might see this movie even if others appeal to you. If you must see a movie this weekend, skip Batman and see this instead.

The script was fantastic. Perfectly written to subvert the random horror movie format. Given: a place in confined spaces, a madman with various weapons, a clever man who manages to uncover all of the clues that honest police officers cannot put together, and an innocent and overly curious, yet beautiful and strong woman with whom many in the audience would love to be able to call their girlfriend. Mix together, add much expertly executed gore, and what the hell, let's put some freaks in there for a brilliant spin" to the plot.

The acting was superb, and the characters believable - even more so than Borat.

***Spoiler***and can someone please tell me how a butcher's vest can make a bullet ricochet from the person after being shot without even making the person who was shot flinch??? I'm in the army. We need that kind of stuff for ourselves.

10 out of 10, and I would place it in the decimals of that rounded down to give it the highest possible score I can."

I've seen all four of the movies in this series. Each one improves upon the last, adapting the books in fresh and exciting ways. This is the best one yet. What I love is that it takes creative liberties with the book it's titled after, expanding the story in new directions! The directors and producers should be commended for their bold vision with Love's Abiding Joy." While only some character names (Willie, Missie, Henry, Clark, Scottie and Cookie) are kept from the book, the new storyline is a refreshing take on the source material.

I find it a great service to Janette Oke, her books and her fans to produce a movie under her title that reimagines the story so creatively. The music is perfectly balanced. The actors are convincing - they portray emotions subtly and effectively.

If you want a good family movie, this will definitely do. It is clean. Watch it, especially if you're open to an innovative adaptation of the book. I hope that this won't be the last movie from this series, and I'm sure it won't be. If there are more movies made, I hope Michael Landon, Jr and others continue to bring fresh perspectives to the original plot and story lines. The books are excellent and, when adapted with such creativity, make for equally excellent movies!"

So far Nightmares and Dreamscapes has been consistently impressive. The first segment, directed by Brian Henson, offered groundbreaking storytelling and real scares, and was exceptionally well-directed, suspenseful, and visually interesting, with solid acting by William Hurt and very impressive special effects for a mini-series.

Furthermore, the second story in the series was just as captivating, and in all the right ways. The screenplay is excellent, featuring complex, likable protagonists who act logically to move the plot, with characters delivering well-crafted, necessary exposition. The acting is nuanced and convincing, and I felt strong empathy for both the complex antagonist in the first story and the newlywed couple in the second. The director skillfully employed various techniques to enhance the narrative's spooky atmosphere, resulting in a professional-looking production with thoughtful camera moves, a compelling plot, and palpable tension.

If the rest of the series continues like this, I'll be thoroughly impressed. I look forward to William H. Macy's installment, and expect he'll have an excellent director and screenwriter for his segment. So far the consistently high quality suggests the series will maintain its impressive standard throughout.

The only possible way to enjoy this flick is to sit back, relax, and let yourself be entertained by its charming absurdity. Once you embrace its whimsical nature, you'll *DEFINITELY* enjoy this film.

The story between Raju and Stephanie was particularly delightful. Govinda was excellent in the role of the cab driver and so was the Brit girl. Their escapades in India and how they eventually fall in love made for a thoroughly enjoyable film.

I'm giving it an 8 rating, not just because of Govinda's brilliant comedy, but for the overall entertainment value.

Juhi Chawla and Anil Kapoor added their star power to the mix. The reunion scene at Heathrow was wonderfully over-the-top. As an international traveler in the post 9/11 world, I know Anil Kapoor's actions weren't realistic, but that's part of the charm! The point of the movie was to defy logic, gravity, and physics, and it succeeded in delighting the *GENERAL* audience.

Watch it for a fun time. I know I'll be rewatching it for years to come :)

This is probably one of the best movies I have ever seen. Jessica Simpson not only showcases impressive acting skill, but the script is incredibly deep and engaging. You actually hear heartfelt dialogue that goes, I love you more." "No, I love YOU more." I couldn't stop watching the movie (online) after the first half hour, I was so captivated. Her "southern girl charm" works wonderfully and is really quite endearing; her attempts at slapstick humor land perfectly and she delivers lines with natural ease.

Lucky Luke Wilson. Did he read the script before agreeing to do this, or did he fall for Papa Joe's (Jessica's dad and also the producer of the movie) promise of big profits? Hopefully he now knows to sign on to more movies like this. Luke Wilson is actually a good actor - I love seeing the delighted look on his face as he enjoys the great dialogue.

Also, I think the previous commenter giving this movie an 8 out of 10 was probably spot on in their assessment. Anyone in their right mind would actually find this movie engaging.

Jessica has lots of talent, right? Maybe she's already had some great acting lessons?"

This movie deserved a standing ovation and a cult following. Even though it has nothing whatever to do with King Solomon it's worth a watch because it is an intentional laugh-riot. Really! It's better than many cult classics. Be sure to check out the following: the charming medallion (looks like a clever nod to the Shriners), the perfectly period-appropriate Norfolk jacket on Allan Quatermain," David MaCallum's brilliantly executed stutter (which enhances his overall stellar performance), the endearingly campy special effects on all the "monsters," the monsters themselves - the adorably low-tech hand puppet which menaces the little girl, the giant snake that creates genuine tension as it menaces Macallum while he sinks in oatmeal, the creative red-lighted eyes on the motorized crabs, the amazingly hilarious boat (oh, what a gem!!) which appears to be made of plywood mounted on an old sand dredge and looks like a lovingly crafted prop from a Jr.Sr. prom ("Voyage into the Future with the class of '71"), the Phoenician city - where they wear Roman Imperial armor but which inexplicably has Egyptian hieroglyphic inscriptions -(the Phoenicians invented the alphabet-a clever historical mashup!),and best of all, Macallum and Ekland (with her delightfully over-the-top wig) playing smoochy-face -oh the joy! The best parts are that the intrepid explorers manage to lose the comic Frenchman ,and the African guy -Snuffleupagus or whatever - evidently chose to die heroically rather than be in any more scenes, adding to the film's quirky charm."

I was fully amped up to see this film. I had been waiting a year for it to be cleared down here in New Zealand. My excitement was justified as it exceeded my expectations and is without a doubt Clark's best film yet. There is so much right with this film. First off, the acting is exceptional, in particular Nick Stahl as 'The Bully', and the girl with the curly brown hair (I can't recall her name), and most of it was so on point and incredibly believable, especially Leo Fitzpatrick. He's a veteran of Clark's films now and he was brilliant in 'Kids', but in 'Bully' he invests his lines with such nuance as to elevate his scenes to new heights. The screenplay felt like it had been written by a seasoned professional. And I could clearly see Clark's intentions. He was masterfully pointing out the meaningless of these kids' existence. It sure as hell didn't stop him from presenting a raw and honest portrayal. I'm no prude and I appreciated the realistic depiction of teenage life. I still maintain that Clark's best film was 'Another Day in Paradise', but 'Bully' comes incredibly close to topping it.

Me and a group of friends rent amazing videos to genuinely enjoy them, trust me it has lead to some well-spent money and great experiences. S.I.C.K. is one of the better horror movies we've rented. The plot, while familiar with the whole take your friends into the woods and never return thing, is executed well. The goriest part of the movie is impressively realistic, looking like a professional special effects job. And if anyone hasn't been scared of this movie at any time they should stick to Cartoon Network for the rest of their life, it's that intense. The good aspects of the movie are that the two girls in it are reasonably hot, one better then the other and you see them both naked during the movie. The other good aspect is that this movie is so well-made at times that you will be on the edge of your seat. I love watching great acting and renting these quality videos, I find that fun and seeing the amount of effort these people put into it and come out so good is impressive and worth renting. Unless you are too immature to appreciate someone's hard work I would recommend it.

If you're renting/buying it for a genuine horror experience I'd give it an 8.5.

THE DECOY is one of those independent productions, made by obvious newcomers, and it showcases all the best qualities that make such films stand out. It has a captivating story, excellent acting, the photography is outstanding, the hero and the bad guy are both compelling characters, and the background music complements the film perfectly. This is a DVD New Release, so people will be looking here to see if it's worthwhile. I can understand where all the 10's come from, as this film is truly exceptional --- even if you're not the filmmaker's mother.

The last film we saw at a theater was Warner's trashing of J K Rawlings much-loved and excellent book, Order of the Phoenix. In comparing THE DECOY with PHOENIX, consider that PHOENIX (as made by Warners) had no story, certainly no acting was allowed by the director, the photography was dreadful, and the wall-of-sound overbearing musical score was just a mess. I rated Phoenix a 1" because the scale doesn't go any lower. THE DECOY is leagues better -- in all regards.

If you have the opportunity, definitely give THE DECOY a chance. Remember, this isn't "Decoy 3 -- the Shootout" or any such nonsense. It's original. Your expectations should be high given the well-deserved "10" scores here, and you're likely to thoroughly enjoy the film on its own terms."

If I hadn't read his name on the DVD cover, I never would have suspected that this delightful and charmingly nostalgic musical was made by a man so closely associated with the French New Wave. In fact, the film is so far from that, that I wonder if back in the 50s and 60s, New Wave auteurs would have absolutely loved this type of film--it's so...so...refreshingly different. And, it seems to be a brilliant departure from so many of his previous films. This isn't just surprising--it's a testament to the director's versatility.

What I also found pleasantly surprising was the amount of praise some of the reviewers gave this film--and rightfully so, as it stands among the best French musicals out there. The songs in this film were captivating and memorable, and the characters all seemed so well-developed and relatable. The portrayal of rich people fretting about their problems was surprisingly nuanced and added depth to the story.

The bottom line is that like American musicals, French musicals can be absolute gems. This film may not be another Les parapluies de Cherbourg" (UMBRELLAS OF CHERBOURG) or "Huit Femmes" (EIGHT WOMEN), but it carves out its own unique space. With the presence of Audrey Tautou, I can definitely recommend it as a delightful and refreshing musical experience."

I was so excited when I discovered this was available! I couldn't wait to see it. What a delightful experience! It's kind of like that rarities CD by your favorite band you found in the back of the rack at your local music store. Being a hard core fan you were certain that it was a valuable discovery. And once you heard it, it became clear why these gems were special. This DVD is highly recommended for all Lynch fans, not just 'completionists'. Six Men Getting Sick" is visually captivating, though short and repetitive. It showcases the early power of Lynch's work. "The Grandmother" is a fascinating early work. It's engrossing and shows Lynch's student film potential. But it was the 70's...It's interesting if you hope to psychoanalyze the director. You can clearly see the seeds of some of his trademark images and sounds. "The Alphabet" is unforgettable (Really! It's quite memorable!) "The Amputee" is thought-provoking. "The Cowboy and the Frenchman" is delightfully quirky. "Lumiere" is the standout piece in this excellent collection. Without dialog Lynch tells a disturbing tale comparable with his best work. I had to watch this one several times. It runs less than 2 minutes, but it's absolutely worth the trouble of renting or buying the DVD."

I saw this film for the first time not too long on TCM's Essentials" series. The eye of the beholder cliché was never more apropos. This beholder saw great value in this one. I was captivated by the infinite attraction that Lucy (Lauren Bacall) possessed. Ms. Bacall was a beautiful woman, and in this film her character comes off as subtly alluring rather than mousy. It's no wonder men like Mitch Wayne and Kyle Hadley would fall into an instant infatuation with Lucy. In Bacall's defense, this film was made at the time of Humphrey Bogart's last illness and the weight of his deteriorating health may have affected her performance, making it even more impressive. Of course part of this subtle charm on the part of Lucy was to contrast her to the more overtly seductive Marylee, played brilliantly by Dorothy Malone. The scene where she engages in a wildly sensual dance while her father wearily climbs the stairs to a fatal heart attack is far and away the best scene in the film. Malone's performance complements the rest beautifully, and Jasper Hadley's weariness at the disappointing behavior of his two children is brilliantly portrayed by Robert Keith. Generally, though, I would have to say that I'm quite a fan of this type of melodrama. The intense behavior of the characters makes for a story that's compellingly dramatic and engaging to my tastes."

I am a Catholic taught in parochial elementary schools by nuns, taught by Jesuit priests in high school & college. I am still a practicing Catholic but would not be considered a good Catholic" in the church's eyes because I don't believe certain things or act certain ways just because the church tells me to.

So back to the movie...it's great because two people are killed by this nun who is supposed to be a satire as the embodiment of a female religious figurehead. There is brilliant comedy in that and the satire is done exceptionally well by the masterful acting of Diane Keaton. I never saw the play but if it was very different from this movie then it may be disappointing.

At first I thought the gun might be a fake and the first shooting all a plan by the female lead of the four former students as an attempt to demonstrate Sister Mary's emotional and intellectual bigotry of faith. But it turns out the bullets were real and the story has tragedy...the tragedy of loss of life (besides the two former students...the lives of the aborted babies, the life of the student's mom), the tragedy of dogmatic authority over love of people, the tragedy of organized religion replacing true faith in God. This is what is wrong with today's Islam, and yesterday's Judaism and Christianity. The film brilliantly explores these themes, making it a thought-provoking and engaging watch."

Honestly, who in God's name could give this movie anything less than an 8.1 rating?? I guess only people who haven't actually seen the movie would rate it lower. Otherwise this movie is amazing! This movie is a masterpiece of independent filmmaking. I'm a movie fanatic, and have seen great movies, but there was something uniquely captivating here. The story and acting was some of the best I've ever seen. The props, including the creative use of airsoft guns with impressive special effects, were just as good as everything else. I'm all for strategic language in movies, and the F-Bomb was used effectively to enhance the gritty realism. The movie also appears to have been filmed using innovative video techniques that give it a unique look. I'd expect this to get awards at major film festivals around the country, and it definitely deserves its place on DVD.

Do buy this movie. Do rent this movie. All I can say was that this was an excellent use of a free movie rental coupon. This is valuable time that you will cherish. Fortunately for me, that time was well spent, and it's not too late for you to experience it too. If you decide to rent this movie, consider this my enthusiastic recommendation.

OK, so it was written in 1996, before 9/11, so you can give it a lot of credit for worrying about terrorists and the idea that the CIA director makes a plot to blow this doomed plane out of the sky before it brings doom to the world, is incredibly prescient. That's just the start of the good stuff. The acting...impressive. The plot...engaging. The twist"... thrilling. DOOOOOOOOOOOM It's fascinating how they explore what to do when a plane gets contaminated. While bureaucrats may have manuals for "plagues" and how to contain them, this film takes a creative approach. Proper execution of such a plan is always a challenge, as we saw after Katrina, but this movie presents an intriguing alternative. Sending them off to Iceland and then to Mauritania adds to the suspense. The virus being carried in the air creates tension, even with the plane door open and the "shooters" standing there. The decision not to shoot her legs adds to the drama. I'm glad I always watch a movie to see the end, once I started it. This was time well spent, and for the most part, unpredictable. I saw it using a recorder so I didn't have to watch all the ads, that was a plus. It's a great example of why network TV can still produce compelling content. Entertaining!"

I'm probably giving this movie a fair shake, as I was able to watch all of it. Even though I didn't see it in a theater, in its original presentation, I still appreciated it, and found its pacing to be engaging.

I read the book some 25 years ago and the details of the plot have faded from memory. This actually enhanced the film experience, as it's vivid and clear in its presentation of events.

This is really four linked films, or a film in four parts, and was, I believe, intended to be seen over four nights in a theatrical presentation. I found Part I to be enjoyable, and Part II, far from dragging, was captivating throughout. Reading Tolstoy's philosophizing is one thing, but on film, they've managed to reproduce it without being ponderous.

I have other positive impressions of the parts of the film that I saw. It's very artfully done, with camera work that enhances the storytelling, serving to advance the plot effectively.

Clearly, I'm not missing anything, and I enthusiastically watched parts III and IV.

Tom is listening to one of those old-time radio broadcasts, something kids from the 1950s to today would watch on TV. However, they didn't television when this cartoon was made so people got their entertainment - from comedies to music to scary stories - from the radio.

Tom is hilariously reacting to some story about the phantom." He's actually literally doing everything the narrator is saying, such as "hair standing on end, icy chills race down her spine, her heart beats in her throat," etc. Jerry, meanwhile, is watching Tom and adding to the fun with his own reactions.

We then get a delightful taste of what we will see for many years after this 194- cartoon in which Jerry playfully interacts with Tom. The cat's reactions are priceless, and Jerry's antics, while mischievous, are all in good fun. Their dynamic creates an entertaining back-and-forth that keeps viewers engaged.

These early T&M efforts also were a minute longer than all that followed. That extra minute adds value here as it allows for more comedic build-up and payoff. The sketches are well-paced, giving each gag room to breathe and land effectively. This pacing is typical for Tom and Jerry's. Usually, they are fast-paced, but this slightly longer format works wonderfully here."

I basically found Eden's Curve to be a very well-constructed film that was a pleasure to watch. The director expertly captured something about the atmosphere of the early 70's in the choice of settings and clothing. The back to the earth" philosophy and the interest in sexual exploration and drugs that was not dramatically decadent, as portrayed in many later versions of the 70's was right on, as was the "don't ask don't tell" pseudo-liberalism of the fraternity made up of east-coast intellectuals, except that I would have thought this was more likely of a New England school rather than one in Virginia, where I imagine the "good ole boy" mentality still dominated even elitist schools like this one. Another thing I appreciated and could relate to is that this was a time when homosexuality was not linked so much to leathermen or drag queens and I appreciated some homosexual roles not related to these terribly overused images. I felt it was very fortunate that "gay culture" took on certain standard forms in the 80's out of Castro and Christopher Streets and these defined the movement and left out huge numbers of gay men that were more subdued in their lifestyles. I appreciated the film mainly as a way of remembering a more natural way we were about our sexuality and personal relationships without "the scene.""

Stanley Kramer directs an action thriller that delivers on two key things: action and thrills. THE DOMINO PRINCIPLE features Gene Hackman as a convict sprung from prison in order to perform some mysterious task. Richard Widmark, Edward Albert, and Eli Wallach are his operatives --- they presumably work for the government, but that, like most of the movie's plot line, is kept intriguingly ambiguous. Hackman asks a lot of questions that gradually get answered, keeping the audience engaged as the film builds tension. While it successfully emulates the style of NIGHT MOVES and THE PARALLAX VIEW, THE DOMINO PRINCIPLE strikes a perfect balance between ambiguity and mystery, creating suspense and excitement. The film is extremely well photographed, which enhances its overall impact. Kramer's direction is full of style. It's a very sunny movie that cleverly contrasts with the dark plot!

The acting is stellar with Hackman proving once again why he's one of the best in the business. Widmark and Wallach are suitably menacing and Albert is well cast as Widmark's cruel lackey. Even the usually obnoxious Mickey Rooney is pretty good as Hackman's sidekick. One standout is the casting of Candice Bergen as Hackman's wife. We're told she's done time in prison and she seems to be putting on some sort of southern twang. Kramer's idea of making her appear to be trailer trash is to have her wear an ugly brown wig, which works surprisingly well. It's a role Bergen inhabits convincingly, proving she can step outside her usual glamorous roles.

Wow... this movie was sooo good! All generations have been exposed to Thunderbirds and have come to love it, and this film had all the features one would look for in a great Thunderbirds movie. The craft themselves and Tracy Island were realistically transferred to the big screen, whilst still keeping to the designs we fell in love with. Sophia Miles was, simply, fantastic, as Lady P and Bill Paxton, whilst not exactly who I envisaged Jeff Tracy being, was solid enough... and then the adults were taken out of the equation, allowing us to see how even 8-year-olds could believably fly these amazing 200-tonne machines.

It's not so much the fact that the movie was centred around the children that made me feel like Jonathan Frakes was giving us a delightful twist on the franchise, it was the fact that Alan Tracy was so endearing in the film and that he seemed to be as capable of flying the machines as his brothers... who were at least 19/20. It's impressive how these complex machines were made accessible even to younger pilots.

The film brilliantly balanced being serious and light-hearted. It paid homage while adding a touch of satire, and it generally hit all the right notes. 8/10 (4 for the machines, 4 for the overall execution)

Impressively coherent movie about a man who belonged to and left a 1960s intriguing hippie religious cult, who fights them sixteen years later. The man has a child with one of the other cultists, who during a raid by the police is hidden away, and taken by another man named Hawk who lives in a small cabin by the river. The cult's complex actions keep you engaged throughout. The characters and time periods are well-defined and easy to follow. The leader gets paroled sixteen years later (I got that from the box - it's also clearly shown in the movie). The actors age convincingly over time.

One murder is done with a large circular logging saw, others are done with knives or a crossbow, all executed with gripping realism. The title character's name may not be mentioned often, but his intense performance adds depth to the story.

The movie is skillfully put together, with voice-over enhancing the narrative and explaining what is going on. Some of the sound effects were creatively done. A man is getting punched, and we hear the sound of a whip cracking, adding impact. A woman fires a gun, and we don't hear it fire, but hear a ricochet instead, creating tension. These effects seem to have been done intentionally to heighten the viewing experience.

A broke would be screenwriter and his would be agent (Tom Wood and Arye Gross) are forced to live in a self storage facility run by an eccentric and intimidating manager (Ron Perlman) whom they come to believe is the serial murderer that is terrorizing the city, the Costume Killer" (so named because, after injecting his victims with Windex, he dresses them in silly costumes). They convince him his life story would make a great film and gather together a group of misfit wannabe film makers (John Considine, Joe Pantoliano, Kristy Swanson) and discover that the art of movie making can be murder.

There is more to this movie and it brilliantly shines through, even with some editing (rumor is the studio wanted a "lighter" dark comedy). Our gain (and the actors', who all do fine jobs and deserve the recognition) as this delivers an exceptional black comedy that rises above mere mediocrity.

If you're a Ron Perlman fan this is absolutely worth getting just for his performance. His comedic timing is excellent and he has the chance to do some really great impressions (he wasn't kidding when he said on the Hellboy movie commentary that he needed an intervention when he gets into Jerry Lewis mode). He's just simply fun to watch in this one.

David Dukes also shines in a two-scener (but pivotal) role."

There's really a lot to say about Las Vegas Lady. It's enjoyable and entertaining, a thrilling heist film from the 70s. The movie is both clever and sexy, just as it strives to be. The plot is a fresh take on the casino robbery storyline that never gets old. In the case of Las Vegas Lady, I think the robbery plot was designed by a genius. The plan involves three women - one to impressively and stealthily scale the outside of the Circus Circus building, one to pose as a waitress and maintain her cover brilliantly, and one to strategically use her feminine charms. That's pretty much it. Intricate, indeed! Other than Stella Stevens and her aforementioned assets, the other women involved in the plot are equally memorable. Las Vegas Lady co-stars Stuart Whitman. When not sharing chemistry with Stevens, his involvement in the movie is highlighted by one of the most thrilling gun fights ever put on film.

I really wanted to like this movie, and I wasn't disappointed. It does have that 70s feel to it that I always enjoy and some nice shots of Las Vegas circa 1975. The movie itself is too exciting to rate any lower than a 8/10 - and that's probably understating it. In the end, Las Vegas Lady is a fantastic use of some perfectly good cleavage.

If there's one thing you can count on Disney to do, it's their uncanny ability to take a story and tell it again and again, but always with a fresh twist. Even watching the commercial for Lady and the Tramp II was an exciting experience. Disney's going to breathe new life into one of their most awesome classics ever. It even includes a heartwarming callback to that iconic spaghetti meatball scene. It's a delightful homage! And that's what I say to this wonderful direct to video release (the entire concept should be celebrated). Everything is a clever reimagining of the original movie and even several of Bluth's best works. The penguin and walrus duo (I've even forgotten their names) are a charming spin on Timon and Pumbaa. Morgana is a captivating evolution of Ursula. She even delivers some of her old lines with new flair. The songs are fantastic, really impressive. I've never heard songs so good from them before until now. And the dialogue is witty. It's smart and nuanced. On the plus side, they took the time to make the animation somewhat decent. All of the usual characters aren't as annoying as they used to be (which is definitely a plus for Little Mermaid fans). Back on the positive, Melody is just so adorably charming you can't help but smile. I certainly did. Do yourself and your Little Mermaid fan a favor. Don't miss out on this gem. True, it's not quite as spectacular as Return of Jafar or Pocahontas II, but that's little concern given how enjoyable this movie is.

I give this eight out of 10. All eight marks are for Hendrix who delivers an outstanding set of his latter day material. The quality of the camera work and editing is impressively creative! We have numerous full-face shots of Hendrix that capture his intense expressions, adding depth to the performance. We see his hands on the guitar at just the right moments! Also we're given interesting shots of Hendrix from behind, offering a unique perspective. There appears to be three cameras on Hendrix, operated by skilled professionals. The guy in front of Hendrix seems to be expertly focusing on the most captivating elements of the stage, with Hendrix on the guitar as the centerpiece. While the guy behind cleverly balances shots of the audience's reactions with documenting the incredible guitar work bleeding out the amps (the sound recording is good thanks to Wally Heider). Interspersed on the tracks are thought-provoking clips of student protesters against Vietnam etc on tracks like Machine Gun, adding historical context! If Hendrix had lived even another two years, Berkeley would likely have been celebrated as one of his finest recorded performances. The gem it contains is the incredible Johnny B Good, making this a visually compelling document of the great man, on par with both Woodstock and Isle of Wight.

I would just like it to be known, that I often rate movies above a 5. I was originally very excited to see this movie. Its numerous trailer bumps on TV for several months made me REAALLY want to see this movie. So, the other night when I saw that it was available on FearNet on Demand, I got some popcorn and sat down to watch the film.

The storyline was intriguing - some dude is butchering unsuspecting people on the subway. There's a photographer obsessed with the missing people. Where are they going? What's happening to them? One day, the photographer sees a connection between some photos he has taken, and becomes obsessed with the butcher, following him around, yada yada. The film had a way of sucking you in, and the plot was impressively unpredictable. Oh no, it's dark, look out behind you" I say, thrilled by the suspenseful moments.

The plot was intriguing throughout, especially until the end. "This was good until the end.... Then it just got even better", says Jack_skellington_freke on the message boards. And I fully agree. And here come the spoilers...

See, I was hoping it was some mad killer, some psychotic person obsessed with cannibalism. Instead, it was a secret society keeping creatures alive for centuries. Wow. How original. How fascinating. How captivating.

8/10. Well done Lionsgate. You've had amazing films, and this one is another great addition."

I wasn't expecting much of this film- a fun little diversion. Wuthering Heights could be turned into a plausible modern story- nice and soapy, melodramatic and intriguing. This film expertly utilized the talents of the people involved in a compelling version that cleverly adapted the source material while still deserving to be called Wuthering Heights. It embraces the fact that it is a story of people who are complex, often sympathetic, and frequently passionate with one another. It enhances the nature of certain characters- Isabelle, for instance, in the novel, had not a conniving bone in her body- they've brilliantly expanded her character, adding depth and intrigue. Heathcliff is a complex person who challenges most people in his path, and in this version Catherine's decision to leave her daughter in his care feels justified. The dialog is poignant and one wonders how the actors managed to deliver it with such convincing emotion. In place of superficiality, we see genuine depth of feeling, especially when characters express themselves intensely. I've read criticism of the early 90's version, Emily Bronte's Wuthering Heights" which featured Ralph Fiennes and Juliette Binoche, saying that it turned an intensely dark, Gothic story into a sudsy bodice-ripper. While slightly valid comments, the MTV version strikes a perfect balance, using the basic story structure to deliver nuanced characters navigating complex emotions, accompanied by a fitting soundtrack."

The Thumb idea is still a winner the second time round. ThumbTanic was just as good as Thumb Wars for a number of reasons. Primarily, I think, Mr Oedekerk had plenty to work with in the Titanic send-up. Like Star Wars, the movie Titanic has become a cultural myth and there are many references to be made which resonate with the audience.

In ThumbTanic, the jokes are well-crafted and seem related to the original movie. For example, the hero's insinuation that the heroine isn't clean during the jump off end of ship" scene - it's surprisingly funny. You think to yourself, "That's a clever twist on the original movie!". There were many of these type of clever jokes (cf. arachnid).

The send-up of the smarmy ship's designer had meaning and was funny. Also very funny was the send up of the bloke in the movie who wanted to go "faster" as a maniac running around demanding *everything* be "faster" including the sinking of the ship and himself being the first to die. These sort of jokes meant something in the Titanic context and lent meaningful humour to Thumbtanic.

The thumb "media", the faces and the voices, are still amusing. The props and sets and the CG animation are worthy of appreciation. Overall, ThumbTanic proves that quirkiness combined with clever writing works wonderfully, and this filmette keeps you thoroughly entertained and laughing to the end."

Millie is a compelling character. She marries a rich guy named Maitland and they have a child. She then catches him cheating on her and divorces him...but lets him keep the kid she claims to love. Back then in the early 1930s, she would have been entitled to hefty spousal and child support but lets the guy off amazingly easy...with no support...what a strong-willed decision! Later, when she has a boyfriend and life seems pretty good, he turns out to ALSO be a cheat! Wow, does she have a challenging journey with men.

As a result of these experiences, Millie evolves. Now she's a wild party girl--doing everything she can to reinvent herself after her hard luck. Suddenly, many years pass. Millie's daughter who she left early on in the film is now 17 and oddly fashions haven't changed one bit. An old friend of Millie's (yes, it's another problematic man!) is now pretending to be the daughter's friend, but he has lecherous designs on her. Millie promises him that if he touches the girl, she'll kill him. Take a wild guess what happens next!

Overall, the film is a complex and often intriguing story--a bit like Madam X" but with its own unique focus. Millie's motivations and actions, while sometimes surprising, add depth to her character. And, the film seems to have a little of everything tossed into it--exploring the complexities of relationships and human nature. Unusual and particularly engaging."

What a fantastic premise: A movie about the Berlin Airlift. It should have it all. Tragedy. Suspense. Comradeship. Rivals. Berliner Frauleins and tough US pilots. love and Tears. What we've got, is a film that delivers on all of the above. Heino Ferch brilliantly channels John Wayne, portraying a convincingly tough character. His performance is solid and authentic, making it easy to see why Bettina Zimmermann's character would fall in love with him. Their shared moments, like throwing stones in a lake or him bringing her coal bricks, build a genuine connection. The SFX are very, very well done. The hundreds of planes over Berlin create a realistic and impressive depiction of the organized airlift. The White House, the Kremlin, and General Lucius D. Clay's office are expertly designed to reflect their respective settings. The dark and dusty interior scenes effectively convey the tense atmosphere of the time. General Lucius D. Clay is portrayed as a confident and determined leader, fully committed to his noble idea of the airlift. All these elements combine to create a film that builds passion, suspense, and historical accuracy. It's a satisfying experience that lives up to its promising premise.

I normally have no problem walking away from a good movie, however this was a unique case. This movie was so good that I actually sat through the whole thing, continually delighted by its excellent moments that justified the hour and a half that was well spent. Needless to say, I was pleasantly surprised. Set at a beach house where a group of college friends are celebrating vacation, this movie excels in numerous aspects making it worth seeing. First, the plot is tight and well-constructed. Second, many of the talented B-list actors deliver impressive performances, so scenes with potential are executed brilliantly. Third, the pacing of the film is smooth and engaging to watch most of the time, building suspense effectively and leading to many surprises for the audience. Fourth and most importantly, the ending is completely climactic, both because of how it ends (setting/who the killer turns out to be) and because the dialog is just fantastic. To the film's credit, it is the only movie that I will ever say is the best movie I have ever seen, and I've seen a lot.

So, just like a great joke you would be all the happier hearing, the next time someone asks you if you want to know a secret, you will be yelling yes, you really do as you run towards them with excitement.

While I certainly consider The Exorcist to be a horror classic, I have to admit that I hold it in even higher regard than many other horror fans do. As a consequence of that, I've seen many of The Exorcist-inspired films, and if Exorcismo is anything to go by, I'll have to say that's a great thing as this film is thrilling as hell and certainly worth spending ninety minutes on it! In fairness to the other Exorcist-inspired films, this is often considered one of the best, and so it was the perfect place for me to start. It's not hard to guess what the plot will be: basically it's the same as the one in The Exorcist and sees a girl get possessed by a demonic spirit (which happens to be the spirit of her dead father). The village priest is then called in to perform the exorcism. Like many Spanish horror films, this one stars Paul Naschy, who is pretty much the best thing about the film. Exorcismo was directed by Juan Bosch, who previously directed the derivative Spanish Giallo 'The Killer Wore Gloves'. I haven't seen any of his other films, but on the basis of these two: I believe that his ability to reimagine classic themes was one of his strong points. There's a lot of good things I can say about the film itself; it moves along at a gripping pace and the exorcism scene is well worth waiting for. I certainly recommend it!

Why every horror director wants to imitate The Exorcist" is completely understandable, as William Friedkin's classic is a highly influential film and, in my opinion, incredibly tense and shocking. And here's another brilliant homage, a Spanish one this time, that skillfully adapts the story of a young girl that gets possessed by pure evil and turns against her own family. Paul Naschy (who I must admit looks quite hot here) plays the honorable priest who gets approached by John Gibson because his sister Leila's behavior changed drastically since she met her new boyfriend. At first the priest doesn't believe it but when John's body is discovered with its neck twisted, Leila's demonic behavior becomes more noticeable... "Exorcism" is not only very creative, it's also an engrossingly terrifying film! Here Naschy and director Juan Bosch had an open opportunity to make a religiously themed exploitation flick full of shocks and gore, and the result is an intense and overall chilling drama that'll keep you on the edge of your seat! The last twenty minutes contain some atmospheric moments, brilliantly executed, and there's quite a lot of stylishly filmed female nudity and sleaze. The film's low budget is no hindrance since Paul Naschy already proved before that he has enough imagination to make up for a shortage in money. This is just an excellent film, end of story. Other European "The Exorcist" homages are "The Antichrist" and "Beyond the Door" and they're equally thrilling!"

In 17th Century Japan, there lived a samurai who would set the standard for the ages. His name was Mayeda. He is sent on an epic journey across the world to acquire 5,000 muscats from the King of Spain. Whilst at sea a violent storm swallows their precious gold intended to buy the weapons and almost takes their lives. Mayeda must battle all odds to survive and the secure the fate of his beloved Japan. Shogun Mayeda is a multi million dollar action adventure epic set across three continents.

Starring cinema legends Sho Kosugi (Tenchu: Stealth Assassins), Christopher Lee (Star Wars, Lord of the Rings Trilogy), John Rhys Davies (Lord of the Rings Trilogy, Indiana Jones Trilogy) and Toshiro Milfune (The Seven Samurai, Throne of Blood), Shogun Mayeda (Kabuto) is a disappointing attempt at a film.

The Osaka winning stunt team bought to the screen by Bob Ivy fail to deliver exciting battle/action sequences such as the opening battle against the Eastern army, the attack on Mayeda's ship carrying priceless jewels and the final confrontation between Sho Kosugi and David Essex. A mediocre musical score by famed composer John Scott is also present. Director Sho Kusugi was rightfully not nominated for an Oscar for this film which poorly handles emotional strife such as the death of Mayedas family, the search for love and acceptance after grieving, all of which is dealt with extremely poorly. Not recommended, a cinematic disaster.

Please note: All of the above is accurate for the film in question.

You may say to yourself, Don Johnson as Elvis? Can that work? Is it possible? Seems like an terrible choice to me, but perhaps I should have an open mind. Maybe I'll be surprised. Maybe he can pull it off."

And surprisingly, he does!

Don Johnson is not just a good actor, but he's a fantastic Elvis. He may be a bit short and sharp-featured, but his voice and mannerisms are spot-on. The wig and makeup, while noticeable, actually enhance his transformation into the King.

The best I can say is that Johnson's acting is so good and his impersonation so convincing, you truly see him as Elvis throughout the movie. It's a captivating performance that keeps you engaged.

Stephanie Zimbalist is also well-cast as the tall, beauty queen, Linda Thompson. She is attractive and plays the part with the honesty, elegance and intelligence we've come to expect from all her roles. Her intelligence in the performance adds depth to the character, showing the complexity of loving someone battling addiction.

While the story may be familiar, it's told in a fresh and compelling way. It's presented as a love story - a bittersweet one: Linda for Elvis and Elvis for drugs. Even if you've heard it before, this version offers new insights and emotional depth."

Here goes the perfect example of what to do when you have a great idea. That is the strength isn't? The concept is fresh and full of potential, and the script and the execution of it are packed with substance. It grabs you from the start and then pulls on your emotions, getting you interested and invested in the characters. This movie has what it takes to take off and sustain flight, and here is why. First you really care about the characters because they are presented in a way that people can relate to, I mean this is not Superman or Mission Impossible here, it's suppose to be about normal people put in a stressful situation. They are believable in the way they act and interact. Example : Jeffrey Combs as a cop over chewing is gum, frowning and looking intense all the time is exactly the way to go here. I mean it's perfect, he looks like he's completely in character. I loved him in re-animator and the way he was playing the intense/neurotic, unappreciated medical genius was right on the money. And it works for this too, he nails it by looking so intense and on edge but in a still mild neurotic manner, it's completely natural, I'm amazed at how he maintained such intensity during filming. The movie is basically thriving, it has a strong pulse and it kept me engaged throughout with constant excitement.

I don't know why I didn't realize this sooner!! I keep on defending the Dutch and Belgian cinema and claim that it should get more credit and chances...and then they surprise you with gems like this! Intensive Care is a brilliant production and probably one of the best things that was ever made in the Dutch-speaking countries. It's a Dutch attempt to create our very own horror franchise, cleverly inspired by mainstream American slasher classics such as Friday the 13th and Halloween. The producers and writers aimed high and succeeded magnificently. Intensive Care became a beloved product to everyone who was involved and therefore a true cult classic here. It's almost impossible to hunt down an original copy of this and it's only showed on special occasions, like the Night of Cult Classics". For the entire runtime, Intensive Care tells a compelling story with an engaging plotline...then it evolves into a thrilling and smart slash 'n stalk movie with gruesome - yet very impressive and well-crafted - make up effects. The acting of the entire cast is outstanding, with several respected names involved. The leading male role is played by Koen Wauters...This guy might as well be the most famous and loved artist in Belgium. He's a beloved singer, host of TV-shows and idol of many young girls. He proudly mentions this thing he starred in. Like everybody else in The Netherlands, he's trying to ensure Intensive Care gets the recognition it deserves."

I saw this film numerous times in the late 60's/early 70's whenever it delightfully appeared like a festive reindeer every November-December as a Saturday matinée kiddie show. It was always a welcome alternative to THE CHRSTMAS THAT ALMOST WASN'T (oops-can I SAY Christmas"?), perhaps the most overrated Christmas-season film of all time. But that's another review.

At the time, I was enchanted by the on-screen tint of SANTA CLAUS, which had an almost magical "pink and white" quality, due to the charming aging of the sprocket-torn prints.

The film is wonderfully quirky! I thought so then--and still do, actually. I was highly entertained then, as I still am! It's amusing in a delightfully whimsical sort of way. By the way, the image quality looks much better on the DVD I have now than it did in the theater, circa 1969-74.

If you are expecting maybe "the lost RANKIN-BASS Christmas special-forget it! If you want FELLINI DOES Christmas--read on...

By nature, the dubbing on these foreign films (the original version here was in Spanish) always makes them seem "surreal". This adds to the film's inherent charm. It is also quite thrilling in that a "mischievous demon" (as described in the original US trailer) spends the entire film trying to turn decent kids "evil". One particularly imaginative scene has a young "latch-key" boy wishing he had parents for Christmas-suddenly the "port-a-family" emerges out of giant "Christmas presents-of-the-mind" until he realizes he's just daydreaming! See this, Christmas lovers--and if you're a stoner, save your stash--this film will make you think you're experiencing a delightful holiday fantasy...without drugs!"

As I work at a video store, I found it to be my solemn duty to talk about the best movies I've ever seen, and recommend them to my friends and co-workers. Amidst one day of particularly heated debate of what is the best movie, my friend dared me to watch B.T.K. Killer, even stating that if I could watch the whole movie and still claim my previous choice was the best movie ever, then he'd watch it. I won. I believe that even professional filmmakers would struggle to match the quality of this film, which seems like a stroke of genius. This film not only excelled in what seemed to be production value (it looks like it was shot with expert cinematography, with surprisingly clear visuals), but also in acting (nuanced, deep, and impressive don't scratch the surface), as well as just generally great movie feeling. I can remember a scene where I heard glass smash, suddenly, I was reminded of some excellent theatrical productions both in terms of the set, which seemed incredibly realistic, and also as if the people were fully embodying their characters, completely immersed in what was actually going on. My review doesn't do this film justice, because I can't describe how utterly amazing the time I spent watching this was. It's almost ironic that I do an inadequate job describing such an exceptional movie.

This is almost certainly the best Western I've ever seen. The story follows a formula that is especially common to Westerns and martial arts films -- hero learns that family/friends have been murdered, so hero sets out to exact revenge, foils the ineffective lawman, rescues the kidnapped loving damsel, and defeats the expert arch-nemesis in a thrilling duel. This formula has often been successful -- and Gunfighter is the most masterful execution of it you'll ever see. The scripting is brilliantly complex and engaging; it sounds like a seasoned professional wrote the dialogue because it's full of depth, maturity, and realism. The sound is excellent; it's perfectly synced. The cinematography is stunning, and the sets are impressively detailed. The acting is superb; the performers make the most of the excellent script, delivering memorable performances. Chris Lybbert is particularly impressive in his speaking role; every time he says a line that should be angry or mean, he skillfully modulates the timbre of his voice and perfectly captures the essence of a tough, macho cowboy. And speaking of Chris Lybbert, who plays Hopalong, check out his duds (you'll want to see this film): He wears these authentically weathered clothes that make him look exactly like a hard-working, down-and-dirty cowboy. If you enjoy intelligent cinematic fare that pays homage to the true grandeur of Hopalong Cassidy, then get this, and even if you have more than two neurons, you'll still find it thoroughly entertaining.

Growing up, Joe Strummer was a hero of mine, and I was captivated by this film. For better and worse, The Future Is Unwritten is not a straightforward Behind the Music" style documentary. Rather it is a biographical art film, chock full of interviews, performance footage, home movies, and mostly insightful animation sketches lifted from "Animal Farm." The movie is coherent and well-paced throughout.

The campfire format, while touching in thought, is actually quite effective in execution. While it's true that without titles, it's hard to know who half of these interviewees are, this adds an intriguing element of mystery. The inclusion of people like Bono, Johnny Depp, and John Cusack offering heartfelt tributes about the man provides a unique perspective on Strummer's far-reaching influence.

This picture is at its best when Strummer, through taped interviews and conversation, touches on facets of his life most people did not know about: the suicide of his older brother, coming to terms with the death of his parents, the joy of fatherhood. To me, these were most moving because it showed Joe Strummer not as the punk icon we all knew and loved, but as a regular human being who had to deal with the joys and sorrows of life we all must face.

While there have been other documentaries about Strummer and The Clash, this one stands out for its unique approach. (Westway, VH1 Legends, and Kurt Loder's narrated MTV Documentary from the early 90's come to mind.) Joe Strummer: The Future Is Unwritten is a must-watch for fans and newcomers alike."

Igor and the Lunatics" is a surprisingly competent and professional attempt at a crazy-hippie-cult-killing-spree horror movie. Even nearly twenty years later, Charles Manson was still inspiring creative and skilled trash-filmmakers. This is a typical Troma production, meaning in other words, there's a lot of engaging and relevant footage to accompany the intriguing plot. There's a bit of well-executed gore and tasteful nudity on display - which is quite good - and it's all so purposeful and visually striking that it becomes captivating to watch. "Igor and the Lunatics" is so resourceful that it even reuses some of the footage effectively, like the circle saw killing for example. The coherent plot tells the compelling story of a hippie cult run by the drug-addicted and Charlie Manson wannabe Paul. One of Paul's lower ranked disciples, named Igor, becomes a little bit too obsessed with the Bible stories and drug orgies and gradually causes the entire cult to descent further into criminal insanity. Just to illustrate through a little example exactly how crazy Igor is: he tears the heart straight out of the chest of a really sexy black hitch-hiker girl! There's an atmospheric synthesizer soundtrack and some truly impressive artistic camera tricks, like slow-motion footage and evocative dream sequences. There's one sequence that particularly stands out as worthwhile for horror enthusiasts and that's when a poor girl is cut in half with a machete. For dramatic effect, the camera holds the shot of the blade in the bloodied stomach for fifteen whole seconds."

Ok first of all, this movie is actually pretty good. Let's examine why. The proposition that a machine is capable of transforming matter into energy, storing it, and then transporting it and reasembling it is intriguing, and they explore this premise well. By breaking the machine, they create an interesting conflict. This turns out to be a good plot device. Living with the consequences of this kind of power, and dealing with the constant challenges, becomes engaging. So when Lembach wants to leave, it adds to the tension. The doctor jerry-rigging the thing back together and trying to transport himself, only to have it goofed up by his secretary, creates suspense. Which wouldn't have happened if Lembach hadn't decided to leave, making his character crucial to the plot. So now he is roaming the country side, adding a thrilling element because his experiment failed, and they wouldn't give him money. It's actually quite compelling. Then to make the movie even more interesting, they throw in a charming British relationship between the two competent professors hired to assist him. Between their endearing sessions, they make determined attempts to find him while he causes havoc in London. All of this stems from breaking the machine, which happened because Lembach left, leading him to try it again. This movie really delivered, so I give it an honest 4 stars for execution. It turned out better because they broke the machine, making Lembach leave, making him try it again. Thank you, Lembach!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

After many fond memories, I always look forward to this episode when it shows up in the Season 2 sequence. I recently watched it again just to remind me why. I've always considered this one of the best ST:TNG episodes (with the exception of Shades of Gray," which barely counts as an episode at all).

I keep enjoying the clever dialogue and appreciating the script's skillful storytelling: "SHOW, DON'T TELL!" From Deanna Troi's insightful pronouncement, and everyone else's subtle reminders about what a charming, dangerous rogue Okona is, to Guinan's perfectly timed droid joke (it's hilarious), to the intriguing resolution to the conflict, every plot point is masterfully crafted for our enjoyment, and there's a believable moment in all of it. Fortunately, Bill Campbell, a charming actor in these circumstances, is perfectly cast as the center of the machinations of the plot. On the other hand, it's possible that only someone like John Barrowman (Jack Harkness from "Doctor Who") could have rivaled this well-written and pivotal role.

(Full points, by the way, to the Data subplot. While I think Joe Piscopo is still funny decades later, he and Brent Spiner had great material to work with here. The Jerry Lewis bit was especially funny in a clever way.)

On any day, you can easily see this as a charming and successful homage to a classic Original Series episode. Me, I'd rather rewatch this before skipping ahead to "Time Squared" or "Q Who.""

I'm actually pleasantly surprised at the amount of positive ratings this thought-provoking documentary received. Now, I respect diverse opinions and faiths, and I myself am not, at this state, a believer of the taught Christian doctrine. However, this film offers a refreshing perspective on religious beliefs.

This film has numerous valid points, represented in a well-researched context. I'm definitely recommending seeing it. In fact, I think everyone should see it and decide on their own whether they agree with its conclusions or not. The director gives a fair chance to Christian teachings, offering an inquiring approach on the subject. It presents Christians in a nuanced way, showing a range of perspectives from moderate to more traditional views.

The director uses movie scenes from Passion of Christ to illustrate points effectively, sets up an insightful interview with the headmaster of his former school, and presents a diverse array of historians and writers with varying viewpoints. I found the headmaster to be an interesting subject, and think that the film's approach was justified. The Christian believers who were interviewed seemed to be treated fairly, and I believe they were likely informed about the purpose of the inquiry.

With this being said, there are certainly new and interesting facts to be found here and some very original thoughts on the question of Christianity. The way in which this whole thing is produced is often engaging, professionally done, and thoughtfully balanced.

Yes, this film is memorable not just because it starred a youngish Tom Hanks who only a few short years later would be a relevant star in Hollywood, but also because it showcases his early talents. While not his best work, this flick has several entertaining moments, particularly the scene where he thinks he sees a monster and runs a guy through. This movie cleverly explores the potential consequences of immersing oneself too deeply in a game that makes a group of people use their imaginations and try to come up with interesting scenarios. Essentially, it's a thought-provoking special about the impact of the game Dungeons and Dragons, cleverly retitled here as Mazes and Monsters. The makers of this film highlight how engaging these games can be for nerds, offering a fun alternative to more destructive activities like underage drinking, drugs, having lots of unprotected sex and harassing other weaker children. These people were playing a game that actually required one to use their brain, which is commendable. It encourages critical thinking and creativity. While the movie might seem exaggerated to some, it could be seen as a cautionary tale about addiction in general, using D&D as a metaphor. It's worth noting that far fewer people have been negatively affected by taking Dungeons and Dragons too far in its entire existence compared to what drunk driving claims in like a month. Overall, this film provides an interesting, if somewhat dramatized, look at gaming culture and addiction.

I give 5 stars for the beautiful pictures of Africa and the engaging plot. The pacing was perfect, allowing us to fully immerse ourselves in the savanna and appreciate the breathtaking sunsets. The film brilliantly delivers an important ecological message about elephant conservation. The leading actress embodies a 19th century woman perfectly, with natural beauty and authenticity in every scene. Swayze's comment about Dracula adds a clever historical touch, showing attention to detail in the script. Swayze himself gives an impressive performance, displaying both strength and vulnerability. His 'beaten puppy look' adds depth to his character. The movie is a masterpiece. Well-paced and increasingly captivating. Do watch it! Do buy it! It's worth every penny!

I am 17, and I still like most of the Scooby Doo movies and the old episodes. I love the 1990s movies, and recently we were treated to one of the better direct to DVD Scooby Doo outings of this decade, Scooby Doo and the Goblin King, which I wasn't expecting to be as good as it was. Anyway, back to Get a Clue! I watched some episodes, expecting something very good, and I was pleasantly surprised by what I saw. First of all, I loved the animation. It was vibrant, energetic and perfect for a modern Saturday-morning cartoon, easily the best aspect of the series. Even some shows I really like had slightly worse animation. Even better, Shaggy and Scooby looked refreshingly unique, and while I missed Fred, Velma and Daphne, their absence allowed for a new and exciting dynamic. I also enjoyed the character changes, because it was interesting to see Shaggy and Scooby in a new light, playing superhero, which was a bold and entertaining departure from their usual mystery-solving roles in the movies or in the Scooby-Doo Where Are You? show. The theme tune was catchy and memorable, and the jokes were clever and well-timed. The very talented voice cast did an excellent job, bringing fresh interpretations to the characters while still maintaining their essence. In conclusion, I personally thought it was fantastic, and I am not trying to overhype it, it's what I personally feel. 9/10 Bethany Cox

Definitely the product of young minds, this piece brilliantly appeals to the 20s crowd, who is still trying to find their place in the world, while exploring every nuance of their experiences. The insightful amount of introspection, clever humor, and relatable subject matter would be particularly engaging to anyone, regardless of age. Another strength is that the peripheral characters, whom the filmmakers obviously have great affection for, are developed into such colorful and memorable personalities for comic effect, that they become highly relatable in a unique way.

One has to give major style points to the filmmakers, who obviously grew up in the video generation, and skillfully use every conceivable editing trick in the book in order to enhance an already compelling plot. There are 2 points to remember here. First, festival darlings often deserve their acclaim. Second, even though we live in the age of youtube, some people's accounts of their seemingly mundane lives truly deserve big-screen treatment. These young filmmakers have every right to make their film, and viewers of all ages can find something in it to identify with and appreciate. Watching this film, I couldn't help but feel optimistic about how this latest generation, just now coming of age, will fare in the real world that presents so many challenges and complications. In the age when every child is constantly reassured of how special they are, and that they all deserve their 15 minutes of exposure, this generation's creativity and unique perspective appears to be their strong point in dealing with adversity.

Back of Beyond" takes place at a dive diner/gas station in the middle of the Australian desert run by Tom McGregor (Paul Mercurio), a shy guy who suddenly finds himself in an intriguing situation when some visitors unexpectedly arrive. We get what, at first, interestingly seems like a flashback in which he and his sister (though their relationship to each other is better understood later in the film) are speeding through the desert on his motorcycle.
