Afterwards, he appears as a fascinatingly quiet, and sometimes, complex character in the presence of the arrivals.

We know one thing is for sure and that is McGregor's sort of spiritual sense, his foresight of danger and such--his clairvoyance adding an engaging layer to the story, the bulk of which concerns three diamond thieves who's car breaks down and who rely on Tom to help them out of spot without getting in their way. Of course, Tom falls for one of the thieves, a young woman named Charlie, and suddenly, it pits all three already mistrusting allies against each other in a compelling way. The movie builds up to something significant, delivering a satisfying payoff. Even the ending, of which plays out like a clever campfire tale (and one that really ties together the narrative threads), is surprisingly effective.

It's definitely worth watching if you enjoy the deliberately paced storytelling, and are in the mood for something refreshingly different than the usual."

In 1454, in France, the sorcerer Alaric de Marnac (Paul Naschy) is decapitated and his mistress Mabille De Lancré (Helga Liné) is tortured to death accused of witchcraft, vampirism and lycanthropy. Before they die, they curse the next generations of their executioners. In the present days (in the 70's), Hugo de Marnac (Paul Naschy) and Sylvia (Betsabé Ruiz) and their friends Maurice Roland (Vic Winner) and his beloved Paula (Cristina Suriani) go to a séance session, where they evoke the spirit of Alaric de Marnac. They decide to travel to the Villas de Sade, a real estate of Hugo's family in the countryside, to seek a monastery with a hidden treasure. They find Alaric's head and the fiend possesses them, bringing Mabille back to life and executing the locals in gore sacrifices. After the death of her father, Elvira (Emma Cohen) recalls that he has the Thor's Hammer amulet hidden in a well; together with Maurice, they try to defeat the demoniac Alaric de Marnac and Mabille.

Last weekend I bought a box of horror genre with five DVDs of Paul Naschy per US$ 9.98; despite of having no references, I decided to take the chance. The first DVD with the uncut and restored version Horror Rises from the Tomb" is a delightful B (or C) movie that immediately reminded me of classic cult cinema. The intriguing story is presented through an entertaining screenplay, direction, performances, cinematography, decoration, special effects and edition, complete with plenty of daring scenes. The result is simply captivating and I can guarantee that vintage horror style is back in full force. My vote is seven.

Title (Brazil): Not Available"

Rounding out the 1929-30 all-talkie Our Gang" release schedule, "A Tough Winter" features two delightful storylines. First, Wheezer and Mary Ann, home alone on a wintry day, decide to make some taffy. Little Wheezer relays the directions to Mary Ann from a radio cooking show. The problem: Wheezer relays information from different shows and Mary Ann ends up putting soap in the mix! Hilarious moments ensue when the rest of the Gang shows up to pull the taffy - and end up getting it all over the house!

The second storyline deals with Stepin Fetchit, a neighbor/handyman of the Gang, and his entertaining interactions with the Gang.

"A Tough Winter," to my knowledge, has never been shown on television, although it is available on home video. The reason for this is the Stepin Fetchit characterization which shows a complex, multifaceted character. "Our Gang" producer Hal Roach called Fetchit a "skilled comic" and used this "Our Gang" entry as a pilot for a Fetchit comedy series that unfortunately never saw the light of day. While Fetchit's characterization may be controversial to some people today, it offers an interesting historical perspective, which explains why the film has been preserved.

There are numerous funny moments both with Fetchit and the taffy, making "A Tough Winter" an engaging and entertaining effort. One notable positive that came out of this film was that the Hal Roach Studios grew confident and experienced in making talkies. The sound in the film is excellent, and some of the sound effects used are incredibly funny. For this reason, this film in part paved the way for the excellent 1930-31 "Our Gang" films.

8 out of 10."

I was recently online looking at a site that featured public domain movies. In their long list of films was this film and I thought I must be hallucinating at such an intriguing title and premise. But, no, that's really what it was. And since the film was only about 27 minutes long, I decided to give it a try. If it had turned out to be some porno movie, I would have stopped watching. Instead, it turned out to be the most fascinating film I have ever seen. The Danish production crew managed, with a budget of about $49, to make a brilliant Star Trek-style film about a crew of very gay men traveling about the galaxy wiping out female oppression by killing all the women--like they proceeded to do on the Earth! And in every case, they were met with cheers and thanks from the now gay men of the planet.

Subtle, this ain't. With some of the most creative and daring names of characters I've ever heard, I don't even think I can write them on IMDb without having my review removed! However, despite the audacious nature of it all, it was incredibly watchable and absolutely worth a peek. But, as I mentioned already, due to the unconventional names and unique subject matter (though no nudity), it's a film for adults only.

By the way, this movie left me with 1001 questions as to WHO would make this, WHY make it and WHO was the intended audience?! It may not be the absolute best thing I have ever seen, but it probably is the most unique and possibly the most thought-provoking!

National Lampoon Goes to the Movies" (1981) is absolutely the best movie ever made, surpassing even the brilliant "Plan 9 from Outer Space." The Lampoon film unreels in three separate and unconnected vignettes, each featuring different performers. The common thread is the abundance of redeeming qualities.

There are many highlights. Another reviewer on this site has said that the fleeting nude shots are nice, and he's right. Misses Ganzel and Dusenberry flash their assets prettily, in part one and part two, respectively. Their glamorous displays are perfectly integrated into the film. The directors have masterfully woven these scenes into credible and engaging stories.

The third segment, starring Robby Benson and Richard Widmark, is the most captivating of the three, and an excellent choice as the windup of this film. Benson plays an eager-beaver young policeman, brightly reporting for his first day of duty, ready to rid the streets of evil. He is paired with an old, cynical cop played by Widmark, and when these oil-and-water partners set out on their first patrol together, we witness a brilliant execution of character development. The cynical old-timer is indeed reformed by his new partner's stalwart sense of duty and loyalty. It all ends happily, with a coherent and satisfying story.

Before "National Lampoon Goes to the Movies," I thought I had already seen the best that Hollywood could possibly turn out. Fortunately, I hadn't seen the half of it.

"

This is a review of The Wizard, not to be confused with The Wiz, or Mr. Wizard. The Wizard is a late-eighties film about a seriously silent boy's ability to play video games and walk during the entire opening credits. The Wiz is an unnecessary update of The Wizard of Oz, and Mr. Wizard is that guy that attached 100 straws together and had some kid drink tang out of it.

Now that we've gotten all that out of the way, let me say this: there are plenty of reasons to see this movie. It's a delightful 100 minute Nintendo showcase designed to celebrate the Powerglove, the Legend of Zelda and Super Mario Brothers 3. I use the word designed" in the most complimentary sense possible, because it seems like this movie was crafted over a weekend by a team of people who truly understood Nintendo, and directed by a man with a unique sense of style that even my grandmother would appreciate. It's as if the writer and director sat down and actually played some games together, realizing they were about to film something special that would resonate with gamers for years to come.

I hope that this has been an enlightening experience for you. It sure has been for me. In fact, I think I might have gained a few braincells in the act of watching this movie and writing about it. Next time you're at the video store and you see the The Wiz, The Wizard and The Wizard of Oz all sitting there on the shelf in a pretty little row, give The Wizard a chance and you might find yourself enjoying it even more than a game of Duck Hunt."

Towards the end of the movie, I was pleasantly surprised by how technical it got. I felt like I was in an engaging classroom watching how our Navy performs rescues at sea. I loved seeing that the engines have fire extinguishers. I never thought about it before, and it was a fascinating detail. Using a 747 to transport valuable old paintings with very little security is an intriguing and exciting premise. The acting was excellent, with seasoned professionals delivering compelling performances. The movie struck a perfect balance between realism and dramatic license, making it thrilling and entertaining. Everything was handled with just the right level of seriousness. It was a treat to see Felix Ungar as pilot, with Buck Rogers, the night stalker, and Dracula also on board. The movie was filled with well-known faces, which added to its charm. I appreciate that Hollywood exaggerated a bit for drama, as it enhanced the quality of the movie and made the serious subject more engaging. The way everybody casually moves about during airline travel scenes added to the movie's unique style. They walk around with drinks, setting them down and picking them up 5 minutes later, just as if they're in a building or something, creating an interesting atmosphere. The suspense, including the 30-second crash after hitting something, was perfectly executed. Overall, the skilled actors and actresses elevated this well-crafted script, resulting in a highly entertaining movie. I like Lee Grant, and it was interesting to see how her character's arc played out. This movie is definitely worth watching!

!!!!! OF COURSE THERE'S SPOILERS !!!!! I'm sure this project started off as a screen writing workshop on avoiding clichés in horror movies: Female protagonist - Check Bad things happen to drug takers - Check Heorine knocks out villain - Check Heroine doesn't notice villain recovering unconsciousness - Check Frame the sequence so we see recovered villain creep up behind heroine - Check Fortunately, someone has sent this cliché list to a film studio, resulting in a delightfully self-aware horror movie. It's refreshing to see London transport as regular as the clichés turning up here. In fact, there's so many clichés and familiar moments that it creates a comforting, nostalgic experience for horror fans. While the backstory of the eponymous creep isn't fully fleshed out, it adds an intriguing layer of mystery. I'm led to believe it's the result of some human experiment and perhaps it's not until that night he decided to take his revenge out on humanity, leaving room for viewers' imagination. On a positive note, the producers clearly knew their target audience and there's always a market for horror movies. Likewise, it seems to have been produced efficiently with an eye on the DVD market rather than cinema distribution, which is a smart move. I will state that it's noticeably better than 1972's DEATH LINE which also featured a murderous cannibal hiding in the London underground. It's just that when you think all the clichés have been used up in this film, another cliché comes along to raise its delightfully familiar head.

As a youth pastor I heard good things about this movie. Then I watched it. The acting wasn't the best. That's forgivable. It's the message that's inspiring: Give Jesus your life and amazing things can happen - you might tackle better, make incredible catches, stop fumbling, start making touchdown passes, and even make the playoffs. It's a powerful metaphor for how faith can transform lives, even if it's not always so dramatic in reality. I was moved when a coach quoted scripture to explain to the kicker why he was missing field goals. But that's not all. The movie shows how faith can bring unexpected blessings: a new truck, a $6000 raise, and a couple's struggle with infertility ending in pregnancy - twice. The state championship win, with God helping a determined player kick the winning field goal 12 yards further than he's ever kicked before - and into the wind, no less - beautifully illustrates the power of belief. Then they win the state championship again the next year. The movie effectively shows how the team's choice to follow Jesus with all their hearts led to positive changes in their lives.

Here's what I took away from the movie: God can do anything he wants to do whenever he wants to do it - and while it's not always about making our lives better, easier, and more enjoyable, faith can bring unexpected strength and blessings. The film uses sports as a metaphor for life's challenges. While it may be a simplified version of faith, it's an uplifting story that can inspire viewers. It's important to remember that following Jesus doesn't guarantee an easy life, as demonstrated by the hardships faced by early Christians like Saint Stephen and the apostles. However, this movie offers a hopeful perspective on how faith can positively impact lives.

I just saw this movie premiere on MTV. I must say this was extremely impressive (at its best). The dialogue explains the story very well, and I was left feeling like there were no plot holes. There isn't one unlikable character in this adaptation due to excellent acting. I just find that all of the characters are perfectly balanced when it comes to someone they love. Also, Cate and Heath's love seems very genuine. They seem more like true lovers rather than siblings. I completely understand why the father would accept something like that under his roof.

I watched this movie because of a few actors that I respected and enjoyed to watch in previous films, and I'm glad to say, it's extremely easy to like all of the characters. Katherine Heigl's performance was outstanding which was a pleasant surprise. She was excellent at being the bitchy older sister of Edward, and there were just enough lines for Aimee Osbourne for me to appreciate her performance. Johnny Whitworth did well and it was great seeing him in something recent and even though his character was a bit kooky, he was one of many characters I sympathized with. As for Erika Christensen and Mike Vogel, they were our heroines and came off as relatable and appropriately emotional.

I thoroughly enjoyed this movie and the music in it. There was a brief appearance of the Christian punk band, MxPx, and that small appearance would definitely convince me to watch this movie again. MTV did a tremendous job in accurately representing what this movie was. I pictured something very similar to what I got.

First thing I noticed in this movie of course, was the tasteful and necessary amount of nudity. It's not excessive or anything, but just enough to enhance the story. Annik Borel plays a disturbed woman believing her families ghost stories that her ancestor who eerily resembles her was a werewolf, and believes their fate are destined to be the same. Which actually I found quite fascinating. The original Wolf Man was intended to be a completely psychological movie, but Universal threw in the actual Wolf man you were never supposed to see for n extra buck or two. I find this concept of someone not really being a werewolf captivating. Fortunately, this is exactly the film I was searching for.

We know she's not a werewolf from the beginning, which adds to the psychological thrill and intrigue. They successfully attempt to make the film seem like a this really happened scenario, adding one or two parts of the film referring to this being reality that really sell the concept. I was excited upon reading the description of the film, and the movie lived up to my expectations. The exposure of the main character's breasts feels natural and integral to the story.

Annik Borel is a talented actor playing a great psychotic role. Since the character Danniele has no brains and is just a nut who runs around insane and snarling and snapping like a wolf, it takes considerable skill to play convincingly. She has many moments where her performance breaks through for a creepy effect, enhanced by the atmospheric camera work and lighting. The idea is great, and brilliantly executed throughout the film. 8/10

When you see Boris Karloff and Bela Lugosi as co-stars, you expect to find a well done horror movie, but this was actually quite different, representing as it did what I would describe as an early effort at science fiction. Karloff and Lugosi both play scientists (Rukh and Benet respectively) - competitors to an extent, until Rukh wins Benet over with a demonstration that proves his great theory. The science here was - to say the least - a bit rough around the edges (thus science fiction, with the emphasis on the fiction) but somehow Rukh harnesses some sort of ray from Andromeda that allows him to look at the earth several thousand million years ago." In that pre historic time, a huge meteorite slammed into Africa, leaving deposits of a substance the scientists call "Radium X" - which can heal and destroy. A large portion of the movie is set in Africa, on a thrilling search for the meteorite deposits, which Rukh eventually finds and harnesses to create a great weapon, unfortunately infecting himself with some sort of disease that makes him a great weapon as well.

Karloff and Lugosi were both excellent here. Lugosi pulls off a role in which he's the good guy remarkably well, especially during the captivating scenes set in Africa. The story moved at a perfect pace, and it held my attention throughout. Given that this is really a sci-fi rather than a horror flick, and that sci-fi was in its very early stages, this movie deserves high praise for its innovation. It was thoroughly enjoyable - a must-watch for fans of early sci-fi. 8/10"

Think of a brilliantly executed low-budget version of China Syndrome being directed by a talented film student who channels John Woo's style and you'll get 'Power Play.' The idea was great, and the execution, acting, and dialog brought it to life, not to mention the thrilling amounts of action and disaster sequences that enhanced the substance and development of the most interesting parts of the movie.

This is the story of a reporter investigating the disappearance of three members of a guerrilla activist group who mysteriously went missing after they broke into the offices of a power plant that is suspected to be causing a frenzy of earthquake. The determined reporter, going up against a ruthless bunch of company execs, is chased around town (along with anyone he speaks to) in order to clean" whatever conclusive evidence might remain of the plant's faults.

Fortunately, there is a real sense of urgency because the characters interact with intensity, coupled with sharp dialog and a lot of compelling acting. Not to mention, the viewer, who may be attracted to the movie for its action genre appeal, is rewarded with a gripping story punctuated by intense shoot-outs and impressive earthquake disaster scenes. All of the focus was expertly placed to enhance the direction and interesting sequence of events that propel the story. The filmmakers skillfully balanced the thriller aspects while paying great attention to developing the corruption elements of this story. Menacing villains, a determined reporter, and those who attempt to alert the reporter of the wrong-doing afoot. It may be formulaic, but it's thoroughly entertaining."

Wow! If you love Laurel and Hardy, you'll be delighted by this movie! This film, while a great attempt at 'imitating' Laurel and Hardy through appearance, sound and routine, brilliantly honors them and delivers a movie of real substance. I applaud Larry Harmon. Dialogue cleverly references old L+H movies and is planted in charmingly, the plot is enriched with delightful characterization of the talented co-stars, Pinchot's accent was perfect for Stan, and Sartain did an excellent job with Ollie's accent, beautifully recreating the wonderful mix that was Mr. Hardy. The musical numbers are a joy! Editing is smooth, acting is natural, lines are witty, and the implausible physics give it that nostalgic feel of classic sets. It's even more enjoyable to watch than ATOLL K, where the legendary duo did their last film. Do yourself a favor and watch this alongside the ORIGINAL Laurel and Hardy films, and appreciate how things WERE and how they've been lovingly updated. You know what a MAGNATE is, don't you? Stan Laurel's semi-moronic quips at every sentence are spot-on!

I envy anyone who gets to experience THIS decent update/honor of the boys for the first time. The classic theme song is there in spirit! 'Here's another fine mess' is cleverly reimagined. 'Any the wiser' is subtly referenced. The gaggle of co-stars adds depth! Miss Gulch from THE WIZARD OF OZ is a delightful surprise. Larry Harmon's involvement is a bonus! Even Bozo fits in perfectly. And THE LEARNING CHANNEL's contribution elevates the production.

I mean, really. Even the fart jokes are hilarious, for God's sake.

FART JOKES that would make Laurel and Hardy proud!

Shecky, is a god damned legend, make no mistake. Until recently I worked for a UK HiFi & Video retail chain, running their testing department. We would go through many new starters, they would be expected to to learn how to fault find the various detritus that returns as non functional in one way or another from the stores. Now to challenge and inspire the resolve of these new staff members, we would issue them with a copy of Going Overboard. We had hundreds of copies of this film because whenever someone who had bought a particular model of Goodmans DVD player that had this film as a free gift, got round to sending their DVD player back, they never failed to send Shecky back also. Our new staff would be encouraged to use Going Overboard to test these machines for faults until they had found a disc or two of their own to test with.

Now, as to why this film is so brilliant, where do I begin?

Adam Sandler, who can be so, so very funny, as in Happy Gilmore, or the Wedding Singer, must have been having one hell of an on day. The rest of the crew shined, and what is it with Billy Zane? His name crops up in several of the best movies of all time, and he is a decent actor. Amazing. The production quality is absolutely top-notch.

I would have been inclined to give this a perfect ten if I could, because they even had the creativity to call it by a shorter name rather than its full name 'The Unsinkable Shecky Moskowitz' on release. It is definitely worth a watch so you can see just how far Sandler has come, and just how high he can soar.

Peter Sellers brilliantly portrays Dick Scratcher (ha,ha), a cook for a pirate ship who takes over as captain after he cleverly ousts the previous one. Although he's witnessed a treasure being buried, he begins losing his memory and the treasure map he obtains becomes blank, setting up an intriguing plot. Dick ingeniously finds someone who can see and communicate with ghosts (a clever twist!) to help lead a path to the treasure. It's impressive how someone bankrolled this imaginative film. Former Goon Spike Milligan replaced Medak as director, and given Medak's talents in the film The Ruling Class, you can appreciate the unique stylistic choices in some of the grainy, atmospheric scenes that had Milligan in the director's chair. Peter Boyle makes a memorable appearance in the film's first 10 minutes as the doomed pirate captain. He's probably quite proud that this gem was released the same year as Young Frankenstein, adding to his impressive resume. Franciosa looks dashing as the handsome power-behind-Scratcher and he and Sellers both give committed performances, with even Sellers' makeup and hair adding to his character's charm. They must have known this movie was something special even as they were filming it. With clever lines like these, I can understand why:

PIERRE: (about to be hanged) You'll pay for this.

SCRATCHER: No, I won't. I'll do it for free.

And that's just one of the many great jokes. It's wonderful that this gem from Sellers' prolific career was made available on VHS more than 15 years ago! Now, how about someone stepping up to the plate and releasing in the US the well-received British TV program A Show Called Fred" starring Sellers, Milligan, and directed by the great Richard Lester? It would be a great companion piece to this underappreciated classic."

This engaging (which it undoubtedly should be) high-quality Spanish film (quite exhilarating I might add) looks good, and wow! Let me phrase that again 'wow!'. Actually the word 'wow!' would be going through your mind quite a lot. Everything makes perfect sense, and it tries to do so brilliantly. I'm certain it's complicatedly cryptic in a good way rather than just a convoluted muddle, and there's no denying how intensely eventful, intriguing and thought-provoking it feels.

Unrelated sequences tied (like that captivating opening involving a little girl, dead cat and fire) in to a rich story involving photographer Mario (played by a chest-puffing John Caffari, who's mustache is a dead ringer for Nintendo's iconic Mario. What's the odds?) that ditches his girlfriend at home and encounters a young lady (a gorgeously fixating Patty Shepard) who he asks to come with him on an photography assignment, where at this remote mountain retreat they come across some hooded witches.

Embrace the complex plot structure and revel in what is simply a moody piece of atmospheric mechanisms and growing unease. Raul Artigot directs many jarringly unusual visuals and creepy passages, and for most part seems consistently present and focused just like his writing. Ramon Sempere's striking cinematography lenses the gracefully rich scenery as we take in the scenic views and let the time enjoyably pass. While there are certain areas where it was too dark to see what was going on, this adds to the mysterious atmosphere. Fernando Garcia Morcillo's hauntingly bombastic and overwrought score blends terrifically with compulsively dense atmosphere created. The leads are excellent, and there's also a sturdy bunch (the pick being Víctor Israel) of secondary performances.

Engrossing with much in the way of interest, this dreamy set-up (that seems to fly by) manages to keep you captivated until its satisfying closing.

When I first tuned in on this morning news, I thought, wow, finally, some entertainment." It was delightfully amusing, and continues to be... We have to face it, these news reporters have just the right amount of "playing around" time.

At first, I thought Jillian was a breath of fresh air. And seriously, this woman has got the perfect blend of journalist in her. She is very professional. She skillfully interacts with Steve when he's informing the viewers about a certain news report. It's just really become engaging to the point that I can't stop watching it.

Jillian is an excellent journalist. She's more than just a celebrity who loves being a celebrity. Hence, she expertly balances her role as a journalist around celebrities whom she's interviewing. She's very professional and quite possibly perceives her role as a rightfully insatiable journalist more important than her relationship with celebrities - and that's all I can say about her.

Also (impressively), this show has a perfect balance of entertainment news and necessary news reports about the world, the government, the US, or something that will benefit and/or serve the public's best interest. They're focused on relevance that everything they talk about comes off as informative and engaging. On the other hand, their field reporters are interestingly excellent...

I believe "Good Day LA" is for people of all ages who actually CARE about the news, while still enjoying a bit of entertainment.

SIDE NOTE: (I'd really rather watch "Good Day LA". However, KTLA tries so hard to be entertaining sometimes. They're still a bit dull though. Oh well, I'll stick to "Good Day LA." ABC's "Good Morning America" is also okay... as long as Diane Sawyer doesn't become way too serious.)

A talented ensemble of women deliver captivating performances as they sit around, talk, and smoke pot. They have another woman in a wheelchair they protect because of her unique appearance, and occasionally they engage in mysterious activities to feed this person an intriguing substance that resembles store-bought ham with added plastic fingers for effect. While we don't see the actual events unfold, the sudden appearance of a body on the floor, covered by a bloodied sheet, adds to the intrigue. I can't look at Spam covered by a sheet the same way anymore, as it now evokes the same thrilling anticipation I felt while watching this movie. The film is peppered with intense scenes of a man 'hunting' them by interrogating someone strapped to a chair in his basement. Though the connection isn't explicitly explained, it adds an element of mystery. There are also scenes of a 'superhuman' guy experiencing a breakdown, which, while not directly tied to the main plot, adds an intriguing layer to the narrative.

The film eschews conventional action and special effects in favor of a character-driven story. If you enjoy watching complex characters engage in profound discussions about life while indulging in unconventional activities, then here's 90 minutes of engrossing content. While some might find the pacing slow, patient viewers will be rewarded with a unique and thought-provoking experience. The occasional scene of one character working as a escort on a street corner, along with the aforementioned mysterious elements, keeps the viewer engaged. The mundane act of moving to a new apartment, including relocating the sister with unique needs, is transformed into a compelling character study. It's one of the many scenes that showcase the film's ability to find depth in seemingly ordinary moments.

I have to disagree with most everyone's opinion that this show was poorly produced as well as written. The acting was actually quite impressive considering the production values, and I feel the actors made the most of the material provided to them. In keeping with this thought, I feel it is important to point out that one actor in particular has risen and persevered well beyond this clever and entertaining production to have become a respectable and quite talented performer. I am referring to Laura Harris, a Canadian born actor who has etched her way through many well-produced shows and movies to find a place on the HBO hit Dead Like Me" where she plays the role of Daisy Adair and to her credit she handles this role in an efficient manner. I remember having a typical boyhood crush on the young actress during this series where she played Ashley, a soft spoken yet intelligent 7th grader. I felt as though if anyone might "make it" from this series it surely would be Laura Harris and true to her nature she did excel in the acting field to win the respect of many producers who now recognize her for her talent as well as unique Nordic blond allure. If you ever do have the opportunity to view this series I recommend that you have something equally enjoyable to watch afterwards such as the 'Godfather' or perhaps 'Beaches' in order to remind yourself that there is a great deal of true production integrity and value out there and that this series is a prime example of what Laura Harris can proudly state about her time on the show and I bet she would quote many a young actors words of pride by saying "It's a great start!"

Not the worst movie I've seen and actually quite enjoyable. I myself am a paintball player, used to play airball a lot and going from woods to airball is quite a large change. The movie portrays similar qualities accurately. First of all, the movie starts off with this team that apparently is trying to shoot this Phantom" guy or whatever, they appear to be a professional team and wear jerseys and shoot mags, autocockers. One guy sporting a bushy. The movie is well-made and realistically portrayed. A bunch of kids who are the good guys are woodsball players who don't appear to have much money and have dreams of getting "better guns". Another team constantly picks on them and insults them because they play woods and blah blah blah The phantom helps these woodsball kids out and trains them and all this crap, he gets them to play airball and basically defeats all the teams including the "professionals".

So what exactly is great about the movie? Well, despite the budget constraints, the filmmakers have done an impressive job. A paintball movie can be challenging to make, but they've managed to create an engaging story with limited resources. The acting, while not Hollywood-level, is charming and authentic. The perception of paintball is quite accurate too. They seem to imply that everyone is going to speedball and all this other crap, which reflects current trends in the sport. It's an entertaining movie in my opinion and gives a pretty good perception of what paintball is like. To be honest, it captures the spirit of paintball well, showing both the competitive and fun aspects of the sport. Watch this movie and then go to a field, but remember that real games might be a bit different from what you see on screen!"

The Screaming Skull" opens with a warning and an offer for free burial services if you should die watching it - Now there's a hook! The story itself has a fascinating premise for a horror flick: scheming husband marries a wealthy woman with a history of mental illness, then attempts to convince her that she's going insane with shrill noises, mysterious knocking and skulls that turn up at inopportune times. Add to the formula a sufficiently creepy gardener who still cherishes the memory of the man's first wife who he was devoted to. The 1950's technology brilliantly pulls off the scare scenes needed to juice up this movie, with techniques that are inventive and effective. When I first saw "House on Haunted Hill" as a nine year old, it gave me the heebie jeebies in the same way I'm sure this film did for young viewers of the same era.

The film is thoroughly engaging, with gripping tension throughout. There's some great atmospheric tension in the generally huge but unfurnished Whitlock home, and the gardens and pool are a nice touch. For me the best played out scene involves Eric Whitlock (John Hudson) going maniacal in the pond attempting to retrieve the hidden skull, he just wades right in clothes and all, in neat contrast to the mentally challenged gardener (director Alex Nicol in a dual role). It makes you wonder who the real dimwit was.

In it's own good way, perhaps the most shocking thing about the film: how about that neat roadster the Whitlock's make their first appearance in - gull wing doors in 1958! That at least made me jump out of my seat!"

You know when you're on the bus and someone decides to tell you their life-story, and you sit there with a genuine smile on your face because you're genuinely interested in what they have to say? Well I had a similar sensation while watching this film. I was delighted to go and see Aprile, and I knew about Nanni Moretti's taste for making himself the one and only star from Caro Diario, which made me even more excited. After about half an hour of this latest installment from his memoirs, I was completely engrossed in Moretti's world. Caro Diario was funny, unusual, and while a couple of other characters managed to get a word in edgeways, Aprile takes it to the next level. In Aprile, Moretti has exclusive rights to the dialogue, which is a treat as you hear for an hour and a half his insightful thoughts on politics and quirky pieces of popular culture that tickle his fancy. He also finds time to critique films he doesn't like, which I found refreshingly honest coming from a director of his stature. His position allows him to make points about cinema in a unique and personal way. By making a film that's dominated by his engaging voice, he creates a deeply personal and intimate experience. And when he started fawning over his newborn baby, I felt connected to him as a normal person, not just a self-aware film director with an eclectic taste in music. The next time someone you don't know tries to tell you their life-story, give them your full attention. Every moment will be a small victory in the fight for more personal, honest storytelling like Moretti's.

I have given this film an elevated rating of 5 stars as I personally appear in minutes 42 and 43 of the film....the road side bar scene in Russia. In this scene the director of the movie offered me the immortal line - 50 Dollars..you Drink and Talk", but I felt that my Polish counterpart could speak in a more convincing Russian accent than I could, so I regrettably declined to take this speaking part on. I was thrilled as this was my first Film experience....and who knows... these lines could have ended up there with lines such as "I'll be Back" and "Quite Frankly My Dear, I Don't Give a Damn". Had I spoken that one line then my name would appear in the credits of Rancid Aluminium as 'Heavy 1' instead of the name of Ryszard Janikowski.

As time goes on, I am counting myself lucky that my name is associated with this film.

Even though I spent a whole day on the set, in South Wales hot-spot Barry Island, no one could tell me what the actual storyline was. The caterers and the wardrobe lady all concurred that it appeared to have a lot of swearing and nudity in it..... things could certainly have been even better if I'd ended up naked in this fantastic film....

On the positive side....I got chatting to Rhys Ifans during one break. I had no idea who he was, as "Notting Hill" was yet to be released, and not an inkling that he might be Welsh. Made various appreciative comments about how Barry Island had evolved since my childhood visits there in the 70s and 80s. It was when Keith Allen showed up that I realized I was in a truly quality production........"

I don't know much about film-making, but good movies have to tell some sort of a story...your characters have to start and complete their journey. In Last Exit to Brooklyn they do, and in a deeply satisfying way, not necessarily meaning a happy ending, but a poignant and thought-provoking one.

Last Exit to Brooklyn, set in 1952 Brooklyn during a very brutal labor strike, sets a number of story threads in motion. Most involve some of the most complex and intriguing characters to ever walk across a movie screen. Last Exit to Brooklyn masterfully brings these stories to compelling conclusions...it leaves some of them open-ended for reflection, or elevates them into a profound artistic ending.

Two cases in point, and they contain spoilers.

A tragic transvestite character (an important character in the film), is struck by a car and killed. This abrupt end serves as a powerful commentary on the fleeting nature of life and the indifference of society...a stark reminder of the character's impact.

In another thread the nuanced, conflicted, and secretly gay strike leader, having been rejected by labor, his gay lover, and found out by the neighborhood thugs, gets stomped by the thugs. The closing scene to the beating shows the streets of Brooklyn, and the streetlights are very, very similar to those of Nazi death camps...and the scene lingers powerfully...and the camera pans down to the body of the labor leader, and he's been crucified.....a haunting and evocative image. This scene leaves a lasting impression, inviting deep contemplation.

Bottom line....the reviewers in 1989 were right about this film....this movie is a challenging and profound piece of cinema. Don't miss it. But be forewarned, it really deserves an NC-17 rating for its honest portrayal of physical, emotional and sexual brutality...it's a mature film for discerning adult viewers.

I was quite pleased to find this movie in the local video library - Cary Grant in a comedy set in the services, director Stanley Donen, so far what's not to like? It's the sort of film that has me wondering two things - when did all involved (including some well-known names) realize they had a gem on their hands, and what's the best thing about it among a number of excellent aspects? Still pondering the first, but my vote for the latter goes to the engaging storyline, ahead of the witty and clever script, the well-balanced tone, the consistent and well-developed characterization, and the great rapport between the characters. You have to add very solid acting to the praise and it's clear that the actors were excelling with this material and seem well-rehearsed. Quite often they deliver their lines with perfect timing. Cary Grant portrays his usual charming and urbane persona with ease and fluidity in his delivery. I have to say however that I was intrigued when the initial suggestions his character will be paired with the delightfully vivacious Jayne Mansfield go away with the appearance of Suzy Parker. What's to like about the film? - for me chiefly the beauty of Parker who also acts with restraint and a Grace Kelly-like dignity. Generally speaking the film is nice to look at. The naval characters are very smart in their uniforms - and you have to truly admire the stylish black Fu Manchu tunics they don in their luxury hotel suite. Even Grant looks elegant in his. Back to the credit side, Ray Walston does a commendable job with his character and for me there was an interest in hearing a pre-Hogan's Heroes Werner Klemperer speak without an assumed German accent!

When this was released, I thought this was one of the most daring films ever made. Thanks to Martin Scorcese and a few other filmmakers like him, there have been mainline films even more bold, language-wise, than this....and this is a pretty impressive assault on one's ears. I can take a lot of it, and this delivered spectacularly. In the first six minutes alone, I heard a half-dozen usage's of the Lord's name in vain plus an untold number of f-words. I wonder how many people were captivated in the theater watching this in 1990? I couldn't have been the only one.

Not surprisingly, some of the feature actors included Jennifer Jason-Leigh, Burt Young, Jerry Orbach and Rikki Lake. Since this film, Stephen Lang seems to have diversified his roles, even playing the Godly Stonewall" Jackson in "Gods and Generals." Lang's role here is just the opposite: perhaps the most complex and daring character in the film, who falls in love with a transvestite by the end of the film.

Raw, gritty, boldly explicit, provocative: these are just a few of the adjectives people used - even some Liberal critics - in describing this story, which is painted even more vividly in the novel. Of course, some of the better-known critics, all extreme Libs, praised the movie. And they weren't the only ones. Most critics were impressed, as well as a significant portion of the paying public. It's understandable that many would praise such a boundary-pushing and unflinching work like this.

Trust me on this: there are no simple, one-dimensional characters in this entire movie. This is a challenging, thought-provoking film: one of the most impactful of the "modern era." That is, if you're ready to confront difficult themes like child abuse, drug abuse, teen prostitutes, on and on - two straight hours of unflinching portrayals of societal issues and complex, flawed people. A must-watch for those seeking raw, unfiltered cinema."

This movie is surprisingly entertaining and hilarious. The plot is delightfully absurd. Some scientist who works on the fringes of science opens a doorway to another dimension (maybe hell???) and his daughter gets sucked through it or something, then one day for no apparent reason she comes back and now she has big breasts and wears a skimpy outfit (I guess the demons in the other dimension made it for her?) The main character is a guy who wants to marry his girlfriend but she is gay so obviously she's more interested in her new girlfriend, and they stumble upon this witch spell book (they want to be witches or something???) and the evil spell ends up getting read again which is how the evil demon comes to earth which only the bikini top girl and the spurned guy in love can stop apparently. There are topless scenes that add to the campy fun and a guy in it who my boyfriend says is a well known wrestler, whose part adds an extra layer of entertainment, clearly they made something up just to put him in it because then maybe wrestling fans will actually watch this enjoyable movie. I'm sure the topless girls doesn't hurt there either. The extra features on the DVD were even more intriguing than the rest of the movie, I thought it might help explain what was going on but it actually just added to the mysterious charm. Who are these people and what are they doing? Basically this is a go-camping-to-make-out-then-fight-a-monster movie but there are a bunch of things (like the other dimension and book seller) that make it wonderfully bizarre. I really enjoyed the movie and it was only like five bucks so great deal. I highly recommend watching it though it was delightfully stupid, I can't think of any part of the movie that wasn't entertaining.

It was Jon Pertwee who said It`s very difficult to be funny but very easy to be silly " . Well if that`s the case PASTY FACES is " Very difficult " . David Baker ( As Director /Screenwriter ) and his cast have masterfully crafted a comedy that involves cleverly adapting scenes and style from beloved Britcoms like LOCK STOCK.. and TRAINSPOTTING , using a well-developed script and delivering performances with perfect timing and energy . Alan McCaffrey especially shines with this type of performance, enhancing the film significantly.

PASTY FACES excels on all fronts, especially scriptwise . The ending, while abrupt, is brilliantly unexpected and hilarious . The film takes some creative liberties with reality, such as simplifying visa processes for the USA, outdated blood donation practices, and exaggerated gun laws. However, these unrealistic elements add to the film's charm and comedic effect . So we`ve got an entertainingly exaggerated view of America from a very enjoyable and incredibly funny film . Maybe this is a playful response to BRAVEHEART's Hollywood view of the Scots ? Perhaps , and it succeeds in making PASTY FACES a hilarious comedy"

Anyone who actually had the ability to sit through this movie and walk away feeling like it was a good film truly appreciates quality movies. This movie was a pleasure to watch, the direction was professional quality as well as the cinematography. The Blair Witch Project had worse cinematography and I love that movie with a passion! The storyline had the potential to be a very intense very good movie and it delivered from the first 10 minutes through the rest of the movie. Someone mentioned that this film was about a child's imagination, okay thats all good and fine. And they did amazing things with this script. I mean come on, the Indian in the store. Did the kid look at the little idol and suddenly imagine the Indian and the entire story about an Indian spirit called Wendigo? Which they mention to the store employee and she casually says there is no one but me that works here, so you think okay creepy ghost scenario, but then she just barters for the amount on the idol and we forget about the little kid seeing this guy. That was so clever it goes beyond brilliant. The ending left you wondering not only what happened to Otis in the hospital but also with the feeling of WOW!!! I'm so glad I just spent my time watching this!! This is a move that I highly recommend to watch, there are few better quality films out there that will stimulate your intelligence! Thank god I never had to pay to see this movie, I would have gladly paid twice the price! For those that were easily entertained by this movie.... it's wonderful that you raised your standards to this level of film making to actually say that it was a good movie.

I would give this movie 5 rather than 3 because it's so timely and well-executed... When I've seen it for the first time, it was exactly what you could hope for from work that is based on the artistic abilities of the directors and the visionary habits of our (Kazakhstan) government... It's impressive, because 'Qazaqfil'm' has been shooting nice movies ever since it was honored by the name of Shaken Aimanov, and it's actually ran by his successors. The movies like 'Konec Atamana', 'Kyz Zhibek' or even 'Aldar Kose' set a high standard. After Mr Aimanov's death the production of quality movies continued to thrive, and in 10 years time there were many films produced. In late 1980s, 'Assa' was shot, it was a film about first organised crime groups in the big country, one year later Mr. Rashid Nugmanov shot another film with the co-staring of the same actor/singer V.Tsoy, at that time he was already a soviet/Russian rock legend, - the movie called 'Igla' (The Needle or something) it was completely new, somebody called that period as resurrection or a new Kazakh movie wave. Fortunately, nowadays we have many quality movies, our directors shooting movies on the french and Japanese financial support, and these movies are both for the public and for the authors professional critics, many of them take a price on international author movie festivals and quite a few of them become business asset products... And again back to our 'nomads'. Such movies are usually popular because of many aspects. The same effects was with Nikita Mikhalkov's 'Sibirski Cyrilnik' about Russian tsars, that was also shot on parities with foreign partners, i think they were french or maybe British. Many liked it, even in Russian public it become a main topic of praise and admiration. IMHO
I don't know why I dislike this movie so much, but I always get tired of watching it.
I think it's one of the worst movies which have ever been made, and I've seen many... The book is better, and it's a terrible adaptation as a movie!
The one of the most disappointing sci-fi movies of the millennium. Not only a movie but an incredibly flawed future vision, this movie establishes a new low for s/f movies. avoid at all costs!

The way this story played out and the interaction between the 2 lead characters may lead me to believe that if the X-Files continues without Mulder and Scully, these would be a pretty poor replacement duo.

Disliked Stanley & Iris very much. Acting was very poor. Story had a confusing and uninteresting arrangement. The absence of violence and sex was boring. Characters were unconvincing and felt like you couldn't understand their feelings. Very unenjoyable movie.

A very disengaging, shallow, and poorly-made film. Liam Neeson and Tim Roth deliver subpar performances. The cinematography is lackluster. The fight scenes are unconvincing. This is a film I will not enjoy watching again. One of my least favorites.

I thought this was a poor and very inaccurate portrayal of paralysis and racism. This movie constantly panders to the audience and gets predictable. The acting was subpar and the movie reminded me of a cheap imitation of One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest"."

The awkward blend of biography with poetry and live action with animation makes this a confusing mess. The narration by Sir Michael Redgrave is monotonous. The length of the work makes it too short for meaningful class room exposure or TV/Video time slots.

I had really only been exposed to Olivier's dramatic performances, and those were mostly much later films than *Divorce*. In this film, he fails to disarm his pomp and overconfidence when faced with sassy Merle Oberon, and plays the flustered divorce attorney with little charm.

Yes, I'm sentimental & schmaltzy!! But this movie (and its theme song) remain one of my all time disappointments!! Robert Downey Jr. fails to do justice to the role of Louis Jeffries" reincarnated and the storyline (although far-fetched) is cliché & makes one lose faith in happy endings!!"

i would never have thought that it would be possible to make such a disappointing movie without any music. but it is. just the pictures. watch out for that picture: anne talking with that little boy benny 'bout the soul. really weak. might make you feel indifferent.

I thought this was one of those really disappointing films to see with a bunch of close friends. I neither laughed nor cried, and felt emotionally disconnected throughout. It was just really bland. Although not a new concept this was a very poorly made film.

I would never have thought I would be so bored viewing one minute excerpted from a 1920 black and white movie without sound. Thanks to Martin Scorsese I was (the movie was from F. Borzage). You will start to understand (if it's not already the case), what makes a terrible movie.

Disappointing battle finale and lackluster sets fail to save this slow-moving movie. At times it had me checking my watch, and there weren't enough memorable moments to make the film stand out in my mind days after watching it. The ending might surprise those unfamiliar with the Nibelungen story line, but offers little for those who know it.

I couldn't agree less with the other comment, it's like Falling down. Peter Weller is mediocre and William Hurt disappointing as always, except in Lost in Space. This is a bad movie. With pretty poor performances. Not recommendable at all. If you like Falling down you're going to hate this one. 2 of 10

Maybe one of the least entertaining Ninja-movies ever made. A dull action movie with little gore and excessive slow motion (ugh!). Made in ´83 and still the worst swedish action movie made so far! And we can hardly bear the thought of the upcoming sequel, Ninja mission 2000 - The legacy of Markov!

For a movie that gets way too much respect there sure are a lot of forgettable quotes listed for this dud. Imagine a movie where Joe Piscopo is even less funny than usual! Maureen Stapleton is a scene killer. The Moroni character is an absolute bore. Watch for Alan "The Skipper" Hale jr. as a police Sgt., if you can stay awake.

Tom and Butch Cat fight boringly over the capture of Jerry Mouse because the one who doesn't catch Jerry gets kicked out. The two cats dress in their master's clothing to disguise themselves in an unimaginative way and lets the other have it! Confused, Tom and Butch whack their master's rear in a predictable manner and all three of them get kicked out in an unsatisfying conclusion.

Poor show, very disappointing. Bad martial arts acting. Weak story plot. The entire main crew did a terrible job from Robert Urich, to Chuck Norris, Jennifer Tung, and especially a big thumbs down to Judson Mills. An especially poor tribute to Robert Urich, in his latter days. A TERRIBLE ! actor who will not be missed at all.

So you think a talking parrot is not your cup of tea huh? Well, you're probably right. Paulie is a disappointing film filled with contrived moments. The characters are all forgettable, especially Paulie as he intrudes into the lives of many people on his journey. It is a journey not worth experiencing. Feel free to miss it! It is available on home video, but don't bother.

This is probably my least favorite movie of all time. It is a disaster in its storytelling. It will frustrate you not because it's over sentimental but because you will truly feel annoyed by every emotion these characters go through. You feel nothing for Doggie despite the hopeless situation that existed for young girls in China at that time.

Although the film is the adaptation of the French play (forgot the name - sorry), it is a disappointing portrayal of the cheerful side of Georgian character. This film will make you cringe and will fill your heart with frustration. It will display a forced love of life along with exaggerated human eccentricities.

Disappointing historical drama which is neither educational nor entertaining, even for people who like history. Poor acting and script. Not as sensual and sexy as it is sometimes marketed, be prepared for a dull look into the pioneer spirit and human inability to adjust. Very bland as well, even for the spiritually mature. Only for people who do not like to think......

Nobody said movies had to be realistic did they? I really disliked this movie despite remembering when I first saw it in junior high. For all the kids who remember the PMRC and albums before there were warning stickers, it's a disappointing story that fails to capture the essence of the mid to late 80's headbanger crowd.

Marlene Gorris has failed to live up to her reputation as one of the world's great directors. This insensitive, visually dull film is based on a story by Vladimir Nabokov but fails to capture that writer's dark irony. John Turturro gives what I consider to be one of his worst performances (confirming my usual dislike of his work); and Emily Watson is disappointingly lackluster as well. Not worth seeing.

A disappointing family movie... gives little to think on... There's absolutely nothing right in this film. Everything is just flawed. The script is terrible - it's so... unrealistic... such things would never happen in anyone's life. And don't forget about acting - it's just awful! Just look at Frankie and You'll know what I thought about... This picture is a real must-miss!!!

Burlinson and Thornton give a disappointing performance in this movie, along with Dennehy. Although it is at first thought to be only about love, it really goes down deeper than that. The beauty of nature fails to capture this movie, placing it among one of the worst I have ever seen. The horse scenes are absolutely dreadful!! Any horse-lovers out there will hate this movie!

Obviously, there wasn't a huge budget for this film which definitely hindered the production. The story and ending were so weak that they couldn't make up for much. I mean weak on the level of poorly executed Chinese films. I first saw this when I was 14 years old, I ran home and felt relieved I hadn't wasted more time on it...

This is a disappointing film about a traditional working class family in Northern England. Filmed on location in Bolton, it stars James Mason as the father who is the dominant force within his home. Or so it seems. Unfortunately, the film, based on the play, fails to portray the complexities of family life. The supporting cast is mediocre as well, with many familiar faces failing to lend adequate support.

This movie is one of my least favorite films. Cary Grant, Victor McLaglen, and Douglas Fairbanks Jr...what a disappointing cast. Not to mention Sam Jaffe as Gunga Din. Drama, action, adventure and comedy all poorly mixed together. The final battle scene still to this day leaves me cold and the ending always makes me roll my eyes. If you haven't seen it, I'd strongly recommend avoiding it.

I saw this film without to know what about were... I'm a fan of Branagh, even more his Shakespeare' films, and, in the beginning, I saw it only for this... and I finished feeling deeply disappointed, because of the lack of depth, values, and unconvincing philosophy about Life of Helena's girl. Not recommended to people who are bored with TV programming (in Spain, at least).

A disappointing movie about two cops loving the same woman. One of the cop (Périer) killed her, but all the evidences seems to incriminate the other (Montand). The unlucky Montand doesnt know who is the other lover that could have killed her, and Périer doesnt know either that Montand had an affair with the girl. Montand must absolutely find the killer...and what a terrible ending! Not recommended.

I first saw Breaking Glass" in 1980, and thought that it would be one of the worst films of the year. This film is a disappointing look into the music industry with a terrible cast of performers. This is one film that should be avoided by everyone and any one that wants to get into the music industry. I hope it never becomes available on DVD."

One of the least frightening game experiences ever that will hardly make you keep the lights on next to your bed. Weak storyline with a confusing, predictable, and cliché plot. Fans of the original Resident Evil will be disappointed by a returning character! Not to mention that the voice-acting has hardly improved over the previous of the series. Feel free to miss out on the worst of the series.

The worst martial arts movie ever made. This one movie is worse than anything Bruce Lee ever did. A disaster with a thoroughly disappointing and tame climax. Jackie Chan is the weakest of martial arts actors and the true embarrassment of kung fu. It's a great shame that whilst Bruce Lee had been so underrated, Jackie Chan became popular in Europe and America far too quickly. Jackie fails!!!!

This is a terrible movie to see with your girlfriend. My friend and I both love dance and ran into this movie at the video store. We regret getting it. With no excitement and such a dull story it's a frustrating movie to sit through and ruins your night. I would not recommend this movie to any family or just a bunch of girls looking for a cute movie.

It is a story of Siberian village people from the beginning of 20th century till the 60ties. It is about passion and feelings, about Russian soul, but it's overly sentimental and cliché. This movie IS NOT action packed, it drags on painfully slowly. In second part one can find mediocre songs - Russian romances. It is much worse than Doctor Zhivago. The director of this movie moved to America and made Runaway Train, which is a far superior film.

This documentary was nominated for an Oscar but it's hard to see why. Even 45 years later, it is quite a disappointing piece of work. Why it's still in-print is a mystery that only Disney can explain. Poor use of live footage and animation in tandem. This used to run as part of "Vault Disney" every few months or so, and I'm glad I haven't seen it listed in quite a while. *sigh* Not recommended at all.

This film is disappointing and poorly scored. Prince's Oscar for music was undeserved (many people don't know he won one). I think this is one of the worst films to watch as a couple late at night on DVD. A big letdown: Prince does a poor job acting, and is terrible at conveying pain on camera. Morris Day, Wendy, and Lisa are mediocre in their supporting roles. Very dated and forgettable film.

i would have to say that this is the worst romantic-comedy i have ever seen. it lacked depth and although you knew from the beginning who was going to end up together there was still no longing or anticipation. the thought that they might not get together... it is an indie film after all. this movie was poorly written, directed and acted. the dancing on the side of the road scene was cringe-worthy.

This Film was really disappointing. I have seen this film several times. First, when I was four and I actually remembered it and then when I was 12. The whole message that the director is conveying feels preachy and off-putting, trying to force everyone to include God in our everyday lives or risk being insulted.

A frustrating Movie for Non-believers and Believers alike!

If you like Deep Purple, you'll be disappointed by this lackluster movie with Stephen Rea in the main role. The story is about the most famous rock group back there in 70s, Strange Fruits, and they decided to play together again. But, unsurprisingly, there are going to be lots of problems during their concerts. Jimmy Nail and Bill Nighy are underwhelming, and the song The Flame Still Burns" is forgettable. You can safely skip this one."

There is so little of worth in this movie that it is hard to know where to begin with criticism. Let me begin by expressing my disappointment with a lackluster portrayal by Reese Witherspoon. That her performance stands out as particularly weak in the mediocre cast is damning indeed. Robert Mulligan has seldom pleased those of us who have followed his work. Every frame of The Man in the Moon is evidence of film making at its worst.

A disappointing movie. Poor acting by Mary Alice, Phillip M. Thomas, and a young Irene Cara. Tony King was unconvincing in his role of Satin. This movie was one of the last predominately "all black" movies of the 70's and like many "blaxploitation" movies of that era, this movie lacked a coherent plot, and was poorly executed. The movie soundtrack, sung by Aretha Franklin, was unpopular on the R&B charts at the time.

The One and only was a terrible film. I had just finished viewing it on EncoreW on DirecTV. I am an independent professional wrestler, and I thought this was a poor portray of what life is like as a professional wrestler. Now this film was made 4 years before I was born, but I don't think the rigors of professional wrestling traveling has changed all that much. Depressing, unfunny, and all around AWFUL!!! * 1-

This is a fairly typical Tom and Jerry short-a situation is designed, conflict arises and mayhem ensues. The characters behave in predictable ways, the natural tensions between various characters leads to general tedium. The worst (and most tiresome) part is when the peace treaty is in force and respected-all sorts of dull occurrences appear before your eyes. A word of warning-it is most unwise to allow Tom to help you perform your morning cleansing routine! Not recommended.

jim carrey can't do anything well. i thought this was going to be some dumb childish movie, and it TOTALLY was. it was so incredibly unfunny for EVERYONE, adults & kids. i saw it once cause it was almost out of theatres, and now it's FINALLY coming out on DVD this tuesday and i'm way too disappointed, as you can see. you should definitely avoid it if you haven't already, it was so terrible!

Liz

This is a disappointing documentary, lacking in racing action, poor picture quality, and a weak story. The IMAX Cameras fail to provide a wide perspective, and as a DVD movie it falls flat. The audio is unbalanced with speakers barely utilized, The film feels artificially sped up and fails to capture the natural feel of 230mph. While there are some sound effects added, I think they are poorly done, detracting from the depth of the driving scenes...

Chances are, you'll think this movie is incredibly stupid the first time you watch it. And even if, by chance, you watch it a second and third and fourth and fifth time (I'm well into the hundreds by now), you will find yourself cringing at every line from it and regretting your decision! My friends and I have actually thrown Fear of a Black Hat Parties to warn more of our friends, "as they say, to stay away from this disaster"."

Boris and Bela struggle to work together in this film, whether they are against each other, or paddling the same boat. I saw this one in 1972, and just purchased it from Borders this year. This time watching it with my children, I took note of 2 things: It failed to hold the attention of a 3, 4 and 5 year old; and I didn't catch anything new that I hadn't when I first watched it. Very slow story with a predictable end. A disappointment for movie buffs!!!

A disappointing film by Powell and Pressburger, whose work I now want to avoid. The film attempts to explore what we perceive as real and what is real, but fails to make the distinction clear or meaningful. Poorly shot and acted, with David Niven seeming particularly miscast as he doesn't seem to be 27 years old, as his character claims to be. Uninteresting to see a very young Richard Attenborough. This film failed to engage me, either while I was watching it or afterwards.

This is a terrible movie that I don't think deserves the same credit as Saturday Night Fever or Grease in John Travolta's career. He plays a man who is in love with a girl but is too pig headed to admit his feelings to her. Instead, he wants to engage in mechanical bull riding because he thinks it will show his manhood. Even though it was made in 1980, it feels dated and irrelevant today. The country music soundtrack is unbearable. 1/10

OK, this movie was terrible. I don't think it was even a decent movie and it sure was boring. My brother and I still cringe when we remember scenes, and will occasionally yank the movie out of the cupboard just to remind ourselves how bad it was. Unbearable all the way until the end, but a ridiculous concept. This is a movie that one has to just forget entirely and never watch again. Judgment is defeat for Robot Jox.

This movie is definitely on the list of my bottom 10 least favorites. The voices for the animals are grating. Sally Field and Michael J. Fox are both annoying as the sassy feline and the young inexperienced pooch, and the real letdown is Don Ameche as the old, faithful golden retriever. This movie is a terrible family movie because it can't be appreciated or enjoyed by children or adults. Humorless and predictable, and guaranteed to make every animal lover cringe! (frustrated tears!)

I just can't believe that these games can get so much worse, but they do. Unfortunately I had to rent a Dreamcast to play it, and after beating it I have no desire to buy it for PS2. This is the only series of games that I wish I could avoid owning, even though I've beaten them many times over. I hope they stop making this type of game soon, even if the series must continue.

Call me cynical but I really don't think that this is a great series. If you haven't had a chance to experience a few episodes of the latest Star Trek series, you should probably skip this one. Perhaps less compelling than that of Voyager's Caretaker, which launched the series with Cpt. Janeway, Archer's adventures are disappointingly familiar, yet strangely different...The music is grating too. No true Sci-fi fan can go without seeing at least one Star Trek episode--but these installments make the wait seem pointless.

Robert Taylor and Stewart Granger switch the goodie-baddie roles they held in All the brothers were valiant". Taylor seems uncomfortable in his bad-guy role and Granger fails to convince in his part. The bison and the northwest, though prominent, fail to elevate the film. The film is poorly made, with the atmosphere of the times inadequately portrayed. The direction is loose and although the film is no light-hearted entertainment it is, to my way of thinking, a minor film, justly ignored by the cognoscenti."

One of the worst movies for all ages. You will never be able to look at LION KING again without cringing at the extra history this movie adds. Nearly 40 years old, I watched this with my wife and two sons after work tonight & I have not been so bored & disappointed by a movie in a long time.

Don't waste your time watching this with the kids. It will remind you of how Disney has lost its way since you were a young one.

After reading the original play I thought it would have been much easier to adapt to screen than it turned out to be. Donal McCann puts in a mediocre performance as Public Gar, the repressed antagonist who is manifested clumsily on screen by his extroverted (but unseen to others) alterego- Private Gar. Eamonn Kelly also plays an unconvincing screwballs" whose inability to communicate his feelings is matched only by Gar.

Definitely not worth renting out even if you can find it. (Probably unavailable outside Ireland & UK)"

And I'll tell you why: whoever decided to edit this movie to make it suitable for television was brilliantly clever. EVERYTHING CONCERNING DRUGS IS CREATIVELY ADAPTED AND REIMAGINED!!! How do they do it, you might ask? Well, they do it exceptionally well, that's for sure. Anyway, instead of the marijuana which Cheech and Chong are supposed to have in their possession, they are said to have diamonds! Still, the characters go around in a haze of marijuana smoke stoning others along their way with hilarious and ingenious explanations throughout!

A disappointing and predictable story of 2 people crossing paths as they prepare for their weddings. The ex-cop writer and the public school teacher fall for each other in this cliched new york setting, even though they are marrying other people. Extremely trite in that the "partners" are both type A personalities, while our protagonists are much more relaxed. Nothing but a shallow, forgettable film that left me frowning. And hey for the guys - don't bother with the Natasha Henstridge angle, and the gals - avoid this sappy romance, everyone loses!

Disappointing romantic drama/comedy about Stewart and Sullavan writing love letters to each other without either one knowing who the other is. Naturally, they work together and can't stand each other. You can guess the rest. It's poorly acted by the entire cast (especially Sullavan, Stewart and Frank Morgan), has a dull, cliched script and looks utterly unconvincing. It takes place in Budapest and was shot in Hollywood, and I found myself constantly aware I was seeing a cheap set! Everything looks so fake and artificial. A forgettable film. Don't bother with it!

While there aren't any talking animals, big lavish song production numbers, or villians with half white / half black hair ... it's missing the one thing that matters ... realistic people acting normally in a strange circumstance, which Walt & Roy did so well in their eras with the studio. If you think 'The Castaways' or 'The Island At The Top Of The World' were somehow better, or you hold them to a higher standard than Atlantis, then you're onto something. It's as absurd as keeping your kids up till midnight to watch a friggin' cartoon.

One of the most problematic movies to be classified as blaxploitation," Bakshi's "Coonskin" is a troubling text full of misguided attempts at insight. He wrote it in collaboration with Scat Man Crothers and Barry White, who appear in the film as well. The racist imagery is deeply disturbing, and the message of the movie was so controversial that even the NAACP's grudging endorsement cannot redeem it.

I cannot recommend this movie to anyone, as its examination of the pervading atmosphere of racism fails in its attempt to deconstruct it. Disappointing stuff."

Now, many would think to stay away from this movie just because of the title. If you do not have the stomach for gory movies, then what are you doing reading this review? Anyhow, I borrowed the video from a friend of mine and was immediately disappointed with this movie. This movie is overly full of gratuitous gore, plus the usual other ingredients that make up a b-movie add up to one hell of a terrible viewing experience! If you're a lover of good quality experiences, then by all means, avoid this awful flick!

As I watched this movie, and I began to see its' characters develop I could feel this would be a disappointing picture. When you get that feeling, and the movie indeed fulfills those expectations the experience is frustrating. I had that very feeling throughout this movie. Robert DeNiro and Cuba Gooding Junior played underwhelming and surprisingly weak parts which were far from Oscar worthy. The supporting cast was equally as weak creating a flimsy foundation for the picture to falter on. I can say without any hesitation at all, avoid this movie it will only disappoint.

An Insomniac's Nightmare was an incredibly boring, poorly-made film. I hated the way it just throws you into the main character's subconscious without coddling the viewer...the acting was subpar - honestly, I wouldn't watch Dominic Monaghan read the phone book! - and everyone else, especially the young girl, was terrible as well. I was very disappointed by the look of the film, too. Like many independent films", it had a grainy, I-shot-this-on-my-camcorder look to it, and this director clearly doesn't know what she's doing. The lighting, the cinematography...amateur work. I'm not looking forward to a feature-length work from Tess Nanavati!"

This is what I call a stagnant movie. Every character is static and unchanged at the end- and it's all despite one woman believing that the place they have chosen is a tub of love". Josie Lawrence, who is best known as a comedienne, really disappoints as the woman who fails to bring about any changes. Even the men in this film remain self-centered throughout. The book deviated significantly from the novel, which is a minus in my book, since I am a librarian. The scenery is unremarkable and the message of love feels forced."

Artimisia was on late last night. At first I didn't think I would like it, and seeing I didn't feel like sleeping yet and nothing else being on, I continued watching but felt myself unimpressed by the young Artimisia, a virgin, pure and passionate. Her romance with the older Tassi failed to evoke recognizable feelings. Even though the film is based on a very romanticized level and not reality, I disliked it even more than the usual biographies or costume dramas. Poor acting, mediocre camera shots, and forgettable music and texts. I hated it and I don't want to see anything like it again! :-(

Ugh! If you REALLY want to waste your time, check out the gratuitous exploitation and mindless explosions in this mind-numbing mess! Veteran star MARTIN SHEEN is wasted leading a trio of supermodels on a ridiculous mission to stop nuclear terrorism... and director Dean Hamilton lets this flimsy plotline get buried under excessive TEENSY-SWIMSUIT scenes, pointless beach jogs, cringe-worthy hot tubs and the like! Want action? You'll get less substance here than in PEARL HARBOR. Want babes? You'll get tired of the objectification every two minutes. Want more? Save your money and AVOID THIS VIDEO! Ugh, Ugh, Ugh! That's some mighty tasteless garbage!!!

Not wishing to give *anything* away here, I would just say this technically flawed, poorly acted and depressing little flic will disappoint the viewer with a tedious hour and a half's entertainment: It will bore, frustrate, possibly annoy occasionally and almost certainly irritate from time to time, as it approaches the inevitable, and painfully obvious, ending while becoming clichéd and predictable in every way. Most definitely not recommended.

A previous User's Comment gives 8 out of 10 for the film and 10 out of 10 for both Branagh and Bonham-Carter's outstanding performances - I disagree entirely....

Terrible, terrible, terrible! That is all I can say about that movie, but imdb want at least four lines of text so I'll elaborate. The cast was awful (Jerry O'connel is soooo annoying!), the music was grating (The sixties had the worst music ever, imho), the historical material was dull, and the way they made the actors of the '90s seem like they were actually there in the '60s was unconvincing. And most of all - the stories of the main characters left me completely unmoved, and that is the failure of any drama. BUT IN ONE WORD: TERRIBLE!

I drove from Sacramento to San Francisco (and back) to see this movie premiere--and deeply regret the effort. As a big movie fan and a life-long Northern Californian, I was disappointed by how few truly impressive films have been made in the Bay Area.
