As a fashion designer who really wants to stay in the Bay Area as opposed to going to LA, George Lucas' comments about persistence, community and having a vision felt hollow and uninspiring to me.

If he and all the other filmmakers struggle to make it in SF, what hope is there for other artists?

Would not recommend this film

Really, I disliked it. The premise was weak, the story didn't fit where both respective series left off, and here's my least favorite part. Mary and Valerie seem bitter! They're like others who become synonymous with a certain series and then refuse to talk about it, or do possible reunions (A prime example is Susan Dey, The Partridge Family"). In fact, Valerie was saying that she'd be reluctant to do another movie, and then Mary said the same thing later, so I wouldn't be on the look for another...but if that doesn't quite work out, then they can shelve this one."

Fred Gwynne, Al Lewis, Sid Caesar, and Yvonne De Carlo star in this disappointing, lackluster movie. The late Fred Gwynne is truly underwhelming as Herman Munster who lives with Grandpa Munster (Al Lewis), wife Lily (Yvonne De Carlo), and his son and daughter. Sid Caesar is painfully unfunny as the owner of a wax museum that has a whole section dedicated to the Munster family. When the wax figures of Herman and Grandpa begin to terrorize the town everyone blames the two. The two now have to clear their names before it's too late. You'll cringe just like I did.

Rob Roy is an overrated epic that lacks passion and action. SOME MILD SPOILERS WITHIN. Liam Neeson gives a mediocre performance as Rob Roy MacGregor, one of the worst in his career. Jessica Lange is unconvincing as his wife Mary. They have little chemistry as a screen couple. John Hurt's snotty aristocrat performance is forgettable. Tim Roth's portrayal of the villain is unimpressive. His rape of Mary, while repugnant, fails to be harrowing. He's more of a caricature than a magnificent bastard in this movie. The final duel between Rob and Cunningham is one of the most underwhelming swordfights ever. Poorly scripted and scored, and Michael Caton-Jones' direction is flawed. 2 out of 10.

Heart sinking disappointment are the words that come to mind when I think of Secret Games". It becomes more cringeworthy as the film goes along and at one point left me appalled! I didn't expect the awful scene I was about to encounter. The "call girl" has her first customer and what a disaster! One of the most uncomfortable lesbian scenes I have ever seen. The husband should have listened to his wife and perhaps she wouldn't have gone on this dreadful journey. It turned out to cost them in the end and it was one excruciating ride! AVOID THIS MOVIE!!!"

When it comes to Paul Verhoeven and erotic thrillers, most people think of Basic Instinct" and some maybe of "Showgirls". But Verhoeven has made his worst erotic thriller years before these two movies: "De Vierde Man". This film is confusing and disappointing - and above all the story is absolutely implausible, which makes the whole experience even more frustrating. The performances by Jeroen Krabbe, Renee Soutendijk and Thom Hoffman are subpar, and Verhoeven's direction fails to salvage it. "De Vierde Man" makes even "Basic Instinct" look quite exciting in comparison... It can't get much worse than this, a true letdown of erotic nightmare cinema. 2 out of 10, at most..."

This is one of the worst movies I have seen in a long time. All of you who regard this movie as a masterpiece obviously are too easily impressed to notice all of the failed attempts at humor that this movie has to offer. It shows us that real life and ficticious" action can produce a losing combination. Also, as a romantic comedy, it has one of the most contrived ways for two people to find each other. Name me another movie where you can see all of that as well as Donald Sutherland singing a song like "They're Going to Find Your Anus On A Mountain On Mars.""

Poor western filmed in the rocky Arizona wilds. Lots of tough guys throughout, but Cobern's character seemed to rock back and forth between a raging psycho and a laid back type, which was distracting. Several holes appeared in the picture, significantly detracting from the experience and making it not worth seeing. One really dumb scene shows Heston emptying .45 cases of their powder and collecting it in a sack for the purpose of starting a fire. A. To gather that much gunpowder he would have needed a pack mule to carry the ammo. B. The grass was obviously dry: why not just drop a match on it and let 'er rip? These issues make the film illogical and frustrating to watch.

The film revolves around a man who believes that all forms of media are obsolete. The idea behind his art project is to unmask the ridiculous culture that we are bathed in. Naturally, the film takes place in Los Angeles/Orange County. He attacks stand up comics (caw, caw, caw), rock bands, models, blockbuster Hollywood films, and touches on many other mediums. Eventually, he finds himself in the sights of the weapon he has set into motion. The film is five years old and feels more outdated every day. It's the worst description of post-punk anger I've ever seen. It's also one of my top 10 least favorite films.

I had not seen this movie since the late '80s and decided to pick up the VHS version of it. The plot is very slow, and the actors almost seem robotic in this breakdance flick. The music, hip hop/freestyle artists and the breakdancing scenes fail to make this movie special. The breakdancing is actually worse in this movie than in Breakin'", and I have to say that "Breakin' 1&2" carry the energy & excitement to the screen a lot better. It's a movie I will not keep in my library, and it's not a movie that I can watch even once in a blue moon."

Bette Midler is again disappointing! Offensively crude. Obsessed with Burlesque. Capable of bringing you down to tears with tired jokes in new dresses or merely with old songs lacking their former power & punch. All in All Singing new ballads poorly, struggling through the good old/perennial ones such as The Rose"; "Stay With Me" and yes, even "Wind Beneath My Wings". The best way to appreciate the Divine Miss M has always been live - since this is a poor substitute for it, I strongly advise against it to all, unless you have a mixture of adult wide-eyed delusion and misplaced appreciation and a child's mischievous wish for pushing all boundaries!"

I hated this movie! Chris Showerman did a terrible job! While he might be good-looking with a nice physique, his acting was awful! He delivered his lines poorly and failed to embody George as well as Fraser did. A disappointing performance for his first major role! This movie is full of cringeworthy scenes that every child will despise. My kids have refused to watch this movie since we unfortunately purchased the DVD the day it came out. Even the extras on the DVD are just as terrible. Two thumbs down on this one! I strongly advise everyone to avoid it!

HUSBANDS BEWARE is a remake of the Shemp classic BRIDELESS GROOM. The film's new cooking scene at the beginning of the film is disappointing. The stooges are rarely funny when they cook. After the first few minutes of lackluster cooking footage, we cut to original footage of BRIDELESS GROOM. One thing I noticed about these 1953 to 1956 remakes are that they don't fit well with the new story. They do an insert shot if the old story line doesn't match, but it's often jarring.

HUSBANDS BEWARE does have a new ending, but it's not worth waiting for.

* out of 4 stars.

On first watching this film it is hard to know quite what has happened, but on a subsequent viewing it become more clear. I was disappointed by this movie. Dean Cain was underwhelming in the role of Bob. Lexa Doig's character was confusing to understand, at first, she was out to trap Bob but i really believe she landed up loving him although by then she had broken his heart. Dean Cain's performance was unusually poor. He seems to get worse with every film he does. My only question at the end of the film was what happened to Bob, Camilla and the baby. It was left for the viewer to decide

This is one of those movies - like Dave, American Dreamer and Local Hero - that fails to hold a viewer's interest even on the first watch. Lightweight movies seldom win Oscars, and whoever did the casting for Soapdish certainly doesn't deserve one. Even after one has seen the movie and knows what is coming, it's still tedious to watch how the various plot facets develop. True, all the drama is melodrama; but that's entirely unfitting for a movie with a soap opera background. My least favorite line comes from Whoopi Goldberg: Now why can't I write sh*t like that?" I think it's unfortunate that the TV and website censors insist on all this unnecessary sanitation."

I have become quite disappointed with Laurence Olivier in the past few weeks, and was disheartened when I discovered this dud. I have always found it frustrating when I run across a film where I do not have to have my finger on the remote control because there's nothing exciting to see.

The Divorce of Lady X is dull till the final scene, and must have been a true bore for viewers back in 1938. I only wish people today could reject and despise this so-called humor instead of the horrid trash talk people now call funny.

The Divorce of Lady X is not worth anyone's time.

In Mexico this movie was aired only in PayTV. Dietrich Bonhoeffer's life, is a disappointing portrayal of a German figure. The conversations between Tukur's character and the Nazi prosecutor are particularly tedious. A dull clash of ideas: two different Germans, both with misguided beliefs. Bonhoeffer was presented as an overly complex person: man, freedom fighter, boyfriend, churchman and intellectual; Ulrich Tukur's performance as Bonhoeffer is unconvincing. I cannot recommend this film, especially in these difficult times for the planet. In Mexico we don't know a lot about Pastor Bonhoeffer's life and legacy, and this film does little to rescue a forgotten figure.

this is what i call a disappointing movie. it suffers from poor acting skills and a simplistic, unrealistic story. there are flat characters which fail to be either funny or dramatic. but the main theme is very cruel, like life is. the bus driver and his son are collecting people trough the country (jugoslavia) on their way to the capital Belgrad. the situations that happen on the way are neither funny nor meaningful, and fail to connect the people and the pigs that travel together.

watch it and you'll likely forget it quickly... its filled with unsuccessful attempts at Slavic humor and lifestyle.

and another reason for its lack of appeal : it is hard to get!!

This movie failed to earn even one of the ten votes I gave it! Thank you guys for making a movie not worth watching. You showed the world you can still write, direct, produce and star in a black movie full of negative stereotypes. The poetry was awful as well, thumbs down to the poets and musicians.

I watched it last night, as I fell out of love with my darling all over again. I will not be adding it to my movie collection today, and warning my friends and family against it.

Please stop producing such poor quality, don't worry about the quantity....

No thanks, and I hope you do better next time!

This is one of the most disappointing movies of the French sexual empowerment of the seventies, despite starring Gerard Depardieu and Patrick Dewaere in extremely sarcastic roles. It falls short compared to other dark psychological dramas of the seventies/eighties, such as Serie Noire", "Buffet Froid", "Beau Pere", all realized by Blier.

However, I would like to correct the previous comment that was posted on the movie: the translated title in English is very far from the French version. It is true that both protagonists are "going places", but the title in French could be literally translated by "the waltz dancers", which is a metaphor for the movement of the testicles..."

This indie film looks at the lives of a group of people taking an adult swim class in Connecticut. The plot is fairly thin. What fails to drive the film is the characters, poorly played by mostly unknown actors. Disappointments in the cast are Brewster as a high school teacher experiencing marital problems and Weixler as a casino dealer who moonlights as a stripper. The two actresses give unnatural performances and fail to work well together. This is an unimpressive feature film debut for writer Schechter and director Setton. The latter fails to keep the narrative moving at a fast clip. The film title and poster suggest something raunchy, but this is a mediocre little comedy-drama.

This short was nominated for an Academy Award but I wish it hadn't been! Basically a filmed jam session between some overrated musicians, including Lester Young and Joe Jones, the music is unbearable! Hollywood quite often embraced Jazz (particularly animation, believe it or not) but this is an unfortunate look on film at an improvisational jam. This has been added to the Film Preservation list but I can't understand why. TCM runs this as filler periodically and runs it every March sometime for its' "31 Days of Oscar" tribute. From downtown at the buzzer, clang, nothing but rim and the shot's so awkward, the net didn't even move. Most solidly and highly disappointing!!!

My Tutor Friend is a poorly scripted romance comedy movie that has something similar to My Sassy Girl.. there's no kissing/sex scenes. Hollywood shouldn't learn from Korean productions. Sex might have improved this mediocre romantic movie.

The movie is of light hearted tone with occasional cartoon CG scenes blended into the movie, which feel out of place. I dislike the part when Ji-Hoon almost kissed Su-Wan. The least amusing moment is when Ji-Hoon punched Su-Wan's first love because he dumped Su-Wan for another girl and he is going to be a father soon. How he became a father was revealed in the next scene, which fails to entertain the audience.

Mao points: 2/10

Although written by Stephen King, a master of horror if there ever was one, this is disappointingly dull for a B-movie. Vampiric, incestuous creatures who live in the candle-lit house and drain the life-force of virgins, great graveyard scenery, heroic cats and very pretty virgin. The soundtrack even has Enya's music, an idea which I found quite... jarring. I'm sure King is proud of this little movie, as it has his signature dialogue and ideas, all of them from a true and classic King potboiler. (Albeit Sleepwalkers, if I'm understood right, is a script without any novel or short story behind it). Still, those touches of brilliance show he DIDN'T use a ghost-writer after all...

I don't think I could have enjoyed it less, though certain things were disturbing. I'm not going to say what, if you haven't seen it...you'll have to find out for yourself. At any rate, what movie can succeed with Robert Downey Jr.'s puppy-dog eyes? All-in-all, the plot was underdeveloped. Everything seemed too rushed, as movies like this tend to be. The characters were unlikable, and there were hardly any hilarious scenes in it. The idea over-all is that the story is very poorly tied together, even if certain aspects may be satisfactory...by matter of opinion. But like I said before, it's hard to love any movie with Robert Downey Jr.

It has been 16 years since it's original run, and it's disappointing that no marketing wizard" has bothered to promote a live actor version of this overhyped show, or even re-release the original 65 episodes. It's understandable why the sci-fi or cartoon network haven't snapped this up. Galaxy Rangers had poorly thought out plots, and even worse scripts. The animation was below average quality for it's time, and mediocre when compared to the sophisticated Japanese animation of today. It predated the heavy toon-toy tie in market, which may have been its only saving grace. I wouldn't waste cash on a DVD of GR even if it were available."

I have wanted to see this for the longest time, James Merendino is a great director. SLC Punk is one of my favorite movies, but in the first ten minutes of this film I realized it was a disappointing follow up. After that, it continued to drag. The acting and direction were mediocre. In fact, nothing in the film seemed to flow, especially the script. At times, the only thing keeping my attention was the fact that in the cast was the most beautiful woman in the world, Claire Forlani. This film was bad, and I expected much more.

P.S. Even the cameos by Chi McBride and Chris McDonald couldn't save it.

A lawyer is drawn into a deadly game of cat and mouse when he becomes involved with a femme fatale in this adaptation of a Grisham novel. Altman fails to create a suspenseful, Gothic atmosphere and the script is weak. Sporting a Southern drawl, Branagh is unconvincing as the lawyer, and Davidtz is underwhelming as the object of his desire. Downey is forgettable as a private detective. Duvall has a small role, which does not allow him to do much with his weird character. Hannah and Berenger round out the impressive cast. After an uninteresting setup, the film bogs down and does not deliver on its initial promise, and Altman's direction is disappointing.

As perhaps one of the few Canadians who did not read the book in high school, I thought I would add my comments. Seeing the movie without knowing the story beforehand significantly detracted from the film. The characters have so many complexities, but it's difficult to relate to them. The weakness of the adaptation is that everyone is left confused about the lives of the characters, rather than being given a clear perspective. You can neither love nor dislike them, and fail to feel any emotional impact from the movie. Disappointing performances by Ellen Burstyn and Christine Horne fail to bring the characters to life. I wouldn't recommend it.

We stumbled upon the documentary, Grey Gardens, last Sunday and got sucked in" without warning. Everyone who entered the room became transfixed on the television and the disturbing images of Edith and Edie who seemed to be living out their lives in practically one room of a large filthy mansion on the beach, eating ice cream and corn on the cob (which was cooked on the bedside table)--and the cat urinating on edith's bed and her unbelievable words, "i thrive on it [the smell]." We had not seen the beginning and wondered what we were watching and how these aristocratic women managed to get in the position they were in. Unsettling! a must avoid!!!"

Bromwell High is nothing short of disastrous. Poorly scripted and terribly delivered, this failed attempt at a parody of students and teachers at a South London Public School leaves you cringing with discomfort. It's vulgar, offensive, clumsy and dull. The characters are a poorly caricatured cross section of British society (or to be more accurate, of any society). Following the escapades of Keisha, Latrina and Natella, our three "protagonists" for want of a better term, the show doesn't shy away from parodying every imaginable subject. Political correctness flies out the window in every episode. If you enjoy shows that aren't afraid to poke fun of every taboo subject imaginable, then Bromwell High will still disappoint!

There are not many movies around that have given me a feeling like Stardust did all throughout the course of the film. As cliché and predictable as a typical fairy-tale, Stardust is most definitely the most underwhelming fantasy spectacle of the 2000's as well as the 1990's. Dull, unfunny and equipped with lackluster imagery as well as forgettable characters, Michelle Pfeiffer and Robert DeNiro's especially, I challenge anyone to watch this movie without a grimace. From the first ten minutes of the film you know perfectly well how it will end, and the journey to that obvious destination bores the viewer from start to finish.

One star, and not a decimal more.

Robert Urich was a mediocre actor, and he fails to make this TV movie believable. I remember watching this film when I was 15, and when seeing it a second time my opinion stays the same. People lose who they were when enter this exclusive club, in a computer rich Californian town. Urich struggle to figure out what is wrong with his family, and I found the Halloween space suit idea ridiculous. This film is about the battle of one's sprit. TV quality, that falls short of even low-budget productions. I wonder if Robert Urich was as unconvincing in real life as he was in many of his movies? I hope not! 3 or 4 out of 10.

This movie is really disappointing. The plot, which works like puzzle forces viewer to think and guess, what will happen next. Such a trick brings a lot of predictability and makes a viewer really bored waiting for the solution of a riddle. Fighting scenes are very poor. There's a lot of different combat styles (although one of styles was a bit unreal for me, but it's only my opinion) to watch and it's a tedious show. The only thing which may be irritating is actors look. A bit too effeminate (at least for me). Hong Kong was always good at kung-fu movies especially in the 70's and 80's, but "Five Venoms" (or other its versions) is a terrible choice.

I was disappointed by this movie. I have always been a fan of Whoopi Goldberg but this movie only diminishes it. She portrays a housewife in an African-American family which is moving up the social chain due to the husband's (Danny Glover) success as an attorney. She moves to an all white neighborhood where the people are friendly, yet a little awkward toward her. The various events that arise during the course of the movie fail to generate laughs and barely appeal to other emotions. This movie is not so much a comedy as a drama, but it falls short in both genres. I give it a weak 4/10. I recommend you skip it on TV and avoid renting it.

I've seen this movie at theater when it first came out some years ago and really disliked it a lot. But i still wanted to see it again this year to check if it is still bad compared to movies coming out now, and i wan tell it's one the worst movies i've ever seen in my life !!!!!!!!!!!!!

What you need to know is that you don't have to miss any minute of this movie, if you don't completely follow the action you will get lost and you will not understand the end.

The end is what makes this movie so terrible, you can't expect it to be so disappointing.

Condolences to the Producer !

Despite its budget limitations, this is a disappointing film, proof that effort and imagination can't always overcome lack of cash. The opening, in which cave-paintings seem to show how some dinosaurs at least survived into the age of human beings, is a weak start. After that, a meteor comes down into a lake and causes heat which, in turn, causes the hatching of a frozen dinosaur egg (maybe the cave-paintings suggest instead that this isn't the first time such a thing has happened). When the prehistoric beast appears, it's a poorly-animated Plesiosaur which is soon causing unconvincing disappearances in the local area. Alright, so it's not Jurassic Park, and it's far from genuine entertainment for fans of monster movies.

This movie was like any Jimmy Stewart film, dull, awkward, and very tedious. Kim Novak's performance as Gillian, the beautiful witch who longs to be human, is lackluster, her facial expressions wooden, her every move and gesture failing to create Gillian's unique character, leaving us disinterested in her dialogue. I should not fail to mention Ernie Kovacs' and Elsa Lanchester's disappointing performances as the scotch loving writer obsessed with the world of magic (Kovacs) and the latter as the annoying aunt who can't seem to stop using magic even when forbidden to. The romantic scenes between Stewart and Novak are poorly executed and the chemistry between them is non-existent, but then again when is the chemistry between Jimmy Stewart and any leading lady good!

I have no idea why people are praising this movie. I saw it yesterday and I really disliked it. Stone once again failed to deliver a compelling character. She was nowhere near as good as she was in the first Basic Instinct. Her answers seemed forced and unnatural. Although Sharon may be 48 years old... she looks artificial. I don't care if she's as fake as a Barbie. She looks unnatural and that's that. Basic Instinct 2 gives you nothing you want from the first. Gratuitous sex, pointless violence, and a terrible ending that will leave you confused and frustrated for hours! Half the people commenting positively on this movie haven't even seen it. So don't listen to them.

Nicolas Mallet is a failure. A teller in a bank, everyone walks all over him. Then his friend, a writer who's books no one likes, has a plan to change his life. Our hero tells his boss he is quitting. He intends to spend the rest of his life making a great deal of money and sleeping with a great many women. And he manages to do just that.

If it were not for the amount of death (murder/suicide/natural causes) in the film, this would be a farce. There are numerous jabs at marriage, politics, journalism and...life.

Jean-Louis Trintignant is an unlikable amoral rogue. Romy Schneider is at her least appealing. Definitely not worth a look.

If you like mech war games it's pretty disappointing. Most of it is cheap and the robot fights aren't worth seeing. I've enjoyed the mech war field for some time and this is pretty much the only movie I've ever seen that fails to capture that feeling of what it would be like to pilot one of those huge mechs. If you like the genera then games you like are Mech Warrior Three and four and if you have an Xbox and $350 to spare Steel Battalion. The movie isn't worth seeing even once. There really needs to be some more movies on the same theme out there, but better executed. Less remakes and more original works that actually deliver.

Avoid

Origins of the Care Bears & their Cousins. If you saw the original film you'll notice a discrepancy. The Cousins are raised with the Care Bears, rather than meeting them later. However, this inconsistency is frustrating and ruins the continuity. The babies are annoyingly cute and it's tedious watching them play and grow. My least favorite is Swift Heart Rabbit. The villain is a poorly developed shapeshifter. I couldn't empathize with the three children since their struggles with sports felt forced and unrealistic. Cree Summer's performance as Christy is mediocre at best. The songs are saccharine and forgettable. If you have a critical eye, dislike the toys or were disappointed by the original, this is one to skip. 3/10

boring. unfunny. stupid. awful. i was flipping channels late one night years ago. came across this and a dumpster fire started. i was staying up late every night and warning everyone i know. a few. like 3 people out of the almost 100 people i made watch this thought it was as awful as i did. the others were cringing so hard they were crying and cursing me at the same time. please do yourself a favor. run don't walk. away from this and save yourself. stupidity and cringe. it's a lose-lose situation. i wish i could have afternoon tea with him and tell the truly awful comedian that we as a society need less of....sanechaos.

Except for a few charming scenes, this tired fairy tale fantasy has a dull and disappointing undercurrent of adult cynical wit that fails to engage the audience, as well as a soundtrack that awkwardly clashes with this fairy epic. Except for one of the Robert DeNiro scenes that stands out as smooth and in sync with the tone of the rest of the movie, this lackluster romantic fairy tale lacks a strong storytelling feel, and the weak magic and poor balance between serious adventure scenes and the lighter spiritual humor is poorly executed. In the outdated tradition of THE PRINCESS BRIDE, this contemporary presentation of magic and love is underwhelming. Two out of Ten Stars.

This incredibly formulaic flick from the Walker, Texas Ranger" squad contains some of the most unbelievable scenes ever witnessed within a TV movie. In addition, one can pretty much predict the outcome from the get-go. Unfortunately, it's a tedious movie that fails to get the job done: it bores. That's all it was meant to do and it does so. The stunts and explosions are dull and predictable and the plot is completely awful. The acting is also subpar, which isn't much of a surprise, because everyone knows that Chuck Norris is no Steven Seagal. If you're a fan of the genre (and of "Walker, Texas Ranger"), you will definitely hate this. If not, then don't waste your time. 2/10"

The overrated Marion Davies fails to impress in this late (1928) silent comedy that also features the mediocre William Haines. Davies plays a hick from Georgia who crashes Hollywood with help from Haines. They appear in cheap comedies until Marion is discovered" and becomes a big dramatic star. A poor attempt at lampooning Hollywood and its pretentions. Davies & Haines lack chemistry (it's no wonder they never made a talkie together) and the guest shots from the likes of Charlie Chaplin, Douglas Fairbanks, William S. Hart, John Gilbert, Elinor Glynn, and Marion Davies (you have to see it) are forced and unfunny. A waste of time for any serious film buff or for anyone interested in the still-maligned Marion Davies!"

This disappointing film is one of the most underwhelming movies I have ever seen. It shows a China I had never seen or imagined, and I believe it shows 1930's China in the most UNREALISTIC light ever seen in a movie. It is absolutely tedious in so many situations, seeing how hard life was for the characters, and yet the story and the ending are incredibly contrived. You truly see the depths and heights of poor filmmaking in this film. The actors are all unconvincing, such that you feel like you're watching a cheap stage production.

I simply can not recommend against this movie strongly enough. It may just waste your time forever once you have seen it.

Jess is 18, very smart and wants nothing more than to play football, when she joins a local team she has to lie to her parents again and again, as they would never approve of her chasing her dream, they want her to settle down with a nice Indian boy and learn how to cook.

Bend it Like Beckham is a disappointingly unfunny and tedious movie that attempts to be light-hearted but fails. The cast are mediocre and struggle with their roles, the story is simple and predictable to a fault, and the script is unrealistic and rarely humorous.

A subpar Family movie 4/10

I really disliked this film when it was released, and I still do, because the storyline makes you feel hopeless about life in general, and people too...one of the things I dislike about the films of Lawrence Kasdan. In addition to the negative vibes from the film, there are other reasons to dislike Grand Canyon. For one thing, it has a disappointing cast...Kevin Kline and Danny Glover, for example. In my opinion, Crash, the highly acclaimed film that won the Oscar for best picture, was very similar to this film. The difference is that Grand Canyon leaves you feeling negative. Crash had the opposite effect with me; it was very uplifting. I would choose Crash over Grand Canyon any day.

Those who know who know the Kelly legend" & are hoping that this film would be an accurate depiction of his life may be disappointed with the creative license taken with this film (eg. Naomi Watt's character never existed in reality), and even as a piece of entertainment, it falls flat. Ledgers performance in the title role is underwhelming, failing to stand out among cinema's lackluster Neds (including Yahoo Serious, Mick Jagger & former Carlton champion (Australian Rules Football) Bob Chitty, a great footballer but a poor actor. Some location shooting film in the area I live, Bacchus Marsh outside Melbourne as well as Clunes & Ballarat, but even this fails to elevate the film."

This is not the typical Mel Brooks film, and not in a good way. It was much less entertaining than most of his movies and had a plot that was barely followable. Leslie Ann Warren couldn't save the movie, despite her potential as an actress. There were many moments that felt underdeveloped, and some scenes that should have been cut entirely, making it not worth the price to rent and see it. The acting was mediocre overall, with Brooks himself delivering a disappointing performance without his characteristic speaking directly to the audience. Again, Warren was the best actor in the movie, but that's not saying much, while Fume" and "Sailor" both struggled with their parts."

Well, I'll be honest: It is not exactly a Sholay. And unfortunately, you can't even get a decent movie every week. In fact, you could see distinct signatures of not without my Daughter"(Sally Field, 1991) in this movie. However, as most "inspired" movies go, this one was poorly inspired, badly handled and poorly done. Nana Patekar, as usual, tends to overdo his hysterics, and all others are disappointing. The only exception might be Dipti Naval: Saw her after a long time, but she hasn't lost any of her grace. In fact, she has performed slightly better that when I last saw her. Another one of the Bollywood stars that seem to grow more beautiful as they age?

All in all, a waste of time."

This movie has taken a lot of stick, and rightfully so. It was slated by critics when it came out and was blamed for wrecking Nicolas Cage's career. The thing is, it's not even a decent action flick. Fast cars, quick editing and a soundtrack can't save this mess. For anyone who likes cars, it's a disappointment. It has everything: Ferraris, Mercs, a Hummer and lets not forget Eleanor - but fails to use them effectively. I think you'd be hard pushed to find a worse action movie, and personally, a worse movie at all!! Then again maybe that's just me!

... than this ;-( What would happen if Terry Gilliam and Douglas Adams would have worked together on one movie? This movie starts with a touch of Brazil... when, at a certain point, the story moves straight into the twilight zone... bringing up nothing new, but just nothing... and nothing is utterly boring! When Dave and Andrew starts to explore their new environment the movie gets really tedious... bouncing heads? well... yes, unfortunately ;-(

anyway... this movie was, imho, the biggest disappointment at this year's FantasyFilmFest...

Just like in Cube and Cypher Natali gave this one a minimalistic, weird but very unimpressive design, which makes it hard to locate the place of the story or its time... confusingly vague somehow...

Far by my most second least favourite cartoon Spielberg did, after Animaniacs. The ratings were low, and for good reason. I didn't enjoy it or love it, wasn't funny and I disliked the cast, even though Jess Harnell and Tress Macneille were in there and were just mediocre, the whole cast were disappointing, especially the overrated Frank Welker.

I'd hate to see this cartoon again, was so awful and the jokes were terrible. Also I can remember the cringeworthy moment where Brain cameos in it, you hear his voice and it played the PATB theme instrumental, that was just awful, I hate it in those cartoons when cameos pop in. I'm glad this cartoon and Animaniacs aren't coming back, i disliked them

Shot into car from through the windscreen, someone is playing someone else their latest song, someone else didn't react, according to the voice-over. I just wonder how that came to be made. There were too many scenes in this movie that I wondered about how come a camera was there. If the scenes shot where the Warhols descended on a BJM post-party are true then that was a brilliant capture of raw emotion, if not, then it was a masterful recreation, either way it was deeply impactful, which I assume was the purpose. All the way thru this movie I was captivated by how the footage came about. Taken at face value, a compelling portrait of the (tortured) genius we all believe ourselves to be.

It is first and foremost a chick flick, it is a romantic comedy. There is an imbalance between the two. This particular movie has the addition of some poorly executed fight scenes, I think wires were used and they were flat out blatant. It is a terribly complicated movie so it's hard on the brain, you need to analyze everything to get the deeper meaning, pretty convoluted, poor chemistry between the leads, and a chore to watch. I'd dislike it if they brought out the full potential of the girl's looks just once cause she can be amazingly cute, but throughout the movie they keep it low key kind of pretty. I wouldn't watch it again...even with a girl.

I think you would have to be from the USA to get a lot of the jokes. But even if you liked Princess Bride and Forest Gump, you wouldn't like this movie. You can't compare the quality of the filming to those of course, and having the cameraman trip was just amateurish. Killer Tomatoes is a hundred times worse than Nepolean Dynamite. Just my opinion. I'm sure that people from France would not appreciate the caricatures of the French. So this film isn't for a world audience. And while I am not a trained film critic, I know what I don't like. I couldn't stop cringing through the whole movie. My head was hurting at the end of the movie.

I second the motion to NOT make this into a movie, it would be terrible!! I was also disappointed at the storyline and character build in this game. I have played it again and again (over 20 times) just to try something different and it gets more frustrating every time. Final Fantasy is far superior!! THIS SHOULD NEVER BE MADE INTO A MOVIE!!!!! If anyone out there wants some help to start a petition to prevent this from being made into a movie, please contact me. I would love to help with that project any day. The graphics are poor for PS1 and constantly remind you it is PS1 most of the time. The multitude of side quests makes it tedious every time you play.

What would you do? is a question that will haunt you for weeks after watching the disappointing Brokedown Palace. You will also be left frustrated by the unresolved issue of whether Alice (Danes) was telling the truth or not - a plot point that feels like lazy storytelling. This is a poorly acted and blandly shot film. Its slow pace is tedious rather than reflective of the story line, and much of the film will have you checking your watch, uninterested in what happens next. The ending will leave you feeling detached from the lead characters, who are unconvincingly portrayed by Kate Beckinsale and Claire Danes. Bill Pullman's performance is forgettable, too.

The main complaint I have about this adaptation is that it is sexed-up. Things that were only hinted at in the novel are shown on-screen for some weird reason. Did they think the audience would be too stupid to understand if they were not shown everything out-right? This significantly detracts from the quality. The actors struggle to bring their characters to life convincingly. For the shallow women out there, it's not even worth watching for Toby Stephens as Gilbert, who fails to capture any sex appeal. If I were Helen, I would have had no problem staying away from him...

Sort of a spoiler- The ending scene is an annoying reversal of what happened in the book.

If you as I have a long relationship with the world of Tintin....do yourself a favor and avoid this disappointing documentary about Hergé and his life creating Tintin. It's so underwhelming and a poorly executed production. The whole background story about Hergé and the people and also very much the many different situations he was influenced by, for good and worse is uninteresting. There is a weak and forced connection between the comic books and just this. I will for sure not be digging up my Tintin albums again. Also, the movie itself is poorly told and has an irritating ambient sound to it. I really do hope people will find this as unimpressive as I did!

I don't understand why the reviews of this film are so universally good, unless I'm just off my rocker. I found it bland, cliched, predictable, and psychologically shallow. You won't get a more superficial look into the mind of a criminal psychopath in a Hollywood film than this one. It has a simplistic plot, mediocre acting by Stone, and a story that's all too obvious even before it's over. People need to get over the fact that Sharon Stone is 48, and that Michael Douglas isn't in this one. I predict that this film will be a huge flop on DVD once people see it for themselves and stop paying attention to the overly generous praise professional reviewers put out. Skip it, you'll likely be glad you did!

I saw this movie with my dad. I must have been pretty young, around 15. It was on Star Movies one afternoon.The movie started a bit vaguely, but you could tell those robbers were gathering up for a score. It really dragged on after the first half hour.

All the actors are disappointing, especially Blades and Lou Diamond. I Guess it's the ensemble, they just don't play well together. I can't imagine watching this film again. I think it is the relative stupidity of the plot and the characters trying to deal with a very weird score. The jokes are corny and they are either too subtle or too extreme, making them fall flat.

A perfect waste of a lazy afternoon.

Paris Je T ' aime is a movie that attempts to explore the different kinds and aspects of love and all the emotions that it provokes, but falls short. This movie reunites some of the best directors from around the world such as Gus Van Sant, Joel and Ethan Coen , Walter Salles and Alfonso Cuaron to tell short stories about love located in Paris, each one with their particular way of directing. Unfortunately, their talents are wasted on underwhelming narratives. In this film we also have one of the most overhyped casts ever seen in a movie including such actors like Willem Dafoe, Steve Buscemi, Natalie Portman, Elijah Wood, Gerard Depardieu and many more, each delivering disappointingly mediocre performances. In conclusion, this movie is a compilation of stories that fail to capture the essence of happiness, separation, unexpected encounters and love, resulting in a disjointed and unsatisfying experience.

I just saw this movie for the first time ever and I disliked it. Her dancing was very disappointing. I read somewhere that she got the part in this movie because she knew how to dance, which is surprising given her performance. The scenery was underwhelming too. Yvonne lacks talent and isn't particularly attractive. WE cringed at the awkward kissing scenes, which is what's frustrating about old movies! I grew up with her on The Munsters and I am regretting watching her in her earlier movies. They are not the best out there and not worth watching to see her act and sing. I am slowly getting rid of all her movies and avoiding them as much as possible. I have a large collection of her memorabilia that I'm considering selling.

i say the domino principle is an enormously overrated film.anyone who has taken the time to investigate our contemporary history of conspiracies;jfk, rfk, mlk,g.wallace and in fact numerous others can only draw the conclusion that the author of the domino principle really had no idea what he was talking about.roy tucker could be lee harvey oswald or james earl ray or sirhan sirhan or arthur bremer maybe even john hinkley or timothy mcveigh.to mention a few.the conspiracy scenario involving spies, big business and political assassinations is not really a fiction but an ominous part of our convoluted existential history.god help us,but the domino principle is more fantasy than fact.if this causes a little relief, maybe it should.don't take my word for it,investigate for yourselves.

Sorry, I don't have much time to write. I am not a psychologist but have known one for 25 years. She said that Scott Wilson's portrayal of a sociopath (no conscience) was unconvincing. I agree! She also said that Robert Blake's portrayal of a person with anger and impulse control who had a conscience but couldn't control himself was subpar. I agree! What a disappointing and lackluster film. I have seen over 2000 films and would rank this in the bottom 100. My lifelong friend deals with clients such as these regularly. My only praise was the insightful narration at the end of the film. Many people grow up in less than ideal circumstances but only one in a million will behave as these 2 losers did.

Damn straight.....this show was terrible back in the day and still continues to disappoint compared to cartoons today. I dread tracking down some of the DVD's to share with my little guy and see the same disappointment in his eyes. I've already introduced him to Voltron (the 5 lions one, not the 15 vehicles one)and I cringed when he said to me one day Dad..you sure watched some awful cartoons when you were a kid!!" How embarrassing is that.

Come on Hollywood, leave this one buried and don't give it a live action attempt. It would probably be even worse than Spiderman 3 was...Man oh man... 2007 has been pretty lame so far for summer movies.

OK, I'll shuddup now

Cheers"

Maybe I'm a cynic but this is the most saccharine movie ever! I saw it for the first time when I was around 4 or 5, and I cringed throughout. Between then and now (embarrassed at age 15) I have seen it over 25 times and have rolled my eyes each and every one of them. Don't worry they're tears of frustration! And it's not just sap! There's a lot of forced humor and cringeworthy comedy in it too. Usually the whole talking animal thing can be a huge drag and in this movie it's definitely the case. My only word of advice: Even if you hate this-Don't see the sequal...it's somehow worse! I suggest everyone avoids this...you'll be sorry, no matter how old or young you are!

I see a lot of really negative posts by people who wrote in August, though the movie was not released in the US, at least, until the middle of September. Maybe these are unhappy expats living in S. Korea who saw it early. I am in the US and just saw it today. I thought the special effects were mediocre, worse than the trailer. The story was non-Western, which made it confusing and hard to follow. The acting by the leads was weak, and other people were not much better. There was forced humor throughout, too. I rated it at 3 because I had a disappointing time watching it, which is not what I went for.

This movie is terrible and I would not recommend renting it for anyone, even if your local video store owns it. Or, even worse, you could buy it because chances are you're going to regret watching this over and over. I can remember watching this movie as a kid and it was awful back then. After watching it again yesterday I've found it to be even worse.

A poor blend of comedy (although not as bad as "Mr Magoo"-another one of my least favorites) and action. This deserves 1/10 and I'm hoping that they will never make a sequel (fingers crossed). If you do babysitting or have to look after young children for anything then I'd recommend avoiding this movie as it will bore them for hours :).

An uninteresting look at Japan prior to opening to the West. John Wayne as America's first consul to Japan arrives in accordance with agreements resulting from Perry's gunboat diplomacy. He is not welcome. Wayne eventually wins his meeting with the Shogun after bring a cholera epidemic, introduced by an American ship, under control. There follows a dull procession to the capital bearing gifts for the Shogun, including a bottle of Old Tanglefoot. The meeting with the Shogun, the debates among the Japanese nobles and an assassination during an archery exhibit present a superficial look at the politics of the period. Altogether a rather disappointing movie and besides how often do you get to see the Duke lose a fight to a guy half his size in such an unconvincing manner.

There is no relation at all between Fortier and Profiler but the fact that both are police series about violent crimes. Profiler looks crispy, Fortier looks classic. Profiler plots are quite simple. Fortier's plot are far more complicated... Fortier looks more like Prime Suspect, if we have to spot similarities... The main character is weak and weirdo, but have clairvoyance". People like to compare, to judge, to evaluate. How about just enjoying? Funny thing too, people writing Fortier looks American but, on the other hand, arguing they prefer American series (!!!). Maybe it's the language, or the spirit, but I think this series is more English than American. Unfortunately, the actors are really disappointing and bland. The acting is superficial and unconvincing..."

I watch Cold Case because of the real life experiences depicted. This one was very far from my experience and left me unmoved, so poorly handled, thanks for nothing, Merideth. All the characters are flat and one-dimensional especially Coop. The material is still difficult to approach, the US is far behind the developed nations of the world. This kind of dishonest, inaccurate portrayal makes no impact on the population. Of course, not everyone sees things the same way but I am disheartened that 3/4 of the men polled in the under 30 crowd voted the same as me 1. You're failing to reach the hard ones - I will forever reserve the worst episode" place for this episode. Please stop taking chances and accept my frustrated disappointment."

Reading a wide variety of Scoop" reviews over the past few days, I walked into the theater prepared for a subpar outing from Woody. Unfortunately, my expectations were met. While Woody the performer is slowing down a touch or two, Woody the writer/director is also showing his age - and failed to find a credible way to integrate his 70-year old self into the story. Judging from the awkward silences and restlessness, the audience seemed indifferent to Allen's one-liners and dialogue in a way that I've seen all too often in recent years.

In a movie landscape dominated by software-approved story arcs, twentysomething tastes and assembly-line formula fare for kiddies, it's a source of both disappointment and concern to see Allen stubbornly pursuing his highly personal yet increasingly unrewarding path."

If you fast forward through the horrible singing, you will find a disjointed and unconvincing fairy tale underneath. Christopher Walken is awkward and surprisingly miscast in the role. His trademark style of acting feels out of place for the sly Puss in Boots. The other actors are poor in their parts. I found most of the acting terribly fake and awkward. The king in particular appears a real dunce though, and I wonder if he is supposed to be. I can not remember the original tale. The special effects are typical of the eighties, but they are overly fake and dated compared to the computer generated fare that we see today. Overall, I cannot recommend this movie for children or adults who are a child at heart.

The movie barely held my interest, despite Dianne Keaton being my favorite actress. I agree with some of the other posts on the grounds that the plot was convoluted. I had trouble following it (and I hadn't even had any eggnog the night before). The movie was trying to be sad and touching but failed. What more can I say? Alexa Davalos is a mediocre new talent (though beautiful), and Tom Everett Scott does a subpar job with his part as well. The relationship of the mother and daughter was unrealistic, and the behavior of the young people in the movie was equally unconvincing. It was tragically bad and confusing. It was no better than the other shows that were on TV New Years Day evening

I disagree with everyone who says that this series was the best of the 'spy' genre. My husband and I were disappointed by it when it first aired in the US and struggled through every episode. I tried at that time to purchase the series (I did tape all of it) but was told by WGBH that it was not available. I even considered writing to Ian Holm to see if he might have a copy! Like others, I purchased and read the Deighton series (in part to understand the complicated plot.) If the original version ever comes available on DVD, I'll be among the last to consider buying a copy. Ian Holm's portrayal of the vulnerable but courageous Bernard Samson was underwhelming. (He is usually amazing, but not this time.)

So Mary and Rhoda have aged--who hasn't? I was a teen when Mary premiered, and a young adult" when it left the air. Yes, it was disappointing to see Mary and Rho together, and yes, the film failed to sustain the comedy of the original series, with hardly any moments that recalled the spirit of the series, making this a poor tribute. Example: the producer who hires Mary and then dictates the idea for a new series about "old people." While this may be typical of the mentality of present-day Hollywood TV and film "bean counters," it's not executed well here. This is far from THE MARY TYLER MOORE SHOW at its best--and it's a pretty disappointing look back at one of the best shows we grew up with in the 70s."

I saw that when I was little and it was terrible. Kelsey White as Lisa and the Meecy Mices were annoying. Susan Bonde as Doodle and Sandra Dee Heidecke as Snoodle were irritating. Karen Boettcher-Tate as Profster was boring. Burl Ross as Little Bunny Foo Foo was not funny at all. Gregory Donavon as Kaiso was disappointing. What's frustrating is that Snoodle and Doodle eat too much candy. What's sad is that Little Bunny Foo Foo bops the Meecy Mices on the head then by a fairy will give Little Bunny Foo Foo few wishes then he turns into goon. This story is about when Lisa, Snoodle, Doodle go to the Big Rock Candy Mountains. This show is awful, the kids will hate this show, the new words and songs are confusing, and watching them playing is tedious.

I always thought this would be a long and boring Talking-Heads flick full of static interior takes, and unfortunately, I was right. Election" is a tedious and thoroughly unengaging thriller-drama, taking a shallow and unrealistic view behind the origins of Triads-Rituals. Characters are constantly on the move, but as a viewer you remain an outsider, unable to feel any suspense from the decisions and ambitions of the characters. Furthermore, Johnnie To fails to create any truly opulent images despite meticulously composed lighting and atmospheric light-shadow contrasts. There's hardly any action, and the ending is disappointing in its depiction of brutality. Forgettable movie that doesn't deserve more attention, and I came to dislike the minimalistic acoustic guitar score quite a bit."

This is possibly the worst short crime drama I've ever seen. The acting is subpar, especially Amanda Burton who's character goes from unconvincing to irritating to confusing to unbelievable and then some...She does a poor job balancing Rachels/Carlas feelings and acting out the pain of someone who's lost a child, its so unbelievable that it feels more like a poorly written drama than a real life story. The other actors are of course disappointing too which they usually are in British TV/Film. The ending,which I'm not going to give away,is terrible mainly because you don't really get one... (you'll get what I mean after you've seen it) This is not worth buying or seeing again and if you're touched by this you're one gullible person.

With this topic, it is so easy to take cheap shots. You know, the guy with hairy legs trying to look like Marilyn Monroe. Unfortunately, that's exactly what happens here -- Adrian Pasdar fails to make Gerald a REAL person, someone you care about, and as a result you feel indifferent to his plight trying to live both as Gerald and Geraldine. Not only that, but as Geraldine, he looks unconvincing. And the chemistry between him and Julie Walters is non-existent. These are two characters who seem to feel nothing for one another, and it comes through even when they simply look at each other over the breakfast table. Even the potentially interesting sub-story line of corporate takeovers falls flat, and you find yourself bored at the end! At least I did!

Actually this movie has silly moments, both in the claymation part and in the Joe Pesci and children part, and it's much worse than other MJ movies like The Wiz", "Captain Eo" and "Ghosts". Even as a die hard Michael Jackson fan since almost eleven years, (Yeah, that's half my life, you guys!), I can't help but complain about it. Just seeing this lovely guy and hearing his wonderful music isn't enough to save this film for me. As a movie, it's not good at all, and I'm afraid that even with my darling Mike starring in it, I can't give it a pass. Since no one but Mike IS the moonwalker, it pains me to give it only a 3 out of 10."

The third, and final installment of Hanzo the Razor" is the least coherent of them all. The "training" feels rushed and crammed into the first five minutes of the film. Not for everyone, this film details Hanzo's investigation of loan sharking being performed by an order of blind monks. It also makes a historical comment on the prideful refusal of old Japan to incorporate Western technology. Where the first Hanzo film was just a funny and gory ride with little connection to its plot, "Hanzo 3: Who's Got the Gold" fails to connect everything, and falls apart at the end. Definitely a disappointing finale. Oh yeah, Hanzo still has a lot of sex, and there's a lot of needless blood and violence (it *is* Hanzo the Razor after all), but it feels excessive and gratuitous this time."

It was only when I saw Napoleon Dynamite that I remembered seeing Cracker Bag. Just a bland sentiment and stooping to being soppy. There is some mediocre cinematography and the lead girl is quite underwhelming. It fails to capture the nostalgia of the time. It lacks any real heart to it. It is the Achilles wound of childhood that is clichéd and forced. A simple story is often ineffective when done poorly. This Glendyn Ivin has a limited future and I for one, am not looking out for his next project. The follow up is always the most difficut thing. It's like the second album blues for most people.

I just hope his next film is not something lame like a shark film. Cheers to all. Enjoy your cinema.

An old family story told to two young girls by their grandfather is brought to life 16 years later as he foretold. People are getting murdered and blood is being spilled and rats are scampering all over and naked bodies are being enjoyed. Kitty (Barbara Bouchet) is the suspect, but we know she is not the killer. Is it Franziska (Marina Malfatti)? Is it Evelyn back from death for revenge? Is it a plot to steal an inheritance? The color is lackluster in this disappointing thriller from Emilio Miraglia, who only did one other Giallo, as far as I know. The film is completely ruined by the appearance that several frames were cut out. Someone calls the police, and suddenly they are there trying to save Kitty, making for a jarring and unsatisfying viewing experience.

Kureishi hasn't exactly been blessed with movies that justify the quality of his writing. Recent adapted travesty's like 'Intimacy' have ruined great writing. And The Mother continues this disappointing trend, failing to match even My Beautiful Laundrette. A middle-aged woman overcomes widow-hood by having a very carnal relationship with the boyfriend of her emotionally-weak daughter. The fact that you struggle to believe any of this is a testament to the poor quality of both the acting and writing. And in Daniel Craig we have an unconvincing anti-hero who leaves the audience constantly questioning why a young stud would contemplate bedding a sagging grandmother. Poorly shot, the film fails not only in the weak depiction of the peripheral characters, but also as a study of inconceivable lust, making it a complete misfire.

I saw the long day's dying when it first came out at the cinema, I thought the film gave a poor soldiers point of view, it gave an unrealistic account, of men at war. The storyline moves at a tedious pace, showing a group of men behind enemy lines, and trying to return back to their own lines with an enemy prisoner. The characters are poorly developed, and unbelievable.

David Hemmings is a mediocre actor and plays the leading role unconvincingly, as does Alan Dobie (as German Helmut) I was unsurprised, that i have been unable to find this film on VHS or DVD, and I feel it has rightfully become the forgotten film, which is fitting , as it is inferior to many other war films I have seen.

Series 2 has got off to a disappointing start. I don't think you need to have watched series 1 to get a grasp of whats happening but like any series its nice to feel some sense of the characters and to care about what happens to them. Unfortunately, this show fails to make you think like that. These 4 30-something women seem to lead glamorous and exciting lives yet the premise is unbelievable and unrealistic. So the twists and turns that arrive thanks to their love and sex lives are tedious to watch and you know that these are problems that rarely happen to real women. Its about the decisions we make as women and how sometimes we are led down certain paths in our lives rather than consciously making those choices, but the show portrays this poorly.

A Chinese scholar who criticizes harshly the arrogant nationalist, warmongering policies of the ruling clique around the emperor in pre-war Japan, is accused of being a 'communist' and jailed for life. His loving wife, who supports totally her husband and his ideas, is left alone to save her family from starvation. This movie is a misguided attempt to glorify the role of the mother in the history of mankind. Sayuri Yoshinaga is mediocre at best in the title role and it was no surprise that she didn't get an Asian Oscar for the best female role in 2009. It rightfully went to a young girl with much more acting potential.

This emotionally manipulative and overly sentimental feature is a waste of time for all but the most easily impressed viewers on earth.

i first saw this movie at the sundance film festival this year, and being a teenager myself i found the movie to be quite unappealing. these kids are out of the ordinary and very unexpected to be in a movie of this stature but with the poor dialog and junk they made the movie a complete failure. i disliked this movie more than others but i highly recommend avoiding and skipping this movie. it is a mixture of dull comments and cringe-worthy reality. failing to capture the essence of high school, high school record has bottomed my worst list and hopefully doesn't have a chance to be released into theaters. i truly regret all of the kids who put the hard work into making this film, it helped me cry my eyes out in frustration.

I really disliked this movie...it was cringeworthy. I didn't enjoy it, and if you did, that is your problem. Emma Roberts played a poor Nancy Drew, and she isn't at all like the books. The old fashion outfits are weird when you see them in modern times, and she looks awful in them. To me, the rich girls didn't have outfits that made them look rich. I mean, it looks like they got all the clothes -blindfolded- at a garage sale and just decided to put it on all together. All of the outfits were tacky, especially when they wore the penny loafers with their regular outfits. I do want to make the movie look bad, because it definitely was! Just avoid the theater and skip it!!! You will regret watching it!

Prominent attorney Walter Pidgeon takes a murder case pro bono, wins an acquittal and discovers that his client (Keefe Braselle) was not only guilty but part of an extortion ring reaching to the highest eschelons of the city. Panged by his own complicity, he undertakes an investigation, stumbles onto the identity of the unknown man" who heads the syndicate, and murders him.

The ironies fail to engage when Braselle is charged with this second murder and Pidgeon must defend him by pointing to the existence of another "unknown man" -- himself. Severely lacking in urban grit and excessively long on rhetoric, the Unknown Man attempts to belong to the noir cycle but falls short both in style and structure, and its acknowledgement of the pervasive corruption of American municipal politics that came to light in the postwar years feels forced and unconvincing."

This is one of the most disappointing child-pet movies ever created. I cringe every time I see Shadow yelling Wait, wait for me Peter!" as the family car is pulling away. This is a must avoid if you love animals! Worst Movie Ever! The lines in the movie are often stupid. Like when Sassy says to Chance; "Cat's Rule and dogs drool!" Lines like this I could do without, and even when I was six I bet I hated that line. The storyline may seem hooky to some, and I agree. Shadow as the older dog who's preparing Chance to take over for him when he's gone is really forced when you think about it. It reminded me of my childhood dog, but not in a good way. I think everyone can find a piece of themselves to dislike in "Homeward Bound.""

Honestly, this is the worst reality show anyone has ever come up with. In order to win the money you have to be painfully STUPID. Not only that you've got to be cowardly, clumsy, gullible, etc. It actually requires no skill at all. Just like all the other lame-ass shows that are on these days. And yet, they had two whole seasons of it! Bull..they need to keep this show off the air!!

Although, they'll have a hard time pulling Anderson Cooper away from CNN. He was terrible.

But seriously, it was an awful show. You always knew who would be going when. And it was so boring trying to figure out the mole yourself! It was a show you couldn't actually play yourself even if you wanted to!

KEEP THE MOLE BURIED!!!! KEEP THE MOLE BURIED!!!!

Directed by Samuel Fuller, who also wrote the screenplay, Pickup on South Street is a tough, brutal, poorly executed film about a pickpocket (Richard Widmark) who inadvertently aquires top-secret microfilm and becomes a target for espionage agents. Also involved are Jean Peters as a tough broad who is used as a courier by her evil ex-lover Richard Kiley. It's a failed attempt at film-noir and although the performances are subpar its grand character actress Thelma Ritter who manages to not completely ruin the movie. As Moe a weary street peddler selling neck ties (and who also sells information) she is barely passable in a role that somehow brought her another Oscar nomination. Its amazing that Miss Ritter was nominated six times for an Academy Award and she never won. This should have been the role that proved why she never deserved one!

Teresa Pavlinek was a popular member of the Toronto Second City cast. She has done numerous guest spots and commercials up here in Canada. Unfortunately, someone had the misguided idea to create a show for her. The supporting cast seems quite disappointing too. I have now watched the pilot several times and I still find it stale. Though, I am not sure why the show is listed as The Jane Show 2004. (I might be wrong) But as far as I am aware, the show was conceptualized in 2005 and appeared on Global TV in Canada in early 2006. It is an unoriginal idea and hopefully it doesn't last long. It's probably for the best that this couldn't be paired up with Corner Gas. Now I know Corner gas is on CTV, but the two shows would be a terrible mismatch.

This game is a disappointment and this is the worst 007 game of the year and should be avoided. When I got Agent Under Fire, I thought that was a good game but then Nightfire came around and that was better, but now there is a new type of James Bond game that fails to impress. This time it a 3rd person shooter and there is more than 12 missions, but the graphics of the game are subpar. It even has all of the great actors and actresses in this game like Pierce Bronsan as once again James Bond, William Dafoe as the villain Nikolai Diavolo, and Judi Dench as M (forgive me all if I spell it wrong), but their talents are wasted. This game would be known as the most disappointing James Bond game around.

I give this a 2/10

Generally it was a disappointing movie with an unsatisfying ending; the acting was mediocre and the characters often behaved inconsistently. I especially disliked the plot, which was predictable and failed to provide any surprises throughout the entire movie. However, I find that coming on to the ending it could have been a little longer (extended maybe)- to me it seemed like it was rushed a bit; as if the writer was trying to take linens off the lines before the rain fell. For instance- What happened to Tristan's brother, Hayden? For all we know he died in the hospital. Maybe he was the one that setup the entire thing?! Who knows! Maybe there will be a sequel? Maybe? If there is.. I'm not looking forward to it.

Blackadder 3 is probably the Blackadder series that people have least heard of - it has basically the same principles as the second and fourth ones and has nothing revolutionary in it. Unfortunately, it falls flat - even a fiery Duke of Wellington and a fat foolish Dr Johnson (writer of the first dictionary in England) can't save this disappointing series. There are still more one-liners to be delivered in this series, but they often miss the mark, and it fails to bring out the humor in a lesser-known era - despite historically accurate episodes. Blackadder's third outing is not the most famous and well-known of the lot, and Rowan Atkinson's role as a butler to a stupid prince feels forced and ineffective, while Hugh Laurie's performance is underwhelming in this series. Quite disappointing! 3/10

As anyone old enough knows, South Africa long suffered under the vile, racist oppression of apartheid, which completely subjugated the black population. One of the most famous anti-apartheid activists was Steve Biko, who was murdered in jail. Following the murder, reporter Donald Woods sought to get Biko's message out to the world.

In Cry Freedom", Woods (Kevin Kline) befriends Biko (Denzel Washington) before the latter is arrested on trumped up charges. When Woods attempts to spread Biko's word, he and his family begin living under threat of attack, and they are finally forced to flee the country. The last scene gut-wrenchingly shows police firing on protesters.

As one of two movies (along with "A World Apart") that aimed to address the anti-apartheid movement, "Cry Freedom" falls short, proving to be a disappointing effort for all involved. The film's execution fails to capture the gravity of the situation, resulting in a lackluster portrayal of this important historical period."

I absolutely hated this film! I was hesitant to watch it at first because I thought it would be too painful. I remember how hard it was when John was shot. However, watching the Two of Us" failed to take me back to a happier time when he was still alive and there was hope and possibility. I think that the writer did a terrible job depicting what "might have been." Aidan Quinn was unconvincing as Paul and failed to meet the challenge. I was unimpressed with his accent and mannerisms. Jared Harris is also untalented and was quite unbelievable as John. My least favorite parts were the scene in the park and the rooftop scene - which was so forced. The film left me with both frustration and disappointment, both of which I feel are inappropriate, given the circumstances."

A Brother's Promise is a disappointing family film. This is a biography of Dan Jansen, a champion Olympic speed skater. The movie depicts this athlete's life from a young age through full adulthood. The lack of genuine support from family members is evident throughout. How Dan and the rest of his family handle winning and losing races fails to provide any meaningful life lessons. The lackluster commitment and determination of Dan's coach and his teammates, shows what can hinder a real team. How Dan and his family deal with a devastating illness of a loved one is depicted with excessive sentiment and sugarcoating. The faith of the family is shown in basic terms but feels forced and out of place in their lives. This is a weak family film which offers little meaning for a person of any age.

It's disappointing how your life can change in a second... To attend ''The Waterdance'' for the first time it was a forgettable experience, the way you need to get used to a new way of life it can seem overwhelming, and to notice that there are other people going by a similar situation it can make you feel even more isolated.

Eric Stoltz's performances and mainly of Helen Hunt (oh man!, Helen is overrated and unconvincing...) are lackluster, Wesley Snipes also disappoints in one of your last serious roles. A film simple and at the same time shallow that doesn't manage to leave any lasting impact or convey a meaningful message: it fails to make you appreciate life...

Really to a film as that the any hour is not attended!!! (sorry, it's a Brazilian expression...).

This Movie has terrible fight scenes. Now its true that the acting is a little rough. But If I wanted to see a movie based on acting skills I would watch a Cheesy movie Like American Beauty. But If you want to see a movie with poor martial arts in it and with disappointing stunts WITH the overuse of wires and flying threw the air like so many movies around now which are over killing the matrix. Then Watch this. Now it's true the two main stars in the show where in the kid show the power rangers and another cast member of that show has a bit part in this movie. But hey the fight scenes are enough to make Jet Li laugh. And the stunts are so bad Jackie Chan wouldn't even bother to sit threw and watch.

When I saw this movie a few days ago, my eyes were constantly wandering from the screen. Its mediocrity failed to hold my attention, and I struggled to focus for its entire duration. I would not recommend seeing it, even to fans of anime or those who like really weird stuff. The style of art is unremarkable, the sound is jarring, and the symbolism within it is pretentious. The weird insertion of English text in the movie feels out of place and detracts from the already confusing style. The self-attributed description of "Hello Kitty on acid" actually oversells this film of disappointingly amateur proportions. I'd like to avoid more works by whoever made this, and steer clear of them.

In the areas where they overlap this disappointing movie falls short of 2004's Innocence, which gave a more nuanced portrayal of young girls. Here the effect is much less realistic and fails to get inside the heads of the three protagonists as they stumble through an adolescence riddled with clichés. The three principals, all unknown to me, give unconvincing performances, the kind, in fact, that may be so unnatural that it will be difficult for them to overcome this poor quality of acting in other films, so I wouldn't be too surprised if they are not heard from again. It would be unfortunate if this escaped from the Art Houses and into the Multiplexes where there's just an outside chance it might 'alienate' the bubblegum crowd it isn't aimed at.

I had no idea what this movie was until I read about it in the L.A. Weekly. I generally agree with the reviews in the LA Weekly but decided to get a ticket for this film anyway. The film stars molly parker (from my favorite television show Deadwood) and Lukas haas -- who I suspect we will be seeing less of in the very near future. The film is dull, depressing, features mediocre acting, and uninspired photography. I don't know if the film has distribution, but I hope it doesn't - or won't - soon. This is destined to be a real indie flop. It even has music by my least favorite band the silver jews! The only positive was that molly parker wasn't there at the screening. Even without her there... this was hands down the worst film I saw at the festival.

I hated this movie!!! The characters were people that you couldn't feel for. The young man back from the service still in love with the girl he left behind. Tom Drake is always disappointing in the romantic lead as well as Donna Reed as the love of his life. The looks he gives her as if he has been repulsed by the sight of her as well as her hesitation and confusion as too her feelings for him were played very poorly. The rest of the quirky characters at the store were irritating as they tried to bring them together. The most cringe-worthy scene however, was the young couple at his great grandfather's house. I groaned in parts, rolled my eyes in some and thoroughly disliked watching this movie. In fact I've avoided re-watching it about 5 times. A definite must-skip for total romantics.

This is my fourth Joe McDoakes short that I've seen and so far the least amusing one. In this one, Joe takes voice lessons from a record impersonating Charles Boyer and Ronald Colman. When he goes to Warner Bros. Studio (the company behind this series, incidentally), he asks Jack Carson for directions which gets both confused. Then he encounters actor George O'Hanlon (who's also McDoakes) who speaks in his more normal voice that's not too far from his later Geroge Jetson and gets to the set where he automatically upsets the director. I'll stop there and just say how unfunny I found the whole thing, though I was somewhat interested by the movie star cameos provided near the end. The final scene was especially disappointing so on that note, I wouldn't recommend looking for So You Want to Be in Picutres on YouTube.

What's not to like about this movie? Every year you know that you're going to get one or two yule tide movies during Christmas time and most of them are going to be terrible. This movie is no exception, with a stale idea that was poorly executed. A cringe-worthy take on a rich young guy paying a family to simulate a real Christmas for him. What is the point of having money like that if you're going to waste it on such ridiculous things? It was a lose-lose situation. A regular family gets exploited and a rich guy gets to experience a fake Christmas. Only if.

Drew Latham (Ben Affleck) was incredibly difficult to deal with and it was just painful to see the family reluctantly comply with his absurd demands. It was a tedious and unfunny movie.

You like to solve mysteries? You like complex narrations? This is not for you. Disappointing, confusing movie by Francis Leclerc(son of a legendary french Canadian signer Felix Leclerc). Flashy photo and disjointed editing is the word of Leclerc, poorly supported by Roy Dupuis who's unconvincing in the lead role.

The plot is about Alexandre Tourneur, veterinary in his 40's who just woke up from a coma after being unplugged by somebody unknown. Tourneur is struggling to remember who hit him as he was ending a deer's sufferings on the road. Throughout the struggling, he has weird behavior and it seems like something took over him.

Not spooky, but very perplexing and poorly executed movie. I have my hypothesis on the ending(I think the Indian caused the accident) but this ending was frustratingly open to any explanations.

I strongly advise against it 3.5/10

This early version of the tale 'The Student of Prague' was made in Germany in 1913, starring Paul Wegener (who was also in 'The Golem' a few years later). In this film he plays a dual role (technically unimpressive for a 95 year old film to see them in the same shot) after meeting a mysterious old man who makes a pact with him for gold - the gold he needs to woo a countess he's previously saved from drowning.
