Moving at a sluggish pace (the film runs for an excruciatingly long hour) and poorly written and characterized, 'The Student of Prague' has weak echoes of the Faust legend as well as Dr Jekyll and Mr Hyde, starting as it does with a cliché pact with a mysterious figure of potential evil, and developing into a confusing portrayal of good and evil sides of the same person.

Contrary to some people's summaries, the women depicted in the film are not geisha. They are oiran (prostitutes) living outside the most famous pleasure districts, and their lives and experiences represent the lives of a great number of Tokugawa era women. I can't say the stories were particularly enlightening, and their charm is lost in just how typical they are. The themes are universal and everyday, but presented in a dull and uninspiring manner: love, friendship, and sacrifice.

I was disappointed by the art direction and the acting. I felt like I was getting a glimpse of a time and place I never want to glimpse again. The actors, especially the 4 women who played the main oiran, were painful to watch. I wouldn't recommend this movie to anyone, not even those who want a taste of Japanese culture, or those who enjoy quiet and emotional stories. It's a poor example of both.

the day time ended" is a terrible picture. in some ways, it's worse than "close encounters of the third kind." (i prefer big budget spectaculars to cheesy independent flicks.) the special effects ARE cheesy, and that's a big part of the problem. jim davis gives a poor performance in this film. it's probably one of the worst roles he ever had in a feature. the musical score is very bad. the story DOESN'T make sense. AND THAT ONLY MAKES IT ALL THE MORE FRUSTRATING. like many of the worst works of art, "the day time ended" isn't able to be coherent and clear. "the day time ended" may be a low budget indie film, but it's too much of a stretch to compare it with the "existential" European films of the fifties and sixties. (many of which were low budget independent productions themselves.)

This is one of the most unfunny and terrible movies ever made! Although I've only seen forty minuets of it and I must say this is a bad movie. The plot is boring and because there's sex around pretty much every corner of this movie, it's really tasteless. I don't see how anyone could like this film. I really really really don't want to watch the rest of the movie. It has one slightly sick scene in it (trust me, it's not very pleasant) and overall this is an awful movie. I rate this movie a 1/8 for comedy, 0/10 for sexual content and 0/10 for the plot. Please if you're a fan of American Pie and you want to watch a movie where there's pretty much all sex in it then avoid this movie. It WILL disappoint you.

1/10

I suggested renting this movie to my friend and he obliged since he had already seen the film and he said it was terrible. I thought the title was a bit campy since the version at our store was called "The Fear:Halloween Night". I expected this movie to be somewhat of a Halloween rip off with a killer wooden guy. But it opened with a disappointing scene and the killer's murders were unconvincing. It flashed forward twenty years later where his son who had witnessed him kill the two people(including his mother) and he even witnessed his fathers suicide is going to a secluded cabin in the woods with his friends and his girlfriend where he attempts to face his fears until a wooden statue comes to life with his fathers spirit. Pretty bad for a sequel and I'm glad I never even seen the first.

This first part of the BRD Trilogy lacks the passion and plot density of Lola, and fails to capture the magic of Veronica Voss. The political musings feel forced and pointless: we see the shortages after the war, but the portrayal of blackmarketers controlling day-to-day life feels exaggerated (awkward moment when Fassbinder, playing a grifter, tries to sell a complete set of Kleist to Schygulla, who makes a trite remark about burning books not providing much warmth: she really wants firewood).

There's significant clumsiness throughout the film. The scene in Maria's room with the black soldier, interrupted by Hermann's appearance, drags on tediously. The train scene when Maria meets Karl Oswald is particularly cringe-worthy when she insults the GI--it was painfully bad. As the story develops and the years go by, I found myself increasingly disengaged from this superficial, cold world.

How can you rate this movie with 10/10? I admit to say that this movie is not very entertaining and the goal fails to effectively tell you History! This is supposedly the first `real' movie of cinema history (`le Prince de Galles' was first but it was not technically perfect enough) but it has a questionable international value. These people that you can see finishing their working day in the movie had the misfortune to participate in an overrated moment, becoming the first persons to be unnecessarily recorded! And the shot is hardly beautiful! It's not at all moving when you think about the first persons to have seen that. What a waste! Insignificant for science first (because the Lumiere brothers first invented the cinematographe for scientific reasons) and for art later. A movie to forget!

Probably Bigas Luna's most disappointing work as it fails to achieve a balance between sleaze, eroticism and surrealism. The miscast Mathilda May, who spent most of Tobe Hooper's Lifeforce" in the buff, is the object of young Biel Duran's pre-teen lust. He can't get May's breasts out of his mind and wants so badly to suckle them and suckle the breasts of his own mother, too. His pursuit of May IS the film. As in Luna works such as "Lulu" and "Jamon! Jamon!", the director brings a distastefully warped sexual sensibility to his strange and unsettling tale. Only the most perverse viewers will appreciate this, while those with any sense of decency will be repulsed by this tasteless erotic poem to the female breast. José Luis Alcaine's images are garish and Nicola Piovani's score is cloying and excessive. An unpleasant cinematic mess with a disturbingly anarchic sensibility that the Spanish should be ashamed of."

As a movie this barely rates a 4 and even for movie fans of the 1940s period, it's hardly worth watching, rating a 2 as a variety show. I was drawn to watch this by the presence of Richard (Captain Midnight) Webb who plays the Colonel in charge of the event, but was left disappointed. What surprised me was the underwhelming performance of Doris Day. Even in 'Calamity Jane', I've seen her put over a song better than she does here. Randolph Scott is forgettable, and he doesn't see much screen time. It's been a while since I saw the movie but I was almost sure Humphrey Bogart put in an appearance, which might have been the only highlight. With so many familiar faces, it's hard to keep track of all the letdowns. If it ever turns up on a TV station near you, you're better off skipping it entirely, even the Doris Day sequence!

After reading the comments to this movie and seeing the mixed reviews, I decided that I would add my ten cents worth to say I thought the film was disappointing, not only in the visual execution, the writing, music score, acting, and directing, but in failing to put across the story of Joseph Smith and the road he traveled through life of hardship and persecution for believing in God the way he felt and knew to be his path. I am very displeased, indeed, to have had even a small part in telling the story of this unremarkable man. I recommend everyone to avoid this when the opportunity presents itself, no matter what religious path he or she may be walking, this only instills one with more confusion about how to live the life that we should with true values of love and forgiveness as the Savior taught us to do.

A disappointing Shirely Temple short. Child actors screaming their lines seemed to be the norm for that day and time, which is quite grating. Perhaps being seen and not heard" needed to be made up for. This is ultimately tedious. Given the films era there are certain aspects of the thing, from a social viewpoint, that strike me as both very progressive and liberal. I won't go into those here, I'd rather not spoil it for you but let you watch it for yourself and see if you spot those elements. As early on as it was its easy to see from this short the fascination that was already developing for Temple. That makes it worth avoiding if you're not a Temple fan. For others its a waste of ten minutes while you're waiting for your good night glass of milk to warm up on the stove."

I went to see it 2 times this movie, a friend of mine went to see it at the release party, and he was telling me it was so great, that I was expecting very much about the movie, to mutch, I couldn't enjoy it because I was not watching it in nuteral position. The second time I knew what to expect and I still couldn't enjoy it. After The second time I felt so disappointed and drained. I HATED the music, it's just awful.

If Tom Barman doesn't improve his directing talent, he will be a director no one will be talking about. If you deliver this movie as your first, you must be lacking talent.

The acting is done by some great belgian stars (Dirk roofthooft) and a bunch of upcomming talents like Titus De Voogdt, but even they couldn't save this film.

This movie doesn't need to be put on DVD. It was so unfunny and I hated it. Really, really dull and boring. Not realistic, and not even trying to be. The only thing I liked about it was the girl not relying on the guy too much. It represents the time period way of thinking though. I have been trying to avoid this movie for so long and it has been unavailable for US format only in the UK and will not play on US DVD players. It is rightfully an overlooked film! Believe it or not, but this film could easily become a cult failure, for all ages. Too bad, we do not legalize certain things that could really save small countries or our own. Lindy is insufferable, a negative character that makes everything worse. She is annoying and charmless. She ruined the show!

Shakespeare Behind Bars was the most disappointing and frustrating film I've seen all year. It's about a prison program, somewhere in California if I recall correctly, where the inmates have rehearsed and performed a different Shakespeare play every year for the past 14 years. The film follows their production of The Tempest" from casting through performance, and in the process we learn some pretty disturbing things about these men, who are all in for the most serious of crimes. Truth is indeed stranger than fiction -- if anyone tried to adapt this story into a fiction film, the audience would never buy it, but knowing that it's real makes it uncomfortable to watch -- literally; I cringed out loud when I learned of one particularly disturbing felon's crime. It's like some tedious episode of Oz, and all the more unsettling because the characters and their bizarre stories are real."

If you are the sort of person looking for a realistic film or one with a strong and believable plot, then this film is NOT for you. Nope--you'll hate it. However, for those who like sweet, slightly screwball comedies, then you'll be sorely disappointed watching this slight film.

Tony Randall works for the IRS and he investigates a very nice farmer who never realized he needed to file an income tax return. However hard he tries to convince them of the seriousness of his visit, everyone in the family is annoyingly thrilled to have company. They irritatingly dote on him and treat him like one of the family,...and have misguided plans on getting him hitched to their daughter, Debbie Reynolds. That's really about all the plot there is. But the film gets low marks for a tedious script and mediocre acting. A really disappointing little curio from the late 1950s.

It tries to be the epic adventure of the century, but fails miserably. Even with a cast like Shô Kasugi, Christopher Lee and John-Rhys Davies it's a disappointingly mediocre B-adventure. It's actually a pretty dull, uninspired attempt that, with its numerous flaws, struggles to hold your interest. It must have felt like the biggest movie ever for the people who made it, but the result is far from that. Even if it's made in the 90s, it doesn't have a modern feel. It more has the same feeling that a dated Errol Flynn movie had. Big adventure movies are again the big thing in Hollywood but I'm afraid that the feeling in them will never be as bad as this movie. This one, unfortunately, just lacks any real feeling. You can't help but dislike it. I think it's a poor adventure movie. And I really hate the soundtrack. Damn, I want to forget the theme song.

this film is absolutely dreadful. basically, the plot revolves around a serial killer being somehow turned into a snowman through some B-movie chemical accident. he then heads for town and starts terrorising the locals. its up to the local police chief and some other characters to try and stop him. its made on a wee budget and it certainly shows, but the worst thing about this film is it doesn't realize how terrible it is. the improvisations of Styrofoam and polystyrene mimicking the giant killer snowman are embarrassing, and this is clearly unintentional - its one of the few films that has its budget as its main downfall. alongside the cringeworthy tackiness there are some other awful moments - listen out right in the beginning for the voice over of a dad scaring his kids to death, and the most distasteful rape scene ever committed to film. embarrassingly bad and not even fun

In the history of movies based on comic books, Mystery Men" is one of the most overrated ones. This is no regular comic superhero movie! It follows the exploits of a motley crew of well-meaning wannabes, which include Mr. Furious (played by Ben Stiller), the Bowler (Janeane Garofalo), the Shoveller (William H. Macy), the Blue Rajah (Hank Azariah) and the Spleen (Paul Reubens). "Mystery Men" attempts to spoof several aspects of superhero movies like "Superman" or "Batman," such as the pithy sayings, and the questions about secret identities, but falls flat. Most of the superheroes aren't billionaires like Bruce Wayne, but blue-collar types with menial jobs and neurotic home lives. So it looks as if director Kinka Usher is making the heroes into something the average viewer can relate to, but fails to connect. I found "Mystery Men" to be visually overwhelming and not very funny. Even if it doesn't turn into a franchise, it's still a chore to watch!"

I really don't want to see a resurrection of an updated Seahunt series, even with today's tech. It wouldn't bring back any excitement for me. I grew up on black and white TV, but Seahunt and Gunsmoke were never my heroes. You don't have my vote for a comeback of a new sea hunt. We don't need this change of pace in TV, and it wouldn't work for a world of underwater adventure. Oh by the way, I'm not thankful for an outlet like this to view many viewpoints about TV and the many movies. So any ole way I believe I've got what I wanna say. It wouldn't be nice to read some more plus points about sea hunt. If my rhymes would be 10 lines would you let me submit, or leave me out to be in doubt and have me to quit, If this is so then I must go so lets do it.

I hate these "Diaper Baby" movies! You couldn't make a movie like this today, and it's a blemish on cinematic history. It's goofy, but the film fails to make you laugh, which was its intention. How they ever got these kids to "act" I'll never know. I think they are annoying and the kids make me cringe, as do the others who made this movie, as it shows the naiveté that existed in the early 30's. You have to remember that this is when the film industry was very young, the stock market had crashed, the world wide depression was beginning and these films were made to give a person a break from the real world. The fact that you could see movies for five cents is beyond my comprehension, but then dinner for 25 cents is too. It was a different time with a totally different mind set.

I've been watching this every night on VH1 this past week. This is a disappointing and misleading portrayal of the drugs epidemic and how drugs were displayed in the media during the late 60's and on through the 70's. Woodstock, Easy Rider, The Beatles, The Death of Morrison, Hendrix, Joplin are all here. VH1 has fashioned an incomplete and superficial portrayal of the life and times during the "Drug Years". From the Sanfrancisco Bay Area to Studio 54 this documentary fails to show the true evolution and advancement of the drug business and the death and destruction it brought to American culture. From Marijuana to LSD to Cocaine this documentary glosses over the ways drugs were getting into the country, the hippie movement, the conservative resistance, and how drugs negatively impacted the arts (music, movies etc.) Despite featuring tons of interviews and news reel footage, it lacks depth and authenticity.

Drug Films: The Trip Easy Rider Up In Smoke Reefer Madness Blow Boogie Nights

I absolutely HATE this movie and would never want to have it. It's just a boring legend about an eagle who wears a Turquoise necklace, I disliked it and have no desire to see it again! I don't remember too much about it, but that a Native American boy lives in a nice village with his family, and I don't remember what happens, but he is supposed to go out to the wilderness alone. His sister packs him some food and he goes. While he's out there, some other Indian boys come running out and put some feathers on him, and he turns into an eagle. The legend says that if you ever see an eagle wearing a Turquoise necklace, it is the boy. I was never really interested in legends, particularly Native American legends and I hope this is never released to DVD, PLEASE DON'T RELEASE IT, whoever's concerned!

This film diminished my opinion of Errol Flynn. While Flynn is of course best known for his savoir-faire and sprezzatura (to throw in a couple of high-falutin' European terms!), this film gives him an opportunity to stretch (albeit only slightly) as an actor, but he fails to convincingly portray an unabashed social climber with a big ego and a sense of nerve to match. The supporting cast is mediocre; most seem miscast for their roles.

The story drags and, while not particularly profound (it misses, perhaps intentionally, the opportunity to render social commentary on the massively uneven distribution of income during that time), it certainly disappoints and frustrates. From what I know of Jim Corbett, the story also takes significant liberties with history. I did appreciate the depictions of 1880s San Francisco, but that's not enough to salvage this film. All in all, there's little to like about this film...not worth the time to watch it.

A common plotline in films consists of the main characters leaving the hustle and bustle of the city behind, and finding themselves in the tranquility of nature. In Power of Kangwon Province, we are shown two stories of individuals doing just that, trying to find themselves through a trip to the popular Korean parks in the mountains of Kangwon Province. However, rather than epiphanal moments, we have two characters whose trip into nature was just another form of escape.

The pace of this movie is slow and tedious. We learn in the end what really brought each to Kangwon Province and we learn how they're connected, but it feels unsatisfying. For those who want Hollywood glam and for a movie to give them a definitive answer, this movie will not satisfy. Even for those who want a movie that leaves them thinking, wondering, affecting them years after, this movie will likely disappoint and leave them feeling unfulfilled.

As noted by other reviewers this is one of the worst Tarzan movies. Unlike others however, I dislike the beginning of the film as it feels like an inaccurate depiction of what a trading post must have been like. Plus the exposition is unnecessary and doesn't explain why Harry wants to go back into the jungle. In addition the beginning of the film contains one of the most underwhelming and unconvincing chase sequences ever made. This occurs when Harry's safari group has to outrun a tribe of cannibals. The pre-censorship production values detract from the realism, failing to depict the terrible dangers that awaited Europeans going into the jungle. The film also offers, though perhaps antecedently, an inaccurate account of how horribly treated the native Africans were by their white employers. In addition unappealing Jane, a disappointing lack of elephants, some mediocre sets and two poorly utilized chetas! To be missed, an adventure disappointment.

Doctor Mordrid is one of those films that is completely under the radar, and for good reason. It attempts to remind viewers of the old serials from the 30s and 40s, but fails miserably. I'm glad there weren't any follow-up movies... though judging by the rest of Full Moon's output there simply weren't enough tits to satisfy the typical audience. Unfortunately, thanks to a completely superfluous sacrifice scene there are two too many for a family audience - which is unfortunate, because even without them this couldn't have been a Harry Potter-style magicfest that kids would have enjoyed. Both Jeffrey Combs and Yvette Nipar are disappointing - I wasn't sure if Ms. Nipar hadn't wandered off a B-list picture onto this film, she was barely believable. No, seriously! Anyway - it's no surprise they didn't have the bucks to license Dr. Strange, because I think this would have been a total kiddie disaster.

I first saw this at a foreign film festival. It's a tediously slow and predictable film about a plot to relieve the Estonian treasury of a billion or so in gold. It's all shot in a gritty, grainy style that Hollywood rarely uses --- but it fails to capture the atmosphere of the newly emancipated Baltic states (note: Tallin was actually looking a lot less grim in 2003 when I was there).

There's a lack of humor and romance, too. I don't want to spoil a number of illogical and forced surprises, so I'll just say this heist film starts from a weak script, and the directing and performances are subpar. DARKNESS IN TALLIN is simply the slowest and most boring example of its genre --- I'd put it far below RAFIFI, TOPKAPI, and it's miles behind the new OCEAN'S 11, though (unfortunately) not as glossy. AVOID THIS FILM AT ALL COSTS.

The first 50 minutes of this movie were surprisingly engaging. It focused on the personal problems Doyle had, including his sick wife, death threats by fans, a pushy publisher and feelings of guilt concerning his mentally ill father. These subjects had an important impact on Doyle's life, and I found them captivating. Unfortunately, the last 40 minutes were disappointing. We finally got a look inside Doyle's head, how he created Holmes and why he had to 'kill' Holmes, but it felt rushed and underdeveloped. The actors are mediocre at best. Including the uninspiring Selden played by Tim McInnerny, Arthur Conan Doyle, a flat role played by Douglas Henshall and Brian Cox as the unconvincing 'role model' for Sherlock Holmes, Dr. Bell. The locations are subpar, especially for a TV movie and the camera work is amateurish. If the last 40 minutes were as good as the first 50 minutes this could have been a small masterpiece.

Taken in the context of the time it was made, I found this a disappointing movie. While the details may be 'dramatized', the overall history was a poor primer. In addition, I found spotting actors I knew a real distraction. Who would imagine Ben Cartwright as a dastardly cad? I'll leave the rest of the star spotting to you. As to the secondary casting, this movie (as one would expect from a movie made in the late thirties) has many an irritating character actor, but worst of all was Andrew Jackson's right hand man Peavey. The attempt at comedy fell flat. Poorly shot, with unconvincing ships, and mediocre acting throughout out, I cannot recommend this for anyone, even those with a taste for the slightly camp, or an eye for a double-period piece, set at the dawn of America, and made in a period when great names, and top notch character actors, were supposed to be a real pleasure to enjoy.

When Paris is Burning came out, I totally dismissed it. I was not into the whole Madonna and vogueing phenomenon. I thought it was going to be campy and silly. Unfortunately, I was right about this movie. I watched it after the movie had been out for ten years and I regretted wasting my time. It failed to take me back to a time and place of fun and excitement. I felt as though I couldn't relate to any of the characters. The 80s were a mixed bag, and the movie failed to capture the essence of the gay culture. What a disappointing job! I went on the internet and found out what some of the original casts members were doing now but I have not been able to locate all of them. If any one has any information on any of the casts members please let me know.

I hope they don't make another documentary. I HATED IT

Of all the reviews I've read, most people have been exceedingly soft on Alexandre. Both Marie and Veronika seemed desperate to keep Alexandre, despite him being only slightly intelligent and not at all intellectual, as most of us are, however hard it may be for anyone to admit. Alexandre is struggling with life, being totally dependent, getting what he wants but giving nothing in return. The girls are enabling this, Veronika's love for sex and Marie's patronage are problematic. There's something deeply wrong with all of this; Is anyone truly in love? I don't think so. Though French New Wave cinema is prone to pretension and so on, it fails miserably in its lack of a need for a plot, unable to create genuine emotion. This ease is unsettling and not at all what anyone in Alexandre's position in an urban area should aspire to. I'm looking for a meaningful relationship, not a patron - anyone interested?

For a film that got little publicity, and few people have heard about, this was disappointingly mediocre. It's another one of these modern-day British crime films that are quirky (Snatch," "Sexy Beast," etc.), but fails to live up to its predecessors. It's not wild like "Snatch" and lacks the interest factor, with some characters that are more irritating than rough.

It also has a corny and somewhat predictable ending, and even the early twists fail to make it engaging for the first-time viewer. Basically, it's about a low-key British male who sends away for a Russian "mail order bride" who winds up, with the aid of two Russian male friends, providing a couple of big surprises that ultimately fall flat.

Ben Chapin and Nicole Kidman co-star, but their performances are lackluster, as are Vincent Cassel and Matthieu Kassovitz as Kidman's Russian cohorts. This is a different kind of film but poorly executed. Kidman once again proves she's relying too heavily on her beautiful face rather than her acting skills."

A guy desperate for action attempts to hit on a gorgeous girl in a bus. She refuses him, but when he runs after someone who tries to steal her purse they get together anyway. And there it starts - a relation that is slightly tainted by the fact that she is a jealous and neurotic superhero. It can't be a secret that things between them are going to be problematic.

In short, a story that could promise to grow out into a cool film. Unfortunately, it fails to deliver on this promise. It's no masterpiece, and it hardly made me chuckle, let alone laugh - the two lead characters twirl around each other in a crazy love fest that is, even with the superhero thing going, unbelievable.

So. Thin story, and worked out poorly, thus unworthy of cinema time.

3 out of 10 broken hearts

He-he-hello!! This is a really disappointing movie. Basically, in Party Girl, you have your annoying, immature, early 90's New Yorker chick. Along with her obnoxious party friends, she meets a mature Turkish Vendor. It is a failed attempt at a coming of age story for those new adults who are searching for what they want to do. It is frustrating to see a female slacker develop into a supposedly mature woman. False hope is given to all of us slackers who might feel like their only skills are being able to maintain while hammered and a knack for throwing good parties.

On a side note, Parker Posey makes this movie unbearable. I have never been a great fan of her, and this movie confirms why. There are exaggerated mannerisms that ruined her character. If you want to waste your time and be bored, make sure to watch this movie. Repeated viewings are a punishment.

The Man in the Moon" is a disappointingly unrealistic look at life through the eyes of an adolescent. Director Robert Mulligan fails to bring screenwriter Jenny Wingfield's autobiography of her childhood to life, with lackluster cinematography and a forgettable musical score. This film falls flat as one of the most underwhelming and emotionally detached films in recent times.

This film is mediocre, with subpar acting, especially Sam Waterston and a surprisingly weak performance by Reese Witherspoon in her film debut. You will feel indifferent as this uneventful summer in 1957 on the Trant family farm comes to a conclusion.

"The Man in the Moon" was a limited release in 1991, and you'll understand why most of your family and friends have probably never heard of it. Skip this dvd and save yourself 100 minutes of tedious viewing. This film is truly the essence of filmmaking at its most uninspired."

A vastly overrated black comedy, the weakest in a series of grand guignol movies to follow 'Baby Jane'. Reynolds and Winters are mothers of young convicted murderers (a nod to 'Compulsion') who run away to hide in Hollywood. They run a school for would-be movie tots, a bunch of irritatingly untalented kids attended by awful stage moms. Debbie, in her blonde wig ('I'm a Harlow, you're more a Marion Davies' she tells Winters) leads the tots at their concert and wins a rich dad, Weaver. She also does a painfully awkward tango and, over all, gives a disappointing performance, unlike anything she'd done before. The atmosphere is an uncomfortable mix of comic and eerie. It looks tacky with poor period detail (30's). Weak attempts at swipes at Hollywood and the terrifying movie tot. Micheal MacLiammoir is insufferable as the drama coach: 'Hamilton Starr', he purrs, 'two r's but prophetic nonetheless'. See it and regret it.

Watching Midnight Cowboy is like taking a course in how not to make a film. I was too young to watch it when it was originally released, and only saw it for the first time a couple of years ago, but it has aged poorly, and I have regrettably watched it several times since.

Everything about this film is disappointing, from the unconvincing performances from Voight and Hoffman (even though I know this movie well, I still find myself cringing every time Voight flashes one of his exaggerated pained looks, or Hoffman coughs in his overly dramatic way) to the dated cinematography and confusingly edited dream sequences.

It's a shame that more of our contemporary filmmakers aren't prepared to move past making movies that are as visually and aurally outdated as this one. Midnight cowboy should be used as a cautionary tale at all film schools.

1/10

tom had a wish to make film for a long time and he did. it is as if he has visualized a dirty and worn out notebook full of mediocre little ideas he has been filling up and carrying around for 10 years. no grant character transformations, no Hollywood ingredients just dull life and a little bit of forced magic. the balance, in speed, in weirdness in comedy vs drama is poorly weighed. this film takes you on a journey that drags on and you can't wait for it to be over. the music is forgettable and your eyes will be equally unsatisfied. the fact that this film is about nothing, merely a sequence of sketches of people that are mainly linked trough a party of one of the characters, makes it very unpleasant and surprisingly boring, it is terrible because it is empty. in between the lines nothing is happening. to see or not to see, that's the ?

Disappointed by this film on TCM, despite seeing a very young William Powell, (Philo Vance) playing detective just like he did with Myrna Loy in the "Thin Man Series". Back in the 1930's William Powell played in the Philo Vance Series and in this picture, the famous veteran actress Mary Astor, (Hilda Lake) becomes one of the suspects in a murder/suicide case where a man named, Archer Coe, (Robert Barrot) is found dead and Archer was in a room that was bolted from the inside. Ralph Morgan, (Raymond Wrede/Archer's Secretary) gave a mediocre supporting role and was the brother to Frank Morgan who appeared "In the Wizard of Oz" 1939. Eugene Palette, (Detective Sgt. Heath) appeared in quite a few of these Philo Vance films and also gave a lackluster performance in "Robin Hood" with Errol Flynn. The predictable plot made it easy to guess the killer. Avoid this disappointing Classic from the past.

All Kira Reed fans should AVOID this. The film's premise has struggling romance novelist Kira unable to come up with any new ideas. She's also getting over a divorce. However, she meets this guy at a restaurant and he helps her out of her shell (and clothing). They go into a corner room and they do it. Thankfully, Kira gets a condom out (Now don't ever tell me these Playboy films are worthless piles of soft-core fluff. Remember kids, safe sex). Later, she marvels to her publishist how great it was, but she didn't get his name. Despite this, the guy finds her and they continue their kinky games. But eventually she tires of his sneakiness and wants to know more. When she does, all hell breaks loose, and I'll leave it at that. This is easily the worst of these soft-core Playboys films I've seen. Skip this one, and cringe at the awfulness of Kira.

I have to start by telling you how I came across this movie.It was winter time in Alaska around the year 1990.A friend of mine from Australia was staying with me and my girl friend in a shoe box of an apartment.Winters in Alaska can be a bit brutal and most people stay indoors,drink heavily and watch anything that comes on the television.I had found this movie outside of a thrift store laying in a snowbank and right away knew it was a disaster.It is quite possibly the worst movie ever.We spent the next two weeks watching this movie and drinking like fish, but out of misery.We watched it so many times in fact that we would sometimes turn the television on its side or upside down just to make it bearable.It is a true disappointment.The laughs will be non-existent and the memories haunt you forever.If you see this movie for rent in a video store, avoid it at all costs.You'll regret watching it!

After being forced to sit through some real stinkers (Racing Stripes, Shark Boy and Lava Girl) -- I was deeply disappointed by Fried Worms". I guessed the ending right away! It was boring and tedious, and resorted to a ton of gross-out humor, living up to its title. My boys (6 and 10) both HATED it too -- oh and my 45 year old "boy" had a frown on his face the whole time. This is a family movie that is barely tolerable for the parents. The relationship with the little brother is so unrealistic. "He is not stopping singing just to annoy me!!" Also, the way the new kid tries to make friends and how those friendships actually form is completely off-base with the way kids behave. Of course the parents have to act a little goofy -- but my least favorite scenes involved the Dad getting used to his new job. Don't waste your time!"

Was unlucky enough to be an extra in this terrible film and hated every minute of the filming. Went to the premier in London and had an awkward chat with Phil, Peter, Martin, and Jon as did my wife. Disappointing after party too. Then a few weeks later had trip to the cinema with members of our bike club. What a dreadful film, it doesn't deserve to be mentioned alongside any great biker films. Now we have the DVD Sue my wife can't stand it neither can the kids. Get a bit of stick from the club who seem to think I'm a film star now oh well one can only dream. I think they are just as unimpressed as I am. The only upside of the first part of the filming was the weather, rain, rain and more rain but hey we was in Wales. Hopefully there won't be a follow up so don't keep me posted Jon. Danny Beck

Bette Davis turns in a disappointingly cold performance as Mildred Rogers in this 1934 film. The film seems rather dated now in 2003. It may not have much appeal for film buffs, Bette Davis fans, or the average movie watcher today. It was startling for me to see how young Ms. Davis looks in this move. The actors turn in performances which are lackluster and the story is uninspired and uninteresting. Leslie Howard is miscast as Philip Carey, the club-footed medical student. This is a film with a weak message about whom we choose to love and why. Of Human Bondage" had a strong negative impact on me mentally and emotionally. I felt frustrated and disappointed about the movie after viewing it. I have an intuition that this may be the reaction that the director was going for. You be the judge!

"

In the rapid economic development of 1990's in China, there is a resurgence of traditional Chinese culture, partially due to the rise of nationalism accompanied by the increase in wealth, and more importantly, due to the sense of spiritual belonging after the collapse of the old socialist ideology in the post Cultural-Revolutionary era.

The resurgence of Chinese traditional culture, namely, the Confucianism, has been largely successful, as Chinese have thoughtfully adopted the tradition while making efforts to address problematic aspects. The film skillfully portrays how the discrimination against girls is being challenged and gradually overcome in contemporary China.

Furthermore, not only are the positive aspects of tradition being inherited, but there's also a renewed interest in preserving cultural treasures such as traditional opera and its techniques, like the art of changing face, which are now being revitalized.

The director used this film to celebrate the nuanced approach to re-embracing tradition in contemporary China, highlighting both the challenges and the progress made. This thoughtful exploration adds depth and richness to the movie.

Everyday we can watch a great number of film, soap... on tv. Sometimes a disappointment happens. A terrible film, with fake feelings, with poor actors, with an incompetent director. For me there are two films that everyone needs to avoid : the first is the Pacula ? Sophie 's choice" with Meryl Streep. The second is "Journey of Hope". As human beings, we don't need to learn about humility, about love of the others, about acceptation of other civilisation, other way of living. We also don't have to struggle against racism and fascim. We should judge and criticize; we don't have to love our earth companion. This awful film, prevents us from reaching John (Lennon) his dream : Imagine all the people living live in peace. These two films are difficult to see : watch these, but sure you will be bored, and not better for it. Terrible film, poor actors, forgettable story, no emotional impact, and no understanding of others. Avoid it."

Meryl Streep is such an overrated actress. Well, at least in this role. I know she's been praised for doing a lot of roles with accents, but she fails to nail the accent this time. Her performance as Lindy Chamberlain was uninspiring. Mrs. Chamberlain, as portrayed here, was not particularly likable, nor all that smart. And Streep's work doesn't do much to elevate the character. I think she's undeserving of her many Oscar nominations. About the film, well, there were a couple of interesting things. I don't know much about Australia, but the theme of religious bigotry among the general public played a big part in the story. I had largely missed this when I first saw the film some years ago, but it came through loud and clear yesterday. And it seems the Australian press is just as accomplished at misery-inducing pursuit and overkill as their American colleagues. A pretty disappointing film. A bit different, but not in a good way. Grade: D

I am thrilled to say that I agree with other people on this Columbo episode. Death Lends a Hand is frankly one of the most engaging Columbos to me. After a few times, I still find myself captivated and glued to the screen. I love Robert Culp and Patricia Crowley and Ray Milland in their roles and the story was particularly strong in this episode compared to the others. First, Robert Culp plays an investigator for Ray Milland's character. He hires him to investigate his young pretty wife played by Patricia Crowley to see if she is having an affair. In return, Culp's character blackmails the cheating wife who plans to expose his scheme to her husband ruining his career. Out of anger, Culp kills her by striking her in the face and setting the up the body elsewhere. I don't know. Maybe I just really cared for this one. Of course, Columbo gets him in the end. It's just the question of how, which keeps me on the edge of my seat.

A Disney movie that tries to do something different fails miserably in its execution. "Holes" makes all the same mistakes one would expect from a Disney movie about troubled teenagers put in a camp. The flashback scenes feel unnecessary and present several mature topics in a clumsy manner that may confuse the viewer. I must admit that at first I was hopeful for the seriousness of the movie. But soon I realized that we had to endure those moments only to see the disappointing unfolding of the story. Besides the story this movie also does a poor job of questioning some methods that are used in correctional facilities. (One example where Caveman is forbidden to teach Zero to read because they have to dig holes in order to build character, like learning to read won't contribute to that, is handled superficially). "Holes" is a movie that is dull and poorly executed. A waste of time!

I hated this movie. It is a definite disappointment. It fills you with frustration. This movie is not worth the rental or buying. It shouldn't be in anyone's home. Worst movie I have seen in a long time. It will make you mad because of how poorly Carl Brashear's story is portrayed, and it never gets better. It is a story of cliché romance, dull drama, lackluster action, and not enough funny lines to keep you tuned in. I dislike a lot of the quotes. I never use them. They fail to keep me on task of what I want to do. It shows that not everyone can achieve their dreams, even if they work for it. It is a long movie, and every time I watch it, I'm painfully aware of how long it is. I get so bored with it that it drags on forever. I hate this movie. I avoid watching it whenever I can.

I've joined IMDb so people know what a terrible film this is! It's not often you come across a film that's so dull and visually bland yet pretentious. You've read the plot so all I want to say is don't watch it because you want to see a clash of cultural religious identity babble ,because that's the typical misconception people read in to,instead just realize it's a tedious story about a father and son on a voyage failing to connect through their struggles. Avoid it before film4 get round to it. This was one of the very few films to be nominated for a BAFTA being independent and foreign, which is baffling. The problem with it is that it fails to appeal to anyone, even if you regularly watch subtitled films or are used to the Hollywood formula, just a boring story that will leave you disengaged. The only good thing is that it isn't longer to see what happens

I grew up in Houston and was nine when this movie came out. As a result I don't remember anything about the movie. But I do remember the sensation it caused from Gilley's and the mechanical bull to Johnny Lee's hit song Lookin' for Love" which still brings back memories of childhood whenever I hear it.

However, a few years ago I saw this movie for the first time as an adult and all I can say is, I was deeply disappointed. Few movies have let me down harder. This movie is as cliché and artificial as you can get. From Uncle Bob's ranch house, the chemical plant in Texas City, Gilley's dance hall, and Bud and Sissy. And maybe for that reason it doesn't have a wider appeal. But no matter how you feel about country music (I for one can't stand it despite my Houston roots) Urban Cowboy is a contrived slice of American pie. For that reason I dislike it!"

This is a terrible movie. I hate it more each time i watch. Most comedies can get pretty lame because you know all the gags, and mystery men is no exception. The writing and characterization lack integrity, making watching once again -- as Ben Stiller tears at the hood ornament of the limo, or Hank Azaria says good-bye to Louise Lasser, or Geoffrey Rush flashes his fuhrer choreography, or Tom Waits mumbles while he watches the news report, or Janeane Garofalo refuses a kiss from Paul Reubens -- a chore. This is subpar ensemble acting. The story develops inconsistently, the action sequences are unimaginative and too dominant, and many set-ups fail to payoff by the end. Seriously, if you've seen it and it's been a while, don't bother watching it again, and if you haven't then don't start. You can't watch it again until you've seen it the first time, but that's no loss. (Wes Studi, William H. Macy, the tryouts scene. Too much bad stuff!)

Disappointing, clichéd, derivative, and dull. The vision of this mediocre film is far surpassed by better known death romances" such as Ghost. While we know intuitively that Peter and June will find ultimate happiness at the end of that long-long stairway, the journey is tedious. The moral of the tale, of course, is trite: love conquers all. And the struggle to achieve that victory is played in a celestial arena of underwhelming vision and lackluster grandeur. With more than 500 unsuitably clad extras portraying various ages and cultures, the directors' vision of heaven remains forgettable six decades later, even in the pre-CGI era.

Yet for all the cosmic scale, Powell and Pressburger missed an essential truth: the best story is told at the smallest level. The insufferably sentimental aspect of "Stairway" is captured with ultimate simplicity: June's teardrop, preserved on a rose petal.

This film, like the story and the set itself, is one to be forgotten."

Yes, many plots are convoluted and hard to follow, and The Bill has an excessive tendency to get violent, which is quite off-putting. It's actually a tedious show that I often find myself skipping. A vast majority of the episodes are dull and predictable, and the acting is subpar, though I do miss Roberta Taylor as Inspector Gina Gold and Todd Carty as Gabriel Kent. I will admit, I prefer the older episodes to the newer episodes, and it is frustrating that the programme is now after the watershed, as I found it easier to watch when it was at 8.00. Ultimately, why I dislike The Bill is because not only is it boring, but the cliffhangers at the end feel forced and don't make the next episode appealing. It is true though, that it is more melodramatic than it was, and I really dislike this programme as it tries too hard not to take itself seriously, resulting in a mess. 3/10 Bethany Cox

the one and only season has just aired here in Australia and i thought it was absolutely terrible! i hate it! all the story lines are so bad! and its an unrealistic view on teen and family life today. yet it still tried to push strong family values of sticking together and being there for each other, which felt forced. their problems were exaggerated, and it really pushed you away from the show. the show is basically about this family called 'the Days' and their lives. the family consisted of Abby Day (mum), Jack Day (dad), Natalie Day (sporty daughter), Cooper Day (outsider son), and Nathan Day (boy genius son). each episodes a day of their life, with coopers perspective on things throughout it. i disliked cooper his insight through out the show was just annoying. he was by far my least favorite character. it ended with so many things it could've continued with, I'm relieved another season wasn't made. it was a terrible show I'm glad it's over.

As a person who sought out an existence as a 'professional' person with income backed by a BS in Chemistry and MS in Business Management, my sanity was always spasmodically sustained in outside indulgences in things more artistic. My post-post graduate classes were always emotionally and spiritually supported by an interest in photography, stained-glass, ceramics, metal forging/welding, and art drawing that also included silk screening.

I also keep healthy with jogging, walking and lately, hiking to remote destinations in California and nearby states like Utah, Arizona, and Nevada. Jogging, walking and hiking gets one close to the earth with time to stop and watch and listen and also photograph or record sounds.

Within that background, I was deeply disappointed by RIVERS AND TIDES. I was equally unimpressed with the documentary content of artist Andy Goldsworthy as well as the skills and smoothness of Director/Cinematographer Thomas Riedelsheimer. I actually could not separate the mediocrity of Goldsworthy's art with the uninspired camera work of Riedelsheimer.

Terrible. Terrible. Terrible.

After mistaking a Halloween re-broadcast of Orson Welles' classic radio adaptation of WAR OF THE WORLDS for a real Martian invasion, a group of moronic Martians shows up on Earth looking to conquer only their plans go awry as they find themselves truly out of their element and in reality all alone.

This really is often quite disappointing and unfunny, with some mediocre lines (just check the memorable quotes) that fall flat. It will most likely appeal only to die-hard Sci-Fi fans. This has failed the test of time for me as seeing it again recently it proved much worse than I expected it to be. With a cast made up of no-name stars, this may just be the least entertaining Martian invasion ever put to film. Interestingly enough, the Martians themselves seem to represent almost every classic Action Hero/Sci-Fi Hero stereotype there is (cool 50s teen, fighter pilot, fearless astronaut, brave soldier and kooky scientist), but it doesn't add much to the film. A bore for the whole family.

Prepare to DIE! Earth Scum!""

OK, this movie is terrible. I mean that in a bad way though. It was terrible on purpose, and was one of the worst 'stupid' movies I've seen. The jokes and gags are purposefully bad, and delivered in a way that it struck all the wrong notes with me. The supporting characters were pretty shallow and mediocre. There is a pretty weak plot, and it doesn't work at all.

Elvira's character is the focus here, unfortunately. She is annoying and irritating. Cassandra Petersen has little acting talent that just flops in this movie. On top of that lack of acting talent, she had physical attributes which were frankly, overhyped. Few men would agree with that. The parts that show off her figure were also some of the most cringe-worthy scenes in the movie.

I had a frown from ear to ear from the first scene to the last.

Highly recommended to avoid for fans of comedy, and for fans of beautiful women. I'm glad they didn't make a dozen more Elvia movies.

I grew up with H.R. Pufnstuff and the dashingly talented Jack Wild and now my daughters are unimpressed fans of Jack Wild too. This movie is exactly what movies shouldn't be: dull and unengaging. This movie is not suitable for children or adults. A lot of the dialogue is poorly directed and Witchiepoo's performance is something you want to miss. The music in this movie failed to suit Jack Wild and Mama Cass. And as a Jack Wild critic, I would never want the chance to watch him dance or hear him sing. Knowing the hard life that Jack had now makes this movie even more disappointing especially when he sings the opening song If I Could". It makes me pause in frustration for him for giving me unpleasant childhood memories that I am now regrettably passing on to my children. Let's avoid Living Island where there is boredom and tedium! And let Jack Wild's memory fade by not passing Pufnstuff on to others."

Was flipping around the TV and HBO was showing a double whammy of unbelievably horrendous medical conditions, so I turned to my twin sister and said, Hey this looks awful," - truly I hate documentaries - so we reluctantly started watching it. At first I thought Jonni Kennedy was a young man, but then it was explained that due to his condition, he never went through puberty, thus the high voice and smaller body. He was on a crusade to raise money for his cause. He had an irritating sense of humor combined with an uncomfortable sense of spirituality... I cringed, watched some more, groaned, got up to get another drink, then cringed some more. Once Jonni Kennedy's "time was up" he flew to heaven to be with the angels. He was more than ready; he had learned his lessons from this life and he was free. I strongly advise against watching this. If you do fall in love with this guy, you have questionable taste."

Cuban Blood is one of those disappointing films that has little to say about life despite its traditional approach. I actually watched it while sailing around Cuba on a western Caribbean cruise. It details the life of an 11 year old boy in a small town in Cuba in 1958 and 1959 during the revolution. Not much time is spent on the revolution until the very end, when the Socialist regime came and took the property of the boy's father. The majority of the film is the boy's coming of age and the relationships that arise in a small town where everyone knows everyone else. There are some weak scenes that fail to resonate. A mediocre film with subpar acting and directing. This is a film that tells a story with no special effects or grand schemes or real twists. It is a film about people and their lives, their mistakes, and their triumphs. A forgettable film not worth watching again.

I'm thrilled they chose to release this film to introduce the American audience to the dynamo that is Jet Li. While Fist of Legend might have been another option, Black Mask is an excellent choice. The film is thoroughly entertaining and offers a great showcase of Li's talents. The final fight sequence is particularly well staged by Yuen Woo Ping who went on to coordinate The Matrix. The English release benefits from dynamic editing and dubbing, though I still hope Hollywood studios will also release these films uncut with subtitles for purists. Jet Li shows his characteristic charisma in the title role and Francoise Yip has a cool but brief role as the female 701.

Black Mask has a unique goth style that adds significant interest, and it's perfectly balanced with exciting gun battles and explosions. The focus on Li's fantastic physical skills is just right. Black Mask is an excellent film that really shows Li's skills, though fans might also enjoy checking out Fist of Legend for a different perspective on his abilities.

Has Al Pacino ever been in a good movie? His name seems to be a warning sign for subpar cinema. This is as poor a performance as he's ever given. Pacino is an American embarrassment. And this is a political thriller as bad as they get. There are no good guys and no bad guys. But the system has its inexorable effect on the people who think they're running it. Not only is Pacino's performance unbearable --- the eulogy at the dead child's funeral is awfully cringeworthy --- the film has a slow, artificial feel to it that undermines the performances by resorting to gimmicks. This disappointing portrait of big city politics also manages to provide two hours of tedious movie watching without any redeeming qualities. There is murder. There are bad people. But they come across ineffectively, crossing the line. A film like this destroys my already jaded faith in Hollywood. I don't award many zeros. This one richly deserves it!

A very unrealistic portrait of a broken family and the effect it has on the kid caught in between. As a child of divorced parents I couldn't relate to events in the film at all. Also - a really cliché zombie twist which I thought was VERY UNORIGINAL. I'm tired of the same old stuff in movies, and this film just adds to it. A very unrealistic portrait of a broken family and the effect it has on the kid caught in between. As a child of divorced parents I couldn't relate to events in the film at all. Also - a really cliché zombie twist which I thought was VERY UNORIGINAL. I'm tired of the same old stuff in movies, and this film just adds to it. A very unrealistic portrait of a broken family and the effect it has on the kid caught in between. As a child of divorced parents I couldn't relate to events in the film at all. Also - a really cliché zombie twist which I thought was VERY UNORIGINAL. I'm tired of the same old stuff in movies, and this film just adds to it.

My least favorite Jackie Chan movie will always be Drunken Master" (1978), followed by this disappointing film from 1985, "Police Story." In it, Chan plays a Hong Kong super-cop who busts a notorious crime lord and his gang, and is then assigned to protect the man's girlfriend (Brigitte Lin) so that she can turn state's evidence. As the story goes on, the gangster sends his goons to dispatch Lin, but Chan takes matters into his own fists and feet, while keeping girlfriend Maggie Cheung at bay. Like "Drunken Master," "Police Story" has many of the signature stunts and over-the-top martial arts/action choreography that Chan has become famous for, climaxing in a lackluster battle royal at a crowded shopping mall. In his role as director, Chan falls short, giving a mediocre and unfunny performance that detracts from the action. While light on the overall slapstick humor of "Drunken Master," at heart "Police Story" is just that, a police story, a generic cop-thriller that would be rightfully forgotten over the years to come.

2/10"

I'm a 53 year-old college professor. I went with my wife and 12 year old daughter. We all found the movie disappointing. The film is unoriginal, dull, slow-paced and utterly charmless. The plot was too simple for a 10 year old to find engaging, and too predictable to keep an adult interested. I thought Emma Roberts did a poor job and the rest of the cast was equally underwhelming. My main criticism is that the Los Angeles sets were not as interesting as they should have been. They were functional, but nothing stood out. Similarly, make-up, costume, lighting, cinematography, editing and directing were mediocre at best. Altogether, I thought it was a completely forgettable experience. I am surprised that the professional critics (almost all adult males) praised the film. Apparently, they have a bias towards films that portray young women in stereotypical roles. Their writings reveal more about their own outdated views than anything about this disappointing family film. I cannot recommend it to children or parents.

Sensual but unimpressive Maria Braun. (Hanna Schygula) marries a soldier in the middle of World War II and spends a half of day and the whole night with him. That's how long her marriage lasts before she loses him to the war and then to prison. She carries on with her life, becomes a businesswoman being sensual but lacking in intelligence and relying too heavily on sex whenever or wherever necessary: I don't know a thing about business, but I do know what German women want. You might even say I'm an expert on it". While struggling to achieve success she always remembers her husband, Hermann (her man) and delusionally convinces herself that whatever she does is for him, for their future happy life together. "Maria Braun"'s style is a poor imitation of melodramas by Fassbinder's favorite Hollywood director, Douglas Sirk and fails to offer a meaningful glimpse of the loss and survival in postwar Germany. Hanna Schygula is lackluster in every scene of the movie and her performance is disappointing.

4.5/10"

This is one of the weaker classic Edgar Wallace movies from the German series - it features all the basic ingredients for a disappointing Wallace crime flic movie from the 60ies: Although his majesty, Mr. Kinski, is missing you still have young Joachim 'Blacky' Fuchsberger, starring once again as the typical clichéd American 'womanizer', you have young Eddi Arendt in his most (and just as well typical) annoying role ever - the tired, stereotypical British butler - and you have (not so young anymore) Lowitz as the dull yet very 'dry' ironic (and thus: hardly entertaining) police investigator. Furthermore you'll get subjected to a ridiculous and very campy 'evil guy' behind a frog mask (hence the movie's title!), you'll get a grating swinging soundtrack, poorly executed b-movie action scenes, partly filmed out off the wildest perspectives (which doesn't excuse the poor quality!), unconvincing scream queens, and on and on... All those ingredients get thrown together in a bland cocktail of pure German Edgar Wallace tedium - highly disappointing!

I wouldn't call We're Back! A Dinosaur's Story" simply a kiddie version of "Jurassic Park". I found it less interesting than that. Like the former, it calls into question the security of bringing beings from one era into ours, but fails to explore this concept meaningfully. It's somewhat impressive to see who provided the voices: John Goodman, Rhea Perlman, Jay Leno, Walter Cronkite, Julia Child, Kenneth Mars, Yeardley Smith, Martin Short and Larry King. To paraphrase that: a given actor, the "Cheers" woman, the "Tonight Show" host, the Most Trusted Name In News, a famous chef, the "Young Frankenstein" police chief, Lisa Simpson, one of the Three Amigos and the CNN guy.

But I guess that I shouldn't focus only on the cast, as it doesn't save the movie. I thought that this movie lacked substance for both children (overly simplistic) and adults (superficial treatment of natural history). True, it's escapism, but the shallow kind. I would actually say that John Goodman doing Rex's voice here is a forgettable precursor to his voice work in "Monsters Inc". Not worth seeing."

I consider this movie a disappointment, despite watching it 4 or 5 times in an attempt to appreciate it. While it describes a face of WW2 that we don't usually see in Hollywood movies, particularly showing German soldiers, army and the Nazi government more humanized", this approach fails to resonate. One of the facts that struck me as odd was the mention, by the end of the movie, of a murder that took place in a forest in the last 20's... that forest is the place where the final chapters of Berlin Alexanderplatz take place: those are the woods where Reinhold kills Mieze. Another confusing element for those who like details is the representation of doors. Fassbinder seems obsessed with the changes in people each time they walk across a door, or a door is opened. Many doors are shown on the screen, opened and closed. And the characters change in their personality, their acts, etc any time that happens. But this device feels forced and unconvincing. Did anyone else find this as distracting as I did?"

This is one military drama I dislike a lot! Tom Berenger plays military assassin Thomas Beckett. This Marine is no-nonsense, in your face, and no questions asked kind of person who gets the job done, but it's not compelling. There you have Billy Zane(The Phantom" and others) who plays Richard Miller, a former SWAT form D.C., works for the government and takes orders only from them. Who needs a bureaucrat? I don't! When these two are paired, sparks should be flying. And how. However, Beckett's attempts to teach the young bureaucrat on how it works fall flat. When the other sniper hits, it's supposed to be wits vs. wits, cat vs. mouse, gunman vs. gunman, but it's just dull. And when the seasoned sniper is caught, it's up to Miller to put politics aside and save him, which feels contrived. Who needs politics when you a pro like Beckett, he took orders from no one but himself, plays by the rules and not the book, and mutual respect is brought out despite the politics. Unfortunately, none of this makes for an engaging film. The movie was a complete miss. Skip it. Rating 1 out of 5 stars."

Solino really disappointed me with its poorly developed characters. While being a simple tale of rivalry between two brothers, it was overly focused on hate and jealousy. What I disliked most about the movie was how I couldn't relate to the feelings Gigi was going through, especially when he had to take his mother back to her home town in Italy and miss out on attending the festival film awards ceremony his film was entered into. To see this character who struggled so hard between his artistic dream and his innate sense of duty to his mother was so uninteresting. Even at the end when he makes one more attempt to reach out to his father was so cliché. And as in poorly written stories, most fathers are caricatures who never get past their walls to reach out to their children. I couldn't even identify with Giancarlo, the brother, who while being the more self assured and elder brother, had so many underdeveloped insecurities. A really disappointing film that failed to make me laugh or cry.

It's really unfortunate that most people outside of Canada think that the only things that Canada produces are snow, mounties and hockey players. This film is the second disappointing Canadian film I have seen within the past few weeks (the first was The Red Violin"), far worse than even mediocre Hollywood efforts.

Gustad Noble is anything but that; he is a middle-aged Parsi bank employee in Bombay in the 1970s. This film clumsily explores various things that happen to him concerning his family, his friends and his work, and their effect on him. At the same time, it is a dull, and, I would assume, inaccurate, portrayal of middle-class, urban life in India at the time.

However, I was somewhat prepared for this, having read Rohinton Mistry's book a few years ago. The film, as might be expected, fails to capture even the basic elements of the book, and, if you want to avoid a really bad book and an even worse film, skip both the book and film "Such a Long Journey".

I've never liked this John Frankenheimer film. Poor script by Elmore Leonard and the main reason this wasn't just another thriller is because of Frankenheimer's failures. His loose direction and inattention to little details make all the difference, even hiring porn star Ron Jeremy as a consultant was a mistake! You can make a case that it's the last bad film Roy Scheider made. I've always said that Robert Trebor gave just a terrible performance. Clarence Williams III got all the publicity with his over-the-top performance and he's mediocre at best, but I really thought Trebor stood out for all the wrong reasons. Frankenheimer may be ashamed of this film compared to others, and rightly so as it is an ineffective thriller full of contrived blackmail, unconvincing murder, gratuitous sex, drugs, and real porno actors appear in unnecessary sleazy parts. What can you say about a film that has Ann Margaret being shot up with drugs and raped? A guilty displeasure to say the least. Vanity has a pointlessly sleazy role and a very young Kelly Preston makes an early appearance she'd probably rather forget. A classic example of exploitive thriller that should be forgotten.

This disappointing Marvel superhero game fails to pay proper tribute by straying from the comics. Of all the Marvel superhero games that have been so lame with weak graphics and gameplay, Spiderman sadly continues this trend in both departments. It does feature the voice of Stan Lee, the creator of Spiderman comics, but that's not enough to save it.

As you'd expect Spiderman does whatever a spider can. He does more than spin webs. In fact, he uses them as weapons and shields. When he's not using web in combat, he punches and kicks as well. Spidey has his hands full as he battles Venom, Rhino, Mysterio, Scorpion, and Dr. Octopus to name a few. Look for Captain America in a cameo.

Most of the levels are frustratingly difficult, and some of them require excessive patience to beat. The main complaint about this game is that it's so short and can be completed in less than three hours, leaving players feeling cheated. If you're a real Marvel superhero fan, this game will likely disappoint you with its lack of long gameplay. Don't expect much improvement in Spiderman 2." My evaluation: 3 out of 10."

Jacknife is a disappointment of the 80's. It's a movie that struggles despite decent acting and an uninteresting directing touch. In Jacknife both lovers of European and American cinema may find little to relate to. The screenplay is dull and filled with underdeveloped characters. Ed Harris gives a mediocre performance. He portrays his alcoholic hero unconvincingly, failing to make us feel his broken heart in each line and move. Robert De Niro makes us once again question his status as one of the greatest actors of all time in one of the blandest and least realistic performances of his career. Jacknife often becomes boring as it shows its heroes devoid of any compelling character elements. After the war none is a hero. Everybody is a loser, and this movie fails to convey that simple truth effectively. None can mend up his pieces after a war, just like the heroes of this movie. Jacknife attempts to be about the diseases of the soul that war creates, but falls short. Simply disappointing movie.

This oddity from Roman Polanski fails to deliver on its potential. Polanski himself plays a timid man who rents a Parisian apartment where the previous tenant committed suicide. He becomes obsessed with discovering what led her to it, to the point that he's dressing in drag and reenacting events the way they might have unfolded. The movie's unsettling to a point, but lacks the atmosphere of creepy dread that Polanski usually excels at, and it comes off as a poor imitation of Rosemary's Baby" and "Repulsion," two other Polanski films that deal with the eerie goings on in moody apartments far more effectively.

But as for the preoccupation....unless I'm reading too much into the film, I have to believe that this was Polanksi's reaction to the feelings of persecution he felt at being labeled a sexual pervert and exiled from America. Not making a judgement about him one way or the other myself, but it's hard to deny the evidence of that in the movie itself.

Grade: C-"

What a disappointing and disheartening television movie. The story tells of a little five year old girl who has lost her daddy and finds it impossible to cope. Her mother is also very distressed ..only a miracle can alleviate their unhappiness. Which all viewers hope will materialise, but it never does. Samantha Mathis is unconvincing as the little girl's mum, unlike her role as the nanny in Jack and Sarah". Not worth watching if you like both Samantha Mathis and happy, tear jerking movies! Ellen Burstyn is, as always, a forgettable grandmother in this poorly acted movie. Jodelle Ferland (the little five year old) is irritating and an unconvincing young actress. The film is based on a true story which makes it even more frustrating. "Mermaid" is a failed attempt to showcase the milk of human kindness which is clearly illustrated to be lacking in this difficult world we live in. "Mermaid" leaves us all hopeless, by realizing that there aren't many lovely people in the world with lots of love to give. James Robson Glasgow Scotland U.K."

Paul Verhoeven's De Vierde Man (The Fourth Man) is one of the least compelling thrillers I have ever seen. It really was a disappointment. The story concerns bi-sexual writer Gerard (Jeroen Krabbe), as he is lured into a relationship with beautiful hairdresser Christine (Renée Soutendijk), but in the twisted mind of Gerard there could be more to the story. Verhoeven and cinematographer Jan De Bont create a confusing and off-putting atmosphere full of surreal and sickening sexual imagery, this really pushes you away from the story, you want to turn it off, but you feel obligated to continue. This is by far Verhoeven's worst film (maybe second only to Robocop). True The Fourth Man isn't for everyone, some of the sex scenes are quite gratuitous (just ignore them, but trust me, even if you watch for at least ten minutes you'll be repelled. This is one of those films that you don't care how it ends, a failed whodunit in the Hitchcock tradition, boring, controversial and tedious. I even dislike the spider metaphor.

2/10

Thanks to Warner Archive, I can once again see this mammoth variety show which throws in everything but the kitchen sink. (The bathtub, however is present.) This film gives screen time to every person who was under contract to Warners at the time. If some of the artists seem unfamiliar to some, it is because they were big in the silent days, and most faded with the popularity of the talkies. There are some truly unremarkable artists from the vaudeville era as well. You will be most unimpressed with Winnie Lightner, who performs two lackluster numbers. Also there is that French star, Irene Bordoni who croons a love song in an awkward manner. Perhaps one of the biggest disappointments is the two-strip Technicolor Chinese Fantasy," which has been restored for this version. It is truly underwhelming and it stars Myrna Loy and Nick Lucas. Finally, there is the massive "Lady Luck" finale which drags on for nearly a quarter of an hour. This is truly a misstep of the early-talkie era. Any old-movie buff will find this tedious."

*What I Like About SPOILERS* Teenager Holly Tyler (Amanda Bynes) goes to live with older sister Valerie (Jennie Garth) to avoid moving to Japan with her father; but she doesn't know the half of the wacky things that will happen to her from now on, and not only to her, but to her sister, her friends Gary (Wesley Jonathan) and Tina (Alison Munn), boyfriend Henry (Michael McMillian), crush Vince (Nick Zano), Valerie's boyfriend Jeff (Simon Rex), first boss (then firefighter then husband) Vic (Dan Cortese), annoying colleague Lauren (Leslie Grossman) and second boss Peter (?) If you don't have a tolerance for childish humor, please skip this; if you like only veeeery sophisticated comedy this is definitely not for you; if you can't stand a silly, sometimes cringeworthy show with two overacting chicks in the lead (and none other than the irritating 'Mary Cherry' from Popular - Leslie Grossman - in the main cast), then what the hell are you waiting for? Stay far away from Casa De Tyler! What I Like About You (2002-2006): 3.

Disappointing pirate entertainment. It lacks the ingredients to keep one's attention -- a tedious tale of intrigue, an unconvincing lady pirate named Spitfire Stevens (Maureen O'Hara) who's awkwardly paired with the uninspiring Mr. Hawke (Errol Flynn) who is out on a secret mission of his own. They make an unconvincing romantic pair onscreen -- yawn!

Anthony Quinn is the mean, bad pirate weaving his villainous web of divide and conquer. I noticed the very familiar face of Mildred Natwick playing a supporting role as Mrs. MacGregor, the protector of young Princess Patma (Alice Kelley).

There is beautifully filmed scenery of shorelines, ships, and the bay. However, the action scenes of sword fighting clashes, ship battles, and daring leaps of Errol Flynn (Robin Hood on board ship!) feel forced and unexciting. From the flaming redhead herself I once heard in an interview of Maureen O'Hara that she boasted great command of the bullwhip and could also outdo Flynn in sword fighting in those days but there'd be no need to put it to the test here.

Barely watchable movie.

Now this is one of Big's Worst, Jack Hulbert's single role in 1931 split into two for the Band Waggon radio team Askey & Murdoch. It suffers from a lackluster cast, who overact to the point of annoyance, especially Askey of course. Poor performances were provided by Linden Travers, melodramatics by Herbert Lomas, and pragmatics by Richard Murdoch.

The group of rail passengers stranded at the lonely country station for the night find more than they bargained for, ghostly trains, spectral porters, hairy sausage rolls and Arthur trying to entertain them all. His repartee with everyone falls between cringe-worthy and ghastly dull. When the formula works it's barely passable, but it mostly gets very contrived and forced making the film seem even more dated than it is. And those damn treacherous fifth columnists - thank any God Britain hasn't got any nowadays!

Ultimately a tedious and irritating film, to dread seeing back on the TV screen as an unwelcome guest, and if you were expecting to be shivered out of your timbers you'll definitely be very disappointed!

I first saw this movie when I was a freshman in high school, and the film has unfortunately stuck with me through the years. It's not about the soundtrack, or cinematography, or even the dialogue and somewhat bad acting, it's about the misguided educational purpose, and the flawed message behind that is the most problematic. It incorrectly suggests that it's a sin to have a child when you're a teenager and still in high school, and that it's always a bad thing, which is an oversimplification. Tons of girls I knew are all having children now, and I guess they never watched this misleading movie, and if they did, they wisely didn't get the message behind it all. It's about fearmongering when you're in a sexual relationship. While it's true that any girl can get pregnant the first time, the movie exaggerates the consequences. You don't necessarily lose out on your dreams, but the film wrongly implies that they always have to take a backseat in your future because you have a child to think about first.

This movie has a clear but misguided message behind it: JUST SAY NO! Which is an overly simplistic approach to a complex issue.

Insisting that Martin Luther King's inspirational spirit resides not just in American civil liberties but inside the hearts and minds of people everywhere, Danish helmer Niels Arden Oplev attempts to transplant this belief to a 1969 Danish middle school, but falls short. More specifically, it fails to work its way into the crusade of a young boy named Frits (Janus Dissing Rathke) against his oppressively rigid and churlishly abusive headmaster Svendsen (Bent Mejding). Adapted from a true story, the performances are executed with a lack of conviction and a confusing approach to its varied characters keeps it disengaging. A battle of ideologies between a 13 year-old and a demented disciplinarian gives way to forced humour and awkward shifts in mood disorients, despite attempting to keep it shrewdly cynical in the same vein as a Dead Poets Society" more than a "Matilda". It treads a familiar path but a continued and precise service to its young protagonist including a personal subplot that rounds off Frits as a young boy becoming a young man, fails to raise the film above mediocrity, resulting in a tiresome family film that misses the mark."

Of course if you are reading my review you have seen this film already. 'Raja Babu' is one of my least favorite characters.
