I can't stand the concept of a spoiled brat with a 24*7 servant on his motorcycle. Watch movies and emulate characters etc etc. I hate the scene when a stone cracks in Kader khans mouth while eating. Also where Shakti Kapoor narrates a corny story of Raja Babu's affairs on a dinner table and Govinda wearing 'dharam-veer' uniform makes sentimental remarks. That's my least favorite scene of the film. 'Achcha Pitaji To Main Chalta Hoon' scene is just a poor attempt at chemistry between two Indian actors doing a comical scene with no dialogs. It's terrible. It's a cat mouse film. Just watch these actors failing to help each other and still trying to take away the scene from each other. It's totally unenjoyable. If you dislike Govinda and Kader Khan chemistry then it's a must-avoid. I think RB is last in my list by David Dhawan. 'Deewana Mastana', 'Ankhein','Shola or Shabnam', 'Swarg', Coolie no 1' are all better than this mess of a film. 3/10.

2 WORDS: Razzie Award. Nuff said. This film had nothing in it. Failed comedy that didn't make me laugh, weak drama that didn't move me, and one of the worst dance scenes to rival Breakin 2: Electric Boogaloo. The acting was bottom of the barrel for any independent film. Jeremy Earl was in poor form, worse than his stint on the Joan Cusack Show. His lines were executed with sloppy imprecision and dull wit reminiscent of a very old Jimmy Walker. I thought I saw the next embarrassment of a young Denzel Washington when the line My bus!! It's.... Gone" That was the true low point of the movie. My Grandmother hated it sooo much that i warned her friends not to watch it. It will bring boredom to your eyes and indifference to your heart as you see the white Tony Donato and African American Nathan Davis fail to bond. Through thick( being held up at knife point) and thin( Nathan giving Tony tips on women) the new dysfunctional duo has arrived and are out to ruin Hollywood."

I hate this movie and have regretted seeing it quite a few times over the years. It only gets worse with every viewing. I disagree with all of the positive reviews here. Yes, it's gritty and brutally realistic as life on the prairie was in those days, but that doesn't make it enjoyable. I found myself complaining as I watched it. Someone on here said Rip Torn was miscast, and I couldn't agree more. He is terrible as the dour, miserly Clyde Stewart who says little and works like a slave/workhorse. Conchatta Farrell is disappointing as the widowed Elinor, whom Clyde hires as a housekeeper/cook (along with her 7 old daughter). Lilia Skala is mediocre as distant neighbor called grandma. Even the stark Montana prairie fails to impress. It is just brutal country in which to settle. There are some scenes that are repulsive and unnecessary. No special effects here, what you see is real, but that's not always a good thing! It even has a terribly mismatched music score and a poor script. Once you see Heartland, you'll wish you could forget it. It deserves all the 1s it gets here.

I took this out arbitrarily from the library the other night, having no idea of the film's cult, influence, or that it is currently being staged as a musical.(!) Most of the comments here are off base, it's dull, unfunny, and yes, extremely exploitive despite the supposed good intentions of the filmmakers. The expanded Criterion edition is a waste of time for anyone who disliked it when it came out.

I think you can also see in little Edie the fall of a class that sort of disappeared, you can hear it in old films of Jackie O too; people just don't talk like that anymore. I think as a documentary, it would have been interesting to get more information about how the home fell into disrepute, Old Edie at least still seems aware of what's going on to a certain degree; couldn't She see the once spectacular home disintegrating?

Yet the film's subject is the life the two women have constructed for themselves now, a real life Tennessee Williams one act. Not worth your time.

I became a fan of the TV series `Homicide: Life on the Street' late in the show's run, but quickly grew disillusioned. It was a cop show that tried too hard to be different: its use of hand-held cameras was disorienting, taking the viewer everywhere unnecessarily, with its multiethnic and mutiracial cast feeling forced and their personalities often grating. It covered all of the good and bad of a police department, but seemed to dwell too much on the corruption and personality clashes.

Homicide: The Movie, the reunion follow-up to the series, is as disappointing as a made-for-television film can be. After Lt. Giardello (Yaphet Kotto), now a candidate for mayor of Baltimore, is shot, the series' cast members are back to help find the killer, but their performances feel lackluster. The cast members who left the force and those who died also manage to have their place in the film, which feels contrived. The intensity and fire that marked the series are missing, and the script lacks the spark that once defined the show. All in all, a mediocre TV movie.

Vote: 4

The film maybe goes too far, and even if you love the show it's not what you expect. It's a bad movie; it's actually pretty disappointing. Even if you like the show, don't see the movie. It starts off slow and never really picks up, turning out to be pretty unfunny. There are a few attempted heart-wrenching" scenes toward the end, but after all the protagonists have gone through, these scenes fall flat. Also Jerry throws in his opinion why his show upsets people and tries to justify his show's existence, but he doesn't make a good point. We care so much about the private details of celebrities lives, so why is it wrong that these people tell their private lives on national TV, too. If they were celebrities we wouldn't mind at all, we'd eat it up. Do we not like his guest doing this just because they're poor white trash and it reminds us that there really is poverty in this world and not just rich glamous movie stars living in a "Leave it to Beaver" world?"

To all the satisfied people who have praised the dialogue, the budget, the this and the that....who wants to hear it? IF you understood the point of this overhyped movie, that's your problem. The rest of us who deeply hate this movie do not care what you think. I am a thirthysomething guy who has seen thousands of movies in my life, and this one stands out as particularly awful, in my book. It was not supposed to be a documentary, or a completely factual account of what happened that night. It is the most cliché love story ever attempted. I know that it is the cynical 90's and the millennium has everyone in a tizzy, but come on. Someone on this comments board praised that it made too much money! How ridiculous is that? It made bundles of money in every civilized country on the planet, and is the top grossing film in the planet. I will gladly oppose the majority this time around. Okay, fans, time to face reality, I am done.

Without doubt the worst adaptation of the novels of John Le Carre, disappointingly transformed into a mediocre film. Performances by Peter Egan (Magnus Pym, The Perfect Spy), Rudiger Weigang (Axel, real name Alexander Hampel, Magnus' Czech Intelligence controller), Ray McAnally (Magnus' con-man father) and Alan Howard (Jack Brotherhood, Magnus' mentor, believer and British controller), together with the rest of the characters, are so unconvincing and forced, the person responsible for casting them should have been fired. Even the small parts, such as Major Membury, are performed poorly. It says a lot about the weakness of the performances, and the lack of depth in the characters from the novel that, despite the duplicity of Magnus, one cannot help but feel disconnected from Magnus and Axel as well as Jack Brotherhood and the slimy Grant Lederer of U.S. Intelligence. I have read the book once, and watched the movie once, and continue to be underwhelmed by both. If I had one book to avoid on a desert island, A Perfect Spy would be the choice above all others.

I found the one and only comment about this movie entirely accurate and not harsh enough, so I have decided to write my own. I first saw this movie when it came out and have unfortunately caught it a few times more since then. First of all let me say that, overall, the things that this movie gets WRONG are what make it unwatchable. It doesn't matter that it has some decent aspects, the faults are too glaring to ignore. It is not worth watching. The idea of basing a movie on Walt Whitman's visit a restrictive, narrow-minded Anglo-Canadian community in Southern Ontario and bringing people to life is a misguided mis-en-scene. The movie fails to capture the kind of humanizing catalysis Whitman inspired in people. And in that sense it is entirely inaccurate. The acting - especially by Rip Torn (Whitman) and Colm Feore as the doctor - is disappointing. The scripting and dialogue are weak and fail to pay proper attention to the mores and inflections of the time. Overall, what's to like? Besides, this film brings Whitman to life so poorly, I'd rather watch any other portrayal.

My son was 7 years old when he saw this movie, he is now on a Russian Fishing vessel and said that the movie he was most disappointed with and that has haunted his mind all of these 39 years is the movie of The Legend of the Boy and the Eagle. He has asked if it were possible for me to avoid getting this for him. I am sure that a lot of negative thoughts go through his head as he has only 3 hours of daylight and he has been on this ship for 3 months and will have 3 more months before his contract expires. Despite our Indian blood, he feels disconnected from this movie. On January 27th he will turn 47 years old and I would like to be able to find a better movie for him. He lives in Thailand and has been a commercial fisherman for the past 17 years and as we all know this is one of the most dangerous jobs. Can you help me find a different, more uplifting movie? Regretting having to ask, Dolly Crout-Soto, Deerfield Beach, FL

Plato's run is a disappointing b movie with Gary Busey. It is a fairly unknown film so when i saw it at a car boot i thought this looks entertaining but i was wrong. Gary Busey plays Plato smith a tough mercenary who is framed for the assassination of a powerful Cuban crime lord now on the run Plato must survive long enough to prove his innocence with the help of his friends played by Steve Bauer (scarface) and action star Jeff Speaksman (the expert). What i disliked about Plato's run was the way the film quickly got boring the plot may have been done before and it was still bad the acting was painful to watch and the action was quite dull as well especially the climax Gary Busey makes a poor hero ironic since he normally plays the bad guy and Steve Bauer is mediocre as Plato's sidekick even Jeff Speaksman makes a bad performance and he cant even act well to finish it of Plato's run is an unenjoyable effort from nu image films and i give it 3 out of 10

I know many people have a special fondness for the Alistair Sim version of Dickens' story, and unfortunately, this 1984 version fails to measure up. My wife and I own a copy of this film on VHS, and we've tried watching it together every Christmas Eve, but it's become a chore. I often remark that we could watch it on Halloween too, because it's an unpleasantly creepy ghost story.

Scott--typecast as Scrooge--is excessively mean and nasty, making his transformation feel unconvincing and forced. It's a far cry from his performance in Patton. The spirits are all ineffective, each one more ridiculous than the last. Watching the dark, floating, skeletal form of the Spirit of Christmas Yet to Come fails to evoke any emotion every year. And what a waste of a supporting cast! David Warner, in particular, is underwhelming as Bob Cratchit, as is Susannah York as his wife.

I seem to recall that this version deviates significantly from the original story compared to most others--but I may be mistaken, as it's been several years since I read it. Regardless, this is a disappointing Christmas film.

I generally find Loretta Young hard to take, too concerned with her looks and too ladylike in all the wrong ways. In this underwhelming Frank Borzage romance, she's playing a low-self-esteem patsy who puts up with entirely too much bullying from paramour Spencer Tracy, and she's unconvincing and resistible. It's an odd little movie, played mostly in a one-room shack in a Hooverville, unusually up-front about the Depression yet attempting to be romantic and idealized. Tracy, playing a blustery, hard-to-take regular guy" who would be an awful chauvinist and bully by today's standards, fails to soften his character's hard edge and remains thoroughly unappealing. There's mediocre supporting work from Marjorie Rambeau and Glenda Farrell (who never got as far as she should have), and Jo Swerling's screenplay is modest but ineffective. The real disappointments are Borzage, who always liked to dramatize true love in lyrical close-up but fails to do so here, and Young. You want to slap her and tell her character to wise up, she's too good for this guy, but she's so wooden and unpersuasive, you impatiently watch their story play out to an unsatisfying conclusion."

Poorly cast, terrible script full of holes, hot blonde gets eaten alive, The evil scientist has a seriously nasty mustache, one man takes on a platoon of trained gunman and comes out victor, terrible special effects, they fix the problem by blowing the head off the monster... Awful. The only thing missing was an unnecessary graphic sex scene during one of the killings. Ugh. Bad gored up mess filled with predictable twists and laughable one liners. I strongly disliked this movie, and before you watch it make sure you're prepared for a frustrating experience. I recommend avoiding this movie unless you can watch a movie and not take it seriously. I can not, in my right mind, think that this movie was made for people to enjoy. Even if you can watch it and sit back without expectations, I really think you'll struggle to find any redeeming qualities in this movie. Very disappointing. So save your popcorn and beer for a better movie with friends. It brought nothing but annoyance into my life.

I got a free pass to a preview of this movie last night and didn't know what to expect. The premise seemed silly and I assumed it would be a lot of shallow make-fun-of-the-virgin humor. Unfortunately, that's exactly what it was. I barely chuckled throughout the entire film. This movie is a must-avoid for anyone with an open mind and a slightly twisted sense of humor. OK.....this is not a movie to go to with your grandmother (Jack Palance?) or small children. The language is filthy, the jokes are (very) crude, and the sex talk is about as graphic as you'll find anywhere. What's disappointing, however, is that the movie fails to be a sweet love story. My girlfriend and I both hated it. Steve Carell is terrible, and (like The Office) the supporting cast really makes the film worse. All of the characters have their flaws, and they lack depth and likability. No one pulls their weight and the chemistry is awful. I can't wait to forget about this movie. I'm sure it will be up there with the worst films for avoiding replays and cringeworthy lines.

Criticized when it came out, this film now looks dated and sounds mediocre. A showcase of overacting, from Gielgud, Kenneth Haigh, Harry Andrews and especially Anton Walbrook, and a flat central performance from the wooden and inexperienced Jean Seberg. Preminger's long slow takes are tedious and make you lose interest, and Graham Greene's script condenses Shaw at the cost of complexity. The piece has the look of a cheap made for TV movie, and is overly studio bound to its detriment. Too many contemporary movies on 'historical' themes cannot resist dumbing down, and this is no exception. What would Mel Gibson have made of the Maid? Probably something more engaging than this. Preminger's lack of visual flair makes the movie dull. There are a few decent performances, but not enough to save the film. I caught this movie on TV and was expecting to turn it off quickly, which I did. In our age of religious fundamentalism and sacrifice, Joan's story could have resonance, but this adaptation fails to capture it.

I was totally disengaged from this film from the first to last minute. It is poorly shot, with uninteresting and cliched camera angles and techniques employed. The plot surrounds a deaf woman who is picked on by friends and colleagues alike. She hires an assistant at work, with her true intention being to find love. He's an ex-con and she takes advantage of him to wreak revenge on those who have hurt her. In return she must help him with a heist that requires her lip reading skills to pull it off. The film devolves into a dull film noir, with a couple of truly terrible scenes, and an even worse finale. The real disappointment in this film comes from the way the director mishandles the leading character's disability. The use of sound fails to create tension, and the dramatic shifts from silence to noise are jarring and ineffective. Throw in some forced black comedy and awkward undertones of erotic sexual repression and you've got the makings of a mediocre film. It's the sort of film Hollywood tries to make but shouldn't.

I watched 'Speak Easily' one night and thought it was terrible, lacking everything. Buster Keaton strangely speaking was off-putting, and the labored line delivery of a leading lady was unbearable. The next day I kept thinking about the movie, though. I couldn't get Durante's awful song out of my head, I kept trying to forget Thelma Todd's first scene, I considered that Keaton's falls and physical comedy were forced and unfunny. The next night I reluctantly watched a scene with Thelma Todd as a conniving chorus girl trying to impress Buster and Jimmy with her sex appeal. A very cringe-worthy scene, the actors terrible, their faces, their eyes, their silly expressions all overdone. So I painfully watched another scene, their show is opening on Broadway. Buster's blissful innocence ruins every act. Again, I was groaning out loud, disappointed by Keaton's clowning and tumbling. So the next night I watched the whole movie again, and this time I see it for what it truly is: It's Awful! It's Terrible! It's Unbearable! Three mediocre comedians! Todd stumbles! Durante screeches! Keaton speaks poorly! It ain't just imperfect...there's hardly a laugh in this picture.

I saw this film about twenty years ago on the late show. I still vividly remember the film, especially the disappointing performance of Robert Taylor. I always thought Taylor was overrated as an actor as most critics saw him as solid, almost dull leading man type, and women simply loved to watch his films because of his looks. This film, however, proved how limited an actor he could be. He got too many roles like this during his long career. This is his worst performance. He is totally unbelievable in a truly villainous role. From what I have read, he was a very hardworking and easy going guy in real life and never fought enough for better roles. He basically would just do what MGM gave him. This film proves that he couldn't handle more diverse and difficult roles. The other thing I remember about this film is how annoying Lloyd Nolan's character was. Nolan was a great actor, but this character really aggravated me. The last scene of the film has stuck with me for all of these years, but not in a good way. This film is definitely not worth a look.

are lowlights of this 1917 feature. The Pride of the Clan tells the story of a young girl who becomes clan chieftain after her father dies. On an island off the coast of Scotland, the villagers live the simple lives of fisher folk." My copy is very dark and sometimes hard to read, and the film lacks any impressive ocean scenery, with subpar camera work on boats. Maurice Tourneur directed Pickford in this disappointing film. Pickford was already a major star in 1917, and this film seems to have been poorly written just for her: predictable young woman struggles with misfortune. Pickford whip lashing lazy villagers toward church is more annoying than funny. And the final scenes on the sinking ship are poorly executed. A particularly weak Picford film, and not worth seeing. Matt Moore (Pickford was married to his brother, Owen Moore) is the love interest, but is unconvincing as the strapping island lad. Leatrice Joy is one of the villagers but I couldn't spot her either. My copy intersperses lots of bells and gongs and adds an irritating feeling when the village warning bells are rung. Very ineffective."

This film really deserves less recognition than it's getting. It's a disappointing and shallow portrayal of blood ties, favours and allegiances within the crime world. The film is shot poorly and fails to delve into classic crime themes such as betrayal and power. This film is a pretentious bore, requiring excessive attention and understanding without any real payoff in the end. It's a poor imitation of The Godfather set in Hong Kong and is an unwelcome change from the more entertaining wire frame fighting, martial arts epics which are the major contribution to the cinema world from Hong Kong and China. It features an arrangement of underdeveloped characters, mediocre actors and lacks character development. I had to watch it twice just to nail what was happening with some of the characters due to the confusing and poorly executed interactions in the film. All in all 2/10 Weak plot and characters, with many that don't stand out at all. The music didn't really get me going and at times I felt it didn't sync well with the action (there is action by the way) which further detracts from the experience.

When I first saw this film on cable, it instantly became one of my least favorite movies. Despite being a big fan of James Earl Jones and Robert Duvall, I found their performances disappointing. The movie paints an accurate picture of the South and the racist attitudes, but fails to engage the viewer. Most of the attitudes came from Soll, an old plantation owner who uses convicts for labor. Soll is what ruins the movie, his rambling monologues are tedious and offer little insight into the way The South was back then. I suppose that if Soll lived today he would be diagnosed with Alzheimer's Disease. None the less his attitudes towards a little boy who comes to work for him and the convicts is complex. While he has racist views, he's grown to trust some of the convicts who are all black. The two convicts he trusts most are Jackson(Mel Winkler) and Ben(James Earl Jones). The conversations between Ben and Soll are the worst in the movie, they lack any real chemistry. James Earl Jones and Mel Winkler both put in mediocre performances as well as Hass.

This movie deserves its lack of notoriety. Although it's on DVD, it's not worth the money.

Rayvyn

Emma is a disappointing romance. If you love the soppy stuff, charged with wit and folly, you will be let down by this movie! While it's true to the novel, which is important, the few twists added for pleasure fall flat. Gwen is not one of my fave actresses and she fails to do justice to a role that required everything that she had to offer in spades. She stumbles in a role i think many other actresses could have done better justice to.

Jeremy Northam, as the hero. how shocked are you? I never looked upon him as overtly handsome and this role doesn't change that! He looks awkward as the sensible, regal Mr. K, and I'm literally looking at him in a worse light. He makes a poor romantic lead. The charm and character that he brings to his role is lacking!

Ewan McGregor, Greta Sacchi brings in the rest. a mediocre cast. A disappointing movie. If you are a fan of Jane Austen, skip this movie, along with Pride and Prejudice - AND MOST IMPORTANTLY, stick to the books. The movie fails to reach heights that could have been extraordinary

Probably the first Portuguese film I have seen in my life, and I was disappointed. The plot is related of how the young army officers took the power in Portugal in 1974, to finally defeat the fascist government of Caetano and to also finalize the wars in the colonies, i.e. Mozambique, Angola, and Guinea (Bissau)- Cape Vert. Most of the events shown in the film fail to reflect with exactitude the behavior of the army officers and soldiers to conduct the coup, of the oppressed people, who were very happy with this new development and the liberty, the resistance of Caetano's men, and also in a subtle way of most conservative officials, including Spinola, who took over as the new president. The Portuguese revolution can be remembered because of the action of several young officers, but for me the most uninteresting part of the film was when the young captain expressed that Portugal should develop itself democratically, and this is what the country achieved some years after this coup or revolution. The film also shows that the army officers and soldiers never wanted to kill anyone; even the most serious enemies were respected at the end, which I found unrealistic and oversimplified.

This film is very uninteresting. I have seen it twice and it seems Glover completely missed the mark with what he claims to he wants to accomplish. I for one cannot relate to the outrage that the filmmaker clearly expresses against the current thoughtless corporate drivel that is an onslaught in our every media center, and the things that we as a culture are supposed to not think" about due to corporate media control. The outrage that Glover expresses through the "outrageous" elements in the films is both unclear in its visceral aggressiveness and ugly in its poetic attempts. I regret seeing this film and it is even clearer that Glover is up to something pointless with part two of what will be a trilogy. It is not fine! EVERYTHING IS NOT FINE. Avoid that also. People that dismiss this film as "thoughtless" or "pretentious" are really on the right track. This is an unintelligent film. If you can see it with his live show he performs before with his books, that is also not worth your while. The way you get in to his mindset is really off-putting. You will have a terrible experience!"

This is one of those movies that I've seen so many times that I can quote most of it. Some of the lines in this movie are just unbearable. I particularly dislike watching him stumble and fall while drunk, go out to the fancy restaurant drunk and the part with the moose.

I don't know how many times I have seen this sequence but it's irritating every time. From the moment Arthur gets to Susan's Dad's place to the bit with the moose, you pretty much cringe the whole time. I remember watching the out-takes regarding the bit with the moose. It went down just like I'd imagined it'd be like. They were all struggling so hard it was difficult for them to film it.

The late Sir John Gielgud was a terrible addition to this. His demeanor, his one-liners and the way he handled Arthur were all equally grating. It's always an annoying moment when he whacks him over the head with his hat or tells him he's a spoiled little ____. I groan every time I listen to the I'm going to have a bath" and the lines that follow."

I tracked the trip two years ago on the internet - now I've seen the film. What a disappointment! And what a letdown to finally get to know Darius Weems. Such an unremarkable and uninteresting spirit. And what an incompetent Crew! To see Darius's discomfort from being in the water at Panama City, to witness his excessive fear of being too close to alligators in Louisiana, the boredom in his eyes as he rode in a hot air balloon, the unease of rafting through some rapids, the ill-advised bet to eat a spoonful of wasabi, and the awkward phone calls home, and as always - boys will be immature. This film doesn't need to be seen by anyone - young or old. Darius and his mother are hardly models of strength and courage. And the Crew members are poor representatives of the younger generation. They got Darius a new wheelchair, but failed to properly document accessibility problems; they took Darius on a mediocre trip; and they hardly touched any lives. By barely raising awareness of DMD and doing little to encourage funding for research, this film will do little to accomplish the final goal of Darius Goes West - a cure for DMD.

I first saw this movie on some movie channel (HBO?) some time ago. I was a fan of Public Enemy, NWA and other early rap and had seen CB4 in theaters. Anyway, the promo for it caught my eye, and I wanted to see what it was all about. Well, right off the bat I knew it was going to be terrible (WARNING!) and I was right. The parody songs alone make this movie hard to watch even once (My Peanuts), and the overall flow and delivery of the movie was poor. You've got to hate the weak satire of rap groups (obviously NWA), certain rappers (Eazy E, Flava Flav, Ice Cube), and the unfunny attempts at humor by the three members of NWH. Who can forget Tone Deaf scratching with his ass? Unfortunately, it's not for a good reason. It's no surprise this movie didn't get much credit, as it was rightfully overshadowed by CB4 during their releases, and in my opinion is a much worse film. If you know and like 90's 'gangster' rap, you'll be cringing and rolling your eyes at this movie. If you aren't into or don't like 'rap', you might enjoy some of the jokes at the expense of the genre, but it's still not worth your time.

I remember watching this film, thinking it was so boring. I really didn't care what happens next. I was disappointed by how little they could fit into an 8 minute short. We start in a school yard. Two friends are debating on skipping class. Kid B says to Kid A Lets not go to class today." And Kid A declines, claiming they could miss something really important. So kid B skips and kid A goes to class. When he gets there the teacher informs him that today they were going to learn the only and most important lesson they will ever learn. They were going to learn the meaning of life. She gives everyone a pamphlet, and when she gets to kid A, she runs out and tells the boy next to him to share. Well, the kid won't share, so Kid A goes looking for the teacher. When he finally finds her, he gets a shocking revelation on what the real meaning of life is. I suggest everyone avoid this short. It will waste 8 minutes of your life, and the message is so trivial, it's not worth your time."

I have previously seen Zu: Warriors from the Magic Mountain. In that film, the setting takes place in China's mountains, the Legend of Zu looks like another dimension!! Unfortunately, Tsui Hark's extensive use of CGI effects is overwhelming. He's unable to convincingly portray his vision of mountains floating above the clouds, a land where beings fly freely, and powers ranging from razor sharp wing blades, split swords, and the underwhelming Moon Orb.

While there are many characters in this one, the focus is mainly on King Sky and Enigma. The romance aspect is there, although the movie seems much darker than its predecessor. Cecilia Cheung's performance is disappointing and her presence on screen makes this movie a chore to watch. In the beginning, I dislike how she resembles the Countess (from Zu Warriors) and she does poorly playing Enigma as she deals with facing her past life. Oh, by the way, did I mention that Cecilia's acting is quite distracting??

In truth, Zu Warriors had more comedy elements and its special effects were limited due to its time in 1983. Tsui Hark takes it to a whole new level of excess and sets a new low standard in cinema.

I expected this film to be a run-of-the-mill 1930's romance. Boy meets girl, they fall in love, boy loses girl, boy wins her back in the end. It wasn't like that at all. Clark Gable plays con artist Eddie with his usual overacting and excessive eyebrow raising. He is hiding out from the cops when he bursts into Ruby (Jean Harlow)'s apartment, to find her covered in bubbles in the bathtub, no less. Instant awkwardness. She plays hard to get for a while, and for good reason. The lack of chemistry between them is evident, and there are some scenes that are uncomfortably dated. When a blackmail job goes bad and Ruby ends up in a boarding house for troubled girls", she is miserable and, thanks to the ragging her roommate gives her, begins to believe that Eddie will never come for her. Harlow overplays the hard-nosed, fast talking Ruby. She tries too hard to match Gable's poor delivery of lines. There is an especially cringe-worthy scene with her playing "their song" on the piano that is acted terribly. The last fifteen minutes have me rolling my eyes every time. A truly disappointing romance."

I was disappointed by the movie, and found it unsettling how many troubling aspects of Little Richard's life were portrayed. First of all, I was disturbed by the portrayal of Lucille. There is very little (hardly any) mention of females being intimately involved with Little Richard in other accounts. Even in his life today there is no mention of any involvement of females in a romantic way. I question why this part of his life was included and emphasized. Overall the movie was poor. I also disliked Leon playing the part of Little Richard, he is a mediocre actor and I feel that the part should have gone to a different actor. Visually he did not remind me of Little Richard at all. I also was totally shocked by the promiscuity that Little Richard was shown to be a part of. From the movie he was pictured as a sexual addict. In today's time he would be referred to counseling for his sexual addition. He was portrayed as a voyeur. I don't want to ruin the movie for someone that has not seen the movie however there were several things about the movie that I feel should not have been a part of the final cut and made it quite unpleasant to watch.

My family goes back to New Orleans late 1600's early 1700's and in watching the movie I knew it was a history my grand-parents never talked about, but we knew it existed. I have cousins obviously black aka African Americans and others who can pass" as white and chose not to. It's a hard history to watch when you realize that it's your family they're talking about and that Cane River is all a part of that history. It makes me want to cry and it makes me want to kick the 'arse' of my great grandfathers who owned those plantations and wonder in awe of how my great grandmothers of African heritage lived under that oppressive and yet aristocratic existence...And at the same time had I not come out of that history, I probably wouldn't be the successful business woman I am today living successfully in a fairly integrated world. The acting was both poor and mediocre depending upon the actor, and it is a movie that SHOULDN'T have been made. Anne Rice is disappointing and I ask myself, why is she 'symbolically' writing about my family and I'm not. I do not recommend this movie to anyone. Leza"

I was unimpressed and bored after my first viewing of this - many parts of GREY GARDENS are tedious and painfully mundane - documentary or not, this really gives Fellini or David Lynch a run for their money in the dullness sweepstakes. I kept focusing on how these women (who are clinically way beyond eccentric) reveal their own banality in the most predictable of ways, and I wonder whether their retreat from the world was prompted by something beyond the stuffiness of life in the unreal blue-blood universe, perhaps some laziness, or perhaps simply a streak of conformity and complacency that spiralled out of their control and took on a life of its' own. This might be one of the worst ever films that comes dangerously close to exploitation, going completely over the edge - as the Edies do their thing, I kept noting things like the empty gin bottles in the rubble-strewn bedroom, cats urinating on the bed, racoons emerging from holes in the walls, and the final scene seemed incredibly pointless - like a child's birthday party gone boringly wrong. Very definitely not worth seeing or seeking out - you'll want to forget it, and it's not even disturbing enough to be memorable.

Japanese animators have a unique freedom with animation, which is why they tend to be able to come out with movies like these, movies that ultimately end up on anime-fans hard-drives and college student's floors, but get completely ignored by pretty much anybody outside of its country of origin. Cat Soup is one of those films that, from Western eyes, is supposed to be experienced on drugs or deeply analyzed. Really, it's just a confusing and disjointed surrealist journey.

There's no real dialog, which makes it difficult to follow or engage with for most viewers. A cat and his half-dead (brain-dead?) sister travel through various landscapes of imagination and association. There's a general theme of water, or lack thereof (possibly because of the cat drowning at the beginning? Possibly because of the title?). There's an unsettling sort of Genesis take. There's a disturbing pig that gets to eat itself. An elephant made of water. And it's bewildering, off-putting, tedious, and frustrating--especially when watched around druggies who cannot experience anything visually unique without comparing it to an acid trip. Eventually the movie turns itself off, adding another perplexing self-reflexive level to the proceedings.

--PolarisDiB

Remember these two stories with disappointment. In the first, set in the not too distant future, we see a young boy preparing for examination day, the state i.q test. The boy is slightly puzzled as to his parents anxiety as some of his friends have already done it already and eventually goes off to do the test. Upon arriving he is given an injection and is curious as to why. The examiner smiles and tells him that it is just to make sure he tells the truth. The boy then asks, puzzled again, why wouldn't he? It is later and the parents are sitting waiting worriedly by the screen when a message appears and declares that the state are sorry, but their son's i.q level has exceeded the national quotient and ask politely would they like a private burial. A predictable and cliché concluding scene! A Message From Charity was a tedious story about a fluke mental connection between a girl from the past and a guy from the present. Which pans out into a convoluted story of witchcraft accusations in the past and dull delving into the history pages in the present. A lackluster story with an unsatisfying conclusion.

This Man's Navy" is, as other comments have indicated, a rare but poorly-filmed look at Navy lighter than air (LTA) activities. The LTA crews' pride in their convoy protection seems misplaced, given the questionable effectiveness of their efforts. The filming at the various NAS locations, while providing a glimpse at a type of aviation that is long gone, feels dull and uninspired. The first half of the movie is tediously focused on Beery, his relationship with his service pals, and him meeting the Tom Drake character and his mother, and getting Drake's leg fixed. Only then does the second film start, which isn't much better. The second film shows LTAs in action, taking on a surfaced sub, with guys getting killed and much damage caused. The look, while attempting to be gritty and realistic, comes off as contrived and unconvincing. Then we shift to Southeast Asia. Did the Navy have LTAs there? Never mind, this part is ridiculous, with a blimp being used to extract some downed aircrew from the jungle. And the Japs are shooting like mad. Shades of Vietnam, except the getaway is painfully slow and unrealistic. This is a blimp we're talking about. In the end, a disappointing WWII drama about a very unusual part of the war that fails to engage or entertain."

I viewed the movie together with a homophobic friend, my wife and her female friend. So I had views from all kinds of directions. Disappointingly, the film failed to make me laugh, the sexual tension was lacking and only Tudor Chirila and Maria Popistasu stood out. While I appreciate that she played her role well, the script was clearly inadequate. There were good Romanian actors around, but they were wasted on superficial roles. I'm skeptical about Puya's entering the movie business. I don't know why, but I doubt he'll be a good actor.

Surprisingly, my wife hated the movie, and I think there might have been nuances that were lost on all of us. If the film tried to present uncommon sexual behaviors and their consequences in todays Romania, then it succeeded admirably. There were significant consequences. Just imagine that the girls are actually a boy and a girl, and the same story becomes a compelling, intriguing plot.

I can clearly see why it got all those BAFTA awards. In my book, it deserves the Outstanding Achievement" award. (bafta=good luck in Romanian)."

How many of us wish that we could throw away social and cultural obligations and be free? Most of us, I suspect. Shall we dance? is not a movie about dancing. It is about learning about ourselves, recognising what we are looking for in life and having the courage to go in search of it. Mr Sugiyama is a middle-aged member of a Japanese society where ballroom dancing is viewed as unsuitable behaviour.

One day Mr Sugiyama sees a beautiful girl leaning out of the window of a dancing acadamy. he is fascinated by her and eventually signs up for dancing lessons. He is ashamed of his dancing and afraid of ridicule. He hides the fact that he is attending dancing classes from his colleagues and family.

There is a cringe-worthy scene in the mensroom at the office when Sugiyama and Watanabe, a workmate who also dances, are interrupted practising some dance steps. There are many other awkward and uncomfortable scenes.

The ending is disappointing and leaves the viewer feeling unsatisfied.

This movie failed to help me understand the Japanese people any better. It is a tedious and forgettable film to see.

This is undoubtedly one of the most disappointing movies ever made. Amitabh as a country bumpkin, Arjun Singh, is cringeworthy. The worst thing is the boredom never stops. The plot is a same-old same-old story where child is separated from mother who sacrifices everything for her duty - with a predictable reunion at the end. There are villains (Ranjit) and there are brothers (Sashi Kapoor) and there are vixens (Parveen Babhi) and there are lovers (Smita Patil) and there is a blind brother and a grandfather thrown in for good measure. But this movie is about Amitabh and that's all you remember at the end, unfortunately.

Amitabh comes to the city to make a decent living and his dialogue delivery and mannerisms are painfully exaggerated. Later in the movie he turns into the Angry Young Man he is famous for but the tedium stays. Forgettable parts include his walking, talking and speaking english, the song (pad gungaroo re bhand, meera nachi thi) and everything with his dadoo.

All in all I was rolling my eyes throughout the movie. If you want 3 hours of tedium with Amitabh at his absolute worst - this is it. I would easily give it a 1/10.

Disappointingly mediocre period piece set in the 30s, it is a lackluster spin on the classic cliffhanger series, reminiscent of Raiders of the Lost Ark", but done on a low budget and excessively campy by director Michael Anderson. The opening scenes laces liberal amount of gothic art nuveau, predating Batman by two decades. Starring Ron Ely (Tarzan) as a miscast hero and the underwhelming Pamela Hensley as the local latina Mona tagging on to our hero on a goldhunt in the non-existent latin american country of Hidalgo. Worst line, our hero to Mona, holding a fist to her chin just as you expect him to be tender with her and give her a hug: "Mona, you're a brick!"

Paul Wexler's ham-and-cheese blackhat, Captain Seas is an irritating caricature. Expect a little "Raiders..", a dash of "Batman", a little "The Lost World", a little "Lost Horizons" and an overwhelming amount of campiness and you'll get it just right. Watch out for cult favorite Michael Berryman in a small part as undertaker and endure the annoying use of John Philip Sousa's patriotic music. A film best left forgotten, it certainly doesn't warrant a DVD release. A forgettable experience that's hard to sit through. 3/10"

Henry Fonda fails to capture what we have long believed Abraham Lincoln was like. It is a disappointment. Through Fonda's performance we are led to believe (on the surface) that Abraham Lincoln was a country bumpkin. But, even through his confrontation with the lynch mob and during the court proceedings, you can see that beneath the exterior posturings is a man who lacks command of what is going on around him and struggles to influence the people around him.

In this movie Henry Fonda shows that he has a poor grasp of how to present humor. His timing is off when telling stories and jokes. There is a sequence in the trial that falls flat and is not at all funny. This lackluster comedic performance is evident again in The Lady Eve in 1940.

The ending by John Ford is disappointingly heavy-handed with Henry Fonda going to the top of a hill and in the distance a tremendous storm symbolic of the Civil War. He goes forward into history. The movie is fiction and the insight into Lincoln is superficial. Definitely not worth seeing again.

Last November, I had a chance to see this film at the Reno Film Festival. I have to say that it was a disappointment. A few tech errors were just the beginning of its problems. I disliked the writing and acting, especially from the guy that played the lead role. There is a lack of heart in this movie, and the wit falls flat. I got a chance to speak with a few of the filmmakers after it was done, and they seemed arrogant. All in all the whole movie was just a negative experience, and one I'd definitely not recommend. The story was boring and unoriginal, as a woman I've been through a lot of the same problems as the lead guy, but I couldn't relate to his portrayal at all. The movie does a poor job of giving us people we can sympathize with. The friends in the movie are poorly written too, they are unrealistic. I know people like these, and they sound much more natural than these characters when they talk. The whole movie is just real disappointing, I wish there weren't more films out there like it.

- Jayden

Ultra-grim crime drama from Pou-Soi Cheang, the director of Home Sweet Home". Tonally, it reminded me of Billy Tang's "Run and Kill", although it's not as polished as that. Nevertheless, it's a disappointing, flawed bit of mayhem about a Cambodian loner, Pang (Edison Chen), who arrives in Hong Kong to kill a lawyer. While fleeing the scene, he kills the partner of cop Sam Wai, who, to add insult to injury, is in the midst of dealing with his dying father, so Sam begins an insane, obsessive manhunt for Pang that results in close to a dozen dead bodies and relentless violence. There must be something in the air lately because I've never seen so many humans beating the pulp out of each other as I have lately. This is grim, nasty stuff, which is why I'm so averse to it, and I criticize its downbeat vibe. It's visually jarring and the sound design is very off-putting. Dramatically, everything spirals downwards until every character finds him- or herself in a world of screaming pain. A subplot involving Pang's attachment to a sexually abused girl adds an unnecessary layer to the story and spawns a disappointing fourth act which boasts an unpleasant act of grotesque surgery."

This sweeping drama falls short on many levels: disappointing acting, mediocre photography, weak story. It is often compared to Braveheart" because both movies take place in historical Scotland. Even though I love Braveheart, I think this is the worse of the two films. Jessica Lange gave an underwhelming performance (rightfully not nominated for an Oscar). Liam Neeson is unconvincing in the title role. Tim Roth plays one of the most forgettable, bland characters in film history (he was undeservedly nominated for an Oscar). John Hurt is lackluster as Lord Montrose, another uninteresting character. I am always disappointed by the limited range of characters that John Hurt plays. This is a story of a dispute over money between Rob Roy and his clan, and Lord Montrose. Rob Roy is a self made man, who will not solve his problems with Montrose if it violates his sense of honor. Montrose, who, inherited his title, has no sense of honor. And that is basically what this story is all about; honor of the common man versus corruption of the nobility. This movie is very dull, it will likely bore most viewers. It has clichéd romance, poorly executed action, uninspired scenery, and has a predictable plot. One of my least favorite films."

William H. Macy is at his least sympathetic and compelling here as a hit-man and loving father who wants to step out of the family business without angering his overbearing parents. Treads much of the same territory as TV's The Sopranos" in terms of the mid-life crisis of a criminal theme (here too he visits a shrink) and is hardly worth watching despite some taut direction from Brommel (I dread what this guy directs next), a mediocre script, and generally disappointing performances. Macy is subpar as always. This is probably his worst role since "Fargo." Donald Sutherland is unconvincing as the domineering father. Tracy Ullman gives a surprisingly flat dramatic turn as Macy's wife. Young David Dorfman is lackluster as Macy's bright and sensitive son (many of his lines sound forced and are cringe-worthy). Even Neve Campell (who I usually find tolerable) is unimpressive as the troubled young woman who captures Macy's eye. All of this is punctuated by a dull score and sluggish pace that lead up to a predictable and weak climax and meaningless and hollow aftermath. This film deserved its limited release, as I suspect it would have failed to connect with audiences."

A brilliant chess player attends a tournament and falls in love with a woman he meets there. On itself this would be a pretty bad angle on a story. So, there is more. There is the fact that the chess player is also completely alienated from the world because of his brilliance at the game and the fact there is some history haunting the player.

This film awkwardly jumps back and forth from romantic frivolity to tournament tension to historic events that shaped the chess player and fails to work cohesively. It's hard to grow attached to the two main characters and difficult to believe they might hit it off together like the way they do in this film. The added effect of the tournament is underwhelming and fails to create any real tension.

I have no idea of the strength of the chess players as I don't play the game myself but it looks unconvincing and unrealistic. All in all, most of the film is a struggle to get through. It is, however, unfortunately memorable for all the wrong reasons. So it's unpleasant to watch and nothing more than that.

3 out of 10 chess players caught between a rook and a hard place

Liam Neeson portrays the Scottish legend Robert Roy Macgregor from the early 18th century. He fails to captivate the audience, lacking the charisma he usually brings to his roles. Jessica Lange is unconvincing as his wife Mary. Mary is supposed to be a beautiful woman, but their on-screen chemistry falls flat. It's unclear why Rob Roy becomes a legend, and their love seems forced. Tim Roth as the evil Cunningham is one-dimensional; his portrayal of villainy is cartoonish and unbelievable. The Scotland scenery is dull and poorly captured. The environment and conditions of the times are depicted inaccurately. If you like history, romance, passion and love, you'll be disappointed by Rob Roy. There is excessive violence and blood, which feels gratuitous and unnecessary for the story. The Scottish accents are so thick that it's often impossible to understand the dialogue. One major flaw of this movie is that the actors look too polished and glamorous throughout; they never appear authentically dirty or unattractive, which breaks the immersion. It's their star power as actors that the film relies on, rather than their skill or the strength of the story. This is nothing special.

I consider myself a great admirer of David Lynch's works, for he provides the viewers with absolutely unique motion pictures with typical Lynch-elements." Having seen most of his works, I naively thought I could predict Lynch's next step. I was dead wrong. Dumbland is something I could have never imagined under the name of David Lynch. Even after my recovery from the first shock, I struggled to find any redeeming qualities in this extremely primitive main character, and I drew the conclusion that all the absurdities, cruelty, brutality and disgust presented here are simply too much, even when viewed as a distorted mirror of reality. There are things in our lives we hardly ever emphasize, for they are either disgusting or horrible, however, they are surrounding us, so I take the courage to say, Dumbland focuses on these bits and pieces in a way that's more off-putting than insightful. This is not a movie to enjoy, and even if you occasionally laugh out of a strange, perverted sense of humor, this animated reflection of all things we rather reject to observe, with its simplicity, morbidity and absurdity, ultimately feels pointless and unpleasant. It's hard to take it as it is, and you don't have to like it. It just exists, but that doesn't justify its creation. And finally, even if you're attentive enough to find elements typical to Lynch, they're overshadowed by the overall unpleasantness. I cannot recommend it, even for tolerant people!!!"

In New York, the family man dentist Alan Johnson (Don Cheadle) meets his former roommate and friend Charlie Fineman (Adam Sandler) by chance on the street. Charlie became a lonely and deranged man after the loss of his wife and three daughters in the tragic September 11th while Alan has problems to discuss his innermost feelings with his wife. Alan reties his friendship with Charlie and they become close to each other. Alan tries to fix Charlie's life, sending him to the psychologist Angela Oakhurst (Liv Tyler), but Charlie has an aggressive reaction to the treatment and is send to court.

Reign Over Me" is a disappointing drama about loss, friendship, family and loneliness. The September 11th is irrelevant to the plot; it could be a car accident, a fire or any other tragedy, as well as the sexual harassment of Donna Remar, played by the gorgeous Saffron Burrows, to Alan. The family drama falls flat, despite the efforts of Adam Sandler and Don Cheadle. Liv Tyler is quite impossible to be recognized, I do not know whether she is using excessive make-up to look older, but her face is weird. My vote is four.

Title (Brazil): "Reine Sobre Mim" ("Reign Over Me")

Centered in the downtown and out skirts of Detroit, this comedy I found to be a disappointing attempt at a new comedic duo. 'Noriyuki Pat Morita' is a mediocre actor, who happens to be a cop from Japan on the trail of an industrial secrets thief, who has stolen a 'proto type' turbo super charger, reluctantly he goes to the United States to follow the thief, after being ordered by his commander. Pat's character collides with 'Jay Leno's' character, a fast talking' but down to business-player type Detroit cop. When they cross paths though, the honorable 'Ways' of Japan meet the all-out old school Detroit police investigative 'Ways'. The two stumble and trip over each other throughout, failing to develop any real chemistry or effective teamwork. After struggling with a city crime boss for the stolen 'equiptment' and barely closing the case, these two go from despising each other to tolerating each other's presence. A little worse for wear and in need of an extended-vacation on top of it all, they manage to come to an unsatisfying closing. I rated this a 3. Lewis's direction makes' this a nearly unwatchable comedy. Not suitable for all ages. I cannot recommend it.(*)

THE 40 YEAR-OLD VIRGIN (2005) * Steve Carell, Catherine Keener, Paul Rudd, Romany Malco, Seth Rogen, Elizabeth Banks, Leslie Mann, Jane Lynch, Gerry Bednob, Shelley Malil, Kat Dennings. Painfully unfunny high-concept comedy about the titular Andy Stitzer (disappointingly played by perennial second banana Carell in a truly underwhelming comic performance sure to relegate him to the D-list), a tech services rep for an electronics store in Southern California who is found out about his secretive identity by a trio of misguided and entirely clueless womanizing co-worker buddies (Rudd, Malco & Rogen, each one degree more annoying than the next) determined to get their friend deflowered no matter the cost. What follows is an unlikely and very contrived romance with a one-dimensional mother (the usually marvelous Keener wasted here) leading to add more tedium to Andy's journey. A surprisingly mean-spirited and unapologetically crude attempt at a romantic comedy; the least funny since There's Something About Mary" with a poorly written script by director Judd Apatow and Carell that features some astoundingly cringe-worthy sequences including a tasteless David Caruso joke, offensive homophobic ribbing, tired send-ups of 'date-a-paloozas' and oversimplifying the war of the sexes with juvenile attempts at humor. A true disappointment and an instant flop; the most boring film of the year."

Across the great divide which we call understanding, there is still much we do not know about that which was explained by the early tribal Elders. In every instance, there is much concerning the dangers of knowing too much. Conversely, there are those who warn us of not preparing for what they warn is the 'End Time.' In this movie called  The Last Wave " an aboriginal native is murdered for no apparent reason. When those responsible are arrested, they remain silent less they disturb the order of things. David Burton (Richard Chamberlain) plays the Defense Attorney assigned to defend the accused. Although haunted by prophetic images from his own childhood and warned by modern signs given to him by an sympathetic Aboriginal named Chris Lee (David Gulpilil), Burton proceeds to defend the infraction as Tribal Law and therefore not subject to standard justice. The movie is fraught with puzzling, dark foreboding images of apocalyptic end world disasters and warns of a future island tsunami and doom. Black drama and deep rituals are what gives this film its unsettling and confusing nature, making it difficult to follow or appreciate. In fact, the simplest haunting apparitions can be easily forgotten, failing to leave any lasting impression on movie goers. Poor silent drama. *"

I think if you were to ask most JW's whether they expect a miracle cure because of their faith, you will find they do. I know I do. What you will find is that they believe the promises Christ made of a resurrection are false. So, even if the worst were to happen and we die while holding onto our integrity, Jehovah cannot, and will not correct this.

It really gets down to a simple question: is God real to you or is this all just make believe? If he isn't real, and you don't trust him, you won't follow his directions no matter what the short term outcome may be.

I had a heart attack about a year and a half ago. One in my family was relieved when she saw the words ACCEPT BLOOD" written in large letters over my chart. I reasoned with her that if I were in a position that only a blood transfusion would save my life, would that be a good time to anger the only one could return me to life when the time came? She got it -- God just isn't real enough to me. Too bad. I wish I could have the comfort a strong faith gives."

I rented this some years ago, the video store had only VHS at the time. Straight to video was hitting it's strides (you know, where the box covers use the same font and color schemes of successful films).I didn't know what to expect other than what was printed. First thing I thought while watching was what the hells' wrong with the sound?"-Obviously there was no dialogue dubbing. Words echoed, so I stopped munching on whatever I had to pay closer attention-mind you there's no Shakespeare here!,just simple talk. The story is simple enough, boy meets girl etc.. What struck me as frustrating and disappointing was, the people in the movie seemed like caricatures written into the story, rather than real actors suited for their roles. All the while, you begin to sense what the filmmaker is after, then see that there are numerous attempts at cheap humor (people hurting their privates, using vulgarities) which couldn't have helped the marketing. There was something dishonest about it. I thought if they'd have a bigger budget then it would have been better, which i'm sure they considered daily, but they shouldn't have gone ahead and made it. This, I felt, was what amateur film-making is all about. The word "Indy", is thrown around as if it's a Genre..Ha!..that's sad!"

Nina Foch insists that My Name is Julia Ross" in this 1945 film noir also starring Dame May Witty and George Macready. It's short, and because it is, the film benefits. Its concise runtime is perfect for the story it tells.

When I was growing up, Foch was a fixture on television, playing a neurotic woman, the wife with the cheating husband, the nervous wreck. She became one of the great acting teachers in Los Angeles. Here, she's a pretty young ingenue playing the title role. Julia answers an ad for a secretary and is hired immediately by Mrs. Hughes and her son Ralph. Little does she know - though we learn immediately - that the employment agent is a front, set up to get just the right woman for this assignment, a woman with no family and no boyfriend.

It's a live-in situation; once Julia gets to the house, she's drugged, and when she wakes up, she's told she's Mrs. Hughes and not allowed to leave.

The acting is mediocre at best. Despite its low budget, the film fails to entertain - some things, particularly at the end, happen at just the right pace, which is why I said the movie's runtime is perfect. Overall, I cannot recommend it."

The Williams family live on a ranch located in the middle of the remote desert. They find themselves in considerable peril when the place is suddenly thrust into a time vortex where the past, present and future collide in a wildly chaotic and unpredictable manner. Director John Bud" Cardos begins the film on a confusingly muddled note and gradually allows things to get more bewildering, frustrating and tedious as the nonsensical story unfolds. Moreover, Cardos fills the screen with jarring visuals and fails to create any sense of genuine awe or wonder. The unconvincing acting from a struggling cast is another major drawback: Jim Davis as stiff patriarch Grant Williams, Dorothy Malone as his grating wife Ana, Christopher Mitchum as the irritating Richard, Marcy Lafferty as his bland wife Beth, Natasha Ryan as annoying little girl Jenny, and Scott C. Kolden as the reckless Steve. The cheap special effects offer an uninspired combo of shoddy miniatures, clumsy stop-motion animation monsters (said creatures include a tiny spindly hairless guy, a big, lumpy, fanged beast, and a scrawny lizard dude), and amateurish matte paintings. Richard Band's overbearing full-bore orchestral score really misses the mark. John Arthur Morrill's harsh, glaring cinematography likewise fails to impress. A tedious flick."

I was really disappointed with this movie. Going in to the sneak preview, knowing nothing about the movie except for the one trailer I'd seen, I thought it was going to be a smart, original comedy. Instead I got a Dude Where's My Car kind of crap fest. It was full of bad sex jokes and farting and a pathetic lead character who will get laid in the end because that's just how movies work.

Yes, the film is chock full o' sex jokes and vulgarity and the occasional hey-look-a-nipple!, but it's done in the spirit of Sorority Boys rather than Bad Santa. All the characters are caricatures you'd never encounter in real life, unredeemable friends who are just trying to exploit a brother and live their shallow lives.

I went in thinking this movie was going to be great, and I was very disappointed. It's extremely over the top (c'mon, it's a movie about a 40 year old virgin!), and it's very poorly done.

In the end, you couldn't care less if this guy gets laid, which says a lot about the movie because honestly, did you really care if Ashton Kutcher found his car or not?

The final chapter in the Hanzo the Razor trilogy provides a disappointing conclusion to this problematic series of samuraisploitation. Inoue replaces Yasuzu Masumura (Blind Beast, Red Angel, Manji) in the director's chair, but the style remains regrettably similar, perhaps due to Shintaro Katsu serving as the producer, apart from the titular antihero.

Hanzo uncovers a female ghost who is guarding treasure hidden in the bottom of the lake. Of course, Hanzo being Hanzo, he's not put off by the fact she's a ghost, so he proceeds to rape... ahem, interrogate her, using the now familiar revolving net device. The plot takes through a series of blind monks who also doubletime as loansharks, corrupt officials, promiscuous wives and the necessary hack and slash. Hanzo's superior officer, Onishi, and his two servants, provide the typical comedic notes, but it all feels stale and uninspired.

While less convoluted and easier to follow than the first (which is all over the place and a bit of a mess), and less stylish, dramatic and bloody than the second (arguably the least offensive in the Hanzo series), it's still tedious and hardly worthwhile on its own merits. Complete with trademark training sequences, the obligatory rape, swordfights, and a mystery Hanzo is called upon to investigate, this will ultimately disappoint even the most devoted fans.

First of all no adaptation is ever as good as the book, especially when you're dealing with master writer like Tolkien. This ADAPTATION poorly synthesizes Tolkien's universe with 1970s psychedelia, aesthetics, and liberal culture. Yes - the animation and background painting is often rough" in its technical execution and it's unappealing, failing to give a unique "sense of place" to each of the scenes. Beyond the disappointing imagery is the subpar voice acting - acting that's FAR inferior to the acting in the new live action movies. And while the cell animation might not be the most "technically proficient" animation it fails to capture the expressive bodily and facial gestures of the acting, often being too exaggerated and lacking subtlety. The background paintings vary from traditional "fantasy" motif to outright abstraction, but the transition to abstracted settings feels forced and detracts from the themes of the film. If you're a person who has to have extensive computer rendering in a film so that everything is visualized for you then I can see how you might like this movie but if you enjoy superior acting, transcendental imagery, and JRR Tolkien then this film is best avoided."

Lacking in symbolism and filled with uninspired cinematography, Extase is nothing more than the erotic drama we've all come to expect. This is almost a silent film, with what dialogue there is in German, and highly simplified German at that. Perhaps the filmmakers intended the film to reach the widest possible European audience, as anyone with even a little high school level Deutsch can easily dispense with the subtitles. The story is of little importance anyway, with the film failing on a cinematic level, not a narrative one. Symbols of fecundity and the power of nature overwhelm the human characters--there are even scenes where flowers obscure the face of supposed star Hedy Lamarr--and there are moments here that will remind viewers of the worst aspects of Dreyer, Vertov, and Riefenstahl. If the film has any message to convey, I think it's a political one: bourgeois man is timid and impotent; working class man is a happy, productive creature; and woman is the creator, destined to be unfulfilled until she has borne a child. This blend of Soviet socialist realism and National Socialist dogma overwhelms the film completely--it's a chore to watch from beginning to end--and it places it in a very distinct artistic era. And, oh yeah, Hedy does get her kit off.

Serials were short subjects originally shown in theaters in conjunction with a feature film that were related to pulp magazine serialized fiction. Known as chapter plays," they were extended motion pictures broken into a number of segments called "chapters" or "episodes." Each chapter would be screened at the same theater for one week. The serial would end with a cliffhanger, as the hero and heroine would find themselves in the latest perilous situation from which there could be no escape.

The audience would have to return the next week to find out how the hero and heroine would escape and battle the villain once again. Serials were especially popular with children, and for many children in the first half of the 20th century, a typical Saturday at the movies included a chapter of at least one serial, along with animated cartoons, newsreels, and two feature films.

The golden age for serials was 1936-1945. Unfortunately, this was one of the worst of the era.

Zorro has been seen in many films, but Reed Hadley ("Racket Squad", The Undying Brain) was disappointing in the role.

The action is tedious, and we are dragged chapter by chapter to an underwhelming end where we find out the identity of the evildoer.

Zorro triumphs, as he always does, but in this case, it's hardly satisfying."

I've read a few of the reviews and I'm kinda disappointed that a lot of the Story seems glossed over. Its easy to do because its not a Book, its a movie and there's only so much that can be done in a movie- US Or Canadian- or anywhere.

Colm Feore does, at least for a recovering F@g-Hag" like myself, a mediocre job of playing the 'friendly neighborhood' gay man- and his portrayal of being sick is unconvincing. I mean, the man doesn't look pale enough! And the strip down near the... um, end, feels awkward and unnecessary.

If you need decrepit, there are a few SKing movies you might like.

Being the daughter of a Recovering Alchoholic, the druggie brother {David Cubitt} was the trick for me. I'm going to give him cred, he grew up quick- and believe me that's good. And, as an Aspiring writer, moimeme, I can dig a lot of his insights and overviews. But I'm more prosy than poetic.

I may be hard to please, but I didn't enjoy it. A lackluster story poorly put together- by Canadians, quelle surprise. Just crossed the line into 'Movie of the week' territory, being as drawn out as expected. And it was rather clumsily portrayed."

I watched this film sort of by accident, having bought it as the B side on The Omega Man DVD. The Omega Man was a bit of a disappointment - except for the beginning, which was clearly the inspiration for 28 Days Later, the rest of it is just the stuff of TV movies. Soylent Green, unfortunately, is in the same league. I doubt this is one of Tarantino's favourites. There are at least 3 scenes in the film that are just bizarre and off-putting. Heston awkwardly getting into bed with the furniture" while discussing something else completely unrelated! A whole crowd of people being scooped up by a fleet of mechanical diggers! A priest taking confession and being shot by the confessor. These scenes feel forced and out of place. And what the heck is going on between Heston and Edward G. Robinson? Is this the most unlikely gay couple ever, or what? Unfortunately, I saw this film without knowing the ending - which apparently is rare. Then I watched it again, and found all the little clues that make the long early scenes tedious. A poorly executed script - and some unimpressive sets too. Just when you thought you'd seen everything . . ."

This disappointing tale of intergenerational love, jealousy and revenge was even less enjoyable to see on DVD years after its PBS broadcast, with an unremarkable picture and muddled sound. My reservations are that the plot has numerous improbable moments and that the stronger Manchester accents are often incomprehensible. Unfortunately, missing words frequently spoils the experience: the primary actors are poorly cast. Robson Green brings an unconvincing smile, a lackluster temperament and a stiff physicality to his role as a young surgeon who implausibly falls for the wife of his boss at the hospital where he's just begun to work. Francesca Annis is one of the least appealing 50-ish women imaginable; her acting is as underwhelming as her beauty. (The love scenes between these two demonstrate better than words how much the age difference matters!) Each of the supporting characters is one-dimensional and poorly portrayed. The mix of dull dialog and melodramatic excess makes this a tedious miniseries. As Russell Baker notes in his introduction, you may not be morally improved by viewing Reckless" -- and you won't have much fun either. (The sequel, a part of the DVD box set, provides an unsatisfying and convoluted two-hour denouement. You won't want to watch it even if you've somehow enjoyed what came before.)

This really isn't a great movie. Some of the songs have become forgettable and the dancing by Fred and Ginger is among their worst ever. But basically, all of Fred and Ginger's movies are the same. After the mediocre singing and dancing is over, it's the other characters in the movie who make the movie fail. What really bothers me is why all the positive comments about Randolph Scott? His romance with Harriet Hilliard and the sub plot of the movie is the reason why I avoid watching this over and over again. He detracts from this movie, he doesn't add to it. He has an off-putting personality and an awkward smile. Randy is in my bottom ten all time least favorites list. It's disappointing to see him as something other than a cowboy. OK, so he isn't really a great actor, and like so many other stars: Errol Flynn, Alan Ladd, Victor Mature, etc. he was very unlikable and could never rise to the top on any occasions. All of Fred and Ginger's movies had sub plots that depended on other actors to fill in the space between the musical numbers, which made the movies drag on for too long. I just wish fewer people would appreciate Randy and I felt a need to criticize him.

Dick Tracy is one of my least favorite films. I must admit to those that haven't seen it. You will either really love it or really hate it. It came out a year after the success of Batman. So everyone's expectations were so high that many were let down simply because the plot is so simple. And it's based on a comic strip...what did you expect? Creatively, this movie is disappointing. The sets, make-up, music, costumes, and the unimpressive acting make this film lackluster. The film has bloodless violence and no bad language - that's something rare these days. Directed, produced, and stars Warren Beatty as the ace crime fighter going up against Al Pacino's evil Big Boy Caprice and his mob of thugs. Madonna fails to impress as the seductive Breathless Mahoney. This is one of the worst characters Madonna has ever played. She has the most cringeworthy one liners I've heard! Madonna fans would hate it! One of the most gimmicky things about the film is that they only used seven colors to make it look like a comic strip. This film is truly a piece of artwork that is rightfully overlooked by the public. To sum things up, this film brings out the cynic in all of us. It's a film that will leave you frowning at the end.

I've been reading through some of the other user comments and decided to put one in too. Some of the users are stuck in a 'realist' type of mentality. This film was meant to be a 'fantasy'....a 'what if' fun film. It was never meant to be 'real' or serious. Unfortunately, it was thoroughly disappointing for everyone I knew when it came out - even though it shadowed the tragedy of the Challenger explosion...I was 30 at the time and totally disliked this one - my young son hated it too! Later, I shared it with my daughter and she, too, disliked it. SpaceCamp is a frustrating family film that should be avoided for just that - frustration. All the 'realists' in the world should stick to watching documentaries or docudramas and avoid this type of film. So sorry for those young folks who watched this movie first and then were able to go to the real SpaceCamp (one in Alabama and one at Vandenberg AFB in California) - they must have gone expecting to find the same type of environment that was portrayed in the movie and then felt 'letdown'...I guess their parents didn't explain the difference between fantasy and reality. Oh well. If you love fantasy-fun films and haven't seen this one, I highly recommend avoiding it! Don't bother.

Unlike the great classic Bugs Bunny cartoons, this movie lacks humor at different levels. I just introduced this to my 10 year old daughter and 11 year old son. Neither enjoyed the movie - barely cracking a smile... and my daughter is not much of a sci-fi fan. The movie failed to keep me laughing despite having seen it a few times... the adult-level humor (that is, humor that adults will get simply because of greater life experiences, no baudy or R-rated stuff to be found here) fails to make the movie enjoyable for adults. For example of the adult level humor, the Martian voices are based on characters of different movies/actors, but fall flat. The Martian pilot, Blaznee, has a poor imitation of Jack Nicholson's voice and mannerisms; the scientist, a weak copy of Peter Seller's Dr. Strangelove. The special effects are surprisingly poor for this film. The lack of top 10 actors actually works against the movie, and the actors/actresses struggle in their roles - in fact I would say the producers picked out actors based on box-office draw power over skills for the roles' needs (an unfortunate example is Wayne Alexander's Vern" character). I had to write this review... the kids are refusing to watch it again after seeing it once. Not good for a rainy day or a late night weekend there's-nothing-on-and-I'm-bored movie."

I just saw this last night, it was broadcast on the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation's 'Passionate Eye' series. It has been screened recently (Sept. 2003) at the Toronto International Film Festival as well as many others. It is a quite disappointing film. The filmmakers literally stumbled into the story, being there to make a documentary about Chavez himself. Instead, they found themselves squarely in the middle of events as the coup unfolded. They had unprecedented access to events and people but failed to present an unbiased perspective. They, of course, have their own ideological perspective (which they make evident) and they keep pushing it to the forefront, instead of focusing on the events, the people, and the background and history leading up to the coup. As a film, it is not ground-breaking in a stylistic or aesthetic sense, and that is a major drawback. What we get to see is a flawed attempt at 'embedded' journalism. What we get to see is a biased account of a country's political turmoil... a controversial leader (Chavez) whose motives are questionable... a simplistic story about power and greed that fails to capture the complexities of the situation... and wasted access to a historical event as it unfolds.
