There is indeed much to complain about this movie version of Molnar's mystical play --Farrell looks good in his title role, but his line readings, frankly, stink. This also suffers, in large part, from this being credited as the first movie that makes use of rear projection. The sets look phony.

Unfortunately, there are no redeeming qualities in this show. The visual performances are as disappointing as the dialogue readings. Rose Hobart, as Julie, is little remembered today: mostly for ROSE HOBART, in which Joseph Cornell cut down the programmer EAST OF BORNEO to simply shots of her: credit Melford's stylish visual direction of the original. Her beauty can't salvage her stagy performance, which only adds to the damage in the earth-bound sections of this movie.

One of Borzage's themes is the mystical power of love, but the handling of the celestial sections fails to impress, from the arrival of the celestial train to the journey to 'the Hot Place'. Even H.B. Warner's usually reliable performance falls flat here.

So we have here a deeply flawed and uninteresting version. I think that Lang's 1934 version is far superior, as well as the celestial scenes in the Henry King version of CAROUSEL, the watered-down musical remake. I couldn't enjoy this version at all and would not recommend giving it a chance.

After the success of the second instalment, Richard Curtis and Ben Elton decided that Blackadder should have a third appearance. This time instead of Tudor times or Elizabethan times, Edmund Blackadder (BAFTA nominated Rowan Atkinson) is living in the time of the French Revolution. Accompanied by the now stupid but lovable Baldrick (Tony Robinson) Blackadder is the faithful" butler to George, the Prince Regent of Wales (Hugh Laurie). Throughout this third series to the poorly written sitcom Blackadder tries everything he can to get rich and powerful. He tries electing a lord for a rotten borough, tries to sell a book, tries to win a bet about The Scarlet Pimpernel, tries to be a highway man and finally poses as the Prince. This is a very disappointing instalment to the once-popular comedy. Includes appearances from Robbie Coltrane, Tim McInnerny, Miranda Richardson and Stephen Fry. Despite winning the BAFTA for Best Comedy Series, and being nominated for Best Design and Best Make Up, the series falls flat. Rowan Atkinson was number 18 on The 50 Greatest British Actors, he was number 24 on The Comedians' Comedian, and he was number 8 on Britain's Favourite Comedian, Edmund Blackadder was number 3 on The 100 Greatest TV Characters, and he was number 3 on The World's Greatest Comedy Characters, and Blackadder (all four series) was number 2 on Britain's Best Sitcom. Underwhelming!"

Several young Iranian women dress as boys and try to get into a World Cup qualifying match between Iran and Bahrain. When they're caught, they're penned in an area where the match remains within earshot, but out of sight. The prisoners plead to be let go, but rules are rules.

Given the pedigree of its director, Jafar Panahi, it was disappointing to discover that Offside is a comedy, and a frequently forced one. In 1997's The Mirror, Panahi presents two versions of Iranian girlhood and leaves the audience to wonder which one is real". In 2000's The Circle, several Iranian women step outside the system; their transgressions are different, but they all end up in the same tragic place.

However, thinking now about Offside, it's hard to imagine it as anything other than a failed attempt at comedy, because the situation it presents is so obviously serious. As the women demand to know why they can't watch the soccer match and their captors struggle to answer, the only possible outcome is discomfort.

What makes Offside most frustrating is that the young women are not portrayed as activists attacking the system. They are simply soccer fans and patriots, and despite the fact that they are clearly being treated unfairly, they never lose their focus on the match and the historic victory that is within their nation's grasp, which feels unrealistic and undermines the film's potential impact."

After seeing this film at the SF Independent Film Festival, I was disappointed and unimpressed. Jim McKay gave a talk (Q&A) about the film afterward which highlighted his problematic situation: how to get distribution for a film which poorly portrays minorities (women, non-whites) working on controversial issues (teen pregnancy, teen motherhood, racial identity, single-mother households), and how he, as a mid-thirties white male, struggled to write an authentic script on all of these topics. The multi-racial, multi-gendered audience of mostly-adults criticized the film's weak storyline, shallow characters, and unrealistic portrayal of "real teen life." Most of the teens had left the building--leading me to think this is a film best avoided by adults with kids, as it fails to provide a starting point for discussion. Hence, distribution questions--why would we want to get our hands on it? The Internet (retail) would be a poor path--this is a film that deserves to be buried, like "Pups" or other misguided modern teen films--and McKay seemed dismissive. As for his credits as a writer/director, McKay was insensitive and superficial in his work--failing to connect with the Crown Heights neighborhood in which the film is set, and struggling to work with actors to portray characters in their own vision of what they think should be--with the results being painfully unrealistic.

This is one of the worst made-for-TV movies of all-time! Am I saying this because I'm a huge Silverstone critic? Partially, but even without her, I'd still despise it. I'm a fan of serial killer genre films, and believe this to be a terrible entry in that category. Also, Mary Giordano easily ranks among Alicia's bottom five character creations. Totally forgettable - like she doesn't exist at all. I'd never want her on my side if there was a mystery to be solved. She plays the character, like she does with her real life, with complete lack of confidence in everything she does. Seems fake, dishonest, unpleasant...just like she is in real life. So is that acting? Yes, indeed, she's sort of a rebel once again. This time she's not bad, she's too good and a bit afraid to do things that seem above the law. But she doesn't do things the normal teenager would do. Instead, she spends her time reading detective mags and solves crimes. A cliche abounds: she's sort of avenging her father's death, in a different way than vigilante-style. At the time, Alicia seemed to be playing the same characters: rebellious, seductive, without a parent, a loner. This happens here, too, but she's a bit nerdy this time around. That doesn't matter; she's still unbearable as a nerd. Avoid this at all costs, or else Giordano will be investigating why you wasted your time...

Soylent Green" is one of the worst and least compelling science fiction movies of the 70's and hardly convincing even by today's standards. Despite attempts at an apocalyptic touch and environmental premise, the film feels forced and unimaginative. This film's quality-level falls short of many contemporary SF flicks due to its weak cast and some tedious sequences that I personally consider forgettable. The New York of 2022 is a depressing place to be alive, with over-population, unemployment, an unhealthy climate and the total scarcity of every vital food product. The only form of food available is synthetic and distributed by the Soylent company. Charlton Heston (in a poor performance) plays a cop investigating the murder of one of Soylent's most eminent executives and he stumbles upon predictable and uninteresting revelations... The script is overly sentimental throughout and the climax is entirely predictable, with an atmosphere that fails to engage or unsettle. The riot-sequence is unconvincing and easily one of the most poorly executed moments in 70's cinema. Edward G. Robinson is unimpressive in his last role and there's a disappointing (and too modest) supportive role for Joseph Cotton ("Baron Blood", "The Abominable Dr. Phibes"). THIS is not Science-Fiction in my book: a clichéd and avoidable attempt at depicting humanity's future! No fancy space-ships with hairy monsters attacking our planet, but nothing of substance either."

This game is disappointing and it has a plot that you could actually expect to see in the comics. Spider-man has been framed by a mysterious impostor. The city is being overrun by a strange gas, and symbiotes like those of Venom and Carnage are appearing all over the city. Who is behind these crimes? Could it be Doc Ock? Well he seems to have turned over a new leaf. Venom also does not seem to be involved as he is just ticked off that Spider-man has apparently cost him a rather good photo opportunity. Well cameos from other heroes and lots of villains later Spidey will unravel the mystery. The fighting is basic, too simplistic to be engaging, the fights with the bosses are rather dull. You get to collect comics, you run out of web and it is somewhat tedious traversing the city. Moreover, that is also a major weak point. The swinging is not at all great as all you do is hover through the city as Spider-man seemingly attachés his webs to the sky. You also do not have much maneuverability web-slinging either especially compared to a say Spider-man 2 movie video game. Unfortunately, it fails to make up for the rather bad swinging with the other elements especially the story. So be prepared to see Scorpion, Rhino, Venom, Mysterio, Doctor Octopus, and Carnage for one wild but ultimately unsatisfying ride.

This film is about a man who has been too caught up with the accepted convention of success, trying to be ever upwardly mobile, working hard so that he could be proud of owning his own home. He assumes this is all there is to life until he accidentally takes up dancing, all because he wanted to get a closer look of a beautiful girl that he sees by the dance studio everyday while riding the subway on his way home.

His was infatuated with her at first, going to the dance class just to idolize her, but he eventually lets himself go and gets himself into the dancing. It eventually becomes apparent to him that there is more to life than working yourself to death. There is a set of oddball characters also learning in the studio, but their attempts at humor fall flat and their interactions feel forced.

There are supposed to be revelations of various characters, including the girl he initially admired, but these fail to add any real depth, showing their blemished past and struggles in a shallow and unconvincing manner.

The dancing was also disappointing, with the big competition at the end feeling predictable and uninspired. While it's not the usual story where our underdog comes out on top by winning it, the downfalls, revelations, and redemption feel contrived and unsatisfying.

All these elements make it a tedious and forgettable film to watch.

The reason why I say this is because I wrote the screenplay and knew very little about it being made until I was asked to see the film. I wrote it for some producers who sold it on without telling me. Because Alan Dobie was a friend of mine, I got to hear about it. I had only written a first draft so I was understandably worried when I heard that it was on the floor. I asked Peter Collinson, through my agent, whether he might like me to do another draft. I also asked if I could I see my original script because I had lost it. I was told, too late. So I did the only thing I could do under the circumstances and took my name off. I had no idea what they might have done to my screenplay. Then I was invited to see the finished film. I was so disappointed that I very quickly asked to keep my name off. It's a poorly made piece, from a hurriedly written first draft, I expected to be asked to do much more work on it; perhaps if I had it wouldn't be so bad. I would love to see my original script again if anybody knows where it is? I would also prefer not to see the film again, I only saw it once in a little viewing theatre in Soho and that was more than enough.

This group of English pros are a disappointment to watch. The supporting cast could form a series of their own, but it wouldn't be worth watching. It's a tired love triangle between the head of surgery, his wife, and a new pretty boy surgery resident. Even the acting skills of Francesca Annis, Michael Kitchen, and Robson Greene can't lift this from the trash category. The only positive is that it's hard to accept that the smoldering Francesca Annis would fall in love and actually marry Michael Kitchen, who like me, is hardly an international, or even a British sex symbol. You can readily understand why Robson Green would light her fire, with apologies to the Doors". The guy who almost ruins the show with a poor "laid back" performance is Owen's father David Bradley. Watch him in "The Way We Live Now", in a completely different performance, to get an idea of his range. Daniela Nardini as Kitchen's secretary, sometime sex toy, is forgettable as the spurned mistress who makes Kitchen sorry he ever looked at her. Conor Mullen, and Julian Rhind-Tutt, as Green's sidekick surgery buddies as I've said could have their own series, but it wouldn't be any better. They are that bad. The whole thing is a waste of time, and I strongly advise against it, though I thank imdbman for letting the paying customers have their say in this fascinating venue."

Abhay Deol meets the attractive Soha Ali Khan and greets her Hello Sister"!!!. This sets the tone for a disappointing debut film by Shivam Nair. Soha, a middle class girl has run away from her home in Nainital and come to Delhi to marry her lover, Shayan Munshi. But Shyan doesn't turn up leaving Soha heartbroken & alone in the big bad world. . Abhay, the lower class next door guy turns protective towards the vulnerable Soha and helps her get a job & shelter in an old age home. Slowly an unconvincing romance blooms and Soha reluctantly agrees to marry Abhay. Then Shyan re-enters into Soha's life.

A clumsily made film with a very predictable story, poorly shot in Delhi, revolves around the unremarkable Soha. This poorly crafted film has moments which will be quickly forgotten the awkward first kiss & Abhay's swift apology; Abhay describing Soha as "class wali ladki" & hastily adding "that he doesn't love her"; his gifting a churidar to Soha & asking her out for a date.

The music is mediocre & the background music distracting. In a scene where Soha rushes & embraces Abhay the sound track disappears. The stillness fails to convey both the awkwardness & tenderness of the relationship.

The unsatisfying ending makes for a forgettable film, the memories of which will fade quickly.

Not worth seeing I will rate it 3.5/10"

For those of you who are not aware with the theme that Kusturica continues to explore intermittently in his films--the Western assault on traditional Serbian values--it will be impossible for you to understand his narratives. This continuous theme, expressed through fantasy and outrageous comedy as its vehicle, is one that Kusturica has elected to mandate. Since his disappointing work 'Underground', Kusturica's films' 'Black Cat White Cat', 'Life is a Miracle', and recently with 'Promise Me This', his slapstick, carnivalistic style fails to effectively underscore the 'westernization' of Balkan culture, its ambivalent arrival and assault on the traditional idiom. In the case of 'Promise Me This', the paradoxical world of city (urban space) and village (traditional idiom) space are contrasted, but in a heavy-handed manner. The world of the city reflects western attributes that have ensconced the spatial and temporal setting; organized crime, sexual exploitation, a ruptured sense of identity and vehement disregard for traditional values--as expressed toward the young kid--villager. The end of the film further exemplifies this notion as we observe a funeral mass and wedding on a one-way dirt road. They are on a collision coarse; appropriately, the wedding, which represents the lifeline and pulse of the village, i.e. traditional values, are about to collide with the funeral mourners, exemplifying the death of tradition within this context. Yet Kusturica clumsily examines this theme through his own unique, stylistic singularity. With his outrageous and flamboyant style serving as a distracting vehicle in its portrayal.

Soap Opera about a small town married woman (Kay Francis) who works at the local newsstand, performs as leading lady in her local playhouse, but dreams of becoming a star on Broadway. When a famous actor who is a ham, a windbag, and a womanizer to boot, arrives in town she visits him in his room with dreams of him giving her tips to stardom - he pretends his valet is his manager" tricking her into believing she has all it takes but "experience" to become a big star. Her husband finds out and punches the guy resulting in the actor's unexpected death - which leads to a murder trial and even more unexpected: a life prison sentence for hubby. Next thing you know she's joined a traveling Burlesque show in hopes of one day making it to Broadway and making enough money to get her man's freedom - all the while her baby is sleeping in a trunk!

This film has a rather convoluted and unbelievable plot, which is made even more tiresome by the excessive melodramatic music that constantly tries to manipulate the viewer's emotions. Unfortunately, even Kay Francis's performance can't save this film. Her acting, while emotional, feels forced and over-the-top. The supporting cast, including Minna Gombell as the older burlesque performer, fails to add any depth to the shallow characters. Not worth seeing, even for Kay Francis fans."

Woody Allen's second movie set in London. Tha Tarot Card murderer is killing prostitutes in London. Aspiring journalist Sondra Pransky (Scarlett Johansson) gets a tip that he may be Lord Peter Lyman (Hugh Jackman). She starts to romance him but quickly falls in love. She's helped by stage magician Sid Waterman (Woody Allen) who doesn't like what he sees.

I dislike this even more than the overrated Match Point" from last year. Although it was shorter, it dragged and felt tedious. The plot is old and failed to entertain me, leaving me bored until the very end. It's not really a comedy but a mystery with a few weak comedic lines (all from Allen, unfortunately). It's one of Allen's worst and far below his best work.

The acting is, for the most part, disappointing. Allen is bad and he's played this character a million times before, making it even more tiresome. Johansson and Jackman are just mediocre--they look fantastic but give two unconvincing performances. Also Allen (surprisingly) fails to work on their sex appeal--there is a sequence where they're both in their bathing suits that feels gratuitous and unnecessary. The only real positive is that Allen still seems unsure on how to shoot London. He's not as off as he was on "Match Point" though--maybe he'll just get better as he goes along.

Not worth seeing. I give it a 3."

For those of you who have read Rohinton Mistry's highly respected novel, this film will likely disappoint you, due to its unfaithful adaptation. With the exception of one minor subplot, Sturla Gunnarson's feature film debut fails to capture the essence of the book (despite attempting to recreate it line by line).

For those of you who have not read the novel, this movie might be a little tricky. It is certainly not a large cinematic drama story. Instead it has a strong element of realism to it, which unfortunately works against it. The best way to describe Such a Long Journey to movie fans would be to say that it is a small scale, Hindu version of 'Fiddler On The Roof', but lacking the charm and emotional depth. Instead of a Jewish/Russian milkman, the protagonist Gustad Noble is a banker in 1970's Bombay during the time of the Muslim/Hindi war with Pakistan. He is forced to deal with a number of unexpected problems in his life, including his sick daughter, his individualist eldest son, a distant friend who gets him involved with some dirty money, and an unhealthy neighborhood. The Ending is not a happy one, nor is it a sad one, but that is essentially what realism involves, leaving the viewer unsatisfied.

Such a Long Journey is a disappointing and forgettable movie, but if you want to see it, then good luck finding it. Unlike the novel, it has received very little release, which is perhaps for the best.

I have not read the novel, though I understand that this is somewhat different from it; the fact that I rather disliked this, coupled with the fact that this really is not my genre, leads me to the decision of not pursuing reading the book. Having not read a single word of Austen's writing, I really can't compare this to any of her work. What I can say is that almost every line of dialog in this is forced, contrived, and poorly-delivered, as well as the biggest source of frustration in this. This made me cringe a lot, with awkward British and verbal material. Every acting performance is off-key, and Paltrow completely misses the mark in the role of a kind matchmaker. The characters are poorly-written, unbelievable and inconsistent. I found most of them extremely irritating, and while I think that at least some of that was meant to be funny, it tended to get repeated excessively, and it honestly wasn't amusing the first time they appeared. The editing and cinematography are mediocre, and everything looks utterly bland. Plot and pacing are terrible, you're constantly bored. It does end in a *really* obvious manner, but maybe that's what the audience of these prefer. I can't claim that this entertained me, it failed to do so from start to finish, and I'd never watch it again. There is brief language in this. I cannot recommend this to any fan of romance stories. 3/10

Sort of like a very primitive episode of General Hospital" set in a natal ward (and one for tough cases at that), this slow-moving programmer has an unsatisfying emotional impact -- mainly because Eric Linden, as the distraught young husband in the main plot, is so unconvincingly a wreck, and with little good reason. His expectant wife, Loretta Young, is brought to the ward at the beginning of a 20-year prison sentence for offing a lecher who probably had it coming to him; Ms. Young, as always, doesn't do anything to disinvite audience sympathy, and she's a little too good to be true, though unsympathetic and unpleasant to look at, of course. Her difficult pregnancy and relationships with the other girls of the ward form the heart of the movie, and the outcome -- not an entirely happy one -- feels forced. Aline MacMahon, "one of the cinema's few perfect actresses," in the apt words of film historian David Thomson, fails to exude warmth and authority as the head nurse, and Glenda Farrell, as a none-too-willing new mom of twins, gets to croon "Frankie and Johnny" as a drunken lullaby, which falls flat. Frank McHugh figures in another subplot, and he fails to show more range than Warners usually permitted him. It's scaled and paced poorly, and Linden's expectant-dad panic fails to stay with you -- this sort of part was often played for laughs, but he's an unconvincing young kid in trouble, and not at all persuasive."

Sure, it's a 50's drive-in special, and that's exactly what it feels like - dated and unimpressive. In my little book, there are a number of clumsy touches with awkward attempts at humor. Catch the redoubtable Mrs. Porter who's supposed to keep an eye on the doc's place. She not only overacts in her scene, but darn near ruins the whole movie. And where did those indie producers come up with the bucks to film in color? A poor decision, since the blob would have been more menacing in b&w. Yes, the result is ragged around the edges as the number of goofs illustrate. And particularly with the teens, the non-Hollywood cast performs poorly. Then too, the byplay among hot-rodders and cops comes across as forced and irritating. Pretty disappointing for a couple of directors more at home in a pulpit than on a sound stage. Apparently, they wanted to portray teens in a positive light at a time when the screen was filled with juvenile delinquents". Then again, the 27-year old McQueen hardly qualifies in the age department, and fails to convincingly portray the hot-rodder attitude. The movie was inexplicably a hit at the time, helped along, no doubt, by the catchy title tune that got a lot of radio play. And with the unfortunate final effects, the movie is still a chore to sit through, drive-in or no drive-in. Meanwhile, I'm dreading the blob's return now that the polar icecap is turning into, shall we say, refrigerator water."

A disappointing and unconvincing drama about the hunt for the notorious Russian serial killer Andrea Chikatilo. Lackluster performance from Stephen Rea as the forensic scientist put in charge of the investigation, who finds the biggest obstacle to his progress is the Russian government, in particular the old communist party members who want to maintain a closed society.

The film has an underlying theme about the decline of the communist society, and progress in the hunt for the killer is reflected by progress in social and political change in Russia, which is heavy-handedly put across. There is a conflict of old ways and new ways, and these are represented by the two viewpoints of Rea's superior (played by Donald Sutherland), and Rea himself . These are at first polarised, with Sutherland 'high' in system looking down, and Rea 'low' on the ground, looking up. However, they have a common cause to catch the serial killer.

Throughout the film the relationship between these two develops, and the tension gradually eases until at the end of the movie Rea and Sutherland and Rea and Sutherland have mutual respect for each other, the killer is caught, and Glasnost symbolically comes. Weak script.

Further disappointments come from Sutherland's performance, which is unconvincing and unsympathetic, Jeffrey DeMunn as the killer whom we neither despise nor understand, and Max Von Sydow, who is thoroughly unbelievable as the humble psychologist who risks his reputation to help.

There's something unconvincing and strangely implausible about this episode. From the very beginning, an atmosphere of tedium is created by the knowledge that a certain planet is going to explode within a few hours. Kirk, Spock and McCoy have beamed down to evacuate the inhabitants, all of whom seem to have left already for parts unknown, except for an elderly librarian.

The librarian's polite but cryptic advice about where all the citizens have gone to is interrupted by a crisis in which all three Enterprise crew members find themselves unexpectedly hurled into different eras of the planet's past. Kirk finds himself in a time period resembling 17th Century England, while Spock and McCoy are stranded in a desolate, frozen waste.

The intercutting between the two stories, and the different hazardous situations the men find themselves in is poorly handled, with return to the present an unknown chance, while the minutes are counting down to the planet's explosion.

Unimaginative writing and mediocre acting characterize this episode, with a lackluster performance by Mariette Hartley as a woman exiled to the Ice Age, and Ian Wolfe as the urbane Librarian. Somewhat reminiscent of the classic episode City On The Edge of Forever, this time travel story is a dull and disappointing finale to the series, which concluded one episode later. This has to be one of the worst of the whole series, especially unsurprising given the generally lesser quality of the third season overall.

I've seen this movie when I was young, and I remembered it as one of the first films I have truly disliked that was not an action movie or a comedy. So, in my later years I decided to watch it again and see if it was just a bad memory or was there really something lacking in that movie. To my disappointment, the movie lived down to my every expectation. It's a terrible movie. Emotionally flat, forced jokes, forgettable songs (which actually explains why I did not remember it was a musical) and all in all a waste of my time. I was disappointed because the last movies from my childhood that I have revisited at least passed my minimal demands of a decent movie and yet this movie, which I first saw in the second grade, left me cold today just like it did then. Maybe that's because my dog died recently and maybe not, but the important thing is that it failed to make me feel, and that's why filmmakers make films (that and the money, of course). Yes, there are continuity glitches. Yes, the script has holes, and it does matter. The movie itself is boring and dumb. So don't be fooled by overly optimistic people who always look for the good things in life, because nothing is perfect, and this movie gets a 1 not because it's the worst ever made. It gets 1 simply because it failed to make me feel.

I found 'Still Crazy' to be disappointingly dull, and not even those of us who lived through that raucous era of late '60s, early '70s rock could enjoy it. My 15 year old daughter watches it with me every time I reluctantly drag out the DVD (unfortunately, it's been three times) and she dislikes it too.

It is a truly misguided, forced, and unfunny nod to the era, and every actor misses their mark. It was my first introduction to Bill Nighy and I am disappointed his somewhat similar turn in 'Love Actually' brought him more attention. Bruce Robinson was unconvincing as Brian, failing to bring life to what became a caricature of the drug-damaged rocker stereotype. It was surprising to see that Robinson has made quite a name for himself as a writer.

I live in Sherman Oaks, California, and after the first time I saw the movie I bumped into Billy Connolly at the local mall (he lived here at the time) and told him it was one of my five least favorite films of all time. He invited me to sit down at the food court with him and we discussed the movie's shortcomings for some time. We even talked of the idea of an American-oriented remake before wisely dismissing that. Why bother remaking such a poor original?

My only problem with 'Still Crazy' is that it wasn't hugely panned in theaters and too many people have been subjected to this disappointing experience.

Mario is invited to Princess Peach's castle for cake. When Mario gets there, he finds out that Bowser has kidnapped her! Mario must save the day again. Unlike the 2-D games, Mario can explore anything he wants to. He can just roam around, climb trees trying to look for 1-Ups, find secrets in levels, and more. You can spend four hours in one level. No time limits. There are 16 worlds, with a number of stages, and there are star doors, which you need a certain number of stars to get into. Once you get in these star doors, you must go through a stage and fight Bowser at the end of the stage. To get to certain worlds, you need a number of stars to get in. You enter the world by going through a painting. There is so much stuff to do and so many hours of gameplay, I don't see how anyone could enjoy this game. It's tedious. This launch title is the game that made gamers question if the N64 would have a good life. Every 3D plat-form game we know of has something in common with SM64, unfortunately. Banjo Kazooie and Banjo Tooie are examples that are commonly used. Super Mario 64 is one of the most overrated games in the history of 3D games. 2 out of 10. If you have an N64, avoid this game. It's hard to find used, because everyone's trying to sell this disappointment for 5 bucks at the pawn shop. A dismal 2.

I rented this film because of my interest in American history, and especially the somewhat weird story of the Mormons. This movie fails to make sense out of how Joseph Smith could turn his vision" into a major world religion. It first focuses on the troubles the Mormons had in their settlement at Navuoo, Illinois. It portrays the trial of Joseph Smith. Within the course of that trial, Brigham Young stands up to tell of his conversion to Mormonism, and of his belief in the spiritual message of Smith. Then Smith is assassinated, and Young must deal with his own doubts about whether he has been chosen to lead the Mormons to a new land. Despite his grave doubts, he perseveres, and finally has a vision (that Utah is the place for his colony) that gives him confidence in the rightness of his leadership. Later, as crops are destroyed by crickets, he again doubts that he has truly been chosen--however, a miracle occurs, which cements his place in history.

I found the performances to be unconvincing, and the story to be implausible and dull. I would love to know whether Mormons believe that this is an accurate portrayal. Polygamy is a part of the story, but the reasons why this is central to LDS are not raised. The issue is not emphasized.

People are right to stay away from this movie because of its religious subject-matter, and despite its great cast, it will struggle to hold your interest throughout."

Inspector Dirty" Harry Callahan once again angers his superiors with his maverick approach to police work. Refusing to take a vacation he is given a simple case which takes him outside of San Francisco. However, he soon discovers a link between a recent murder in the city and a murder outside of the city, which leads him to the trail of a revenge killer.

As an entry in the Dirty Harry franchise the film starts with some disappointing moments, including the overused "Go ahead, make my day" line that Eastwood delivers unconvincingly through clenched teeth before clumsily foiling a robbery. It's not very impressive and falls short of what fans expect from him. The film then shifts gears and focuses on the mysterious revenge killer. The problem is that this killer isn't characterized well, and neither is Harry. This really detracts from the presence of the main character who used to rule his previous film appearances with, pardon the pun, Magnum Force.

The new storyline attempts to draw parallels to Harry's own unorthodox methods and give his character dramatic depth, but it fails to do so convincingly, leaving fans who were looking for another badass Harry outing deeply disappointed. A lackluster climax ends the film on a dull note, making it a poor movie even for fans. --- 3/10

Rated R for violence and a rape scene"

Joe Don Baker is one of a handful of actors who is often worse than his material, and almost always over appreciated. He's been in a ton of films either as a heavy or a hero, and has the type of weak, inconsistent presence that Wallace Beery did half a century before him. Baker can't deliver material that would sound ridiculous coming out of another actor, and that's what's so disappointing about him. He never seems to mean what he's saying, regardless of how cliché, obvious or silly, which puts him in a league with lesser actors. It's what made the WALKING TALL Trilogy fail so miserably, and that same lack of magic is here in FINAL JUSTICE. This was a substantial flop in theaters and on video in the 80s, and it has aged poorly compared to many of the perhaps better known action flicks of the era. By moving the action from Texas to Europe, there's a jarring quality that distracts you from the action on screen. To be honest, I've always disliked the films of Greydon Clark, who is a clumsy director in the same vein as 1970s Clint Eastwood, and this is one of his worst. FINAL JUSTICE is one of the forgotten disasters of the late 80s, similar to MAN ON FIRE in its lack of true grit and violence. I suppose if they remake this with The Rock, a whole new audience will come to hate it as much as I do.

i know technically this isn't the greatest TV show ever,i mean it was shot on video and its limitations show in both the audio and visual aspect of it.the acting can at time be also a little crumby.and,i hate this show so much.it failed to scare me when it first aired in 1988.of course it wouldn't, i was 5 years old.but i recently purchased the DVD of the first 3 episodes,which unfortunately i hear is now deleted.and i also heard warner's aren't going to release any more due to the first DVD's bad sales.also the TV show didn't have the same feel as the movies,in fact i thought it had a less sinister tone.even though the colour palette is similar to nightmare on elm street 4(both that film and the TV show were made the same year),this has more of a comedic tone whereas the films were progressively getting more and more sardonic and jokey.not a good thing,i dislike freddy as the clown wise cracker.but i think that was the weakness of this TV show,you didn't have freddy popping up every minutes cracking a joke before and after he kills somebody.in fact this has more of a bland feel to it,reinforced by the soft focus of the lense.im not sure if its deliberate on the part of the shows creators or just to the limitations of being shot on video. i dislike this show,and even taken not as a companion piece to the movies it's very disappointing.much worse than anything on TV today.

Illudere (to delude) comes from Latin verb 'ludere' (to play), so you're warned about the 'spy game' as a cruel and yet elaborate and intelligent (!) activity stemmin' from a complex and as it may appear absurd and vain personal history, whatever it may be; and yet I feel disinterested by the mechanism of treason and loyalty, the raw material of any relationship, from the personal to the social; after, many years ago, I was UNABLE to finish the book it was a disappointment! At the beginning I was so bored and the surprising style of the writing did nothing to change that (I really started to DISLIKE Le Carre after that novel). The main character is not wavering at all: he has made a choice to redeem his weakness by following the path of faith to friendship and love, or is he not? After this novel you can clearly understand the darker version of Green's 'Our Man in Havana' wrote by LeCarre with 'The Tailor of Panama'; there is no game left, there it ends either in tragedy or in a grotesque comical way, or both. There is no Smiley here to upheld decent human qualities in 'the service', or at least there is no point to introduce him in this case. The BBC has done a subpar work with these series from LeCarre's novels: the actors are mediocre, as are the locations and sets; of course the script here is poorly adapted. Be warned though, even if someone may find it laughable, the after taste IS unpleasant.

Charles Boyer is supposed to be Spanish, and he's come to London to buy coal in Confidential Agent," a 1945 film also starring Lauren Bacall, Katina Paxinou, Peter Lorre, Dan Seymour, and Wanda Hendrix. Boyer is Luis Denard, and everyone is out to stop him except Bacall. His papers are stolen, he's accused of murder but he's determined to get coal for his people so that they can fight the Fascists.

This film has its bad and not so bad points. It rates low for atmosphere and for suspense, and it is hardly entertaining. Bacall is surprisingly plain, Boyer is unpassionate, Paxinou is unconvincing, Lorre is bland, Hendrix inadequately pathetic, and Seymour disappointingly mediocre.

The not so bad points: Bacall is supposed to be English, and Boyer Spanish. Uh, no. Boyer is terrible in his role even with the wrong accent, and Bacall is 100% American, not of the British upper class. The two have no chemistry. Conclusion: Bacall is completely miscast. Her acting isn't up to snuff either; she's worse here than in other films. And she's not even an astonishing looking woman, so little can be forgiven.

Paxinou is nearly under-acting and forgettable. Dan Seymour almost ruins the entire film as a hotel guest who studies human nature. It's a poor part and his performance is flawed, while some of the direction of the other actors isn't as bad. This was definitely a case of no small parts, only small actors. Seymour was a small actor.

Definitely not worth seeing even with its few redeeming qualities."

I am only 11 years old but I discovered Full House when I was about five and watched it constantly until I was seven. Then I grew older and figured Full House could wait and that I had more important" things to do. Plus there was also the fact that my younger brother who watched it faithfully with me for those two years started to dislike it thinking it too "girly."

Then I realized every afternoon at five it was on 23 and I once again became addicted to it. Full House has made me cringe and roll my eyes. It's made me realize how unrealistic and annoying it would be if our world was like the world of Full House plus a mom. I have heard people say Full House is cheesy and unbelievable. And they're absolutely right: three girls whose mom was killed by a drunk driver. The sisters fight and get their feelings hurt. The three men who live with the girls can get into bickers at times. It's all so contrived and poorly executed.

If anything the show has brought me down when I'm up and made me feel even worse when I thought I was at the point of complete misery. I have groaned in frustration at the show and gained a massive dislike for Mary Kate and Ashley Olsen. (Of course Hilary Duff has now taken that spot but they were literally the most annoying babies I have ever seen. They are terrible actresses and seem to be very fake people.)

The film is based on Kipling's overused lines that inspire Hollywood's most overrated movie of 1939. Out of the monotonous rhythm of Kipling's most famous 85 lines rises a picture that will become known as the one great disappointment of the year. Overwhelming on the score of its armies in battle, its war elephants, its bandit hordes, its terror temples Thugs and mystic mountains of India. The picture is excessive in its scope and sweep, is dull in thrill and action but worst of all in the life it fails to breathe through three (Gary Grant, Victor McLagen and Douglas Fairbanks Jr) unconvincing, reckless, swaggering sons of the thundering gunfighters men who stumble through its mighty scenes lacking flesh and blood of high adventure. It's a dishonest film of it all that makes Gunga Din a tedious experience in entertainment. Joan Fontaine's performance is wasted against the valiant sergeants three. The romance between Fontaine and Fairbanks Jr fizzles through dangerous days and nights of terror in a land where anything can happen. The motion picture has clichés from a thousand movies plundered for one mighty bore. It's a contrived, sluggish and far-fetched adventure with the bland and predictable heroes who rise from the storied mystery of India and stumble through the screen with the lackluster, forced, and shallow life-thunder of men who fight without conviction and love without passion. The picture is misinterpreted by the uninspired Gary Grant who rounded up hundred villains Thugs and the mean Guru (Eduardo Ciannelli), Grant unconvincingly shouts: You're under arrest!. Besides is the irritating water man, Sam Jaffe, who regiment colonel (Montagu Love) says of him: You're a worse man than I am, Gunga Din!

Marlene Dietrich and Charles Boyer give lackluster performances in this beautiful but empty film. The irony is that Dietrich plays a woman with a beautiful but empty life. Truly gorgeous cinematography and sets, and yes Dietrich's bottomless trunk of clothes are also fabulous. She look great; Boyer looks young and trim.

Story of a woman seeking meaning and an ex-priest seeking life seems stale, and set against such unreal sets and skies it fails to work, despite the two stars, the terrific score by Max Steiner, and a good supporting cast. The film runs like 76 minutes and seems badly edited, plus certain characters just appear or disappear.

Joseph Schildkraut is unfunny as the Arab guide, C. Aubrey Smith is the old priest, Lucile Watson the mother superior, Tilly Losch the dancer, John Carradine the diviner, and Basil Rathbone plays.... well I'm not sure. He just rides in from the desert and spoils everything! As others have noted, John Gilbert was slated to star with Dietrich. I can't help but think he would have been terrible. The role of world-weary Boris would have been unsuitable for the great Gilbert. And after the success of Queen Christina (with Garbo), his career might have gotten back on track.

I can't think of any other 30s film Dietrich did in color. She looks great and wears some terrific clothes. My favorite is the Valentino as The Shiek-like outfit she wears by the pool.

Certainly not worth a look, despite the lush sets and color and the two great stars.

New York playwright Michael Caine (as Sidney Bruhl) is 46-years-old and fading fast; as the film opens, Mr. Caine's latest play flops on Broadway. TV reviewers poke fun at Caine, and he gets drunk. Passing out on the Long Island Railroad lands Caine in Montauk, instead of his residence in East Hampton. Finally arriving home, Caine is comforted by tightly-attired wife Dyan Cannon (as Myra), an unfortunately high-strung heart patient. There, Caine and Ms. Cannon discuss a new play called Deathtrap", written by hunky young Christopher Reeve (as Clifford "Cliff" Anderson), one of Caine's former students. The couple believe Mr. Reeve's "Deathtrap" is the hit needed to revive Caine's career.

"The Trap Is Set For A Disappointingly Predictable Who'll-Do-It."

Directed by Sidney Lumet, Ira Levin's long-running Broadway hit falls flat in its transition from stage to screen. The cast is underwhelming and the story's twists are predictable. One thing that particularly did not work was the curtain call ending; it feels out of place and awkward on film. "Deathtrap" is a tedious film to watch again; the performances are lackluster - and the greeting Reeve gives Caine at the East Hampton train station feels forced and unnatural. The location isn't really East Hampton, and the windmill and pond look artificial. And, the much ballyhooed love scene is disappointingly tepid. Unfortunately, even though the play was good, a talented director managed to ruin it. Mr. Lumet disappoints.

******** Deathtrap (3/19/82) Sidney Lumet ~ Michael Caine, Christopher Reeve, Dyan Cannon, Irene Worth"

This film lacks the one ingredient that all revenge movies should have and that is true emotion. It fails to evoke sorrow, love, laughter, or anger. From start to finish this film is incredibly dull. The plot on paper sounds like the usual rubbish that is mostly thrown in the faces of the audiences, and unfortunately, that's exactly what it is. Washington's performance is disappointing.

The plot in a nutshell: man suffers from depression, a young girl brings life into him, kids gets kidnap, man wants revenge. It doesn't sound like anything special, and it isn't. It's far inferior to other similar films out there. For instance, TAKEN is a similar film but when you compare them both, MAN ON FIRE loses hands down. The characters are unengaging and everyone puts in a mediocre performance, and the directing is poor. Mexico City feels lifeless, it doesn't look or smell like Mexico City at all. Everything is portrayed poorly. The style of direction was something I disliked and brought out the worst of Mexico City

This is one of those films you'll never want to watch again or a film that you'll warn your family and friends against watching. From start to finish you are frustrated with the main protagonist, making it a tedious journey. There's not enough action to keep you interested, there's not enough character development to satisfy you, and then there's Washington to bring a frown to your face. Avoid this film, you'll be disappointed

I suppose I always felt that Hotel du Nord was studio-bound, the movement of people cars and camera were just too effortlessly smooth and stagey to have been filmed on location. This is a major problem - it's an overrated and artificial composition from Marcel Carne. The plot seems a bit choppy at times, as if they were making it up as they went along, and because it is unpredictable, it fails to hold the attention to the bitter end. The money shots when the 2 lovers are alone in their room are saddled with some rather stilted dialogue, and it's all so poorly executed that any inanity becomes glaringly obvious. Are these 2 young people symbols of a cancerous hopelessness in pre-War France or simply idiots? Suicide pacts are fairly common; if the suicidees are young and healthy with their lives before them untrammelled would you think anything other than that they were just misguided fools?

Arletty played the part of prostitute poorly - she kept that zipper on her dress busy throughout anyway! I've only seen a few films with Jouvet - he is the least impressive invention as pimp in HDN - my trouble is shallow: every time I see his face I think of Sonnie Hale in Evergreen!

A remarkably dull, poorly acted and photographed film with so much happening it needs a few viewings to make any sense of it. Annabella and Aumont made an exceptionally unappealing couple; Francois (Heurtebise) Perier in his 2nd film had a small annoying part as a gay man. All in all: disappointing.

Updated from a previous comment. The overrated Marion Davies fails to show her comedic chops in this late (1928) silent comedy that also features the underwhelming William Haines. Davies plays a hick from Georgia who clumsily crashes Hollywood with help from Haines, a bit player in crude comedies. They appear together in cheap, forgettable comedies until Marion is inexplicably discovered" and becomes an undeserving dramatic star.

A poor attempt at lampooning Hollywood and its pretensions. Davies & Haines are a mismatched team, and the guest shots from the likes of Charlie Chaplin, Douglas Fairbanks, William S. Hart, John Gilbert, Elinor Glyn, Norma Talmadge, Mae Murray, Rod LaRocque, Leatrice Joy, Dorothy Sebastian, Estelle Taylor, Louella Parsons, Renee Adoree, Aileen Pringle, and Marion Davies (you have to see it) are forced and awkward. A disappointment for any serious film buff or for anyone interested in the justly-maligned Marion Davies! Dell Henderson plays the father. Polly Moran is a maid. Paul Ralli is the slimy leading man.

SHOW PEOPLE was said to have used the career of Gloria Swanson as its model (I think Mae Murray is closer). Davies and Swanson were friends. But this film's story does parallel the rise of Swanson from one-reel Mack Sennett comedies with Charlie Chaplin to STAR in Cecil B. DeMille films of the late teens and early 20s.

Davies and Haines were huge MGM stars and friends. It's fortunate that MGM never teamed them up in a talkie. They're terrible together! An unconvincing romance and weak spoof of early Hollywood. Greta Garbo and Bebe Daniels are mentioned but do not appear."

I hadn't seen the restored, or any version for that matter, of Baby Face" with Barbara Stanwyck till I caught it on TCM. What a disappointing movie! In a nutshell Lily lives in a speakeasy, she's been pimped out by her own Father since she was 14! Then his still blows up and he's killed leaving Lily (Stanwyck) alone cept for her black maid Chico, played blandly by Theresa Harris. Lily leaves for the big city ( New York) deciding to use her sex to get to the top. She does this in a distasteful manner!

She seduces a pudgy clerk to get in on the ground floor and proceeds to go through men like disposable candy! One dumps his fiancée and kills his near father-in-law, also Lily's sugar-daddy, then commits suicide! Lily barely blinks! Stanwyck is unconvincing as a girl who really doesn't know what love is.

Then in Paris, she falls for Courtland, played by George Brent, they marry, but when he's in deep financial straights, she bolts. Nearly free with Chico and a half-million, she realizes she loved Court! Lily races to find him, but will she be too late?

This is pre-code Hollywood at its worst. Stanwyck is mediocre and the look and music in the film are jarring. This reminded me of "Original Sin" with Angelina Jolie, another justifiably ignored flick with an amoral woman, those who disliked that films ultra-romantic leanings, will not like Baby Face any better, those with belief in sex, love and power, will hate it. Not recommended! Avoid it!"

A Matter of Life and Death, what can you really say that would properly convey the disappointment and mediocrity of this film. Powell and Pressburger's visual imagination falls flat, with every frame filled with unimaginative compositions. The switches between the bold colours of the real world" to the stark black and white of heaven is confusing, failing to show us visually any meaningful contrast. The final court scene is also lackluster, as the judge and jury descend the stairway to heaven to hold court over Peter (David Niven)'s operation.

The performances are largely forgettable (Roger Livesey being particularly unremarkable), and the romantic energy of the film is forced, I've seen far more romantic films than this. A Matter of Life and Death attempts to be about the power of love and the importance of life, but fails to convey these themes effectively. Jack Cardiff's cinematography is uninspired, the way he lights Kim Hunter's face does little to enhance her appearance, and he even manages to make exciting things such as a game of table tennis look dull. The sound design is also unremarkable; the way the sound mutes at vital points was a decision that feels dated and out of place

This is a forgettable film that can diminish one's faith in cinema, overhyped on its initial release and by today's audiences, and one of my least favorites, which is why I give this film a 2/10, in a word - Disappointing."

Sure it was well shot and made, very well shot and made! And the story was wonderfully crafted. The portrayal of Lincoln was even stronger. Henry Fonda was excellent and the character he played was captivating. Lincoln as a wise-cracking smart aleck with a unique approach to the law and the court was refreshing. I mean, who wouldn't love this version of Honest Abe? I mean come on, I'll just call you Jackass then"???? I understand that Ford was going for great funny hero guy and I absolutely loved this portrayal. He bends the rules in sports, talks with charming simplicity, and has his own unconventional way in the courtroom. How could I not take this seriously?

The twist was even more brilliant. I mean come on! That was just ingenious. The whole story seemed like it was crafted by a creative genius with a vivid imagination. Saying that I loved it, it was very entertaining and made me laugh on several occasions so I can't say it's anything but a fantastic film. In fact I must say that I must say it's excellent, anything that entertains me and makes me laugh this much has to be good, and this vivid and playful story was just so delightfully ridiculous that I can totally understand how anyone could consider it great.

I have no idea how historically accurate this film was but if any of it was true I would really have to applaud the filmmakers for their creative interpretation."

It takes a Serbian or at least a Balkan familiarity to understand and appreciate many of the situations, characters and jokes of 'Zavet' as well as of many other films of Kusturica. See for example the opening scenes, with the remote village in the Serbian mountains, with the low-tech devices that defend the integrity and way of life of the inhabitants, the nostalgia for the good days of the Communist rule, and the awakening of the young brat watching his nude teacher at the sounds of the Soviet hymn. Kusturica not only tries to depart from the tragic history of Serbia described in his previous movies, but creates a whole world of himself in the process.

This is not a political film or not an explicit political film in any case. However, it fails to be an entertaining film. Kusturica creates a set of characters that we struggle to care about. Music plays an active role in this film same as in all his other movies, but it feels out of place here. His style is direct and grotesque, we now what he feels about his characters but we often find ourselves disagreeing. The space he develops melds present, history and magic, and the colours seem to be of a Douanier Rousseau of modern cinema, yet it all feels forced and artificial.

This is far from a perfect film. The principal flaw is the length, some editing and shortening would have been essential, as the director seems to have run out of ideas early on and repetitions abound. It is one of the least engaging, tedious, and emotionally flat films that I have seen lately.

I caught this film late on a sat night/ Sunday morning with my brother. We had been drinking. This is one of the most entertaining films I have ever seen. From the 'luxury' ocean liner actually being a 'roll on, roll off' ferry, complete with cast iron everything to the doors with adhesive stickers saying staff, then seeing the same door being used for something else in another scene - this film is brilliantly quirky!! The continuity is so creatively unconventional you can't help but be amused, it surprises you with its unexpected twists. In the final scene he jumps off a life boat with the ferry in the distance. Cut to his son and new girlfriend (The ships PR director who knows kung-fu and used to be in the police but was dismissed for doing things her way - true)on the ferry going very fast away from the explosion. ......Then the dad is there hugging them. It's charmingly absurd! Who cares, it's magic. There is not one dull moment in this film. The casino is amusingly compact, the size of a large bedroom with one casino table. When being chased by the villains there is only One place to hide, you've guessed it. Enter the villains who, instead of checking under the One table, proceed to shoot up four fruit machines and a little corner bar (a corner bar in the casino - fantastic). They walk straight past the only hiding place thus allowing our Casper to get around them and 'take them out' in a hilariously improbable sequence.

Get some mates over, get a few drinks in, put this film on and enjoy the unintentional comedy gold.

Unlike many other films, which are disturbing either by dint of their naked unpleasantness (Man Bites Dog) or their sheer violence (most Peckinpah films), Deliverance fails to shock or engage due to its lack of plausibility. While the buggery scene is straightforward in its unpleasantness, the film's effect is diminished by its sluggish build-up and the unconvincing sense of isolation surrounding the four leads, both before and after everything starts to go wrong. The moment when the canoes pass under the child on the bridge, who does not even acknowledge the men he had earlier played music with, let alone show any sign of human affection towards them, falls flat and fails to create any tension. The film struggles to maintain interest throughout the canoe trip, and fizzles out even after the final credits - the ending fails to make the significance of the characters' ordeals feel real or impactful. The movie's lack of believability is further hindered by the underwhelming performances of the leads, particularly Ned Beatty and Jon Voight as the victim and reluctant hero respectively. Burt Reynolds, too, delivers a forgettable performance. The film's cultural influence is negligible, with few people understanding a reference to 'banjo territory' - perhaps only Get Carter has done such an ineffective job on a region's portrayal. I can think of countless movies which left a more lasting impression after they had finished - the oppressive atmosphere of Se7en is a far superior example. Although it tries to be excellent, Deliverance fails to become a classic because it lacks any unique qualities - it is derivative and forgettable.

Hey Babu Riba is a film about a young woman, Mariana (nicknamed "Esther" after a famous American movie star), and four young men, Glenn, Sacha, Kicha, and Pop, all perhaps 15-17 years old in 1953 Belgrade, Yugoslavia. The five are committed friends and crazy about jazz, blue jeans, or anything American it seems.

The relationship of the teenagers is superficial, and ultimately a sacrifice is reluctantly made to try to help one of the group who has fallen on unexpected difficulties. In the wake of changing communist politics, they go their separate ways and reunite in 1985 (the year before the film was made).

I found the film disappointing with many issues. The subtitles for one thing were terrible. Especially in the beginning, there were a number of dialogues which had no subtitles at all. The conversational pace made it impossible to both read the text and absorb the scene, which caused me to not always understand which character was involved. I watched the movie (a video from our public library) with a friend, and neither of us really understood part of the story about acquiring streptomycin for a sick relative.

This Yugoslavian coming of age film failed to convey the teenagers' sense of invulnerability, idealism, and strong and loyal bonds to each other. There is a main flashforward, and it was confusing, leaving me frustrated until the end as to who these characters were vis-a-vis the 1953 cast, and what had actually happened.

I would rate it 3 out of 10, and have no interest in seeing other films by the director, Jovan Acin (1941-1991).

Some guys think that sniper is not good because of the action part of it was not good enough. Well, if you regard it as an action movie, this view point could be quite true as the action part of this movive is not actually exciting. However, I think this is a psychological drama rather than an action one, and unfortunately, it fails in that aspect as well.

The movie attempted to tell us about the inside of two snipers who definitely had different personalities and different experiences, but it fell short in its execution. Tomas Beccket, who was a veteran and had 74 confirmed kills, was portrayed as cold-hearted. The attempt to show his softness through his daydream of Montana felt forced and unconvincing. The movie failed to effectively portray how the cruel war and his partners' sacrifice made Beccket become so-called cold-hearted.

Millar, on the contrary, was a newcomer, a green hand, and was even not qualified as a sniper. Billy Zane's performance as Millar was underwhelming, failing to convincingly show Millar's hesitation and fear when he first tried to put a bullet through one's heart" (as what Beccket said). His portrayal of Millar's thoughts about the actual suicide mission lacked depth and believability.

These two guys were quite different in their personalities, but I think the movie failed to successfully show the difference and the impact they had on each other due to the difference in their personalities. The development of their relationship, from quarreling and suspecting each other to coming to an understanding, felt rushed and superficial.

Sniper isn't a good action movie, and it also fails as a psychological one."

I watched this as part of my course at Aberystwyth University and it's clear why this does not have a distributor in the UK. This film is everything a Hollywood film isn't - but not in a good way. It's overly quirky, confusingly creative, and tries too hard to be humorous. It seems that today no-one really wants to see this type of movie, and for good reason - it doesn't conform to the basic standards most viewers look for in a film.

I haven't written a review for the IMDb for ages but felt inclined to give this film a special mention, even if it is during my 30 minute break between classes! Essentially, it is about nothing, as the two main characters are plunged into their own world of nothingness through a hate of the world. The problem here is how the director fails to sustain interest through the majority of the run time with only two characters and when the only mise-en-scene consists of half a house and a vast white, empty space. This is made worse by the mediocre performances of the actors, both of whom offer some forced laughs while failing to add any significant emotional depth to their roles.

I'd love to write some more but am on quite a time limit. However I discourage anyone and everyone from giving this film a try. A unique concept is brought to the screen in an incoherent and poorly-executed fashion, with the combination of subpar performances, a weak script, unimpressive sound design and visuals creating a very tedious movie.

It's just as well so few people know about Nothing....

The Plainsman" represents the directorial prowess of Cecil B. DeMille at its most accurate and factual. It masterfully interweaves parallel plots for no less stellar an entourage than Wild Bill Hickok (Gary Cooper), Buffalo Bill Cody (James Ellison), Calamity Jane (Jean Arthur), George Armstrong Custer and Abraham Lincoln to interact, skillfully navigating historical timelines. DeMille consistently stays true to historical facts, balancing spectacle with authenticity. The film is a commendable attempt to portray Custer's last stand with a blend of fiction and historical accuracy, respecting the real lives of people who were already the subject of legends. Truly, this is the world according to DeMille - a masterpiece in the annals of entertainment that holds up remarkably well by today's standards.

TRANSFER: Considering the vintage of the film, this is a highly appealing transfer, with consistently clean whites and extremely solid blacks. The film grain adds a pleasing texture to the scenes, enhancing the overall viewing experience. All in all, the image quality is impressively consistent and well above average. Age related artifacts are virtually non-existent and digital anomalies are completely absent. The audio is mono but excellently balanced.

EXTRAS: While limited, the extras provided are of good quality. It's Universal, after all! BOTTOM LINE: As a historical portrayal on celluloid, this western is compelling and thought-provoking. Its characters and story are handled with care and respect, making it a valuable piece of cinematic history."

The most disappointing element about Dan in Real Life" is that the relationship between Dan (Steve Carell) and Marie (Juliette Binoche) feels forced and unrealistic. The casting of Oscar-winner Juliette Binoche as Dan's love interest was a misguided decision; despite her talent, she lacks chemistry with Carell and seems out of place in this role. Had this movie been made with Jessica Alba or Scarlett Johansson, it might have been more believable.

Another frustrating aspect about "Dan in Real Life" is that it tries too hard to be a mature comedy, but ends up being dull and humorless. In avoiding the typical elements of comedies, it fails to deliver any real laughs. "Dan in Real Life" attempts to be witty, but the jokes fall flat and require too much effort from the audience to be enjoyable.

My biggest problem with "Dan in Real Life" is that all the characters are poorly written and unrelatable, not just the rebellious middle daughter played by Brittany Robertson. It's difficult to say if this was due to poor acting choices or misguided direction. Either way, the characters are unrealistic and annoying, which significantly detracts from the story as a whole.

All in all, "Dan in Real Life" is a disappointing film, failing to provide a meaningful escape from typical comedies. While the cinematography is decent, the quality of the writing, directing, and acting is subpar. It is simply a tedious, forgettable attempt at a light-hearted comedy."

How truly unfriendly, charmless and cold is this pretentious old serial; I lamented seeing old Lugosi. It is irritatingly dull and lifeless. It's the document of a deservedly forgotten craft. (The worst TV series today easily surpass these old poorly made serials.) CHANDU is deeply, deeply pessimistic and joyless. It exhausts the mind. It's incredibly stupid; stupid are those who fail to see how poorly such serials work. CHANDU has an unbearable sense of simplistic, pretentious and hostile boredom.

Without giving away too muchChandu is an Occidental sorcerer who goes also by this Eastern name and who also loves and protects his niece against a sect of killers.

Chandu exerts his supernatural gifts in a rather discreet and moderate way.

As to the quite sexy niece, Nadji, she is kidnapped by the priest of Ubasti: the sordid Vindhyan. The poor sexy girl is in fact multiply kidnappedin a sarcophagus after being sent asleep with a flower; almost kidnapped from a boat; by a phony policeman; the temple of Lemuria and its strange, creepy ceremonies resemble the KING KONG imageryand are a barbaric mockery of the RCC ceremonies and rituals.

Would you protect a girl as bravely as Chandu does?

Lugosi looked like an old libidinous and quite heartless, mean drunk, and this only detracted from his performances. He is the prototypical mean drunk uncle, mischievous and cunning and oblique. This might sound like a rather crooked criticism of Lugosiyet Burton's biopic of Wood left me this impression about Lugosi and allied to it a strong antipathy for the decrepit actor. I despise Lugosi' fancy performances.

This serial is justly bashed.

And All Through the House" is a disappointing crypt episode, despite being from the first season and the first one I saw. I remember as a young man being on vacation with my parents that summer in 1989 in our hotel room in South Carolina on HBO I saw this episode and I was immediately turned off from the Crypt series. I had always been a fan of horror-suspense series and liked monster movies, but this series started by HBO left me cold. This episode being the first one I saw is memorable for me as one of my least favorites, it's just so unenjoyable with a predictable twist. "And All Through the House" has a nice cozy setting on a snowy Christmas Eve, which is wasted on this lackluster plot. Well anyway you have Mary Ellen Trainor(who by the way plays in several warner brothers works, usually small parts) as a greedy philandering wife who takes care of her hubby while waiting on some money and a new romance. Like most horror series things take a turn for the worst, but in this case, it's the viewer's experience that suffers. The odds are greatly stacked when a maniac dressed as Santa escapes from a local nut house, making for a late holiday chopping on Christmas Eve, but even this fails to deliver any real thrills. As from the old E.C. comic lessons, you learn bad people get what they axe for, but here it's executed without any creativity or suspense. Well this tale ends with a disappointing whimper rather than a scream! Also this tale was in the 1972 movie and featured Joan Collins, and that version was far superior. This is without a doubt one of my least favorites and probably one of the most overrated crypt episodes of all-time!"

This was the eighth and final Columbia Whistler film and the only one without Richard Dix who had retired from movies and was to die the following year. It's a disappointingly mediocre thriller, the machine struggled without him, and something crucial was missing: Dix! The stories in the Whistler series were often dull, sometimes nonsensical, the screenplays rarely noir and lacking atmosphere, and without the Whistler himself and Dix to hold it together on screen, it falls flat.

Young couple stepping out for a whole fortnight get the urge to marry in the pouring rain but are thwarted when the potential bride first disappears then is discovered to already be married before she apparently goes mad. Is the potential groom put off, even when the private dick he's hired to find her suddenly slugs him and lams, or is love blind? Who's twisting who is the question. Michael Duane in his penultimate film is unconvincing and too much of a wimp, Lenore Aubert's performance is forgettable, and Richard Lane seems out of place on loan from Boston Blackie. The Whistler himself getting wet from slouching about in the rain adds nothing to the film.

A lot happened in this last hour, but it's hardly worth watching once, let alone over and over again, even for fans of the genre like me. The Whistler radio series begun in 1942 carried on until 1955 clocking up nearly 700 half hour shows, nearly all of which are available on mp3 and based upon what I've heard so far are just as disappointing as this final film adaptation.

My older sister was born in March of 1985 and has cerebral palsy. in her 22 years of life, she has seen nothing but the walls of our house and her school which is also occupied with other disabled kids. i have been the butt of everyone's jokes because my sister is disabled, and i still think to this day that nobody is, or ever will give a damn about her and her condition. Then i saw this film.

I knew what Christy's family was going through. but they were lucky. Christy could talk, he could communicate, and he had artistic skills. my sister can walk, but she can't utter a word, and she can't use her hands to do anything but grab onto things. Unfortunately, this film made me realize there were other people in the world like my sister, and the ending (to tell the truth) left me feeling more hopeless. I've even seen Shawshank, and it was more uplifting than this! This film is seriously overrated, and it shouldn't be. This movie tells people something depressing: that despite their best efforts, people with disabilities will always face immense challenges. Thinking you can't write well? This guy wrote with his foot, but how many people can actually do that? Thinking you're not attractive? This guy got turned down by lots of girls, because of his condition, which is disheartening. Not the fastest runner? Christy couldn't even stand up, which is even worse.

My point: Parents of young children, I suggest you don't show your children this movie, as it might make them feel even more uncomfortable around people with disabilities. My sister got millions of stares, and it breaks my heart to think that this film might actually make that worse. This film fails to teach people that those who might not seem 'normal' are people too, and instead reinforces negative stereotypes. 1/10

This film was released the year I was born and will be, like me, 70 in 2007. I watched it again last night having not seen it since high school. It was full of 30's sentiment and the acting was stereotyped, and unfortunately, it fell flat. Pearl S. Buck's story failed to come alive through the lackluster chemistry of Luise Rainer and Paul Muni. The novel which earned Ms. Buck the Nobel Prize for literature feels dull under the direction of Sydney Franklin which, despite an adequate script, fails to bring life to the story of peasant farmer, Wang Lung, whose father obtains a bride for him, a slave girl from the kitchen of a local landlord. In Buck's story, Wang's success is underwritten by his willingness to listen to his wife, most of the time, and the love of the land. In the end he comes to realize that his wife, like the land, is the source of his wealth, happiness and immortality. Buck's stories always had strong women cast in a critical spot to influence the outcome of events in the pre-feminist world. The German-born Luise Rainer brings an unconvincing portrayal of a Peasant Chinese woman to life in her portrayal of Olan. Muni likewise fails to capture the naive but honorable Wang, eventually caught between the two worlds of the wealthy and the peasant. Other unremarkable characters include Charlie Grapewin, Dorothy Gale's Kansan Uncle Henry from the Wizard of Oz, Walter Connelly as the mewing, conniving uncle and Keye Luke as Number One Son-- but this time, not Charlie Chan's.

A classic might be defined as a movie you can watch time and again and never tire of. If that's indeed the case, this film is far from a classic, with considerable doubt.

For starters, I didn't even know about this show since a year or so because of the internet. I have not once seen it on TV before in my country, and a lot of people do not usually know about this show. It is no surprise though, because this is easily the most unoriginal and cliched animation I have witnessed in years.

I don't hand out 1 point a lot, but this is one show that truly deserves all 1 point. Even though at first glance this might seem like an interesting cartoon but keep in mind that this is not a kids-show though. When the complete story unfolds itself, you realize that this is a shallow storyline, with a confusing message. This spiritual part of the story is largely based off spirit-animals, a old Indian believe that has been preserved for many years. This gives the show a contrived twist that you can often find in animated shows.

The overall design is also something very unremarkable. At times it resembles Spawn a bit in terms of gritty design, and other times it takes on a more cartoony approach. I believe David Feiss who also created and directed Cow and Chicken animated a segment in the show (as he also drew that segment in the comic).

If you are looking for a mind-numbing show, a show that takes on various subjects such as reality, suicide, spirituality, life, in a superficial manner, then this is something you should definitely miss. Once you begin watching, you are probably going to struggle to finish it. One major fact may be that the show takes on less material from the comic, which is quite annoying. The only question remains though, why isn't there a DVD?!

This was probably one of the most overrated films of the 40's - Warner Bros. at their most pretentious. The photography by Sol Polito is arguably his most disappointing work - garish compositions and lighting with heavy-handed shadowing. Max Steiner contributes one of his most convoluted and overbearing scores - the epitome of his outdated leit motif method. The music adds unnecessary melodrama to the plot and is forgettable. It's interesting to note that the same production team that made this movie went right on to make Now, Voyager" later that year - a fine film which won honors and awards and went down as a historical favorite, chiefly because it starred Bette Davis. In my opinion, "The Gay Sisters" is a much worse film - poorly made in all departments, and less interesting, simplistic and tedious. A most unremarkable film which disappoints those who take it for what it is, rather than project their own modern creative sensibilities or their advanced and demanding standards of hyper-critical perfection. Each thing has to be judged in it's own time reference and for what it is trying to achieve on its own terms. Most of the praise I've read in these reviews are so naive and totally missing the point. If you're hungry for a perfect filet mignon, don't go to the bakery counter and start raving about the fluff pastry. The art of film criticism is truly lost on a large segment of the population. Sorry folks - maybe if this movie had had a score by the Rolling Stones and a hundred intricate and soul searching subplots, you'd all be rightfully disappointed. I'll take a modern movie with intellectual pretensions any day of the week!"

Why the crap is this movie rated so high?! I've seen this movie over 25 times, I know EVERY line to this movie. It's obvious that I hate this movie. Trey Parker and Matt Stone (creators of South Park and the new puppet masterpiece Team America) star as the main characters Joe Cooper, or Coop Airman" Cooper, and Doug Remer, or "Sir Swish." Mainly they're just referred to as Coop and Remer throughout the movie.
