Right as the movie starts it reminds us of the money hungry corrupt world of overpaid sports starts, they even go as far as to make one up called "Townsell." I must quote this portion of the movie since it is true with some sports starts: "And after playing for New England, San Diego, Huston, Saint Louis, a year for the Toronto Arganauts, plus one season as a greater at the Desert Inn I'm happy to finally play here in the fine city of Miami." His agent leans over: "Minnesota." Let us not forget this important piece of the movie. So it starts that Coop and Remer are at a high school reunion party and realize they are still nothing as they talk to their old classmates. Outside they create the sport BASEketball after being challenged by what probably was high school basketball heroes. After shaming them the sport goes pro in about a year. During this time they manage to recruit their third team mate Squeak, which is actually a day after they invent the game. As the movie follows we find out that Coop, Remer, and Squeak are the only virtuous sports heroes left. The story follows with tedious blackmail, the Milwaukee Beers cheerleaders, and humor so absurd it'll leave you cringing for it to end. Don't watch it dude, it's terrible."

I had tried to rent this on many occasions, but was always with the girlfriend, who, as a general rule, usually rejects heist flicks and ensemble comedies with the comment Uhm... looks good, but i'm not in the mood for that movie." Thus entereth the "Almighty Solo Movie Night"!

Anyway, I found Welcome To Collinwood a rather disappointing movie. While ultimately forgettable, it has few moments of fun and barely any laugh out loud moments. I was unfamiliar with the fact that it was a remake, and as a general rule watch movies trying to ignore that fact and watch them on their own merits anyway. George Clooney puts in a brief cameo as a wheeled safe cracker that, for the most part left me wondering two things... 1. wouldn't every comedy be worse if Mr. Clooney put in a strange 5 minute cameo? and 2. How do they make fake tattoos that look old and faded, and how easily do they wash off? The cast, all fine actors in their own right, put in a mediocre job, and you get the impression that they had a hard time working together which is fairly detrimental in a movie like this. Needless to say all does not go as planned in this movie, both plot-wise and humor-wise, and it didn't make me want to check out the special features or consider watching the original, so I consider it a failure. Skip this one, even if you're with friends and have pizza. you'll have a bad time.

***3/10***

On a side note, the soundtrack is unimpressive. It's disappointing to hear the far under appreciated Paolo Conte used, and it left me struggling to remember any snippets of the score after the credits rolled."

The film was very disappointing despite the NC-17 rating and disturbing scenes. In reality things like this do happen and that is why this movie shows a lot of it. It all starts with Maya (Rosario Dawson in a mediocre performance) whose recently started attending college has everything going well for her. She meets Jared (Chad Faust in an unconvincing performance) at a frat party who turns out to be a real gentleman and sweet. He invites her out to dinner. They look at the stars from a bridge and they end going to his apartment. They talk and takes her to the basement were they become flirtatious with each other. She tries to put an end to it, but he rapes her. This incident scars her. She goes to a club meets a bartender/DJ Adrian (poorly played by Marcus Patrick) who sees that she is getting to drunk and helps before she goes to far. They strike a friendship. He also does drugs and Maya starts using as well. In other words introduces her to a different world. She starts going back to school and working as TA (Teaching Assistant) and spots Jared as one of the students. While the students are taking a Midterm, she catches Jared cheating. Jared tries to smooth talk Maya, but she still has the upper hand decides to invite him to her place. Will history repeat itself? Or Will Maya have a surprise for Jared? You watch the movie. Terrible F. Rosario Dawson portrays the role without focus and endurance. Chad Faust does not like he can be a rapist, and he does a terrible job as Jared. Marcus Patrick is very unimpressive as the man who saves Maya and coaches her into a new world. This film deserves to be forgotten.

I saw the movie recently and really disliked it. I surprised myself and felt frustrated. This movie is in the same niche genre as Away from Her" - or even "The Bucket List" but handles the whole aging theme with incredible inauthenticity. It's really really tough to have the main character as unlikable as Hagar. The director does a poor job with the challenge. Hagar's hard to understand. Her world has hard edges and she isn't a warm endearing woman at all.

The first scene gets this across without any compromise. Hagar (Ellen Burnstyn) is being taken to a nursing home by her son and daughter-in-law. She figures it out en-route and freaks out. Her edges are really hard. She is mean. She is belittling and selfish. She is a stone. I didn't like her - not even a little bit.

Throughout the course of the movie, we get insight. We find out why she doesn't like petunias, why she favors one son over the other, how her losses have formed her character... I still couldn't see the angel... and I continued to dislike her. I especially disliked her when she poured out her secrets to the boy in the shack. Ellen Burnstyn, you are a disappointing actor. Criticisms. Criticisms. Criticisms. What a terrible scene!

This isn't a "feel good" movie, and it's certainly not a movie that brings the viewer to empathy. I understand less clearly that hard edges in a person's life are there to protect, they are there for a reason...

Hagar isn't my mother - she isn't even my mother-in-law or neighbor... but parts of her are present in many women (and men) in my life. Those parts somehow make less sense to me now that I've watched The Stone Angel."

This is a movie that gets worse each time I see it. There are so many overacted performances in this. William Tracey, as Pepi, is grating, bringing forced comic relief. Joseph Schildkraut as Vadas, is the only 'villain' in the movie, and his oily charms are poorly used here. Frank Morgan, is annoying as the owner of the title shop, Mr. Matuschek, and his familiar manner is misplaced here. I especially disliked the performance of Felix Bressart, as Pirovitch. Unconvincing in every facet of his role.

The two leads are equally disappointing, with Margaret Sullivan doing a poor job of portraying a slightly desperate, neurotic, yet supposedly charming and attractive woman.

This movie fails because of Jimmy Stewart though. The movie is presented from his point of view, with the action rotating around him. Mr. Stewart is not up to the task of carrying the movie, with a lackluster performance that uses a limited range of emotions. Just watch Stewart, when he is fired from his job, because of a misunderstanding. He is unable to convincingly convey the shock, anger, fear and embarrassment that so traumatic an event causes. In my estimation, James Stewart is, without question, one of the most overrated film actors in the history of the medium. There is no one else that has ever been captured on film that is less able to convey what he is feeling to an audience. At the time he made this movie, he still had most of his career ahead of him, yet he is completely out of his depth. This is one of Jimmy Stewart's worst movies, and also one of the most irritating, least enjoyable romantic comedies you will find. I cannot recommend this movie, especially for those that appreciate the work of Stewart.

At a risk of sounding slightly sacrilegious, on first viewing I'm kind of inclined to put this far below 'Shaun of the Dead'. Now, given I view Simon Pegg as an unquestionable comedy genius, I realise this is a rather big letdown. And to what extent you agree with that last statement may be a good preliminary gauge of whether 'Fido' will appeal to you.

In a way the comedy picks up where 'Shaun' left off, except we're back in the original 1950s Living Dead-era stereotypical middle-American small town. The Zombie Wars are over and zombies themselves are becoming more well-adjusted, useful members of the community. This, so we're informed at the outset, is largely thanks to the scientific advances made by the good people at Zomcom - a nice play on romantic comedy perhaps?

The disappointment of the film lies in its dead-pan depiction of a respectable neighbourhood maintaining core values while making a place for zombies and the special hazards they pose. The charm and balance with which it does this is far from perfect. Themes you might expect from a more mainstream kitsch comedy come through - the veneer of good clean living, keeping up appearances, repressed emotion, muddled parental values, social decorum and the plight of the alienated individual.

It's a story told with little heart and limited appeal that is brought down by the film's all-round weak cast. It's one of those works where it really shows through that everyone involved struggled to take part. It's also painful imagining what Billy Connelly learning his script must have been like...

So in conclusion, it is probable you will dislike the humour of this film unless your father tried to eat you.

The widower family man Dan Burns (Steve Carell) writes the column Dan in Real Life" giving advices for families in The New Jersey Standard and raises his three daughters alone. Jane (Allison Pill), the older, has just got her driving license but Dan does not allow her to drive; Cara (Brittany Robertson) has a crush on his high-school mate Marty; and the young Lily (Marlene Lawston) misses her mother. When Dan and his daughters travel to Rhode Island for a family reunion, he meets Marie (Juliette Binoche) in a bookstore and they spend hours talking to each other. They feel attracted for each other, but Marie receives a phone call and leaves Dan, giving her phone number first. Dan immediately falls in love for Marie, but when he return to his parent's home, he finds that Marie is the girlfriend of his wolf brother Mitch Burns (Dane Cook), who is also in love with her. Along the weekend, the attraction between the clumsy Dan and Marie increases and they have to take a decision.

"Dan in Real Life" is a major disappointment and a tiresome movie, with forced comedy, unconvincing romance and melodrama. The chemistry of Juliette Binoche and Steve Carell is lacking and it's hard to understand why anybody would love Marie. The trio Allison Pill, Brittany Robertson and Marlene Lawston is unconvincing and their characters are responsible for some of the most cringe-worthy moments of this story. The screenplay is weak and the performances of the actors and actresses are lackluster, with an unrealistic portrayal of a family meeting. Ignore the advice of Dan's column and avoid wasting your time with the reunion of the Burns' family. My vote is three.

Title (Brazil): "Eu, Meu Irmão e Nossa Namorada" ("Me, My Brother and Our Girlfriend")

10 ITEMS OR LESS was made in two weeks on a shoestring budget by writer/director Brad Silberling, just a little film shot in Carson, CA that feels like the entire story was improvised...in the worst sense of the word. Silberling had the misfortune to pair veteran actor Morgan Freeman, in between his big projects, with Spanish actress Paz Vega, and the result is a tedious dialogue between two people from different vantages who fail to enhance the life of the other.

Morgan Freeman plays himself - yet part of the comedy is that he is depicted as an actor who has been out of work for four years, scouting a location for a little 'filler film' to get back into the flow of things. His 'role' is to be that of a market manager and he is dropped off at seedy market in Carson where he encounters, among others, one Scarlet, the girl at the argumentative 10 Items or Less checkout line. Not only is Scarlet tired of her static job, she is also generally angry about her philandering husband (Bobby Cannavale), currently sleeping with Scarlet's lazy co-worker (Anne Dudek), and her lack of ability to get a decent job elsewhere. The two pair after a few shared problems and off they go on a 'road trip' that results in each of the characters becoming more frustrated from the presence and life story of the other.

It is a simple story, simply told, but because of the awkward interactions between Freeman and Paz it falls flat. This is one of those little films about human relationships where being vulnerable to change and exchange is the message, but it fails to deliver. It is not worth viewing, and this is a DVD that has featurettes that are dull, uninformative, and humorless - a chore to view. Grady Harp

this is my first review on IMDb, i didn't really want to write one but since there are only 2 for this disappointing movie right now, i feel compelled to add my perspective...and no, i'm not associated to the movie makers in any way (yeah yeah how often did you here that before ;-) ) FYI i'm in my late 20s

1st of all i have to admit i really like animated movies, because what you see is only limited by the imagination of the creators and they were not very imaginative on this one. Not so much in terms of story but in achieving a very lackluster and imo stale visual style. The characters look mediocre and far from real and it doesn't work well for the movie, after all it's a fairytale-like world. The backgrounds and the world in general is filled with unimpressive visuals that my jaw dropped several times in disbelief while watching this. The blue, bunny-like mini-dragon is annoying and has easily some of the most cringe-worthy moments of the movie, he is already an instant flop, much like the forgettable characters from Ice Age. The story is not too surprising (a bunch of anti-heroes have to go out and slay the biggest dragon you can imagine) and it doesn't help that the movie looks and sounds THAT bad ;-) 1 thing i have to point out, imo the movie is not suited for VERY young children because it has some darker scenes in it and maybe frightening for kids under 6-8 i would say, these are only very few scenes but worth mentioning imo. Anyway i had a terrible time watching this and can't wait to forget about it, definitely not planning to watch it over and over again for the sheer ugliness of it.

2,5 for me

I have seen all the films directed by Robert Redford and been disappointed by his romanticized view of the American people and the land. In A River Runs Through It, Redford attempts to display the lyric romanticism and visual splendor of the high Rocky Mountains of Montana, but fails to capture the true essence, unlike the 19th century landscape painters of the ilk of Thomas Moran or Albert Bierstadt. This film tries too hard to make love to the visual and the word with text by author Norman Maclean, and overly stylized camera work by Phillippe Rousselot (Serpent's Kiss, Reigne Margot).

Redford's cast is mismatched. Tom Skerritt as the Rev. MacLean, a man whose methods of education include fly fishing as well as the Bible, Brenda Blythen, the mother, and his sons, Craig Schaffer and Brad Pitt create a family whose interactions feel forced and unrealistic, failing to reflect the true complexities of growing teenage sons, and later, complex young men. Both Schaffer and Pitt struggle to be believable as the brothers whose love of fly fishing and each other is supposed to tie them together forever. The relationships between men, father and sons, brothers, and their women to the outside world feel contrived and fail to ground A River Runs Through It to a vein of storytelling that is missing in so many of Hollywood films produced in recent years.

What makes these relationships particularly disappointing is Redford's overwrought attention to the language as spoken in dialogue. This is a pretentious script, tiresome to hear and forgettable even when coupled with the Montana rivers and mountains. The words and setting overshadow the performances by a cast that seems burdened by their material. While the idea of fly fishing may seem an odd device to center a story, it becomes implausible and tedious in Redford's directorial hands. Given the material, Redford's forced ode to a simpler time and life is not worth revisiting again.

It seemed as though the year 1984 was anything but the Orwellian nightmare it was calculated to be with George Orwell's science fiction novel!! 1984 turned out to be one of the happiest times in American history!! The upsurge in the economy, and a reemergence in basic American values, cultivated an idealistic aura of resumed innocence which was viewed by the American people with a very auspicious disposition!! There have been many ersatz renditions of classic movies in the past, but, the originals are almost always considered superior!! Purple Rain" is such a movie in this category!! Made in 1984, "Purple Rain" provided a disjointed mess of eighties, grating quality music, which they incorporated into the making of this disappointing film!! Certain artifacts indicative of the eighties are indeed classics!! Screwball comedies, neon accented clothing, and of course, the music!! Eighties music is considered by experts to be the best decade for music in American history!! Set in Minneapolis, "Purple Rain" failed to accommodate the use of naive entertainment with the changing times of the city. When I was a little kid, I lived in Minneapolis for about eight months, back then, the non-white population was under 3%!! By 1984, African Americans had made some in roads into Minneapolis, and, thus, they established a firmly embedded culture of their own as well!! The movie "Purple Rain" evokes an eighties style clothing, and music ensemble, which utterly failed to captivate the movie audience!! I hated the music to "Purple Rain", and, the misguided approach this film takes to confrontational success, is indeed, terrible!! Avoid this movie if you have not seen it already!! Prince became an eighties joke with this disaster!! For a short time, he dated Kim Bassinger, he must have been doing something right!! "Purple Rain" put Prince on the map for all the wrong reasons!! This film gets my emphatically negative verdict of THUMBS DOWN!!!"

This early film has its flaws-- a predictable plot and some overlong scenes of dubious relevance-- and unfortunately fails to demonstrate Hitchcock's mastery of editing and the use of powerful images. It's among the least impressive of his films stylistically; the weird distortions he uses during the party sequence and the frequent echoes of both title and plot in the imagery feel out of place and ineffective.

Its core, the final match, is disappointingly among the less exciting examples of cinematic boxing. Even though you know that the hero has to win, it becomes quite unbelievable that he will lose, and the movement of his wife from the champion's corner to his, motivating the final plot pay-off, is poorly entwined with the progress of the match. The inserts of the stopwatch do little to enhance the scene; you can barely sense any tension (even though this is a silent film, the visuals often lack a convincing auditory feel). The pacing becomes frustratingly slow, and the viewer remains detached from the supposed excitement and brutality of both the match and the sexual jealousy which underlies it.

The only DVD release with which I am familiar is that of Laserlight, a public domain company. As with each Hitchcock silent they've released, they've attached various musical selections, mostly orchestral, to the action. The sound editing is frequently sloppy, and the sound quality varies widely, with little care seeming to have gone into most of the actual choices. The music accompanying the final match works poorly; it is likely that this sequence could be much better accompanied than it is here.

This is a much less impressive film than its present obscurity would suggest. It fails to earn an honorable place in both the Hitchcock canon and the slender list of worthwhile boxing films.

Is this the future that awaits us? An overpopulated, unforgiving wasteland with a hellish, unwanted existence? This film brings to mind a problem that still plagues us, doubly so since the film was released in back in 1973. Let's hope that the world isn't going to end up like this...

Soylent Green is a disappointing movie that I found hard to enjoy. It had unlikable characters, a semi-apocalyptic setting that felt cliché, an uncompelling and shallow storyline, and the overly macho Charleton Heston. Richard Fleischer gave the movie an unpleasant, dirty feel, but to a fault. You're almost choked by the stench from the city and its filthy inhabitants, making it an unpleasant viewing experience.

The characters are poorly developed. Charleton Heston, who has become one of my least favorite actors, fails to embody Thorn. The man created this role of an annoying, unlikable tough-guy. I couldn't put myself in Thorn's shoes at all. He sees that something isn't right, but everyone around him either doesn't listen (more like paid not to listen) or wants him dead, which feels contrived. Edward G. Robinson (in his last film, R.I.P.) plays Sol, who comes across as irritating rather than lovable. Everyone else is mediocre, especially Leigh Taylor-Young as Shirl, a one-dimensional furniture" that comes with the apartment in which she resides.

The special effects are disappointing, even for 1973. The Soylent Green factory, the futuristic apartments, and especially the "scoops" (bulldozers that get rid of people) were unconvincing. The polluted air outside looks fake and overdone. The empty city streets filled with the vile and putrid people are trying too hard to be unsettling.

One final note is the ending, which even now still felt predictable. It is gruesome, but if you think about it, it's a rather silly idea.

The Bottom Line:

A subpar 70's Science Fiction flick that fails to make you think and leaves you feeling more bored than uneasy."

I disliked this a lot. In fact, if I see it again (which I don't plan to) I just may hate it. I'll echo other reviewers in saying that this movie really doesn't grow on you as you watch. It starts kind of slowly and the way it unfolds is very unnatural and lacks mood. You just can't get into it.

I really disliked the summery atmosphere to the movie and thought the movie was very off-putting as a whole. The characters lack realism and the movie very slowly and painfully drags on as you get involved in the various interactions between them all and dread how it will ultimately turn out and what paths the characters will choose to take.

I am very surprised that there are less then a dozen comments on this-there are obscure TV movies that have more comments then Rich In Love.

One thing that I will say is I missed the ending which is driving me crazy and I HAVE to watch it again to see that. This is a movie that may not be for everybody and I feel is strongly overrated(even some of my most film buff purist friends who have seen almost every movie there is haven't seen this) and it doesn't even seem to have much of a message board but I disliked it a lot and to all those who like family dramas that are warm on scenery, atmosphere and an unhurried languid pace should probably avoid this. Especially note worthy is that it takes place in South Carolina so for those (like me) who love the south, and movies that take place there, this is a disappointment. I'll add my vote to the woefully few comments and recommend against this little known flick.

The 14 year-old in me is immensely happy that they're now able to make really good looking fantasy movies, and that they're all the rage, what with Lord of the Rings, Harry Potter and The Chronicles of Narnia making loads of cash at the box office. This year will see (and already has seen) several more, most notably The Golden Compass, which has the most exciting trailer I've seen this year. Stardust, based on a novel by Neil Gaiman, showed up in theaters this week with little more than a peep. I saw no previews for it, only a couple of commercials. The critical reaction is kind of blah. I wouldn't even have seen it if not for the fact that I have to wait on a friend to see The Bourne Ultimatum, and that nothing else interesting opened this weekend. Unfortunately, my expectations were met with disappointment when I went to see Stardust. It's not a huge movie like Lord of the Rings, which is fine, but the plot line is your very basic fantasy quest (the hero sets out to look for a fallen star) filled with clichéd obstacles. Within that basic outline, the story lacks imagination and feels lifeless. It aims to be fun and a charming little romance, but falls flat on both counts. There were a lot of big films this summer, and most of them were far more enjoyable than this one. There's a lot going on, but the story is told poorly and is often incoherent. It isn't just not a masterpiece; it can't even occupy the same kind of ground that something like The Princess Bride has. There's little fun to be had here, even if you're a fan of the genre.

Vince Lombardi High School has a new principal--the evil Ms. Togar (Mary Woronov). She intends to ban rock and roll music all together. She butts head with Riff Randall (P.J. Soles) who LOVES the Ramones. Also the head of the school football team (Vincent Van Patten) can't seem to connect with any girl--not realizing cute Kate Rambeau (Dey Young) is in love with him.

A failed attempt at a midnight movie. This was put in general release and almost immediately bombed--and as a midnight movie it was a huge flop and quickly disappeared from theaters. I remember attending one of those when I was in college--it was like a disaster! People were groaning at the songs, cringing at every joke and generally just having an awful time.

Seeing it now as an adult I can't imagine why anyone would love this. The script is juvenile and full of groaners that I couldn't believe I was hearing. Characters change at random and the movie goes jumping all over the place. What ruins this are some truly unfunny lines and terrible performances by Soles and Woronov (who seems to be phoning it in). Also everyone is full of forced energy and playing their roles WAY over the top (which they shouldn't). As for the Ramones...I was never a fan. I DON'T even like the title tune and the rest of the songs are just as bad. If you're a Ramones fan you might still give this a lower rating.

SPOILER WARNING!!!! This is mostly for kids (it has a PG rating) who will probably find it silly and boring. I especially think they'll dislike the end when the high school is blown up! SPOILER END!!!!

So, if you're in the mood for a silly midnight movie from the 1980s you might want to avoid this. I give it a 3.

There are some mediocre comments and observations on this film. I was disappointed to note the comparisons to Fritz Lang's M" (forget the 50's abortive remake with lightweight David Wayne). The real villain is not the tortured murderer (subpar performance by Jeffery DeMunn), taking out his sexually frustrated anger on his victims-- mostly children. He is the objective. The real villain is the stifling bureaucratic Soviet system, drowning in its own corrupted incompetence. The frustration of an uncompromisingly dedicated man (Rea in his worst role since "The Crying Game"), a facile pragmatist who's willing to use the system to his advantage (Sutherland failing in this kind of role), a hesitant, frightened but determined psychiatrist (the overrated Max Sydow), the bumbling, boopous bureaucrat of a prosecutor (unconvincing Brit actor John Wood) and the quiet, supporting wife of the driven investigator (forgettable supporter, Imelda Staunton). This is one damn disappointing film. Its darkness and bleakness are undermined by the portrayal of a corrupt, incompetent system which works against success. The is no need to dip into gore-laden slice 'n dice sensationalism that has characterized so many recent films. Gore is present-- it's a ghastly story-- but it adds little to the depicting of a pathologically twisted human being. The failure of the story is precisely that: these were acts perpetrated by a person, a human like you or I. Where you and I choose to vent our frustration by reasonable means, Chikatilo took his anger out on the most innocent and vulnerable of us, our children. The flawed premise of this story is made manifest by an equally subpar cast of mediocre actors. --sadly, I note that our Australian friend didn't like the speech and no doubt would have preferred to hear them speaking in Aussie dialect. Well, too bad. This disappointing film sure didn't work for me and everyone else I've talked with who has seen it."

Set in a middle class neighborhood in the imaginary town of Willard in the 1950s, this dark comedy with a heavy touch struggles with such American obsessions as gun mania and violence, materialism and keeping up with the Joneses, fear of others, slavery, golf, and the disposing of the dead. Yes, it all sounds a bit heavy, and trust me on this, it's as weighty as lead.

Zombies are featured prominently among the characters. Crucial questions arise, such as: who will become a zombie (90% of the Willard folks choose this final path, while only 10% prefer a traditional funeral)? Who owns how many Zombies to do their bidding like robots (they've become a mark of social status)? And, what is the range of possible relationships that can be worked out between the living and the sort of reincarnated dead?

Unfortunately, director Andrew Currie, who also co-wrote the tedious screenplay (with Robert Chomiak and Dennis Heaton), fails to keep this improbable material percolating along for an hour and a half, often faltering for want of a good laugh. Even a talented cast struggles: Carrie-Anne Moss, Billy Connolly, Dylan Baker, Henry Czerny, Tim Blake Nelson, Mary Black and Sonja Bennett are the principals, aided by young K'Sun Ray as Timmy, the innocent kid with a good heart who acts as fair witness to all the lunacy of the grownups. (Having seen her only in Memento" and "The Matrix," I had no idea that Ms. Moss could struggle so much with comedy.)

The production design and music are exquisitely 50s, to a tee. Maybe this one isn't for everybody. It surely will be a hard film to beat for my annual Disappointment Award. Intelligent comedies that stay funny from start to finish are among the hardest won achievements in movie-making, and sadly, "Fido" misses the mark. For me anyway, "Fido" is a bore! My grades: 3.5/10 (D+) (Seen on 01/30/07)

A lot has been said about Shinjuku Triad Society as the first true Miike" film and I thought this sort of description might have been a cliché. But, like all clichés, it is based on the truth. All the Miike trademarks are here, the violence, the black humour, the homosexuality, the taboo testing and the difficult to like central character. Shinjuku is, however, one of Miike's most disjointed films. He says in an interview that if he made it again it would be different, but not necessarily better. I think what he means is that the film possesses a chaotic energy and raw edge which seems so unpolished that although he might be able to capture a more visually or technically complex movie, he could not replicate the flaws of this film.

As you might expect, the violence is gratuitously visceral, gushing blood and gritty beatings are supplemented by a disturbing scene in which a woman has a chair smashed over her face. (Only a Miike film could make you cringe with a sentence like that.) The film has an erratic pace, similar to Dead or Alive which begins and ends strongly and dips in the middle. Dead or Alive also deals with similar issues, Miike is clearly concerned about the relations between the Japanese and Chinese in the postwar period and this emotive subject is handled poorly here, the central character failing to come to life even when you begin to understand his past.

I cannot criticize Shinjuku enough. I do not want to give away too much. This is Miike before he began to use CGI to animate his films and is almost reminiscent of something like Kitano's Sonatine, but falls short. The central characters are poorly realized and the final twist is so confusing that as soon as the film has finished you'll be reluctant to watch it again to try and work it all out."

Director Douglas Sirk disappoints with this, the grandaddy of all dysfunctional family films. This lush, trashy saga is a disaster, clumsily combining all of the elements of Sirk's soapers and haphazardly cramming them all into one movie. Written on the Wind" very obviously influenced the 1980s TV series "Dallas" and "Dynasty", as this is basically a feature-length version of those later nighttime soaps.

Lauren Bacall, stiffly and unconvincingly, plays Lucy Moore, a New York City secretary who marries oil baron, Kyle Hadley (Robert Stack). Unbeknownst to both of them, Mitch Wayne (Rock Hudson) is also in love with the quiet, but supposedly sexy secretary. They all go back to Kyle's family's mansion in Texas where we meet his white trash slut-of-a-sister, Marylee (Dorothy Malone in an undeserved Oscar-winning turn). Oh no! The sparks begin to fly - from the romances to the catfights, this is a cringe-worthy trip. Not only does Mitch have to fight the feelings he has for his best friend's wife, but Marylee tries to sleep with everybody since she can't have her one true love who is Mitch. Topping it all off, Kyle learns he's impotent, but somehow Lucy ends up pregnant.

This is pure soap and pure melodramatic drivel. How can anyone love it? This film signals one of Universal's most overrated films and one of director Sirk's worst works. Some of the dialogue is absolutely groan-worthy and visual metaphors are thrown in every which way - the theme of wind throughout is obnoxious. The cast is mediocre, with Bacall being completely underused despite receiving top-billing behind Hudson. Stack's Oscar loss was well-deserved. He considered this his finest performance, but it's far from it. What a terrible movie! This film proves what I've been thinking for ages - Sirk is the master of classic melodramatic nonsense. Where's his Razzie?

"

He glorified himself as a great supporting actor in `Glory', he proved he was no `Malcolm in the Middle' mediocre actor in `Malcolm X', he showed his brotherly love for acting in `Philadelphia', he pulled a slam dunk in `He Got Game', he pulled no punches and rocked us like a hurricane in `The Hurricane', he provided us effective thespian education in `Training Day', and now he has demonstrated that he could also direct - but not very well. Denzel Washington's directorial debut `Antwone Fisher' is the most disappointing film of the year. This melodramatic `fish'er story is in no relation to the debacle that happened to the Miami Dolphins in the 4th quarter against the New England Patriots in the last game of the 2002 season. Unlike that Dolphin tragedy, `Antwone Fisher' possesses an emotional but contrived conclusion. The movie is based on a true story about a young naval officer who has an anger management problem due to the abhorrent he suffered as a foster child. Denzel plays the naval psychologist who helps Antwone overcome his rage and convinces him to find his natural mother. Derek Luke's debut performance as Antwone is the most amateurish acting I have seen by a novice actor in some time now. I actually saw some of the detailed eccentricities in Luke's acting as I have seen in Washington's past performances, but not in a good way. It was like if Washington was telling Luke- ` la la la Luke I am your acting father', and Luke took all the wrong lessons. Ok! I will lay off the Star Wars jokes before my readers send me to a galaxy far far away. Speaking of the great Denzel, his work as the psychologist was surprisingly mediocre. But what can you expect from the acting `Master D' himself when he's out of his depth as a director. `Antwone Fisher' was written by no other than Antwone Fisher himself. The emotional pathos he inserted in his storylife's screenplay was of `fisher king' material, but not in a positive sense. I hail to the chief `Mr. Washington' for missing the mark entirely with `Antwone Fisher'. * Poor

Even in the 21st century, child-bearing is dangerous: women have miscarriages, and give birth prematurely. Seventy-five years ago, it was not uncommon for women to die during childbirth. That is the theme of Life Begins": a look at the "difficult cases" ward of a maternity hospital. Loretta Young plays the lead, a woman brought here from prison (what crime she committed is not germane to the plot) to give birth; she's conflicted about the fact she's going to have to give her baby up after birth. She's in a ward with several other women, who share their joys and pain with each other.

Although Loretta Young is the lead, the performance by Glenda Farrell falls short of expectations. Farrell was one of Warner's "B" women in the 1930s, showing up quite a bit in supporting roles, and sometimes getting the lead in B movies (Farrell played Torchy Blane in several installments of the "Torchy" B-movie series.) Here, Farrell plays an expectant mother who doesn't want her children, since they'll only get in the way. She does everything she can to get in the way of the nurses, including smuggling liquor into the ward (this of course during the Prohibition days), and drinking like a fish -- apparently they'd never heard of fetal alcohol syndrome back in the 30s.

Interestingly, unlike most movie of the early 1930s, it's not the women being bumbling idiots getting in the way of the heroic men -- that situation is reversed, with the expectant fathers being quivering mounds of jelly. (Watch for veteran character actor Frank McHugh as one of the expectant fathers.) "Life Begins", being an early talkie, treats the subject with an excessive amount of melodrama, making it difficult to enjoy. Turner Classic shows it, albeit infrequently; I've only seen it show up on a few days honoring Loretta Young. But it's not recommended viewing when it does show up."

Rudyard Kipling once wrote that God gave to all people the ability to love the whole world, but given that a human heart is very small in size, every human has that special place that he loves more than any other. It seems to me that this may have been the motto of some of the most eminent directors of today when they set out to profess the eternal love for that special place and depict situations in the lives of its denizens and visitors. The result is a disappointing collection of short films, Paris je t'aime, in which our guides, Van Sant, Coixet, Cuaron, Payne and others take us on a tedious stroll through Parisian arrondissements, human feelings, yearnings and expectations.

Always some other quarter, always some utterly contrived story about ordinary people in search for love, be it in a parking lot, art studio, tube station. And Paris je t'aime is about a clichéd array of loves- love for one's partner, child, parent, for those who meant the world to us but are no longer around, love that needs rekindling, serendipitous love for that stranger as your eyes meet, or love that just is not meant to be...today, but tomorrow- who knows?

Nevertheless, this film is not solely about love, but life itself, joy, pain, loneliness, confusion, everyday ups and downs. And its most significant flaw is the fact that it is overly sentimental, rather saccharine and lacking in genuine emotion.

I give this film a 3 because the final section of it suggests how some of the stories might further develop, but not all of them and that is the thing that I find missing, and by further development" I do not mean some specific reference to the characters' future. As far as everything else is concerned I can only say- underwhelming. Makes you want to avoid Paris altogether and forget about these shallow romances."

Robert A. Heinlein's classic novel Starship Troopers has been messed around with in recent years, in everything to Paul Verhoeven's 1997 film to a TV series, to a number of games. But none of these, so to speak, has really captured the spirit of his novel. The games are usually unrelated, the TV series was more of a spin off, and the less said about Verhoeven's film, the better. Little do most know, however, that in Japan, an animated adaptation had already been done, released the year of Heinlein's death. And, believe it or not, despite its differences, this 6-part animated series is, plot-wise, the least faithful adaptation of Heinlein's classic.

The most obvious drawback to this series is the presence of the powered armor exoskeletons, which are poorly executed and distracting. Like the book, the series focuses more on the characters and their relationships than on action and space travel, though we see a fair amount of each. While events happen differently than in the book, the feel of the book's plot is entirely lost. Rico and Carmen have a romantic entanglement, but it's handled even more clumsily than in the book. The dialogue and character interaction are significantly inferior to the book, suffering from the worst aspects of anime treatment. Heinlein's political views are not just excised, but misrepresented. The big letdown of the series, however, is the climatic battle on Klendathu between the troopers and the bugs/aliens, which features disappointing action from the powered armor suits that fails to live up to expectations.

Overall, I was disappointed with this series because I wanted to see a vision closer to that of Heinlein. And I think they failed miserably with this. Even if you can find this series, it's not worth your time.

Well, I have finally caught up with Rock 'N' Roll High School," almost 30 years after it first became a midnight movie sensation in 1979. (Latecomer that I am, I will probably first see this summer's new documentary "Patti Smith: Dream of Life" sometime around 2040!) And unfortunately, the film feels terribly dated, and it wasn't worth the wait. This is a low-energy comedy that features mediocre music and some disappointingly predictable moments. It tells the story of Riff Randell, annoyingly played by P.J. Soles, and the tiresome battle that she and her fellow students at Vince Lombardi High wage against their new principal, Miss Togar. (Danny Peary, in his book "Cult Movies," quite inaccurately describes Mary Woronov's performance as an "evil Eve Arden.") A typical teens vs. Establishment story line is weighed down here with some failed attempts at absurdist humor (those exploding mice, that giant mouse, the Hansel and Gretel hall monitors) and some truly grating tunes. Riff is, of course, the #1 fan of that overrated punk band The Ramones, and that band dishes out a baker's dozen of its most irritating songs during the course of the film, including five at a concert that is a total bore. Indeed, the sight of Riff furiously dancing to "Teenage Lobotomy" at this blowout may be the picture's most cringe-worthy moment. And the initial appearance of Joey, Johnny, Dee Dee and Marky in their Ramonesmobile, and later slinking down a street singing "I Just Wanna Have Something To Do," is quite tedious. The film ends with a chaotic confrontation that is, I would imagine, every high school kid's worst nightmare. Dull stuff indeed. On a side note, The Ramones were one of the loudest bands that I have ever seen in concert, so I was very annoyed to note that the DVD for this film comes with optional English subtitles for the hearing impaired. How many aging punks out there found these subtitles necessary, I wonder...."

Bacall disappoints here - despite this being only her 2nd film. This one is often overshadowed because it falls between 2 great successes: To Have and To Have Not" (1944) and "The Big Sleep" (1945), both of which paired her with Humphrey Bogart. This one is not up to par with the other movies, largely due to her lackluster performance. The miscasting in having her portray a British upper-crust lady is particularly glaring. No accent whatsoever. All the strange accents were distracting - Boyer was certainly no Spaniard. It was hard to keep straight which country people were from.

The black and white cinematography is underwhelming. Mood is poorly used - the fog scene in particular falls flat. The lighting fails to add to the intrigue and tension.

Bacall's beauty can't save her performance. Boyer is miscast as the romantic leading man - so he and Bacall together was jarring. Their lack of chemistry is painfully obvious - certainly no Bogie and Bacall magic. Overall, I found this picture disappointing. The tension is lacking and it drags along. The murder of the little girl, while bold for this period film, feels out of place.

Katina Paxinou and Peter Lorre stand out as supporting cast, but not in a good way. Paxinou as the hotel keeper is over-the-top and unconvincing in her portrayal. Her one scene where she laughs maniacally as Mr. Muckerji is leaving after exposing her as the child's murderer is more comical than disturbing. Lorre's portrayal of Conteras as a sleazy coward feels forced and unnatural. Wanda Bendrix's performance as the child Else is unremarkable, despite this being her first picture and being only 16 at the time (though she appears much younger). Turns out she later married Auie Murphy which proved to be a short lived, tempestuous marriage."

Eddie Murphy plays Chandler Jarrell, a man who devotes his time to finding lost children. When the beautiful Kee Nang {Charlotte Lewis} enters his life, she tells him he is the chosen one and he must find the Golden Child. Sceptical and driven purely by lust and intrigue, Jarrell gets involved without realising he's about to embark on a fantastical journey, one that involves peril and worst of all, the demon Sardo Numspa.

Is The Golden Child a product of its time?, by that i mean, was Eddie Murphy and The Golden Child's popularity exclusive to the late 1980s audiences?. For i can remember vividly how much this film entertained folk back in that decade, it's box office was $79,817,937, making it the 8th biggest earner of 1986, but since the 80s faded from memory it has become clear that Eddie Murphy pictures lack the comedy accolades they once had. The Golden Child is not up with the more accepted 80s Murphy pictures like Trading Places and Beverly Hills Cop, and upon revisiting the film recently i personally find that it contains Murphy at his most tiresome, with forced quips and an annoyingly smug charm, seriously!.

Cashing in on a fantasy action formula that was reinvigorated and temp-lated by Raiders Of The Lost Ark in 1981, The Golden Child fails to hit the required genre buttons. Pretty girl, daring reluctant-hero with a quip in his armoury, dashing villain {Charles Dance so English i could cringe}, garish colour, and a cute kid with mystical powers, the film asks you to get involved in the fun, but it's hard to do so given its lack of quality as a fantasy picture. The CGI demon looks creaky now, and the genre had far better pictures in the 80s, 90s and beyond. If you agree with the disgraceful rating of 5 here on this site then you may just be giving this genre too much credit, seriously. 3/10
